headline: Mumbai Metropolitan Region Authority-like body planned for buying medicines, equipment
article:
NAGPUR: The state is planning to set up the Maharashtra Medical Authority, on the lines of MMRDA, to buy drugs and medical and surgical equipment for its medical colleges and hospitals.

With extensive delays in the purchase of medicines, and surgical equipment for state-run medical colleges and hospitals through Haffkine Bio-Pharmaceutical Corporation, the state government has said it may soon set up Maharashtra Medical Authority on the lines of MMRDA for buying these. Medical education minister Girish Mahajan said this on Friday in the state legislative council, while replying to a calling attention motion by MLCs Praveen Datke, Chandrashekhar Bawankule and Nago Ganar.

MMRDA-like body planned for buying meds, equipment

Mahajan also said since there is a big delay in providing medicines to patients, the state has increased the purchasing capacity of hospitals at the local level from 10% to 30% as a stop-gap arrangement. Mahajan said delays are caused since orders are not placed in time due to staggered administrative approval and lack of manpower in Haffkine."Following complaints received on this behalf, attempts are being made to fast-track the tendering process at Haffkine... At the same time, the government is thinking about setting up a Maharashtra Medical Authority on the lines of the Mumbai Metropolitan Region Authority (MMDRA) too," Mahajan said in his written reply.

The state's public health department had earlier this year proposed to the government to review the idea of purchases through a single entity-Haffkine Biopharmaceutical Ltd. The reason for the proposal was the failure of Haffkine's procurement cell to make timely purchases for various systemic problems, leading to a delay of 1.5 to 4 years in delivery of drugs and equipment. A senior official said they had suggested creation of an independent corporation on the lines of Tamil Nadu Medical Services Corporation, which looks after the ready purchase of medical equipment and drugs.
summary: The Maharashtra government is considering establishing the Maharashtra Medical Authority, akin to MMRDA, to streamline the procurement of drugs and medical equipment for state medical institutions. The move comes in response to significant delays in purchasing through Haffkine Bio-Pharmaceutical Corporation, causing delays of 1.5 to 4 years in delivering essential supplies. Medical Education Minister Girish Mahajan highlighted this issue in the state legislative council, mentioning plans to boost local hospitals' purchasing capacity temporarily while exploring a more permanent solution through the proposed Maharashtra Medical Authority, modeled after MMRDA and Tamil Nadu's procurement system.

headline: No scope of Prez rule in WB: PC
article:
Faced with a stiff opposition on its decision to send a Central team to West Bengal’s Lalgarh area, the government today assured both Houses of Parliament that there was no scope for the imposition of President’s Rule following the Bommai judgment.

As opposition parties, led by the CPM, termed the government’s move as “unconstitutional and undemocratic,” Home Minister P Chidambaram stepped in to say, “Post-Bommai, there is no scope ...for the imposition of the Central rule. The move to send the Central team is entirely non-confrontational. There is no need to view it through the prism of Article 356.” Chidambaram gave the same assurance to the Rajya Sabha.

The minister’s reference was to the 1994 Supreme Court ruling where it said no state government could be dismissed without being afforded a chance to prove the majority on the floor of the House.

Assurance apart, both Houses saw an aggressive Left corner the government on the issue, with the LS seeing three adjournments and RS two. Left and SP members were the most vocal, and stormed the well in Lok Sabha in question hour. CPM’s Basudeb Acharia sought the suspension of the question hour, but was denied a chance by Speaker Meira Kumar.

He made the noise nevertheless, with the Trinamool countering him with a demand for imposition of the President’s Rule in Bengal. The BJP for its part subtly sided with the Left, despite the latter’s earlier support to the dismissal of three BJP governments in the wake of the Babri Masjid demolition.

Though Leader of the Opposition LK Advani accused the Left today of double standards on the Central rule, he warned the Centre against taking the Article 356 lightly; in Rajya Sabha, BJP’s Arun Jaitley voiced the same sentiment and supported CPM leader Sitaram Yechury’s contention that the deputation of the Central team was unconstitutional. “We would like to be assured that this wasn’t done at the behest of the Congress’ alliance partner,” Jaitley said.

A cornered Chidambaram naturally was on back foot and said the team was only meant to assist law and order issues. “I have a good working relationship with West Bengal; CM Buddhadeb Bhattacharya,” the Home Minister added, referring to growing inter-party clashes on the issue as the reason behind the move.

Back in the LS, the uproar was led by Acharia who denounced the government move saying every state had some problem. “Law and order is a state subject,” he reminded the Centre, accusing it of succumbing to Mamata Banerjee’s pressure.

SP’s Mulayam Singh Yadav also attacked the government warning of such moves becoming precedents. “That means you can impose the President’s Rule in any state,” he asked, while Advani said the Article 356 should only be used in the “rarest of cases and certainly not in ones stemming from law and order”.

“The constitution-makers had conceded the possibility of misusing of the Article and wanted it to be turned into a dead letter. The Sarkaria Commission had also gone into these aspects,” said Advani with CPI’s Gurudas Dasgupta also objected to the Central team being sent.
summary: The Indian government assured both houses of Parliament that there was no scope for the imposition of President's Rule in West Bengal following the opposition's protest against the government's decision to send a Central team to the state's Lalgarh area. Home Minister P. Chidambaram stated that the move to send the Central team was non-confrontational, and there was no need to view it through the prism of Article 356, referring to the 1994 Supreme Court ruling that no state government could be dismissed without being afforded a chance to prove the majority on the floor of the House. The opposition, particularly the Left and Samajwadi Party, accused the government of acting unconstitutionally and undemocratically.

headline: Companies adopt wierd names to catch consumer attention
article:
NEW DELHI/BANGALORE: In New Delhi’s posh South Extension area, there’s a shop called Mom & Me by the Ring Road.
Nobody needs to be told what they sell there: all kinds of mother and child products from toys and strollers to advice and
apparels. Plain and simple brand name. But not everybody thinks Mahindra Group’s retail venture has the best brand
name because it does not appeal to one’s curiosity.
Well, the new hype among marketers perpetually engaged in a fight to win the customer’s attention is having a whacky, if
So we have Happily Unmarried gift seller, Phat Phish music recorder, and apparel brands Fried Water, Tantra, Aliva,
People Tree and Penny Lane, catching eyeballs first before revealing their product line.
"This is the most ridiculous phase in our revolution... many entrepreneurs nowadays ask us to come up with creative
titles as they want to be different," says Harish Bijoor, brand consultant and CEO of Harish Bijoor Consults Inc. The idea
is to make a strong first impression.
"It is a time of instant fame which is followed by hard work to retain the fame," says Satbir Singh, chief creative officer of
ad agency Euro RSCG. He says that social networking sites such as Facebook, Orkut and Twitter have ensured faster
word-of-mouth communication and higher brand recall by consumers.
Though it doesn’t ensure success, this strategy seems to have worked in cases such as Fried Water. "They exemplify a new
concept, which is to shock to get attention, and use that as the starting point to get customers," says Prof K Kumar of IIMBangalore, who has studied this in one of his cases.
Bangalore-based Wyn Brands is not a career coaching firm or a winemaker. It is an agriculture produce firm, which
specialises in bringing fresh farm produce directly to the customer in various shops and malls.
A cut-vegetable supply firm founded in 2003, Wyn bills itself as first of its kind in India—buying, storing, cleaning,
cutting, packaging and delivering fresh vegetables to restaurants. So why not a name that has ‘farm’ or ‘fresh’ or ‘green’?
"The recall value is good with this name, and it signifies progress, an upward movement," says Stephen Poonnen, founder
and MD of Wyn Brands.
So how do they come up with these names? Anand Surapur, owner of Phat Phish Films and Phat Phish Records, thought
of the name while he was waiting for a fish fry on the Goa beach. He used to like a music band called Phish. And since
fish was cooked quick, it became Phat Phish. The album ‘Rabbi’ was released under Phat Phish label in 2004 and was an
instant hit.
The trend is catching up fast. In the next six months or so, there will be new milk brand named ‘Dudu’ and an acidity
relief medicine called ‘Buru buru buru buru’ in the market. "We know these brand names will immediately catch
attention as consumers can relate," says Bijoor.
But their success depends on their honesty, he adds. "If the brand is honest and works well with the target audience, then
the name, in the long run, will be associated with trust, conviction and sincerity that it offers." Interestingly, it’s start-ups
and new entrepreneurs who bet mostly on different names, while older players prefer more conventional names, which
mostly include the established business names, for their new ventures.
"Brands with such weird names will not target major masses but will target a particular niche segment," says Prof Piyush
Sinha, who teaches retailing at Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad. "Established names will be wary of
experimenting with such new names with a fear of rejection as consumers identify and accept them with their previous
titles.Going for whacky titles of brands has been prevalent in the western markets for long. Apparel brands such as Mango,
Diesel, Gap and FCUK are all international brands. So are Apple gadgets and Orange phone service.
But names can also get you into trouble. Steve Jobs, when he formed Apple, is reputed to have chosen the name because
he was a Beatles fan and loved the Apple recording label.
He was not to know that 30 years later he would see the recording company in court about the name. But then, anything
to stay in sync with the consumers.
summary: In the competitive world of marketing, unconventional brand names like Happily Unmarried, Phat Phish, and Fried Water are gaining attention for their quirky appeal. This trend aims to make a strong first impression and capitalize on fast-paced communication through social media. While such names may not target mass markets, they resonate with niche segments and can lead to successful branding if backed by honesty and consumer trust. Established players often stick to conventional names, while startups and entrepreneurs embrace creativity. However, the strategy isn't without risks, as seen in the potential legal challenges faced by brands like Apple. Overall, the trend reflects a global phenomenon where brands strive for distinctiveness and consumer engagement through unconventional nomenclature.

headline: Meagre salary forces man to end life
article:
MUMBAI: A man, Rajesh Pawar (43), committed suicide in his Kandivli (E) home on Saturday. His suicide note stated stated he was unable to run his household on his meagre salary. Rajesh Pawar , the deceased, worked in a garment factory and but hadn't been going to work for the past few days. Pawar was an chronic alcoholic. "Pawar hanged himself at the Abdul Satar chawl, where he lived wife his family, on Saturday morning when he was alone. His wife, who is employed as a domestic help, was away for work while his son who studies in class VIII was playing outside at the time. Pawar sent away his daughter, who is a class XI student, to visit a relative. He did not tell any of his family members about his intentions," an official from Samta Nagar police station said.

He held no one responsible for his death and that he was fed up with his life. He also stated that his salary was not enough to foot all household expenses.
summary: Rajesh Pawar, a 43-year-old garment factory worker from Kandivli (E), committed suicide on Saturday due to financial distress and personal struggles. His suicide note revealed his inability to manage household expenses on his low salary. Pawar, who had been absent from work recently and struggled with chronic alcoholism, took his own life at his home while his wife was at work and his children were elsewhere. He did not blame anyone for his death and expressed a sense of hopelessness about his situation. The incident highlights the severe impact of financial difficulties and personal issues on mental health.

headline: Bankers do not see any interest rate spike
article:
In a notable development, leading bankers, including State Bank of India Chairman O. P. Bhatt and Corporation Bank Chief J. M. Garg, are expressing their outlook on interest rates, forecasting a period of stability for at least the next six months. These sentiments have been conveyed ahead of the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) upcoming policy review scheduled for later this month.

Expectation of Interest Rate Stability:

The bankers have collectively conveyed their expectation that interest rates will remain unchanged in the near term, at least until June-end. This anticipation reflects their assessment of the current economic landscape and the need for a predictable and steady monetary policy.

Call for Unchanged Monetary Stance:

In alignment with their forecast, the banking leaders are urging the RBI to maintain its existing key policy ratios and rates. This call for an unchanged monetary stance underscores the importance of stability and continuity in financial markets, providing businesses and consumers with a sense of predictability.

Rationale Behind the Stance:

While the specific reasons behind the bankers' recommendations are not explicitly outlined, such calls for stability often stem from a delicate balance between stimulating economic growth and managing inflation. The ongoing global economic uncertainties and the need for a cautious approach to monetary policy may also influence their stance.

Economic Context:

The bankers' views are situated within the broader economic context, where the central bank plays a pivotal role in shaping monetary policies. Interest rates, including the repo rate and reverse repo rate, have far-reaching implications for borrowing costs, investments, and overall economic activities.
summary: Leading bankers, including State Bank of India Chairman O. P. Bhatt and Corporation Bank Chief J. M. Garg, anticipate stable interest rates for the next six months. They urge the Reserve Bank of India to maintain its current monetary stance, advocating for unchanged key policy ratios and rates during the upcoming policy review.

While China’s motorization has been a boon for foreign automakers -- all the

summary: In 2013, China set a milestone by becoming the first country where over 20 million vehicles were sold in a single year. The total vehicle deliveries increased by 14% to 21.98 million units, with expectations to exceed 24 million in 2014. Passenger vehicle sales alone reached 17.93 million, surpassing the US auto industry by 15%. Despite these impressive figures, concerns over pollution and traffic congestion have prompted Chinese cities like Beijing and Tianjin to impose stricter vehicle quotas and licensing restrictions. Analysts predict that growth in the automotive sector will increasingly rely on smaller cities and inland areas, challenging local automakers to compete effectively against foreign joint ventures.

headline: eepika Padukone at a launch as Swiss timepiece maker, unveiled a new watch line, the Tissot Racing-Touch in Mumbai
article:
Tissot, the 160-year-old traditional Swiss timepiece maker, unveiled a new watch line, the Tissot Racing-Touch, with brand ambassador Deepika Padukone in Mumbai.

Commenting on the launch, Deepika said, “I have been with Tissot for six years and they still surprise me every time by with their innovations. So many features and all in one watch – Tissot truly represents our generation that needs everything at their fingertip, adding to it the adrenal rush that the racing touch brings to it. What more could one desire?”

In line with its signature ‘Innovators by Tradition’, this timepiece has an edgy design and with a racing and sporty DNA, the watch accommodates 11 tactile functions, all easily accessed by its dynamic and driven wearer.
summary: Tissot, the renowned Swiss watchmaker with a rich heritage of 160 years, introduced its latest watch line, the Tissot Racing-Touch, in Mumbai alongside brand ambassador Deepika Padukone. Deepika, who has been associated with Tissot for six years, expressed admiration for the brand's continuous innovation. The Racing-Touch watch combines style with functionality, featuring 11 tactile functions tailored for dynamic and sporty individuals who appreciate convenience and adrenaline. This launch reinforces Tissot's commitment to blending tradition with innovation, catering to the needs of the modern generation.

headline: Zebra Finches can smell
article:
It was long thought that songbirds did not use their sense of smell. That was because a 1968 study had found that the olfactory bulbs in their brains are smaller than those of other kinds of birds.

But a new study reports that zebra finch fledglings can recognize their relatives by smell.

Although the olfactory region in the finches “is small, it seems to work,” said E. Tobias Krause, a biologist at Bielefeld University in Germany and one of the study's authors.

Krause and his colleagues report their findings in the journal Biology Letters .

After the zebra finches hatched, the researchers placed the chicks in different broods, away from their parents.

At the age of 20 to 23 days, each bird was presented with odour samples from the nest it hatched in and the nest that served as its foster home.

The birds indicated their preference by entering or perching in front of the artificial nest box that produced the more appealing odor.

“They choose the nest of their genetic parent,” Krause said.

Detecting relatives
The birds may be using smell to detect relatives and avoid inbreeding, Krause said.

“Our results are restricted to zebra finches, but it is very likely that other songbirds and other birds have this capacity for kin recognition,” he said. .”
summary: Previously, it was believed that songbirds lacked a sense of smell due to smaller olfactory bulbs. However, a recent study reveals that zebra finch fledglings can recognize relatives by scent. E. Tobias Krause and colleagues from Bielefeld University found that despite the small olfactory region, finches could discern odors. In the experiment, chicks were placed in different broods and later presented with odor samples from their genetic nest and foster nest. They consistently preferred the scent of their genetic nest, suggesting kin recognition. Krause speculates that this ability helps birds avoid inbreeding. While the study focuses on zebra finches, it implies that other songbirds likely possess similar capabilities. The findings are published in Biology Letters, indicating a reevaluation of songbirds' olfactory abilities and social behaviors.

headline: Swachh initiative changes quality of life
article:
The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, launched in 2014, has proven to be a game-changer for numerous remote communities across India. A shining example of this success can be seen in the 38 Adivasi Raj Gond families residing in the Mohanguda hamlet of Indervelli mandal in Adilabad district, Telangana. Previously plagued by poor sanitation, open defecation, and frequent health issues, this tribal hamlet has witnessed a remarkable transformation due to its wholehearted adoption of the Swachh Bharat sanitation model.

Before the intervention, the residents of Mohanguda lived without access to toilets, clean drinking water, or proper waste disposal systems. Open defecation was widespread, resulting in serious health hazards like diarrhoea, skin infections, and vector-borne diseases, especially among children and elderly people. The village's isolation and limited resources compounded these problems, and the health and hygiene situation remained bleak for decades.

The Swachh Bharat Mission, in coordination with local administration and voluntary organizations, brought a turning point. Awareness campaigns were conducted in Gondi, the native language of the community, explaining the importance of hygiene, personal sanitation, and safe waste disposal. With government aid and technical support, every household was equipped with a functional toilet. Drainage systems were laid, and soak pits were installed to manage wastewater. Women, who had earlier faced immense difficulties and loss of dignity due to the lack of private sanitation, became active participants and supporters of this change.

Apart from better health indicators, the change in sanitation habits has also brought social benefits. School attendance among children has improved, as many girls earlier dropped out due to the lack of separate toilet facilities. Instances of waterborne illnesses have significantly reduced, saving families medical expenses and allowing them to channel resources into livelihood and education. The hamlet is now a model for other tribal villages, drawing visitors from nearby mandals and officials from district headquarters who wish to replicate its success.

Today, Mohanguda is not only open defecation free (ODF) but also moving towards becoming a clean and green village. The success story is a testament to how targeted government schemes, when implemented with community involvement, can uplift even the most marginalised groups. The Raj Gond families now live with dignity, improved health, and a newfound sense of empowerment — all thanks to the Swachh Bharat initiative.
summary: The 38 Adivasi Raj Gond families in Mohanguda hamlet of Adilabad district have seen significant improvements in health, hygiene, and dignity after adopting the Swachh Bharat sanitation model. Previously affected by open defecation and related diseases, the village achieved transformation through awareness campaigns, construction of toilets, and improved waste management. Women and children especially benefited, with better privacy, health, and increased school attendance. Mohanguda is now open defecation free and serves as a model for other tribal villages, demonstrating the power of community-driven development through government schemes.

headline: Iran says U.S.-U.K. attack on Houthis will fuel instability in region
article:
Iran on Friday condemned the U.S.-British attack on Houthis in Yemen, warning that it will fuel "insecurity and instability" in the region, Iranian state media reported.

 Russia calls for UNSC meeting after U.S. and Britain strike Yemen

"We strongly condemn the military attacks carried out this morning by the United States and the United Kingdom on several cities in Yemen", said Nasser Kanaani, spokesperson at Iran's foreign ministry.

"These attacks are a clear violation of Yemen's sovereignty and territorial integrity, and a breach of international laws," he added.

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian praised the Iran-aligned Houthis' actions against Israel-linked vessels and said the movement upholds maritime security. He urged the United States to end its all-out support for Israel.

"Yemen's action in...confronting the genocide of the Israeli regime is admirable. Sanaa strictly adheres to maritime security," Amirabdollahian said on the X platform.

"Instead of attacking Yemen, the White House should immediately stop all-out military and security cooperation with Tel Aviv — against the people of Gaza and the West Bank — to restore security across the region," he added.

The Houthis have vowed to respond to the attacks but analysts said on Friday the prospects of these Western strikes igniting a regional war seem limited for now as Tehran seeks to avoid getting sucked directly into all-out conflict.
summary: Iran strongly condemned the recent U.S.-British military strike on Houthi-controlled areas in Yemen, warning that it could exacerbate instability and insecurity in the region. Iranian foreign ministry spokesperson Nasser Kanaani described the attacks as violations of Yemen's sovereignty and international laws. Iran’s Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian expressed support for the Houthis' actions against Israel-linked vessels, praising their efforts in upholding maritime security. He also criticized U.S. military support for Israel and called for its cessation to help restore regional security. While the Houthis have vowed retaliation, analysts suggest that while tensions have risen, there is currently little likelihood of these strikes triggering a broader regional conflict, as Iran aims to avoid direct involvement in a full-scale war. The situation remains fluid, with global powers closely monitoring developments.

headline: Aamir calls Imran a kanjoos
article:
We love the cat-fights and the gals warring over their men and
movies. But frankly, nothing has as much ‘shock’ value as the
Khans – whether it’s their friendships or falls-outs.
Its headlines. In their ‘King’dom, the rules are all different.
Recently, at Imran’s wedding, Aamir dropped a subtle hint about
his superstardom. The media quizzed Imran about how much he’s
shelled out for sis-in-law (the usual shaadi ka rasm), but before he
could say a word, Aamir answered, “Oh, Imran is a miser. He is
such a big superstar.
I mean, I am number one but he comes quite close and yet, he
doesn’t want to spend.” Bechara Imran, just had to agree with mamu. And why not? The superstar has the final
say, right? Wonder what Aamir gifted his just-married bhanja...not the ‘superstar’ title definitely
summary: Aamir Khan playfully teased his nephew Imran Khan at the latter's wedding, implying that despite being a big superstar himself, Imran was reluctant to spend. Aamir jokingly stated that Imran is a miser, but given his growing stardom, he comes quite close to being number one. The playful banter highlighted the unique dynamics within the Khan family and showcased Aamir's lighthearted approach to the situation. The specific gift Aamir gave to Imran was not mentioned in the report.

headline: How Tata Trusts reinvents itself by helping state governments and MPs with data-driven tools
article:
Data can be eye-openers. Sudhir Mungantiwar, Maharashtra’s minister for finance, planning and forestry, was taken aback when he saw the low penetration of cooking gas connections in his home district of Chandrapur.

Even though the Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana, which provides LPG connections to families below the poverty line, had some beneficiaries in Chandrapur, the majority of poor homes did not get it. In fact, only 18% households had got the connection.

The data on gas connections, which stumped Mungantiwar, was collected by a team of youngsters trained by Tata Trusts. Armed with tablets, they had fanned across the district, collecting information from households. Chandrapur is part of eastern Maharashtra, in the Nagpur division, with a population of 2.2 lakh, according to the 2011 Census.

Mungantiwar realised, as he explained to ET Magazine in an interview, many poor families had slipped through the cracks of the criteria under the Social and Economic Caste Census 2011. In early 2017, he set out to correct it; cooking gas connectivity in Chandrapur has now inched closer to the 50% mark. Next, Mungantiwar wants to apply the data captured by Tata Trusts on housing needs.

Mungantiwar roped in Tata Trusts after he read about its pilot project in Vijayawada, the constituency of TDP MP Kesineni Srinivas. Tata Trusts is running pilots on data-driven governance in four districts across the country, apart from providing research assistance on data-driven governance to 20 parliamentarians, including Tarun Gogoi of the Congress and Rajiv Pratap Rudy of the BJP. The Trusts is also involved in capturing municipal data in three cities across India — Pune, Jamshedpur and Surat (See element “From Villages to Cities”).

R Venkataramanan, managing trustee of Tata Trusts, identifies data-driven governance as a key area for it. He told ET Magazine: “Our goal is two-fold: helping administrations target their schemes with greater accuracy, and generating awareness among communities of the plethora of government support they can avail.”

Stakeholders in Governance In the process, Tata Trusts, a group of charitable trusts led by former Tata Group chairman Ratan Tata, has emerged as partners for politicians, ministers and administrators of all hues. Mungantiwar himself talks about how Tata Trusts spearheaded the process and made multiple visits to his district. He says: “Chandrapur missed out on the Tatas 100 years ago, when JN Tata considered the district for setting up his steel plant, but chose Jamshedpur instead. They have finally reached here.”

More than 700 km from Chandrapur, in the city of Pune, Municipal Commissioner Kunal Kumar recalls a meeting with Ratan Tata, where he sought Tata Trusts’ help for a project to make CNG out of municipal waste. In the course of the conversation, Kumar learnt that Tata Trusts was partners of the Canada-based World Council on City Data (WCCD) and could help Pune city become a member of WCCD and set up a data portal.

“Three months ago Ratan Tata got an officer from TCS posted with the Pune Municipal Corporation for a period of three years,” says Kumar. (PricewaterhouseCoopers is also a partner in this project.) Apart from working on capturing all the data, relevant municipal data that could be of use to a citizen is being uploaded to the internet. Kumar says that this is a proactive system where information is provided upfront unlike, say, RTI where one has to apply for it. A citizen-led complaint redress system has also been started.

Thanks to the data, organisations are building apps for utilities like public bus services. “Another application is a predictive system for vector-borne diseases. We have captured information of occurrence of vector-borne diseases, we want to use it to predict where it may break out and when,” Kumar explains.

Meanwhile, in Odisha, Kalikesh Narayan Singh Deo, a BJD MP from Bolangir, has partnered with Tata Trusts in more ways than one. Singh Deo says that after visiting the US a couple of years ago and interacting with the then secretary of state John Kerry, he was impressed with the amount of work done by interns attached with senior elected representatives, and wished there was something similar in India. He pushed for a system with the former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar too.


Eventually, the Constitution Club of India (a Delhi club for MPs), the Swaniti Initiative and Tata Trusts jointly started a programme called SPARC (Supporting Parliamentarians on Analysis & Research in Constituency), giving young researchers internships with MPs. Singh Deo says that having an intern constantly working on data and solutions has been a godsend for his work as an MP.

Figuring it Out
Bolangir had problems managing its water bodies. So did Chevella in Telengana, a constituency neighbouring Hyderabad, represented by TRS MP KV Reddy. The issues were different, though. Bolangir was drought-prone, while Chevella’s ponds had water hyacinths. Tata Trusts set about addressing the problems.

A boat designed to remove water hyacinths was deployed to clean up the 60 ponds in Chevella. For Bolangir, JCB machines were used to dredge and deepen the ponds. Says Singh Deo: “Elected representatives in India get little assistance in terms of research and data about their constituencies. Tata Trusts has been a big help.” He adds that bigger, even “riskier projects” can be tried out under Tata pilots before a government body takes over and scales them up.

He hopes the internship programme also scales up so all elected representatives can get such support. There is already a huge demand from other MPs, he says. “Data-driven governance promoted by Tata Trusts is a great service unlike other CSR (corporate social responsibility) programmes that often focus on working around company factories,” says Singh Deo.

Tata Trusts — Sir Ratan Tata Trust and Sir Dorab Tata Trust — owns around 64% of Tata Sons, the Tata Group holding company, and therefore is more of a businessowner than a corporate CSR programme. As events of October 2016 showed, when Tata Trusts moved to replace then Tata Sons chairman Cyrus Mistry, first with Ratan Tata as an interim chairman and ultimately with N Chandrasekaran in February 2017, questions were raised in many quarters about its conduct. For a while, Tata Trusts was seen to be losing the perception battle.
Given the recent history, being a partner in governance surely helps. Apart from state governments, Tata Trusts has signed up with some high-profile partners like Google, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation as well as the WCCD. Says Venkataramanan: “We have worked with partners for decades. We team up with entities that supplement our efforts to reach marginalised communities.” Maharashtra minister Mungantiwar has kind words for Ratan Tata. He says: “It seems Tata is doing this work from his heart.

Apart from data-driven governance, they are also helping us in many other projects — from supporting training for bamboo-related industry to welfare of cancer patients.” 2017 was a rich year for Tata Trusts in terms of building partnerships with governments. It has signed a whole set of Memorandums of Understanding with state governments — from Assam to Rajasthan to Karnataka — on varied subjects like taking care of migrant workers and nutrition.

It is also changing the manner in which administrators think and is winning many to Tata’s way of figuring out issues with numbers. Pune’s Municipal Commissioner Kumar points out that while a demand-based approach to development leads funds to areas that are more vocal in asking for them, a datadriven approach is focused and far more effective.
summary: Tata Trusts, a group of charitable trusts led by former Tata Group chairman Ratan Tata, is running pilots on data-driven governance in four districts across India, as well as providing research assistance to 20 politicians. The group is also capturing municipal data in Pune, Jamshedpur and Surat as part of an attempt to help the Indian government improve its schemes and generate awareness among communities. It is also investigating ways of helping administrations target schemes more accurately.

headline: Why is the universe ripping itself apart?
article:
What is the universe made of? This question has driven astronomers for hundreds of years.
For the past quarter of a century, scientists have believed “normal” stuff like atoms and molecules that make up you, Earth, and nearly everything we can see only accounts for 5% of the universe. Another 25% is “dark matter”, an unknown substance we can’t see but which we can detect through how it affects normal matter via gravity.
The remaining 70% of the cosmos is made of “dark energy”. Discovered in 1998, this is an unknown form of energy believed to be making the universe expand at an ever-increasing rate.
In a new study soon to be published in the Astronomical Journal, the properties of dark energy have measured in more detail than ever before. The results show it may be a hypothetical vacuum energy first proposed by Einstein – or it may be something stranger and more complicated that changes over time.
What is dark energy?
When Einstein developed the General Theory of Relativity over a century ago, he realised his equations showed the universe should either be expanding or shrinking. This seemed wrong to him, so he added a “cosmological constant” – a kind of energy inherent in empty space – to balance out the force of gravity and keep the universe static.
Later, when the work of Henrietta Swan Leavitt and Edwin Hubble showed the universe was indeed expanding, Einstein did away with the cosmological constant, calling it his “greatest mistake”.
However, in 1998, two teams of researchers found the expansion of the universe was actually accelerating. This implies that something quite similar to Einstein’s cosmological constant may exist after all – something we now call dark energy.
Since those initial measurements, we’ve been using supernovae and other probes to measure the nature of dark energy. Until now, these results have shown the density of dark energy in the universe appears to be constant.
This means the strength of dark energy remains the same, even as the universe grows – it doesn’t seem to be spread more thinly as the universe gets bigger. We measure this with a number called w. Einstein’s cosmological constant in effect set w to -1, and earlier observations have suggested this was about right.
Exploding stars as cosmic measuring sticks
How do we measure what is in the universe and how fast it is growing? We don’t have enormous tape measures or giant scales, so instead we use “standard candles”: objects in space whose brightness we know.
Imagine it is night and you are standing on a long road with a few light poles. These poles all have the same light bulb, but the poles further away are fainter than the nearby ones.
This is because light fades proportionately to distance. If we know the power of the bulb, and can measure how bright the bulb appears to be, we can calculate the distance to the light pole.
For astronomers, a common cosmic light bulb is a kind of exploding star called a Type Ia supernova. These are white dwarf stars which often suck in matter from a neighbouring star and grow until they reach 1.44 times the mass of our Sun, at which point they explode.
By measuring how quickly the explosion fades, we can determine how bright it was and hence how far away from us.
The Dark Energy Survey
The Dark Energy Survey is the largest effort yet to measure dark energy. More than 400 scientists across multiple continents work together for nearly a decade to repeatedly observe parts of the southern sky.
Repeated observations let us look for changes, like new exploding stars. The more often you observe, the better you can measure these changes, and the larger the area you search, the more supernovae you can find.
The first results indicating the existence of dark energy used only a couple of dozen supernovae. The latest results from the Dark Energy Survey use around 1,500 exploding stars, giving much greater precision.
Using a specially built camera installed on the 4-metre Blanco Telescope at the Cerro-Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, the survey found thousands of supernovae of different types.
To work out which ones were Type Ia (the kind needed for measuring distances), the 4-metre Anglo Australian Telescope at Siding Spring Observatory in New South Wales was used.
The Anglo Australian Telescope took measurements which broke up the colours of light from the supernovae. This lets us see a “fingerprint” of the individual elements in the explosion.
Type Ia supernovae have some unique features, like containing no hydrogen and silicon. And with enough supernovae, machine learning allowed the researchers to classify thousands of supernovae efficiently.
More complicated than the cosmological constant
Finally, after more than a decade of work and studying around 1,500 Type Ia supernovae, the Dark Energy Survey has produced a new best measurement of w. It was found that w = -0.80 ± 0.18, so it’s somewhere between -0.62 and -0.98.
This is a very interesting result. It is close to -1, but not quite exactly there. To be the cosmological constant, or the energy of empty space, it would need to be exactly -1.
Where does this leave us?
With the idea that a more complex model of dark energy may be needed, perhaps one in which this mysterious energy has changed over the life of the universe. (The Conversation)
summary: Astronomers, through the Dark Energy Survey, have made detailed measurements of the properties of dark energy, which constitutes about 70% of the universe. Dark energy is believed to be causing the universe to expand at an ever-increasing rate. The results suggest that dark energy might be a vacuum energy as first proposed by Einstein, or it could be something more complex and dynamic that changes over time. The measurement, represented by the parameter "w," is found to be -0.80 ± 0.18, indicating that dark energy may be close to, but not exactly, the cosmological constant proposed by Einstein

headline: Green's the new black as 16th Auto Expo gets off the block
article:
As many as 75 vehicles will be launched and unveiled - five of these global debuts – at India’s marquee automotive show, scheduled to be held in the National Capital Region (NCR) starting Wednesday after a gap of three years. On an average over 600,000 visited the show in the last three editions in 2020, 2018 and 2016.


Legacy players like Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai Motor India, Tata Motors and Kia India will showcase a range of electric vehicles, both concepts and production models, reflecting the increased push from governments world over to transition to zero emission vehicles.

The country’s largest carmaker Maruti Suzuki – which has been working on expanding its portfolio in the SUV segment - will take the covers off an Electric Concept SUV at the show. On display will also be two all new SUVs from Maruti Suzuki, which along with the all new Brezza and Grand Vitara, have been designed to take on best-sellers from Tata Motors and Mahindra & Mahindra.

Rival Hyundai is slated to launch the all-electric SUV Ioniq 5, which will be positioned at the premium end of the market. The Korean auto major will also exhibit electric sedan Ioniq 6, fuel cell vehicle Nexo and robot Spot at the show. Kia India will have on display a total of 10 vehicles, which includes a Concept Electric SUV EV9 and Recreational Vehicle KA4.

“The spread of power train options is much wider compared to the previous editions”, said Vinod Aggarwal, President, Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers (SIAM), adding, “Automakers are working on multiple sustainable mobility solutions ranging from biofuels like ethanol, gaseous fuels like CNG, LNG, electrification technologies including EV and hybrid and hydrogen. These will be on display at the motor show.”
summary: India's upcoming automotive show will feature 75 vehicles, including five global debuts. Legacy brands like Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Tata Motors, and Kia will highlight electric and sustainable mobility solutions. Maruti Suzuki will unveil an Electric Concept SUV and new models, Hyundai will showcase the Ioniq 5, Ioniq 6, and Nexo, while Kia will display 10 vehicles, including the Concept Electric SUV EV9. The event reflects the industry's shift towards zero-emission vehicles and diverse powertrain technologies.

headline: IPL 4: The Gen i bids
article:
This year’s IPL Season 4 is more than just cricket players and locker room gossip. It’s also about
the Gen i who are holding the reins behind the teams
The IPL auction is over. It took the 10 bidders 16 hours and 3.3 billion rupees to decide
who among the 350 players they wanted. Now, the nation awaits the thrills and spills of
the Season 4, and it looks like this season there will be more to watch out for than the
players and their locker room gossips. For, quite unnoticed, IPL has been a young
makeover – Gen i has been slowly, but surely taking over the reins of the teams in many
instances, something that became quite evident during the bidding for Season 4.
They were there last time too, but this time, fronting the negotiations, and almost
becoming the face of their respective teams have been Siddhartha Mallya, Sushanto Roy,
Gayatri Reddy, Akash Ambani. Here’s all the dope on them...
Siddhartha Mallya
Last season, he was at the stands with Deepika Padukone, but this time, expect him to
be in the thick of things, for this whiz kid who says he played “hockey and rugby” in
college is “handling the affairs” of Royal Challengers Bangalore. A suave businessman at
25, this young dude who’s lost oodles of weight, was among the The Times 50 Most
Desirable Men & Women list of The Times of India. He’s already a director on board of his
dad Vijay Mallya’s rollicking business, one of the perks of which is getting to select
models for a calendar shoot! During the auctions, when Kings XI Punjab raised the stakes
for batsman Saurabh Tiwary at the last minute, Siddhartha decided to “have a word” with
Preity, and finally managed to get the batsman for his team.
“It’s a good, overwhelming feeling. One of my first endeavours in India. Just being in the
whole set up – there’s a lot at stake, but it’s good,” he told a channel last year. His dad isWill Sid and Deepika displace Raj and Shilpa as the ‘it’ couple this season?
Gayathri Reddy
The young are known to wear their attitude on their tees, and her’s – the one she wore
for the auction said – ‘Status Symbol’. Guess you won’t miss her in the stands anymore
(you didn’t quite ‘see’ her last time, did you?), for, the lady’s announced her arrival on
the scene! Pretty as a peach, Gayathri partied hard during the last season, but this time,
looks like she means business. Egged on by her brother, she fought for the players she
wanted, and got a balanced team in place. No wonder her media baron dad T
Venkattaram Reddy let her helm things this time. She seems to know the game rather
well, and defended bidding for Daniel Christian saying, “Christian is a good fast bowler
and a decent batsman. He is also a brilliant fielder.”
“I think it’s a good idea to put back all the players into the auction pool, and we also get
the opportunity to retain our key players,” she said last time. “T20 is all about youth and
the majority of our population is 25, and so my being in the game a reflection of that.”
Will she be able to add the much-wanted glam quotient to the game this time?
Sushanto Roy
Sushanto Roy, 34, CEO in his dad Subrata Roy’s company. And now, CEO of Pune
Warriors. A Kirori Mal College graduate, he has loads of experience in real estate. He is
also the man who made “Karishma – The Miracles of Destiny” touted to be the biggest
and costliest TV serials which starred Karisma Kapur, but which had to be pulled off
because of dismal TRPs.
“It was first time for me and before coming to the auction, I felt these are big guys and
big names and will be serious. But it was a lot of fun being with them. It was quite a light-hearted environment even though we were bidding against each other,” said he.
Will be bring bollywood stars to watch his team’s matches?
Akash Ambani
Nita and Mukesh Ambani’s son Akash is a newbie. He sat with his mother through the 16
hours of auction, and has just recently begun to attend the AGMs of his dad’s company.
Akash used to be a Judo lover, guess he doesn’t practice anymore. Is cricket his
newfound love? Anyway, he’s considered to be the lucky mascot for Mumbai Indians, and
was pretty much there for all the matches last season too, and perhaps that’s why Nita
got Akash to sit with her at the tables. This 20-something dressed in business suits on
both the days, but looked really young to be batting for the players he wanted. Also, he
needs to dude up a bit – now, were he do a Mallya junior and lose some weight, gel up
that hair, and get a Bollywood babe to hang on to him, well...
Mum’s the word for him, really!
Will Akash make his presence felt in a big (pun intended) way this time at IPL Season 4,
or do we have to wait for the next season for that?
summary:
This passage highlights the evolving role of young influencers in IPL Season 4. It emphasizes the emergence of a new generation, like Siddhartha Mallya, Gayathri Reddy, Sushanto Roy, and Akash Ambani, who are taking charge behind the scenes of various teams. Siddhartha Mallya, a suave businessman, is actively involved in Royal Challengers Bangalore's affairs, showcasing his negotiation skills during the auctions. Gayathri Reddy, the daughter of a media baron, exhibits a keen understanding of the game and aims to bring glamour to the league. Sushanto Roy, a CEO in his father's company and now heading Pune Warriors, shares his lighter auction experience and hints at potentially bringing Bollywood stars to their matches. Akash Ambani, relatively new to the scene, represents Mumbai Indians, though his impact remains to be seen, raising questions about his potential future involvement.

Overall, the piece sheds light on these young influencers stepping into influential roles within the IPL, hinting at a potential shift in the league's dynamics beyond just the players and games.

headline: EC announces by-poll to Lumla assembly seat
article:
ITANAGAR, 18 Jan: The Election Commission (EC) on Wednesday announced by-poll to Lumla assembly seat in Tawang district.

According to a notification issued by the commission, the by-poll will be held on 27 February.

The assembly seat fell vacant after the demise of Jambey Tashi in November last year.

The commission announced that the filing of nomination will take place on January 31, while the last date to file nominations will be seven February. The scrutiny of nominations will take place on eight February. The last date for withdrawal of candidatures will be 10 February. The counting will take place on two March.

The model code of conduct for governments, candidates and political parties has come into force in the entire Tawang district with the announcement of election schedules. It will remain in force till the completion of the election.
summary: The Election Commission has scheduled a by-poll for the Lumla assembly seat in Tawang district, Arunachal Pradesh, following the passing of Jambey Tashi. The by-election is set for February 27, with the nomination filing starting on January 31 and concluding on February 7. Scrutiny of nominations will occur on February 8, and the last date for withdrawal of candidatures is February 10. The counting of votes will take place on March 2. The model code of conduct is in effect in the entire Tawang district until the election concludes.

headline: U.S. to lift cap on intake of medical students
article:
The United States administration is likely to introduce a bill in the Senate and the Congress to remove the federal cap on the intake of medical students, according to the Association of Physicians of Indian Origin (AAPI), a body of physicians of Indian-origin in India. This would benefit international students, including those from India.

According to Vinod K. Shah of the AAPI, President Barack Obama has assured the association that his government would introduce the bill to add an additional 15,000 residency slots.

This has been a long-standing demand of the AAPI to increase residency slots for medical graduates to facilitate more international students join post-graduate courses, Dr. Shah told journalists at the Global Healthcare Summit here on Saturday.

The maximum intake of students by various U.S. universities at present is 18,000 seats, of which around 16,000 are reserved for the U.S. citizens, leaving only 2,000 for international students.

“If the bill is passed, it will benefit the students from India the most as they constitute about 30 to 40 per cent of the total international students selected to study in the U.S.,” Dr. Shah said.

Recognition of courses

The move is also expected to benefit India as it recently started recognising post-graduate medical courses obtained by Indian-origin students of five countries: the U.S., U.K., Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

“An official notification has been recently passed and included in the gazette to recognise PG medical courses certificates obtained by NRI students from these countries,” Ketan Desai, President of the Medical Council of India, said. The move is to avail the services of students who receive expert training in these countries. They can start practising in India without going through any more tests, Mr. Desai added.

This year, the AAPI has roped in the British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin (BAPIO) and top-notch Indian medical professional associations to make the summit a truly global one.

The summit will share best practices and experience from leading experts around the world to develop actionable plans for launching demonstration projects. The focus will be on prevention, treatment and management of “priority disease states” in India with measurable metrics to ensure that the plans are viable.

It also aims at bringing together some of the world’s most renowned experts to focus on priority disease states such as allergy, immunology, cardiovascular, diabetes, infectious disease (HIV/AIDS), emergency medicine, mental health, and maternal and child health. The summit will have a wider global perspective with the addition of medical tourism and health information technology.
summary: The United States administration is considering a bill to eliminate the federal cap on medical student intake, potentially adding 15,000 residency slots, as confirmed by the Association of Physicians of Indian Origin (AAPI). This move aims to accommodate more international students, particularly benefiting those from India, who make up a significant portion of foreign medical students in the U.S. It coincides with India's recent recognition of post-graduate medical courses from select countries, facilitating Indian-origin students' practice in India without further testing. The AAPI, collaborating with global medical associations, hosts a summit focusing on disease prevention, treatment, and management, including medical tourism and health technology.

headline: Morning Digest: Covishield vaccine gets approval from DCGI’s expert panel, farmers to escalate protest on January 4 if deadlock continues, and more
article:
Covishield Vaccine Approval:
A key decision was taken regarding the approval of the Covishield vaccine, a candidate vaccine developed in partnership by the University of Oxford, Vaccitech, and pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca. A photo shared by the University of Oxford showed a vial of the vaccine, emphasizing the collaborative global efforts in the fight against COVID-19. The approval process for Covishield involved a rigorous review by the Subject Expert Committee (SEC) under the Central Drugs Standard Control Organization (CDSCO). The SEC's marathon meeting, which lasted from the morning until late into the evening, culminated in a recommendation for the approval of Covishield to the Drug Controller General of India (DCGI), which serves as the final approving authority for vaccines and drugs in India.

This approval was a pivotal step in India's vaccination campaign, as Covishield was seen as a key vaccine candidate for inoculating millions in the country. The vaccine had already shown promising results in clinical trials, and with the nod from the SEC and DCGI, it was set to be a crucial tool in combating the pandemic in India.

Farmers' Protests:
Meanwhile, the Samyukt Kisan Morcha (SKM), a coalition of farmers' unions, held an internal meeting on January 1, 2021, to intensify their protest against the contentious farm laws introduced by the central government. The SKM leaders threatened to escalate their protests if their demands for the repeal of the three agricultural laws were not met. Among the actions they threatened to take were shutting down malls and petrol pumps in Haryana, organizing a tractor march on the Kundli-Manesar highway, and proceeding towards Delhi from Jaipur along the highway.

These threats came amid growing tensions between the farmers and the government, as the farmers remained resolute in their stance against the farm laws, which they believed would undermine their livelihoods. The SKM's planned tractor march was part of a larger strategy to apply pressure on the government to address their demands, further escalating what had already become a significant nationwide protest movement.

These two stories, one concerning the battle against COVID-19 and the other reflecting ongoing social and political tensions in India, underscored the multifaceted challenges the country faced at the start of 2021.
summary:
In January 2021, India's Subject Expert Committee (SEC) recommended the approval of the Covishield vaccine, co-developed by the University of Oxford, Vaccitech, and AstraZeneca. After a marathon meeting, the SEC gave its recommendation to the Drug Controller General of India (DCGI), marking a crucial step in India's vaccination efforts against COVID-19.

Simultaneously, the Samyukt Kisan Morcha (SKM), representing farmers protesting against the new farm laws, held a meeting on January 1, threatening to escalate their agitation if their demands were not met. They announced plans to shut down malls and petrol pumps in Haryana, conduct a tractor march on the Kundli-Manesar highway, and push further toward Delhi. These actions highlighted the ongoing tensions between the government and the protesting farmers.

headline: wo Bodies Wash Ashore In Vayalur
article: Chennai: Bodies of a man and a woman washed ashore near the banks of the Palar river at Vayalur near Kalpakkam on Friday. Police are still trying to ascertain their identity, but suspect that they were a couple.Some villagers spotted the corpses near the banks of Karai Thittu and alerted police and fire personnel. On information, a police team rushed to the spot and recovered the bodies before sending them to the government hospital at Chengalpet for autopsy. Police suspect that these bodies may have been dragged by the river to the shore after they were buried on the banks somewhere else.The Satras police have registered a case and further investigations are on.
summary: The bodies of a man and a woman were discovered washed ashore near the banks of the Palar river at Vayalur near Kalpakkam. Their identities remain unknown, but authorities suspect they were a couple. Villagers found the corpses near Karai Thittu and alerted police and fire personnel. Upon arrival, the police recovered the bodies and sent them to Chengalpet government hospital for autopsy. Investigators speculate that the bodies may have been carried by the river to the shore after being buried elsewhere along the banks. Satras police have initiated a case, with ongoing investigations into the incident.

headline: TikTok back in US: A look at its India journey and what happened after 2020 ban
article:
From teenage dancers to grandmothers sharing cooking tips, video-sharing app TikTok has been embraced for its ability to transform an ordinary person into a global celebrity when a video goes viral.
But it is also rife with disinformation, and its Chinese ownership has spurred national security issues in the United States and India in the past.

TikTok was shut down in the US late Saturday as a deadline loomed for its Chinese owners, ByteDance, to sell its US subsidiary to non-Chinese buyers.
But on Sunday, the app restored its service after President-elect Donald Trump promised to issue an executive order delaying the ban. TikTok currently has more than 170 million users in the US.

 Raged over TikTok ban in US, teen sets fire at local Congressman's office
Trump also posted on his Truth Social platform that the United States should take part ownership in TikTok.

In a statement posted on X, TikTok said: "We thank President Trump for providing the necessary clarity and assurance to our service providers that they will face no penalties providing TikTok to over 170 million Americans."

TikTok’s India journey and govt ban
Indian users had flocked to TikTok as early as 2017. It allowed India’s millions of regional language speakers to share their content and create digital communities. 

However, in 2020, the video-sharing app faced an exodus of users after the Indian government banned it following clashes between Indian and Chinese military officials along the border.

Citing national security concerns, India banned TikTok along with more than 50 other Chinese apps in June 2020.

Till that time, India was TikTok’s biggest overseas market outside of China, with over 200 million users.

The Indian government had used the ban as precedent to crack down upon other digital platforms they deemed to be a threat, said a report by Time.com citing digital rights activists.
summary:
TikTok, the popular video-sharing platform known for transforming ordinary users into viral sensations, faced a temporary shutdown in the U.S. on July 19, 2025, as a deadline approached for Chinese parent company ByteDance to divest its American operations. However, the app resumed service after President-elect Donald Trump announced an executive order delaying the ban, and even suggested that the U.S. should hold a stake in TikTok. The app, with over 170 million U.S. users, thanked Trump for providing “clarity and assurance.” Meanwhile, backlash included an incident where a teenager set fire to a Congressman’s office in protest.

In India, TikTok was banned in June 2020 over national security concerns following border clashes with China. At the time, India was TikTok’s largest foreign market with over 200 million users. The ban led to similar crackdowns on other Chinese apps, sparking debates around digital sovereignty and internet freedom, according to digital rights activists.

headline: Budget 2018 may roll out tax sops for home buyers
article:
The government may use Budget 2018 to make owning a house slightly more affordable and even rekindle the interest of home buyers. These measures could be in the form of tax sops for home owners and those looking to buy property.

Tax benefits help in bringing down the effective interest burden in properties that are financed through a home loan.

Here are few things that Budget 2018 could do to help taxpayers own a home and save tax simultaneously.

Principal repayment enhancement
In Budget 2018, the tax benefit on the principal amount repaid on a home loan for a self-occupied property may get an additional benefit of Rs 50,000 or more within the section 80C limit. While existing home loan takers can use the prepayment feature to benefit from it, new borrowers get an additional incentive to take home loans.

Interest payment enhancement
Currently, for a self-occupied property, in addition to the tax benefit on the principal amount, the interest paid is deductible up to Rs 2 lakh per annum. In the upcoming budget, we may see an increase in this limit.

Illustratively, on a Rs 40 lakh loan at 8.35 percent for 15 years, the interest paid in the first and second year is nearly Rs 3.28 lakh and Rs 2.90 lakh, respectively. Increasing the limit will help home buyers save more tax and could boost housing demand.

Preconstruction interest
Currently, for an under-construction house, the interest pertaining to pre-construction period is allowed as deduction in five equal annual instalments, commencing from the year in which the house property is acquired or constructed. Thus, total deduction available to the taxpayer under section 24(b) on account of interest will be 1/5th of interest pertaining to pre-construction period + Interest pertaining to the post construction period.

For someone buying an under construction property for self-use, this limit may be a dampener. On Rs 40 lakh loan, the total interest paid over 5 years could be nearly Rs 7.5 lakh and it can be split in 5 equal instalments before taking tax benefit from the year of possession of the house. Even though the interest portion is high in the initial years of the loan and comes down later on, the annual instalment amount along with the interest paid for that year (post possession) could easily cross the Rs 2-lakh limit of section 24 especially on loans above Rs 25 lakh.

On a higher loan amount, such a limit is restrictive and a borrower may not get full tax benefit on the interest paid. Increasing this limit could help tax payers save more tax.

Loss from house property
For a house that is let-out on rent, Budget 2017 had changed the tax incidence for them. From FY 2017-18, the 'loss from house property' was restricted to Rs 2 lakh per annum for rented houses and 'deemed to be let-out' houses. There could be an increase in the Rs 2 lakh-limit announced in previous budget.

This move put a limit to the amount of interest a person pays on his home loan that can claimed as a set off (in case of 'rented/deemed to be rented' house). This, thereby, has effectively reduced the tax benefit an individual gets from interest paid on a home loan. However, the unadjusted loss from house property can be carried forward for eight assessment years but can only be set off against income from house property.

Real estate and GST
Real estate still does not come under the ambit of Goods and Services Tax (GST).. However, construction activities including residential structures will attract GST of 12 percent. This makes under-construction projects costlier than a ready-to-move-in home. As per the CBEC (Central Board of Excise and Customs), "Sale of building is an activity or consideration which is neither a supply of goods nor a supply of services." This makes the ready-to-move-in properties lucrative compared with under-construction ones.

According to Surendra Hiranandani, CMD, House of Hiranandani, "In the GST regime, the input tax credit is available on taxes paid on materials bought for construction which can be adjusted against the GST liability, the effective tax rate post adjustment is quite high as compared to the old rate of 5.5 percent. Further, stamp duty continues to remain in force even after implementation of GST and the rates vary from state to state which increases the costs for the consumer. We hope that state governments abolish the same or merge with the existing GST rates."

Section 80EE reintroduction
Home buyers who took loans in FY 2016-17 were allowed to take an additional tax benefit of up to Rs 50,000 under Section 80EE of the Income Tax Act, subject to certain conditions. The deduction is over and above the limit of Rs 2 lakh, provided it is for a self-occupied property. Although not available in the FY 2017-18, this benefit could be reintroduced in FY 2018-19, with modifications.

Here are the conditions that have to be met to avail the addition tax benefit:
o The additional deduction in respect to interest on loan taken would be applicable only for residential house property;
o It is available only for first-time home buyers;
o The maximum benefit is capped at Rs 50,000 a year;
o The value of the house property cannot exceed Rs 50 lakh;
o The loan amount cannot exceed Rs 35 lakh;
o The loan has to be sanctioned between April 1, 2016 and March 31, 2017.

Those who have already taken the loan, as per the conditions above, can continue to avail of the tax benefits in the later assessment years. If Budget 2018 reintroduces it for the FY 2018-19, home buyers stand to gain.
summary: In the upcoming Indian Budget 2018, tax sops for home owners and prospective property buyers could be implemented to make owning a house more affordable and to encourage home-buying. Possible measures include an increase in the tax benefit on the principal amount repaid on a home loan for a self-occupied property, a potential increase in the deduction limit for interest payments on home loans, an enhancement of the deduction for preconstruction interest, and an increase in the limit for the loss from house property for rented houses. Additionally, the reintroduction of Section 80EE, which provides an additional tax benefit for first-time home buyers, is a possibility.

headline: Masik Durgashtami January 2021: All you need to know
article:
This month Masik Durgashtami will be observed on January 21, 2021, Thursday. Pausha, Shukla Ashtami begins at 13:14 on Jan 20, 2021, and ends at 15:50 on Jan 21, 2021. Here is all you need to know.

Masik Durgashtami January 2021: Durgashtami is a very auspicious day dedicated to Goddess Durga (Durga is the epitome of energy and wrath). On this day, devotees observe fast and worship Goddess Durga. It is believed that one who observes the Durga Ashtami vrat with full dedication is bestowed with happiness and good fortune in their lives.

Masik Durgashtami Vrat is observed every month during Ashtami Tithi of Shukla Paksha (waxing phase of the Moon). However, the most significant Durgashtami, which is known as Mahashtami, falls in the month of Ashwin during nine days of Shardiya Navratri festivities.

Masik Durgashtami is also known as Maas Durgashtami or Monthly Durgashtami.

Masik Durgashtami January 2021: Date
This month, Masik Durgashtami will be observed on January 21, 2021, Thursday. Pausha, Shukla Ashtami begins at 13:14 on Jan 20, 2021, and ends at 15:50 on Jan 21, 2021.

Masik Durgashtami January 2021: Significance
The purpose of observing Masik Durgashtami vrat is to clear all the difficulties in life by the blessings of Durga. The devotees observe fast on this day to get divine protection, prosperity, success, happiness, and peace in their lives. It is believed that those who observe the Masik Durgashtami with diligence get rid of all bad karmas of the past lives.

Goddess Durga was formed by combining the forces of Lord Shiva, Lord Vishnu, and Lord Brahma to defeat the demon Mahishasura.
summary:
Masik Durgashtami, a sacred day dedicated to Goddess Durga, will be observed on January 21, 2021 (Thursday). The Ashtami Tithi begins at 1:14 PM on January 20 and ends at 3:50 PM on January 21. Devotees across India observe Masik Durgashtami Vrat on this day every month during the Shukla Paksha Ashtami (waxing moon phase), seeking the blessings of Goddess Durga for protection, prosperity, happiness, and success.

The vrat involves fasting and special prayers offered to the goddess, who symbolizes divine energy and power. It is believed that sincere observance of the vrat helps remove obstacles and clears bad karmas from past lives. While Masik Durgashtami is observed monthly, the most important Durgashtami, called Mahashtami, falls during Shardiya Navratri in the month of Ashwin.

Masik Durgashtami is also known by other names like Maas Durgashtami or Monthly Durgashtami and holds deep spiritual significance for followers of Shakti worship.

headline: ‘No new cases of Avian flu in Vadodara’
article:
Ten days after Vadodara district reported its first confirmed case of bird flu after three of the five samples of crows found dead in Savli tested positive, the Vadodara animal husbandry department on Thursday said that the H5N8 strain now “appears to have weakened” as no new cases of avian flu or mortality have come forth.

Animal husbandry officer for Vadodara Dr Prakash Darji told this newspaper that while 34 teams of the department have been making daily rounds of the eight taluka heads of the district, no new mortality or suspected avian flu cases have been found.

“Our teams are going on a daily round of the talukas to keep a tab on the situation and so far we have not come across any more mortalities among birds after the incident of pigeons found dead in Kia village of Karjan ten days ago. The report of the pigeons and two peacock carcasses were negative. So, we can say, at the moment, that the avian flu outbreak was restricted to Vasantpura in Savli taluka of the district where the crows died on January 10,” Darji said, adding that some samples of backyard poultry also tested negative for the virus.
summary: Ten days after Vadodara district reported its first confirmed bird flu case with three crow samples testing positive for the H5N8 strain, the Vadodara animal husbandry department said on Thursday that the virus now “appears to have weakened.” No new avian flu cases or bird deaths have been reported since. Dr. Prakash Darji, the district’s animal husbandry officer, said 34 teams continue daily monitoring across eight talukas but have found no new mortalities. The outbreak was limited to Vasantpura in Savli taluka, with other tested birds, including pigeons and peacocks, testing negative.

headline: Police to beef up vigil in desolate zones after dark
article:
KOLKATA: A vast zone of the city that bustles with activity in the morning becomes desolate and risky, especially for women, after dark. This is the business zone, most of which is non-residential. Police are now trying to increase human surveillance in these areas.
Areas like BBD Bag, Esplanade, Garden Reach, Metiabruz, parts of Kidderpore, Maidan, Beliaghata and areas in and around Sealdah and Kolkata stations are completely deserted after 10pm and turn into hubs of criminals and hooligans. "Roads like Indira Gandhi Sarani, Dufferin Road, Strand Road, Outram Road, Eden Gardens Road,
Queens Way, Hospital Road, Lovers Lane, Kyd Street are completely desolate at night. Movement of people is negligible and that makes these areas very risky," admitted a police officer.Joint CP (headquarters) Rajeev Mishra said: "We have indentified some areas of Kolkata (that are vulnerable) and we are thinking of planning the police vigilance system in a new way." When asked about details of the plan,Mishra said: "We will increase police posting and strengthen the surveillance system as much as possible, but I cannot divulge the details."
However, senior officers at Lalbazar said CCTV vigilance cannot stop crimes but only detect them and so, to truly have an effect, manual watch should be enhanced. But, here lies the main problem - that of staff strength, said a senior officer of Kolkata Police. It is very hard to man such a big area with only a 40,000-strong force, the officer explained. Previously, there was a Radio Flying Squad (RFS) that used to move around on patrol vans only to keep a watch on the streets. Each van consisted of an officer, two constables apart from the driver and they used to constantly update police stations about activities in their areas. This helped police stations to take action quickly. Recently, this RFS has been broken to provide additional force to added areas.
"RFS was like the eyes and ears of police stations, but now police stations have to depend solely on their patrol force and city watch sections," the officer said.
Police to beef up vigil in desolate zones after dark - Times of India

Each police station has two to three patrol vans and three to four motorbikes for 'city watch', but that is not adequate to cover a large area. "Most police stations cover an area of 25-30sqkm and the entire area cannot be covered with only two or three vans. Moreover, we don't have adequate staff because most of the policemen have to look after law and order and investigation at the same time," said an officer of Hare Street police station.
"We have started checking vehicles. Previously, we used to do it once a week, but now we have decided to increase the checking mechanism. Though after 10pm it's 'fewer-vehicles time', it's at this time when some vehicles are used for anti-social activities and that needs to be examined. We have also decided to post policemen at all kiosks even at night," said DC (traffic) Dilip Kumar Ad
summary: Kolkata's business zones, desolate and unsafe after dark, are seeing increased police surveillance to combat rising crime. Vulnerable areas include BBD Bag, Esplanade, and Sealdah . Police plan to enhance human surveillance due to limited CCTV effectiveness, despite challenges of understaffing. The Radio Flying Squad, once crucial for patrolling, has been disbanded, straining resources. Vehicle checks and night patrols will be intensified to improve safety, as per Joint CP Rajeev Mishra.

headline: Office of profit: President Ram Nath Kovind okays disqualification of 20 AAP MLAs
article:
President Ram Nath Kovind today accepted the Election Commission's recommendation to disqualify 20 MLAs of Delhi's ruling Aam Aadmi Party for holding offices of profit.
 
 A notification issued by the law ministry quoted the president as saying that in the light of the opinion expressed by the Election Commission (EC), the 20 members of the Delhi legislative assembly have been disqualified
 
 The AAP MLAs were appointed parliamentary secretaries and their
 appointment was described as them holding offices of profit by a petitioner.
 In a blow to the AAP, the EC had on Friday asked the President to disqualify its 20 MLAs.
 *... Having considered the matter in the light of the opinion expressed by the Election Commission, I, Ram Nath Kovind, president of India, in exercise of the powers...do here hold that the aforesaid 20 members of the Delhi
 legislative assembly stand disqualified from being members of the said assembly," the notification said.
 All the 20 AAP MLAs had moved the Delhi High Court challenging the EC's recommendation but Justice Rekha Palli had refused to pass any interim
 order.
summary: President Ram Nath Kovind has accepted the Election Commission's recommendation to disqualify 20 Members of the Legislative Assembly (MLAs) belonging to Delhi's ruling Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) for holding offices of profit. The AAP MLAs were appointed as parliamentary secretaries, and their appointments were challenged as holding offices of profit by a petitioner. Following the Election Commission's recommendation, the president issued a notification stating that the 20 members of the Delhi legislative assembly stand disqualified from their positions.

headline: World Bank approves Rs 1000 cr loan to help people get Bengal govt services
article:
World Bank approves Rs 1000 cr loan to help people get Bengal govt services
January 23, 2022
New Delhi, Jan 22 (PTI): The World Bank has approved a loan of around Rs 1,000 crore to the West Bengal government primarily to support its effort to help the poor and vulnerable groups access its social protection services.

According to a statement released by the state government on Saturday, the loan will help the administration improve services such as medical help through telemedicine, support for the elderly and differently-abled, financial inclusion of citizens with digital payments and disbursement of benefits for public schemes.

“The World Bank on January 19 has sanctioned a $125 million (about Rs 1,000 crore) loan to the government of West Bengal to support the state’s effort to help the poor and vulnerable groups access social protection services,” the statement read.

The loan under the ‘West Bengal Building State Capability for Inclusive Social Protection’ operation will strengthen the capability of this state to expand coverage and access to social assistance and targeted service for poor and vulnerable groups, it said.

When contacted, a top official of the West Bengal government said, “This loan will strengthen the state’s capability to expand its coverage and reach out to the thousands of poor people with its welfare programmes.” The Mamata Banerjee government runs over 400 programmes that provide social assistance, protection, care services and jobs, the statement said.
