summary: The World Bank has approved a loan of approximately Rs 1,000 crore to the West Bengal government aimed at enhancing access to social protection services for the poor and vulnerable groups in the state. This loan, sanctioned on January 19, will primarily support initiatives such as telemedicine for medical assistance, aid for the elderly and differently-abled, digital financial inclusion, and the disbursement of benefits for public schemes. The loan falls under the 'West Bengal Building State Capability for Inclusive Social Protection' operation, aiming to bolster the state's capacity to extend coverage and access to social assistance and targeted services. A senior official from the West Bengal government emphasized that this funding would enhance the state's capability to reach thousands of impoverished individuals with its welfare programs. The Mamata Banerjee-led government currently operates over 400 programs offering social assistance, protection, care services, and employment opportunities.

headline: Uncapped players set for a fat purse
article:
As some of the big names in the Indian Premier League (IPL) horizon go under the hammer after a long time, the likes of Chris Gayle, Kieron Pollard and R. Ashwin will steal the limelight over the next two days during the player auction.

But for the first time, the uncapped domestic cricketers are likely to be chased as desperately as the international stars by all the eight franchises.

In fact, so sought-after are some of the top domestic players that in all likelihood the next two days will witness the highest price tag for an uncapped player in the history of the IPL, eclipsing the sum of ₹8.5 crore paid by Delhi Daredevils for Pawan Negi in 2016.

Ever since the domestic uncapped players were included in the auction pool, multiple players have earned bids much higher than many regulars on the international circuit.

And the Baroda all-rounder duo of Krunal Pandya and Deepak Hooda will be on the wish-list of virtually all the teams.Higher purse

Hooda, who was sold to Sunrisers Hyderabad for ₹4.2 crore after Rajasthan Royals was suspended, recently had a feel of the India dressing room during the T20 series against Sri Lanka last month but did not get a game, while Krunal, the older brother of Hardik, will surely fetch a sum much higher than his last auction purse of ₹2 crore.

Despite Mumbai Indians having an option to exercise the ‘Right to Match’ option for the all-rounder, Krunal could go for a sum closer to his younger brother’s retention amount of ₹11 crore. The same is the case with Hooda, who is one of the biggest hitters in domestic cricket.

Tamil Nadu all-rounder Vijay Shankar will also not be too far in the list as the middle-order batsman and medium-pacer is on the radar of multiple teams.

Young guns

Besides, fast bowlers Basil Thampi and Aniket Choudhary are also expected to add a few zeroes to their worth come Sunday. Also, a plethora of India’s current under-19 squad may join the list. Batsmen Prithvi Shaw, Himanshu Rana and Shubman Gill are set to pocket eight-figure contracts along with all-rounder Kamlesh Nagarkoti and pace bowlers Shivam Mavi and Aditya Thakare.

One of the main reasons for the domestic uncapped players being in demand is the fact that at least three teams are set to undergo a virtual overhaul of their squads.

Rajasthan Royals and Kings XI Punjab have indicated their decision to form a new team while Delhi Daredevils is expected to continue with its recent tradition of a makeover to the squad every season.

It could result in the domestic uncapped players — along with Australia batsman D’Arcy Short and England all-rounder Jofra Archer, who has earlier featured in an Under-19 World Cup for the West Indies — becoming household names over the weekend.
summary: In the IPL 2023 auction, uncapped domestic cricketers are anticipated to attract as much attention as international stars. The Baroda duo, Krunal Pandya and Deepak Hooda, may command significant sums, potentially surpassing previous records. Young talents like Vijay Shankar, Basil Thampi, and Aniket Choudhary, along with members of India's under-19 squad, are expected to secure lucrative contracts. The demand for domestic players is driven by squad overhauls planned by Rajasthan Royals, Kings XI Punjab, and Delhi Daredevils, promising an exciting weekend for cricket enthusiasts.

headline: Centre rolls out first nasal vax as booster
article:
New Delhi : India on Thursday rolled out the first nasal vaccine against Covid-19, to be administered as a primary or booster dose for adults, potentially widening the pool of people who may take a third vaccine against the infection, cutting tertiary costs, and easing pressures on supply and storage networks.

The vaccine, manufactured by Bharat Biotech and branded iNCOVACC, was launched by Union health minister Mansukh Mandaviya and science minister Jitendra Singh, and will initially be available only at private facilities, where it will cost ₹800 for a spray.

In a statement, Bharat Biotech said the vaccine was designed to be economical and is targeted at low- and middle-income countries.

“As a needle-less vaccination, Bharat Biotech’s iNCOVACC will be world’s first such booster dose. India will now have more options when it comes to third doses or precautionary doses,” said the Hyderabad-based firm, which also manufactures Covaxin, one of the two key intravenous jabs that form the bulk of India’s national Covid-19 inoculation programme.

“A roll-out of iNCOVACC is expected to begin in private hospitals that have placed advance orders. Initial manufacturing capacity of several million doses per annum has been established, this can be scaled up to a billion doses as required,” the firm added.

The vaccine has been approved for use as a primary series vaccine and heterologous booster in India.

“Being the world’s first intranasal Covid-19 vaccine, this marks a glorious tribute to the call for Atmanirbhar Bharat (self-reliant India),” Mandaviya said during the launch.

On December 24 last year, India’s technical expert panel on immunisation — the National Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (NTAGI) — recommended that the vaccine be used as a precautionary dose for adults.

The vaccine has been developed by the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, US, and licensed for manufacturing and distribution by Bharat Biotech and another American company , Precision Biologics.

Experts are hopeful of its utility since it is easy to administer, and is a new inoculation -- factors that could help overcome hesitancy around booster doses. Around 716 million of 940 million adults in India are yet to take the third dose of a Covid-19, according to data analysed by HT.

Scientists and health experts have long viewed nasal vaccines as a vital means to end the pandemic. These sprays aim to protect the site that the Sars-CoV-2 virus first targets — the nasal pathway. The vaccine paints the mucous membrane in the nasal pathway with a layer of antibodies, preventing an infection at the very source.

Conventional vaccines work differently: they trigger antibodies that circulate in the bloodstream; these antibodies are best suited to preventing the disease from taking hold, but are usually unable to avert an infection or transmission.

The company said iNCOVACC was evaluated in phase 1, 2 and 3 clinical trials involving over 3,000 participants with successful results.

Administered as a nasal spray, it does not require syringes, needles, alcohol wipes, bandages, etc, saving costs related to procurement, distribution, storage, and biomedical waste disposal, routine requirements for intravenous injections.

The company also said that clinical trials and extensive humoral and cell-mediated responses were conducted to evaluate the vaccine as a primary dose schedule, and as heterologous booster dose for people who have previously received two doses of the Covaxin and Covishield, the most widespread Covid-19 vaccines administered in India.

“iNCOVACC recipients demonstrated significant levels of Mucosal IgA antibody levels (measured in the saliva). Mucosal IgA antibodies in the upper respiratory tract may provide benefits in reducing infections and transmission,” said the company.

The vaccine can be stored in a regular refrigerator temperature of 2-8°C, making it easy to store and distribute across the country.

“Nasal vaccines might be able to prevent even asymptomatic Covid because it generates local IgA antibodies (first line of defence), cutting chain of transmission and possibly bringing an end to this pandemic,” said senior immunologist Dr Narinder Kumar Mehra.

According to the company, the vector-based platform can be easily updated with emerging variants for mass production within a few months.

“Despite the lack of demand for Covid-19 vaccines, Bharat Biotech continued product development in intranasal vaccines, to be well-prepared with platform technologies for future infectious diseases. Bharat Biotech has also initiated development of variant-specific vaccines for COVID in an attempt to be future ready,” it said.
summary: India launched iNCOVACC, the world's first nasal Covid-19 vaccine, developed by Bharat Biotech. Priced at ₹800 per spray, it targets low- and middle-income countries, approved for primary and booster doses. Administered as a nasal spray, it generates mucosal IgA antibodies, potentially reducing infections and transmission. The vaccine underwent successful clinical trials involving over 3,000 participants, demonstrating efficacy. Its vector-based platform allows easy updating with emerging variants, while storage at regular refrigerator temperatures simplifies distribution. iNCOVACC offers a cost-effective, easily administered solution to combat the pandemic, with potential to ease supply and storage pressures, advancing India's self-reliance in vaccine production.

headline: Centre puts entire stake of Air India on sale
article:
The government on Monday announced a plan to sell its entire stake in Air India, renewing its attempt to sell the state-owned airline after a similar move in 2018 failed to attract any bidder.

A document released by the government on Monday invited initial expressions of interest (EOI) in the airline and set March 17 as the deadline for the submissions. The Air India Specific Alternative Mechanism (AISAM), headed by Union home minister Amit Shah, approved the release of the preliminary information memorandum (PIM) for inviting EOI for the disinvestment move.

Civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri said the airline was a “great asset” and its position was “fragile” due to heavy debt. He said Air India, as a brand, will continue to fly but it needs to be privatised.

“Due to its accumulated debt of about ₹60,000 crore, its financial position is in a very fragile condition and Air India is currently under a debt trap. Any private investor can turn it around and make Air India a profitable venture by bringing operational as well as financial efficiencies. The government has limited financial resources whereas the private investor can bring the required capital to make it turnaround. We hope and wish that Air India remains a vibrant airline and fly forever,” Puri said.

Monday’s announcement only marks the first of a multi-stage process. The government has given time till February 11 for the submission of written queries on PIM and the share purchase agreement (SPA) while the last date for submission of the expression of interest is March 17. It will announce the qualified bidders on March 31 following which the Request for Proposal (RFP) will be issued. The government has not yet announced the date for the RFP stage.

he move is also a politically contentious one.The Congress criticised the Centre over the move. “The sale of Air India has been going on for the last six years since 2014 when this government assumed office. A special group of ministers (GoM) was formed to look into it. Five ministers deliberated on it. If the government seriously wants to sell Air India, they should look for a real investor and have to go for a real strategic sale. The government has been misleading on the issue,” Congress spokesperson Supriya Shrinate said.

CPI general secretary D Raja blamed the government’s “bad policies” and maintained that the national carrier has the potential to emerge as a powerhouse in the aviation sector.

Experts also said the timing of the Centre’s move amid an economic slowdown could pose a challenge.

“While divestment is a positive step, it has to be when you have a strong platform, not with a wobbly economic base. After the first failed attempt, it makes sense for the government to divest and find a company that can help make the Maharaja stronger... And this should be done especially when we have a positive economic climate. At the moment, the investment sentiment with India is not conducive… There are several external risk factors also in aviation such as oil prices, the Iranian crisis and the corona virus outbreak, etc.,” said Mark Martin, founder and CEO of Martin Consulting, an aviation consultancy.

As part of the strategic disinvestment, Air India plans to sell its entire stake in Air India Express and 50% shareholding in equal joint venture Air India SATS Airport Services (AISATS). All the three will be sold together and management control of the national carrier will be transferred to the investor, the government said. The government previously offered only 76% of its stake for sale.

In November, Puri told Parliament that the national carrier, which loses ₹26 crore a day, would have to shut down if it was not privatised. In 2018-19, Air India’s net loss was provisionally estimated at ₹8,556.35 crore. It has a debt of over ₹60,000 crore, half of which has already been taken out of the books and parked in a special purpose vehicle, Air India Assets Holding Ltd.

In its latest plan, the government will target selling its entire stake in the airline and 50% of a ground handling unit. The successful bidder will have to take only a debt of ₹23,286.5 crore (the 2018 offer required them to take on a little over ₹33,000 crore) , while the liabilities will be decided depending on current assets at the time of closing of the transaction, according to the PIM. The remaining amount of the total ₹60,074 crore debt, as on March 31, 2019, will be transferred to the special purpose vehicle. The firm’s land and buildings at the Delhi and Mumbai airports and the corporate office, which are core assets for running the airline, will be given to the new investor on a right-to-use basis for a limited period, the document added.

Puri said that after no bids were received for the national carrier in the first attempt made in 2018, the government learnt its “lessons and analysed critical areas to make the current disinvestment bid more attractive to the prospective Interested Bidders (IBs)”. The government in 2018 called bids for a 76% stake sale in Air India including 100% in subsidiary Air India Express and 50% holding in ground handling company AISATS but failed to get even a single bid amid reports of a consortium of Indigo (Interglobe Aviation) and Qatar Airways being interested.

Air India and Air India Express had combined revenue of ₹30,632 crore in 2018-19, which is the highest among Indian carriers, Puri said.

The government said it was committed to paying certain employee-related dues before the closing of transaction. The total employee strength of the two companies is 17,984, out of which 9,617 are permanent employees. About 36% of the permanent employees will be retiring in the next five years, Puri said.

The government has relaxed the bidding norms wherein net worth for potential bidders is fixed at ₹3,500 crore and minimum stake for an individual consortium partner is lowered to 10%. The net worth criterion was ₹5,000 crore in the 2018 bid document.

Another key change is that an entity can put in a bid on the “strength of its parent”, which means that an entity floated by a big corporate can participate in the disinvestment process, a person aware of the PIM details told Press Trust of India.

Staff dues of about ₹1,383.70 crore on account of Justice Dharmadhikari Commission’s recommendation on past arrears will be paid by the government.

As per the conditions decided by AISAM, the liabilities to be retained in Air India will be equal to certain current and non-current assets.
summary: The Indian government has announced its intention to sell its entire stake in Air India, renewing its efforts to privatize the state-owned airline. This move comes after a similar attempt in 2018 failed to attract any bidders. The government has invited initial expressions of interest, with a deadline for submissions set for March 17. The decision to privatize Air India is driven by its heavy debt of around ₹60,000 crore, putting its financial position in a fragile condition. The government aims to attract private investors to turn around the airline and make it a profitable venture.

headline: Dangal box-office collection: Here's proof that Aamir Khan is a pro at breaking records

Aamir Khan's recent film 'Dangal' has created a new record at the box-office by defying demonetisation and becoming the highest grossing film ever.

headline: Tuticorin stays on edge
article:
The Madras High Court stay is expected to stall for at least four months the plans by Sterlite Copper to build a second copper smelter in Tuticorin to double its capacity from 400,000 tonnes a year.

If the Vedanta group company decides to pursue the project, a public hearing will have to be held and new environmental clearance obtained.

Residents of 18 villages and fisher folk of Tuticorin have been demanding that the expansion be halted.

A bench of Justices M. Sundar and Anitha Sumanth directed the Centre to submit within four months a report after holding the hearing in the district to invite public opinion on the plan for expansion.

The Tamil Nadu government has constituted an inquiry commission headed by Aruna Jagadeeshan, a retired high court judge, to look into the circumstances that led to the police firing in which at least 12 people have been killed.

Chief minister E. K. Palanisamy has announced a solatium of Rs 10 lakh to the family of each victim and Rs 3 lakh for each of those severely injured.

Two senior IAS officers have been deputed to monitor the situation.

Tuticorin town remained on edge on Wednesday. The police opened fire in the afternoon after two of their buses were torched by some relatives of the victims who were waiting outside a hospital to receive the bodies.

Many of the relatives got involved in an altercation with the police over the decision to conduct post- mortems without their concurrence.

When the police resorted to a lathicharge to disperse them, the protesters set ablaze the two buses. According to unofficial reports, at least one person was killed and five injured in the fresh firing.

The police took out a flag march on Wednesday afternoon to ensure peace.

Although the protest is being held for the past 100 days demanding the closure of the existing copper unit over allegations that the factory was causing illness and had contaminated the groundwater, affecting farming within a 50km radius, the dam burst on Tuesday.

More than 20,000 people, including a large number of fishermen, marched towards the collectorate on Tuesday.

The police said they opened fire after the protesters torched 30 vehicles and vandalised the collectorate.

Chief minister Palanisamy maintained that the police firing had become unavoidable.

The Opposition parties have slammed the AIADMK government for " total failure of law and order " . They have demanded the resignation of the chief minister.

Congress president Rahul Gandhi dubbed the police firing " state- sponsored terrorism " , alleging that " Tamilians are massacred because they are not bowing to the RSS " . He asserted that " the RSS cannot silence Tamilians " . M. K. Stalin, the working president of the Opposition DMK, alleged that the police used assault rifles and automatic weapons.

Kamal Haasan, actor and chief of the newly launched Makkal Neethi Mayyam, visited Tuticorin hospital on Wednesday morning to enquire about the condition of those injured in the police firing.

He wanted to know who ordered the firing on " peaceful processionists " . A case was registered against Haasan for visiting the hospital despite prohibitory orders.
summary: The Madras High Court has issued a stay that is expected to delay Vedanta group company Sterlite Copper's plans to build a second copper smelter in Tuticorin, Tamil Nadu, for at least four months. The move follows public opposition, with residents of 18 villages and fisherfolk demanding a halt to the expansion. The court has directed the Centre to submit a report after holding a public hearing in the district to gather opinions on the expansion plan. The Tamil Nadu government has also set up an inquiry commission to investigate the circumstances leading to police firing that resulted in at least 12 deaths.

headline: Automobile sales hit the slow lane
article:
According to year-end figures released by the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers (SIAM), car sales growth dropped to just 6.9 per cent in 2005 from 24.6 per cent at the end of December 2004.

Many carmakers in India, including Tata Motors, saw demand slowing down during the year. There were other factors like the floods in Maharashtra and Gujarat and stricter emission norms, which hit the demand. The emission norms had led to price rise.

Total car sales in 2005 stood at 8.58 lakh units against 8.02 units in 2004. Utility vehicles and multi-purpose vehicles also could not insulate themselves from the slowdown, with sales growth dropping to 8.9 per cent and 3.5 per cent respectively from as high as 25.3 per cent and 11.6 per cent in 2004.

For commercial vehicles, a massive slowdown in demand for medium-and heavy commercial vehicles saw overall growth wilting to 9.04 per cent in 2005 from 28.3 per cent in 2004. This segment was worst hit as sales growth dropped to a low of 3.7 per cent from 28.6 per cent. A total of 1.97 lakh units were sold in 2005 against 1.9 lakh units in 2004.

Motorcycles sales continued their blazing run, although scooters and mopeds remained a pale shadow.

Motorcycles sales in 2005 grew 17 per cent to 55.7 lakh from 47.5 lakh in 2004. Even as the growth rate declined by around 2 per cent year-on-year, 2005 figures were no mean achievement as the base was high. Scooter sales, which had been looking up for sometime on account of Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India, went into negative growth, ironically because of the same factor
summary:
Car sales growth in India fell to 6.9% in 2005, down from 24.6% in 2004, due to lower demand, floods, and stricter emission norms.

Utility and multi-purpose vehicles also saw slower growth: 8.9% and 3.5%, respectively.

Commercial vehicle growth plunged to 9.04% from 28.3%; worst-hit were medium and heavy vehicles at 3.7% growth.

Motorcycle sales remained strong, up 17% to 55.7 lakh units, despite a slightly lower growth rate.

Scooter sales declined, impacted by production issues at Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India.

headline: Cong, NC disrupt national anthem in J&K Assembly
article:
JAMMU: The national anthem was disrupted twice during a joint
session of the Jammu & Kashmir legislature on Monday, when
members of the opposition from National Conference (NC) and
Congress shouted anti-government slogans while it was being
played. The uproar over the unrest that left several dead in the
Valley last summer, also caused the J&K governor to cut short his
address.
The disruption of national anthem is construed as disrespect by
law. The opposition members on Monday created a ruckus when
the anthem was played. Soon after J&K governor N N Vohra began
his address, NC and Congress members raised slogans and
climbed their desks with placards in hand to protest against the
government. The placards read, “Revoke PSA (the controversial public safety Act)”, “Stop killings in Kashmir”, and
“Where is political dialogue?”
Independent MLA Engineer Abdul Rashid protested as well.
Owing to the chaotic situation, the governor was compelled to abruptly end his speech after 12 minutes. National
Conference legislator Basheer Veeri was seen wearing a black jacket to protest against alleged human rights
violations in the Valley. The opposition members justified the disrespect of the national anthem by saying that
they were provoked by the treasury benches
summary: During a joint session of the Jammu & Kashmir legislature, opposition members from National Conference (NC) and Congress disrupted the national anthem twice, shouting anti-government slogans related to the Valley unrest. J&K Governor N N Vohra's address was cut short due to the uproar. Opposition members protested government policies with placards, prompting chaos. Independent MLA Engineer Abdul Rashid joined the protest. The governor ended his speech after 12 minutes amidst the disturbance. National Conference legislator Basheer Veeri protested wearing a black jacket. The opposition justified their actions, claiming provocation from the treasury benches, despite the disruption being construed as disrespect to the anthem.

headline: ‘Indu Mills had devpt potential of Rs 3,600cr’
article:
MUMBAI: The National Textiles Corporation said its 12.5-acre Indu Mills property at Prabhadevi, which Prime Minister Manmohan Singh agreed to hand over to the state free of cost, had a development potential of around Rs 3,600 crore.
Last week, the PM assured a state delegation, led by chief minister Prithviraj Chavan, that the sea-facing property would be allotted for a memorial for B R Ambedkar.
NTC officials are tight-lipped because of the sensitivities involved; all that they divulged was that their valuation of this prime property came to around Rs 300 crore per acre. However, a senior state official debunked the NTC figure, saying the property could not be worth that much, given the existing ready reckoner rate for land in that area. The bureaucrat said the plot was reserved only for industrial use and so, there was no question for commercial exploitation. “The FSI for industrial use is 1,” he said, adding the proposed memorial would have a substantial part of the land reserved for a park, to be open to the public.

The official said there were several ways NTC could be compensated, including giving it an equivalent area outside the city. Another option could be to offer the transfer of development rights or TDR to NTC. This TDR could be exploited in the suburbs. But civic officials said TDR could only be sanctioned if a civic amenity was created on the surrendered plot.

According to sources, the Indu Mills was one of the finest parcels of land in the island city; rates in a nearby high-end residential tower are being currently quoted at Rs 70,000 a sq ft.

The NTC had plans to build a luxury hotel and commercial complex there to garner revenue to revive its sick units elsewhere. The original understanding between the state and NTC was that the latter would surrender four acres for the Ambedkar memorial. As compensation, NTC was to receive extra construction rights on the eight acres.


The plan had to be change after supporters of Republican Sena forcibly occupied the mill premises on December 6. When the NTC approached the HC following the state’s failure to act against the “encroachers”, the court rapped the government for its inaction. On December 22, the state informed the court that it had persuaded the squatters inside Indu Mills to vacate within a week and if they did not, they would be evicted. Last week, after meeting the PM, Chavan said a panel comprising Union ministries of environment and forests, urban development and textiles officials and state government representatives would be formed to resolve the issue
summary: The National Textiles Corporation's (NTC) 12.5-acre Indu Mills property in Prabhadevi, valued at around Rs 3,600 crore, is set to be handed over to the Maharashtra state government free of cost for a B.R. Ambedkar memorial. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh assured this to a delegation led by Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan. Despite NTC valuing the land at Rs 300 crore per acre, a state official contested this figure, noting the land is reserved for industrial use with an FSI of 1. Various compensation methods for NTC are under consideration, including providing alternative land or Transfer of Development Rights (TDR). The original plan to use four acres for the memorial and compensate NTC with extra construction rights on the remaining land changed after supporters of Republican Sena occupied the premises, prompting court intervention. A panel will be formed to resolve the issue.

headline: HDFC slashes home loan rate by 0.05 per cent
article:
"HDFC reduces its Retail Prime Lending Rate (RPLR) on housing loans, on which its adjustable rate home loans (ARHL) are benchmarked
by 5 basis points with effect from January 6, 2020," the mortgage lender said in a statement.
NEW DELHI: In line with the country's largest lender SBI, HDFC Ltd on Friday
reduced the benchmark lending rate by 0.05 per cent, a move that will bring down
interest rate for existing as well new borrowers.SBI earlier this week slashed in its external benchmark-based rate by 25 basis points to 7.80 per cent from 8.05 per cent.
"HDFC reduces its Retail Prime Lending Rate (RPLR) on housing loans, on which its adjustable rate home loans (ARHL) are benchmarked by 5 basis points with effect from January 6, 2020," the mortgage lender said in a statement. New rates will now range between 8.20 per cent and 9 per cent, and the change will benefit all existing customers, it said. The rate cut by lenders come despite the RBI keeping its benchmark repo rate unchanged at 5.15 per cent in December monetary policy review.
During the interaction with media after the announcement of monetary policy on December 5, RBI Governor
Shaktikanta Das had said that although it is not in a hurry to keep reducing interest rates, the central bank would work
to ensure that transmission turns more eective since much needs to be passed on.
While the RBI had cut repo rates by 135 bps in ve policy reviews in 2019, the one-year median MCLR has declined by
only 49 basis points. The weighted average lending rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans sanctioned by banks declined by
only 44 basis points.
summary: HDFC Ltd has reduced its Retail Prime Lending Rate (RPLR) by 5 basis points, effective from January 6, 2020. This move will lower interest rates for both new and existing borrowers on adjustable rate home loans (ARHL), bringing the new rates between 8.20% and 9%. This follows a similar rate cut by State Bank of India (SBI), which reduced its external benchmark rate by 0.25% to 7.80%. Despite the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) maintaining the repo rate at 5.15% in December, these cuts aim to improve loan transmission. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das emphasized the need for more effective transmission of rate cuts to borrowers.

headline: BJP unfolds poll agenda in Punjab
article:
LUDHIANA: Apparently gearing up for the coming Lok Sabha elections, Punjab BJP has started executing its poll agenda by addressing different issues related to trade and industry in the state. With this purpose, the state BJP has started wooing them by highlighting the alleged harsh financial measures taken by the Congress led state government so far.
As a party identified with the interests of traders class, it is no surprise that the party has started unfolding its poll agenda by concentrating on the dissatisfaction among these sections. As a first step, Punjab BJP chief Avinash Rai Khanna addressed a meeting of traders organised by Punjab Pradesh Beopar Mandal in the city on Saturday evening. Khanna candidly told TNN that this was part of their agenda for the coming poll. Talking in poll mode, he held out a promise of his party for doing its best for the welfare of trade and industry so that it may work in tax friendly environment and progress. This issue was deliberated recently in the extended meeting of the state BJP headed by Khanna
The state BJP finance secretary Ashok Juneja said that they would focus on the VAT issue which had generated a lot of heat. The state witnessed a prolonged stir in which the trade and affected small-scale industrial units, particularly the hosiery ones stopped production against its implementation for prolonged period. There are host of issues the party would take up like imposition of exim forms, entry tax and increase in sales tax on de-oiled rice bran, petrol and mobile oil. The party would also highlight that the way these measures have implemented has only added to the woes of the traders and entrepreneurs. Juneja claimed that information collection centres set up by the state government have ended up as barriers. The vehicles carrying goods are detained on flimsy clerical and technical mistakes, he said. The BJP is all set to exploit the resentment prevailing over large-scale sales tax raids. The party is of the view that this is adversely affecting trade and industry which is already passing through recession. In a typical poll bait, state BJP has decided to highlight what BJP led NDA government did for trade and industry. The Union Finance minister Jaswant Singh has made the income tax department as tax payer friendly where persuasive measures are adopted for increasing revenue. The speedy issuance of refunds and reduction of forms required for different formalities are proposed to be highlighted. The BJP is also eyeing to exploit the issue related to removal of octroi. The SAD-BJP government had removed octroi but the Congress led government is silent on this issue despite promise made in its election manifesto, he said. The party would focus on various relief measures taken during the previous SAD-BJP tenure. The sales tax laws were made trade and industry friendly by introducing summary assessment scheme, deemed assessment, abolishing ST-XXIl-A forms and removing sales tax barriers, claimed Juneja.
summary: In preparation for the upcoming Lok Sabha elections, the Punjab BJP has begun implementing its election agenda by addressing issues related to trade and industry in the state. The party aims to woo these sectors by highlighting what they perceive as harsh financial measures taken by the Congress-led state government. Punjab BJP chief Avinash Rai Khanna recently addressed a meeting of traders organized by the Punjab Pradesh Beopar Mandal, emphasizing the party's commitment to the welfare of trade and industry. The party plans to focus on issues such as the Value Added Tax (VAT), imposition of exim forms, entry tax, and sales tax increases. They also criticize the implementation of these measures, claiming they have added to the woes of traders and entrepreneurs. The BJP intends to highlight the NDA government's efforts to make the income tax department more taxpayer-friendly, citing measures such as speedy refund issuance and reduction of required forms. They also plan to address the issue of octroi removal, which was promised in the Congress's election manifesto but has not been fulfilled. The party aims to showcase relief measures taken during the previous SAD-BJP tenure, including making sales tax laws more industry-friendly.

headline: Unions on Chakma-Hajongs asks AAPSU to appeal for special hearing
article:
ITANAGAR, Jan 2: The District Students Unions Co-ordination Committee of Namsai, Changlang and Papum Pare on Chakma/Hajongs Issue constituted by the All Papum Pare District Students’ Union, All Namsai District Students’ Union and All Changlang District Students’ Union, has requested the All Arunachal Pradesh Students’ Union (AAPSU) to immediately appeal to the District Election Officer (DEO) of Papum Pare, Namsai and Changlang to conduct special hearing before 15 January to look into the case of fresh enrolment of 442 names of Chakma and Hajong refugees in the electoral roll of 14 Doimukh, 46 Chowkham, 49 Bordumsa-Diyun and 50 Miao assembly constituencies.
The enrolment reportedly took place during the Special Summary Revision and special drive conducted in the month of October and November last year.
Further, they have urged the AAPSU to fill Form 7 objection application and submit it to the concern Electoral Registration Officers (EROs) at the earliest for deletion of old enrolments done before 2017, wherein 3986 Chakmas and Hajongs were enrolled in the electoral roll in the districts of Papum Pare, Namsai and Changlang.


The affected district students’ unions claimed that it has verified the documents enclosed in Form 6 application for new enrolment by the Chakma and Hajong refugees and found that the Election Voter Identity Cards were issued by concerned EROs without citizenship registration proof and under violation of Section 31 of the Representation of People Act, 1950.
Meanwhile, the Committee decided not to further pursue the Chakma and Hajong refugee issue with the government of Arunachal Pradesh and authorities concerned, without the permission of the AAPSU.
This comes days after the AAPSU advised the people of the refugee affected area to consult with them before raising the refugee issue with the authorities concerned.
summary: The District Students Unions Co-ordination Committee of Namsai, Changlang, and Papum Pare, constituted by various district student unions, has urged the All Arunachal Pradesh Students' Union (AAPSU) to appeal to the District Election Officers of Papum Pare, Namsai, and Changlang for a special hearing to examine the case of fresh enrollment of 442 names of Chakma and Hajong refugees in the electoral roll. The enrollment reportedly occurred during a special summary revision and special drive conducted in October and November 2022.

headline: Metro timetable to be made available in app
article: Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) has announced that the metro timetable will soon be integrated into its mobile application to improve commuter convenience. Currently, passengers rely on station display boards and announcements for train schedules. With this new feature, users will be able to access real-time information about train timings directly on their smartphones, making travel planning easier. The update aims to reduce waiting times and help passengers better coordinate their journeys. Officials stated that the app update would also include notifications about service changes and delays. This move is part of KMRL’s broader efforts to modernize services and enhance the overall commuting experience. Passengers and city residents have welcomed this initiative, hoping it will make daily metro travel more efficient and user-friendly.
summary: Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) has announced that it will soon integrate the metro timetable into its official mobile app to provide real-time schedule information to passengers. Until now, commuters have relied on station boards and announcements to track train timings, which often led to inconvenience and delays. By enabling users to access accurate train schedules on their smartphones, KMRL aims to make travel planning more efficient and reduce waiting times. The updated app will also offer notifications about any service changes or delays, enhancing communication and reliability. This initiative is part of KMRL's broader push to modernize its services and improve the overall passenger experience. The move has been welcomed by regular metro users, who believe it will make daily commutes more predictable and comfortable.

headline: Deepa: Rushdie was invited for Kolkata Literary Meet
article:
A day after the controversial author Salman Rushdie’s visit to the city was called off at the last minute, filmmaker Deepa Mehta said the organisers of the Kolkata Literary Meet had invited him.

“[Rushdie] was going to be a surprise guest... Lit meet paid 4 his tkt [Mumbai-Kolkata flight ticket],” tweeted the Indo-Canadian director of Midnight’s Children , based on Mr. Rushdie’s book of the same name. Mr. Rushdie, in turn, retweeted Ms. Mehta’s tweet on Thursday.

The 1981 Booker Prize winner for Midnight’s Children , and Ms. Mehta were scheduled to arrive here on Wednesday to promote the film.

However, the organisers of the literary meet had said Mr. Rushdie was never scheduled to attend it, though Ms. Mehta was to have come but she could not make it.

Only Rahul Bose, who is playing General Zulfikar in the film, could attend the event.

Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose’s daughter Anita Bose Pfaff said: “It is very unfortunate that Salman Rushdie was not allowed to visit Kolkata. I can’t really judge how his trip would have been, had he come to Kolkata.” On the sidelines of an event here, she said: “These kinds of religious intolerance are dangerous for a secular country like India. Small groups can hold a country hostage. It is very important to create a general attitude against such things.”

Dr. Ptaff said: “People should learn from Netaji’s Indian National Army how to co-exist as different communities and religious groups.”

Criticising Wednesday’s developments, Mahasweta Devi, litterateur and social activist, said: “Kolkata has been an open city for all kinds of cultural activities and people. It is unfortunate that he [Rushdie] could not come. He should have been welcome to the city with all the respect.”

“None should be forbidden to the city, be it filmmakers or artists. It should be always open to all,” she added.
summary:
A day after Salman Rushdie's last-minute visit cancellation to Kolkata, filmmaker Deepa Mehta confirmed that the Kolkata Literary Meet organizers had invited him. Mehta revealed on Twitter that Rushdie was intended as a surprise guest and that the literary meet paid for his Mumbai-Kolkata flight ticket. Rushdie retweeted her message.

Rushdie, the 1981 Booker Prize winner for "Midnight's Children," and Mehta were scheduled to promote the film adaptation in Kolkata. However, the organizers claimed that Rushdie was never on the official schedule, and Mehta, who was supposed to attend, also did not make it. Only actor Rahul Bose, who plays General Zulfikar in the film, attended the event.

Anita Bose Pfaff, daughter of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose, criticized the decision to prevent Rushdie’s visit, emphasizing the dangers of religious intolerance in a secular country like India. She stressed the importance of fostering a general attitude against such actions.

Mahasweta Devi, a noted litterateur and social activist, also condemned the developments, highlighting Kolkata’s history as an open city for cultural activities. She expressed regret that Rushdie was not welcomed, stressing that the city should remain open to filmmakers and artists alike.

In return, Israel freed 110 Palestinian prisoners. The exchange was a rare moment of relief amid the ongoing conflict, with the freed hostages reunited with their families after months of captivity. Notably, 29-year-old German-Israeli Arbel Yehoud, abducted during the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack, was also released. The Thai hostages, who were agricultural workers, were received by officials from the Thai embassy in Israel. Palestinians in Ramallah and Gaza celebrated the return of prisoners, while some former detainees received a hero’s welcome. However, the exchange was delayed by Israel's insistence on ensuring the safe passage of future hostages. The ceasefire between the two sides has temporarily reduced violence in the region.

headline: Odia singer Shasank performs in Rising Star
article:
Another singer from Odisha, Shasank Sekhar, enthralled audience and judges with a power-packed performance in Rising Star India, aired on Colors TV.

Hailing from Bhubaneswar, the Ollywood playback singer sang ‘Teri Meri Kahaani’ from the movie ‘Gabbar’ and struck a chord with the judges, Shankar Mahadevan, Monali Thakur and Diljit Dosanjh, who also voted for him.

He garnered a whopping 94 per cent votes and raised the wall to a deafening applause from the audience.

Rising Star India (Season 2), lIVE music reality and talent hunt show will see singers perform live with simultaneous online audience voting on VOOT app, besides the app and website of the television channel. A screen that streams live results of the voting literally rises when a participant crosses the cut-off of 80 per cent votes, qualifying for the next round.

It was an emotional moment for Shasank as his wife and daughter joined him on the stage prior to his performance. A short video showcased this 28-year-old singer’s struggles for the past 10 years and he expressed how difficult it has been for him to make a name for himself in the music industry.

While Diljit Dosanjh compared him to south superstar Prabhas of ‘Baahubali’ fame because of his hairstyle, Shankar Mahadevan said he sang like popular playback singer Arijit Singh and advised him to work hard to be on par with other contestants. Monali Thakur asked him to keep faith and discouraged him from even thinking about quitting music. Diljit Dosanjh also offered his seat to Shasank’s wife and daughter to witness the performance from the judge’s chair.

Shasank is a known name in Odia music industry and has sung in movies, music videos and performed at stage shows across the State.
summary:
Shasank Sekhar, a talented singer from Bhubaneswar, Odisha, captivated the audience and judges with his performance on Rising Star India, broadcasted on Colors TV. Singing 'Teri Meri Kahaani' from the movie 'Gabbar,' Shasank received high praise from judges Shankar Mahadevan, Monali Thakur, and Diljit Dosanjh, who all voted for him. With an impressive 94% of the votes, Shasank's performance earned him a standing ovation from the audience.

Rising Star India (Season 2) is a live music reality and talent hunt show where singers perform live, and the audience votes in real-time using the VOOT app. Shasank's emotional moment on stage, joined by his wife and daughter, was showcased in a touching video, depicting his struggles over the past decade in the music industry.

Diljit Dosanjh likened Shasank to south superstar Prabhas for his hairstyle, while Shankar Mahadevan compared his singing to popular playback singer Arijit Singh, advising him to work hard to excel. Monali Thakur encouraged him to have faith and urged him not to give up on his musical journey. Diljit Dosanjh even offered his judge's chair to Shasank's family to witness his performance up close.

A well-known figure in the Odia music industry, Shasank has contributed to movies, music videos, and stage performances across the state, showcasing his talent and dedication to music.

headline: SAU different: Brand Brain Box with a Heart
article:
Start with the soothing silky feel of saris from Bangladesh, throw in a dash of Urdu poetry from Pakistan, weave in
the rich carpets of Nepal along with the aromatic teas of Sri Lanka.
Pepper it with the white beaches of Maldives and top it with the sheer brain power of Indian geeks. Mix all this to
create a heady product with a â€˜Made in South Asia'' stamp. Sounds good? Will this brand create waves?
It would, feel experts. "Brand South Asia would be Brand Brain Box," says ad guru Alyque Padamsee.
"South Asian countries may be Third World economies, but they form a first class think tank. The biggest import
of the West is South Asian brain power. In Silicon Valley, the majority of companies are owned by Indians,
Pakistanis and Sri Lankans. Similarly, the Indus Entrepreneurs (TIE), an association of South Asian entrepreneurs
in the US, is a powerful voice," he explains.
If South Asians are known for their brains, they are also known for wearing their hearts â€” and family values â€”
on their sleeves. "Family values are the other major USP of the region and it''s bound to impress the Western
world as well," feels Padamsee.
Brand Emotion, or Brand Family, finds many takers among experts. "The distinctive South Asian culture makes us
stand apart from the cold, matter-of-fact way of life in the West," says Piyush Pandey, creative director, O&M.
"Finally, the ethnic lifestyle, which includes alternative Asian therapies or fiery Asian diets, will attract Western
markets."
Vijay Kalantri, president, All India Association of Industries, feels if these countries stop cutting each other over
4/13/24, 9:31 PM SAU different: Brand Brain Box with a Heart - Times of India
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/sunday-times/deep-focus/sau-different-brand-brain-box-with-a-heart/articleshowprint/403411.cms 2/2
common trading commodities and present a unified high-quality brand â€” like South Asian Tea or South Asian
Textiles, it will go a long way.
According to Chef Sanjeev Kapoor, Brand Passion is our main USP. If South Asian foods are marketed on a
combined platter to the world, it will set trends, he says.
"The reason why the West has so many food chains while we don''t is that we don''t believe in emotionless,
mechanised cooking. Our cooking is both, passionate and bold. While the Italians or the French stop at one herb
in a dish, we fearlessly use 15 types of spices in one curry," he says. "A South Asia Union with no trade restrictions
will help in the growth of all our cuisines."
Even in field of arts and entertainment the region has myriad hues, which can be amalgamated to present a
unified brand, say experts. But this would need a fine balancing act.
As filmmaker Shyam Benegal says: "Pakistani poetry, Bangladeshi songs and Sri Lankan dances can hold their
own anywhere. But there''s a danger of India playing the bully and presenting Bollywood as Brand Asia. That will
be unfortunate."
Most experts feel the West would feel competitive, if not threatened, by the South Asia brand. However, Pandey
says, "The West has always been interested in the subcontinent. And if a common thread emerges from it in the
form of a single brand, they would gain too. Trading with, or travelling through the Union, with a single currency
makes life easier. After all, Brand South Asia shouldn''t be about power, but about making life better."
Piali Banerjee
summary: The concept of "Brand South Asia" combines the cultural richness and intellectual prowess of the region to create a unique identity. It emphasizes the brainpower of South Asians, their strong family values, and distinctive lifestyle. Experts foresee potential in unified branding efforts, such as promoting South Asian foods, textiles, and arts internationally. However, there's a caution against overshadowing diverse cultural elements with dominant forces like Bollywood. While some anticipate Western competition, others believe collaboration could benefit both regions. Ultimately, the goal of Brand South Asia is to enhance lives through cultural exchange and economic cooperation, rather than exerting power.

headline: Huawei slashes Honor View 10 price for India by 20% at Rs 30k
article:
NEW DELHI: Smartphone maker Huawei will start selling its first artificial intelligence-enabled handset Honor View 10 for Rs 29,999, a price 20 per cent lower than the global markets, from January 8.

"For Honor, India matters and we are poised to put India first in our global growth map which is why today we have announced a special India price for Honor View10. The launch of Honor View 10 marks the beginning of a new AI era, making high-end AI mobility technology accessible in India," Huawei India-Consumer Business Group, Vice-President Sales, P Sanjeev said in a statement.

He said, Honor View 10 will be the most affordable Artificial Intelligence (AI) device available at Rs 29,999 for the Indian consumer. It has been priced at Euro 499 or about Rs 38,000 for the rest of the markets.

Apple and Google too have launched AI-enabled smartphones in India.

Honor View 10 will be able to sense who is using the phone, translate messages as per preferred language of the owner without the need to connect with Internet, sense functionality preference of the user, and transpose user face picture on animated character.

The smartphone comes with a 64 GB RAM, 128 GB internal storage, supports additional 256 external storage and 3,750 mAh battery with a fast charger.

The company has started selling 4G VoLTE smartphone Honor 7X having 32 GB internal storage for Rs 12,999 and for 64 GB internal storage, the smartphones have been priced at Rs 15,999 a unit on Amazon.

Huawei claims to have almost doubled shipments of Honor smartphones in India in 2017 as compared to 2016. It sells the Honor smartphones online and plans to further ramp up its manufacturing facility in India.
summary: Chinese smartphone maker Huawei is set to launch its first artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled handset, the Honor View 10, in India for Rs 29,999 ($470), 20% less than the global market price. The device boasts AI features, including face recognition and the ability to translate messages without an internet connection. Huawei aims to make AI technology more accessible in India, emphasizing the country's importance in its global growth strategy. The Honor View 10 will compete with other AI-enabled smartphones from Apple and Google in the Indian market. Huawei claims it almost doubled shipments of Honor smartphones in India in 2017 compared to the previous year.

headline: Divya Khosla choreographs five songs in Yaariyan
article:
Divya Khosla choreographs five songs in Yaariyan
TNN | Jan 15, 2014, 02.06 PM IST
Divya Khosla choreographs five songs in Yaariyan
Debutante director Divya Khosla Kumar has also choreographed five songs in her film Yaariyan. These include Baarish, Meri Maa, Love Me Thoda Aur, Allah Waariyan and Zor Lagake Haishaa.

Divya, who has directed music videos in the past, said, “Songs form a very integral part of the film and they take the story forward. People have loved my visualisation in Baarish and Allah Waariyan. If my work in the songs is being loved so much, I’m sure, by God’s grace, the audience will love the film as much. It will make you laugh and cry and leave you on a feel-good note.”

Adds producer Bhushan Kumar, “Divya has worked with great precision and detail. Apart from directing the film, she has also tried her hand at choreography and we’ve received very encouraging reviews. Her shot taking is larger than life.”
The film stars Himansh Kohli, Rakul Preet Singh, Dev Sharma, Nicole Faria and Shreyas Pardiwalla.
summary: Debut director Divya Khosla Kumar has not only helmed but also choreographed five songs in her film "Yaariyan," showcasing her multifaceted talents. The songs, including "Baarish," "Meri Maa," "Love Me Thoda Aur," "Allah Waariyan," and "Zor Lagake Haishaa," play a crucial role in advancing the narrative. Khosla, known for her work in music videos, emphasizes the significance of songs in storytelling, expressing gratitude for the positive reception of her visualizations in tracks like "Baarish" and "Allah Waariyan." Producer Bhushan Kumar lauds Khosla's precision and attention to detail, noting her foray into choreography alongside directing, which has garnered praise. The film, featuring Himansh Kohli, Rakul Preet Singh, Dev Sharma, Nicole Faria, and Shreyas Pardiwalla, promises to evoke a range of emotions, leaving audiences with a feel-good experience.

article:
Creationists apparently have their work cut out in Miss Liberty’s land. A
recent survey by the Pew Research Center’s Religion and Public Life Project
shows that most Americans (60 per cent) accept evolution.
However, when you add atheists and religionists to the discourse, the debate

becomes shriller and things begin to fly!
Pure atheists (untouched by
spirituality) such as Richard Dawkins,
who once called himself Darwin’s
Rottweiler, like to use evolution to
debunk or discredit religion.
Hard-core religionists return the favour
by proclaiming their faith as being
incompatible with any science that rejects or circumvents a literal reading of
the Bible’s Book of Genesis. Notwithstanding such extremes, a significant
portion (24 per cent) of the population looked upon religion and evolution as
compatible entities. Nor were scientists averse to accepting some sort of
higher power or deity (51 per cent).
Dr Francis Collins, the scientist who headed the US government’s first human
genome project, believes, for example, that evolution complemented faith.
Others such as the late paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould looked upon faith
and science as two mutually exclusive or non-overlapping magesteria.
In a postscript to this famous essay, Gould dedicated the piece to the memory
of his late friend, Carl Sagan, who also shared his “personal suspicion” about
the non-existence of souls, adding that he could not think of a better reason
for hoping that they were wrong than the prospect of spending an eternity
roaming the cosmos in friendship and conversation with this wonderful soul!
summary: A Pew Research Center survey reveals that 60% of Americans accept evolution, though debates between atheists and religious individuals intensify the discourse. Richard Dawkins, an atheist, uses evolution to challenge religion, while some religionists reject non-literal biblical interpretations. Nonetheless, 24% see evolution and religion as compatible. Scientists, including Dr. Francis Collins, sometimes integrate faith with science, while others like Stephen Jay Gould maintain they are separate domains.

headline: In the top story for today, a clash broke out between Aam Aadmi Party and BJP councillors, ahead of voting for the Delhi mayor elections over who would take oath first.
article: a clash broke out between Aam Aadmi Party and BJP councillors, ahead of voting for the Delhi mayor elections over who would take oath first, with the AAP blaming the BJP for ensuring a departure from procedural norms. The ruckus started after presiding officer Satya Sharma asked BJP-appointed Alderman Manoj Kumar to take oath first. AAP started protesting and the Leader of the House Mukesh Goel said it was for the first time in the history of 25 years of the Municipal Corporation of Delhi polls that the winning party was being sidelined and the runner-up BJP was being asked to take oath first. As per convention, AAP sources said, the senior-most councillor — in this case, Adarsh Nagar councillor Mukesh Kumar Goel — should have been nominated the presiding officer of the meeting to elect the mayor. However, party sources alleged, Lieutenant Governor Vinai Kumar Saxena decided on BJP’s Gautampuri ward councillor Satya Sharma and sent the file directly to the chief secretary for notification.
summary: A clash erupted between Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) and BJP councillors ahead of Delhi's mayoral elections, as a dispute arose over the order of oath-taking. The uproar ensued when the presiding officer, Satya Sharma, directed BJP's Manoj Kumar to take the oath first. AAP accused BJP of violating procedural norms, asserting it was unprecedented for the winning party to be sidelined, with the runner-up BJP asked to take the oath first. AAP sources claimed the convention of appointing the senior-most councillor as presiding officer was overlooked, alleging interference by Lieutenant Governor Vinai Kumar Saxena in favor of BJP's Satya Sharma.

headline: HERE COMES THE SUN
article:
With Aditya-L1, XPoSAT and Chandrayaan-3, India has hit a celestial hat-trick in its quest to better understand the mysteries of the solar system and the universe.

Viewed as a God by saints and the richest source of energy that sustains life on earth by scientists, the Sun will now be under the close scrutiny of Aditya-L1.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised the country’s scientists. “India creates yet another landmark. India’s first solar observatory Aditya-L1 reaches its destination. It is a testament to the relentless dedication of our scientists in realising among the most complex and intricate space missions. I join the nation in applauding this extraordinary feat. We will continue to pursue new frontiers of science for the benefit of humanity,” he wrote in a post on X.

Aditya L1, India’s first space-based observatory to study the Sun, was placed in a halo-shaped orbit around the Sun-Earth Lagrange Point 1 at the designated time on Saturday.

The point is around 1.5 million km from the Earth, in the direction of the Sun.

Lagrange points, named after French mathematician and astronomer Joseph-Louis Lagrange, are unique locations in space where the gravitational forces of two massive bodies nearly neutralise each other. Though it is tough to park the spacecraft around these points because of the two gravitational forces at play, it requires less fuel to pin it to the place.

Understanding the Sun is not important for India alone. Aditya-L1 is also for the whole of the world – S Somanath, ISRO chairman

Aditya L1 has been placed precisely in the orbit and that the prediction of the velocity requirement was correct, said Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) chairman S Somanath. “Based on our calculations, it is in the right place. We will monitor for a few hours and make corrections, if necessary. We don’t expect that to happen,” he said. “Understanding the Sun is not important for India alone. Adiya-L1 is also for the whole of the world. We look forward to scientific outcomes. At least five years of life is guaranteed with the fuel left in the satellite,” he said.

From its vantage point around L1, Aditya L1 will have a continuous and uninterrupted view of the sun for the next five years. “The insertion of Aditya-L1 into this Halo orbit presents a critical mission phase, which demanded precise navigation and control. A successful insertion further involved constant monitoring along with the adjustment of the spacecraft's speed and position by using onboard thrusters. The success of this insertion not only signifies ISRO's capabilities in such complex orbital manoeuvres, but it gives confidence to handle future interplanetary missions,” ISRO said. Aditya-L1 will keep a close watch on the changing space weather, especially disruptions in the Sun.
summary: India has successfully launched Aditya-L1, its first solar observatory, in a halo-shaped orbit around the Sun-Earth Lagrange Point 1, located 1.5 million km from Earth. The observatory, which is considered a god by saints and the richest source of energy for life on Earth, will closely monitor the Sun for the next five years. Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised the scientists for their dedication to the complex space missions. The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) chairman, S Somanath, said Aditya L1's precise positioning and accurate velocity prediction. The spacecraft will continue to monitor the changing space weather, particularly disruptions in the Sun, and will have a continuous view of the sun for the next five years.

headline: The possibilities of connections are exciting: Singer Vidya Shah
article: Hoping that the post-Pandemic high continues and is not eclipsed by the fear of yet another wave, singer Vidya Shah, who has been performing at multiple venues across the country for several months now, has a consistent rhythm for 2023 set in place. "Besides some upcoming performances, I am working on a couple of projects including continuing on 'Women on Record', a celebration of women in the gramophone era. Besides, my series on the rendition of Begum Akhtar's works will complete 10 years in 2023. I am doing a concert centered around that wherein will be weaved anecdotes of Akhtar's life. It will be about honouring her as an artist, and her life as well," she tells. Though initially trained in Carnatic music, she later received guidance in the North Indian genres of Khayal (from Shubha Mudgal and Mujahid Hussain Khan), Thumri Dadra, and Ghazal (from Shanti Hiranand). Shah has performed at several prestigious national and international forums, including the Tansen Samaroh in Gwalior, The Kennedy Centre in Washington D.C, The Asia Society in New York and the British Museum in London. Also planning to work with historian William Dalrymple on his book 'The Anarchy', she is editing a collection of essays to be published next year centered around journeys of women in studios, the making of entertainment, theatre, gramophones, and talkies. " Plus, I am starting out a short research process; an audio archive on songs and folk narratives related to the freedom movements of 1947 and 1857. Known for bending genres and experimenting consistently, Shah says it is a driving force for her and adds value to her work. "It introduces me to new research and the sheer richness of our culture. Besides, it is in the nature of our arts; especially music -- it is so rooted in anecdotes... there are so many stories, and they are extremely important to me. It brings me closer to the audience." The singer has been actively involved with social issues --in 1991 she was Programme Fellow at, Indo-German Social Service Program (IGSSS) and later was an activist with Khedut Mazdoor Chetna Sanghatan (Rights based Trade Union for Agricultural Laborers) in Madhya Pradesh. Besides being the founder member of Paridhi Research – a rights-based women's organisation working on reproductive and sexual health with a focus on birth control methods, she was the Programme Coordinator with Naz Foundation (India) Trust. "The social journey has been extremely fruitful. Music or any kind of art is so socially embedded even in folk narratives and I cannot see them in isolated silos. My father-in-law, Haku Shah would always say that there is culture in everything. There is art happening everywhere, in each instant. And what excites me about all this are the possibilities of inumerable connections."
summary: Singer Vidya Shah plans a busy 2023 post-pandemic, with performances and projects like "Women on Record" and a concert honoring Begum Akhtar. She blends Carnatic with North Indian music, performing globally and engaging in social activism. Shah's upcoming ventures include collaborating with historian William Dalrymple and curating an audio archive on freedom movements' songs.

headline: PAKYONG DAC FELICITATES TWO EMPLOYEES FOR THEIR SPORTING ACHIEVEMENTS
article:
Pakyong District Collector Tashi Chophel presided over the felicitation ceremony of two remarkable athletes from DAC Pakyong at Rorathang today. The athletes participated in the 10th World Strengthlifting & Incline Bench Press Championships 2023.

The prestigious event, attended by 13 countries at the Lal Bahadur Shastri Stadium in Hyderabad, served as the perfect stage for these extraordinary individuals to showcase their exceptional skills and dedication.

Chewang Bhutia, the Personal Security Officer to the District Collector, secured gold medal in the fiercely competitive 80kg category. 

Another outstanding achiever is Rikila Bhutia, an employee of the District Administrative Office (DAC). She triumphantly obtained a well-deserved bronze medal in the highly competitive 50kg category.

Likewise, the day also marked the warm welcome of the new SDMs while bidding farewell to the former Magistrates.

The DC Pakyong commended the athletes for their unparalleled dedication and hard work, which led to their remarkable achievements on the international stage. He wholeheartedly congratulated them for their outstanding performance and assured them of his unwavering support for their continuous growth and development in their respective sports. 

Furthermore, the DC Pakyong extended his heartfelt gratitude to all the former officers for their unwavering dedication and exceptional performance throughout their respective tenures. He also extends his sincere best wishes for their future endeavors.

The event also had the presence of Laden Lhamu Bhutia, Zilla Adhakshya; Prabha Pradhan, Zilla Upadhakshya; Inchung Bhutia, Advisor Food & Civil Supplies Department, along with Anupa Tamling, ADC Pakyong and officers from various departments and the staff of DAC Pakyong
summary:
Pakyong District Collector Tashi Chophel presided over a felicitation ceremony at Rorathang, honoring two athletes from DAC Pakyong who excelled in the 10th World Strengthlifting & Incline Bench Press Championships 2023. Held at the Lal Bahadur Shastri Stadium in Hyderabad with participation from 13 countries, the event highlighted the athletes' exceptional skills and dedication.

Chewang Bhutia, the District Collector's Personal Security Officer, won a gold medal in the 80kg category. Rikila Bhutia, an employee of the District Administrative Office, earned a bronze medal in the 50kg category.

The ceremony also welcomed new Sub-Divisional Magistrates (SDMs) and bid farewell to the outgoing magistrates. DC Pakyong praised the athletes for their dedication and assured them of his continued support for their growth in sports. He also thanked the former officers for their dedication and performance during their tenures, wishing them success in future endeavors.

The event was attended by Laden Lhamu Bhutia, Zilla Adhakshya; Prabha Pradhan, Zilla Upadhakshya; Inchung Bhutia, Advisor for the Food & Civil Supplies Department; Anupa Tamling, ADC Pakyong; and various departmental officers and DAC Pakyong staff.

headline: State needs juvenile courts
article:
The two-day workshop on Capacity Building Program for Journalists organized by Impulse NGO ended on Saturday. The programme focused on the human trafficking problem in northeast region and ways to report about them in the media.

On the second day, there was extensive discussion about the legal problem faced by the young criminals due to lack of juvenile court in Arunachal Pradesh. Sunil Mow, advocate with Itanagar branch of Guwahati High court dwelled on the urgent need to set up juvenile court in the state. “We have filed a PIL in this regard. There is immediate need to start juvenile justice system in our state as many offenders in the recent days have emerged to be under age children,” told Sunil Mow.

Hasina Kharbhih from Impulse NGO Network discussed about how journalists should approach while writing story on human trafficking. “It is important to make sure that journalists understand the emotion of a victim while conducting their interview. If a victim cries in between the conversation, don’t end the interview. Let that person go through their moment of emotion and then continue the rest of interview,” shared Ms Hasina.

She also highlighted safety concern, which journalists need to keep in mind while reporting on human trafficking issue. “Human trafficking is a dangerous crime and lots of syndicate criminals are involved. Those journalists working undercover or out in open must ensure their own safety,” told Ms Hasina.

The last day of programme saw active participations from the students of mass communication, Rajiv Gandhi University. These young budding journalists asked many questions to the attendees, which included prominent journalists of state and some NGO’s.

The two day workshop was organized by Impulse NGO in association with Arunachal Times (media partner), Athupopu Social Foundation (state partner) and sponsored by UNIFEM (United Nations Development Fund for Women).
summary: The two-day workshop on Capacity Building Program for Journalists, organized by Impulse NGO, concluded with a focus on human trafficking in the northeast region and strategies for effective media reporting. Discussions on the second day centered around the legal challenges faced by young criminals due to the absence of a juvenile court in Arunachal Pradesh. Advocates emphasized the urgent need for a juvenile justice system in the state. Hasina Kharbhih from Impulse NGO Network provided insights on approaching interviews with trafficking victims, emphasizing the importance of understanding their emotions. The workshop aimed to enhance journalists' understanding of human trafficking issues and improve reporting standards.

headline: Jayalalithaa to remain in jail, bail hearing deferred to October 7
article:
Jailed AIADMK supremo Jayalalithaa will have to stay in prison for at least six more days as the Vacation Bench of the Karnataka High Court today posted for October 7 hearing on her pleas for suspension of the sentence and immediate bail in the disproportionate assets case.

As Jayalalithaa sought immediate relief, the court yesterday first posted the hearing for October 6 but hours later listed the matter for today after her counsels pleaded for urgent hearing.

When the matter came up before the Vacation Bench judge Justice Rathnakala, Jayalalithaa's counsel Ram Jethmalani pleaded for suspending the sentence pending appeal under Section 389 of the Criminal Procedure Code and for her release on bail.

Section 389 states that pending any appeal by a convicted person, the Appellate Court may order that the execution of the sentence or order appealed against be suspended. Also, if the person is in confinement, that he or she be released on bail, or on own bond.

During the brief hearing, Special Public Prosecutor Bhavani Singh filed the objections to Jayalalithaa's pleas and also a memo about his appointment as the SPP in the case.

Singh, who was SPP in the Special Court in the disproportionate assets case, had told the court yesterday that he had not yet received any official notification appointing him as the SPP for the criminal appeal filed in the High Court.

As Singh sought more time, the judge had first posted the matter for hearing on October 6, which was later rescheduled for today following pleas by Jayalalithaa's counsels.

Jayalalithaa's aide Sasikala, her relatives V.N. Sudhakaran, disowned son of the former Chief Minister and Ilavarasi will also have to spend at least six more days in jail as their petitions for bail and suspension of the sentence were also adjourned for October 7.

The High Court is on Dasehra holidays from September 29 to October 6. October 7 is also a government holiday on account of Bakrid.

In her petitions seeking immediate bail and challenging her sentence, Jayalalithaa has maintained that the charges of amassing wealth against her were false and that she had acquired property through legal means.

Jayalalitha has also contended that the trial court has overlooked several judgements and has not considered the binding nature of various income tax orders and decisions of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, which had accepted the income and the level of expenditure pleaded by her. — PTI
summary: Jailed AIADMK leader Jayalalithaa's plea for suspension of sentence and immediate bail in the disproportionate assets case has been postponed by the Karnataka High Court's Vacation Bench to October 7. Her counsel, Ram Jethmalani, argued for suspension of sentence and bail under Section 389 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Special Public Prosecutor Bhavani Singh filed objections to Jayalalithaa's pleas, citing his recent appointment as the SPP for the case. Jayalalithaa, along with her aides Sasikala, V.N. Sudhakaran, and Ilavarasi, will remain in jail until the next hearing due to the court's Dasehra holidays. Jayalalithaa maintains her innocence, asserting that the charges against her are false and that she acquired property legally. She argues that the trial court overlooked key evidence supporting her innocence.

headline: Migrant Menace
article:
The recent decision by the government to grant citizenship to many Chakma and Hajong refugees settled in Arunachal Pradesh ruffled many feathers in the state. The decision led to widespread opposition by all indigenous citizens of the state and a state bandh was declared to protest against the decision. Most Arunachali natives are aware and are very wary about the threat posed by refugees like Chakma, Hajong and Tibetans.
However, there is an emerging threat from another direction which does not get adequate attention. There is a clear and present danger posed to indigenous population by migrants from other regions of India. Many areas of north east are subject to this potent but concealed danger. Tripura is a typical example wherein the aboriginal tribal population has been reduced to a minority. The dominance of migrants has been such that the native tribal population are demanding a new state within Tripura.


Another example is Assam. Almost all major businesses of Assam are dominated by migrants. With Guwahati being the main wholesale centre of North East India, the migrant community controls the economy of the entire north east. Important cities like Guwahati, Dibrugarh, Tinsukia, Jorhat, etc are dominated by other non-native communities. Demographically and politically also, the dominance of migrants is such that amongst the 14 Lok Sabha MPs of Assam, only 4 are original Assamese.
As per latest census figures, almost 36 percent population of Arunachal Pradesh is non ST, i.e. migrants. Even in our state most businesses and shops are dominated by migrants. It may not be wrong to state that the economy of our state is also dominated by migrants. Most supplies to govt organisations are dominated by migrant suppliers based in Assam and other states. There is a huge economic outflow of Arunachali money to other states.
A few months back there was a major incident at Silapathar in Assam between natives and migrants. The incident led to violence and massive protests in Assam with allegations and counter allegations from both sides. This incident should be a major lesson for our statesince migrant communities based in border towns like Silapathar, Tinsukia, Dibrugarh, Lakhimpur, Tezpur etc indirectly control the economy of Arunachal Pradesh.
The dominance of migrants in the economy of north east is partly due to the reluctance and incapability of local natives in this field. Normally, natives are more interested in govt jobs and there is a stigma associated with getting into business and industries. Before more damage is done, urgent steps are required to curb this menacing threat of migrants.


Many constituencies of our state are already dominated by migrant voters. The day is not far when there would be an MLA or MP from the migrant population in Arunachal Pradesh. Our political leadership and citizens need to take notice of this clear and present danger.(The writer is a retired Group Captain of the Indian Air Force)
summary: The government's decision to grant citizenship to Chakma and Hajong refugees in Arunachal Pradesh sparked protests, but the focus on indigenous threats overlooks the influx of migrants from other parts of India. Examples from Tripura and Assam highlight the economic and demographic dominance of migrants, with concerns over political representation and economic outflow. Incidents like the one in Silapathar underscore tensions between natives and migrants. Urgent measures are needed to address the growing influence of migrants in Arunachal Pradesh before it impacts political and economic dynamics further.

headline: Advani hints at 'daughter' Uma's return
article:
RANCHI: Hinting at the possibility of suspended leader Uma Bharti''s return to the party-fold, BJP president L K
Advani on Friday said she had expressed "desire" to have discussions with him which will take place when she
returns from "leave".
"Uma is currently on leave. When she returns, there will definitely be talks (with her)," Advani told reporters at the
conclusion of the party''s three-day National Executive meeting in Ranchi.
Bharti had "written letters to me which I have read. Her letters indicate her desire to discuss matters with me. She
also met me before leaving (for Himalayas on ''leave'')," he said.
