headline: CRPF 158 Battalion holds Civic Action Programme
article:
Giving a new dimension to the cordial relations between the armed forces and the public, CRPF 158 Battalion in the highly Naxal affected areas of Lohardaga district, Pesharar and Chainpur, is implementing the Civic Action Program Year 2023 as per the instructions of the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India and the Directorate General of CRPF and Jharkhand Sector, CRPF. 24 were organized. On this occasion, Rakesh Kumar Mishra, Second Commanding Officer, Roshan Kumar, Assistant Commandant and Ashiq Ali, Assistant Commandant, 158 Battalion, CRPF provided free fertilizer, tin sheet, solar lantern, mosquito net, blanket, plastic container to the villagers as per their need. school bags and sports equipment were distributed. 

Apart from this, a medical camp was also organized by Dr. Ranjit Kumar, Chief Medical Officer, in which he distributed free medicines and also checked the health of the villagers. Due to which all the villagers present there appreciated this program. -He greatly appreciated and requested to organize such a program in future also. This program was conducted under the leadership and direction of CRPA 158 Battalion Commandant Rahul Kumar. 


During this, eminent citizens of Peshawar and Chainpur, local police and civil administration officials, villagers and people from the electronic and print media world were present. On the occasion, CRPF 158 Battalion Commandant Rahul Kumar said that through the Civic Action Programme, we not only provide basic necessities to the needy villagers, but by screening short films on inspirational topics, we also educate the people of the area, especially the youth and students. They also inspire patriotism. Civic Action Program is a good medium to establish mutual trust between the people of the area and the security forces, to awaken the feeling of security in the minds of the villagers by making them aware of the role of the security forces.
summary: The CRPF 158 Battalion is strengthening ties with villagers in the Naxal-affected areas of Lohardaga district through its Civic Action Program 2023. Following Ministry of Home Affairs directives, they organized 24 events, distributing essentials like fertilizer, tin sheets, solar lanterns, and school supplies. A free medical camp led by Dr. Ranjit Kumar was also held. Commandant Rahul Kumar emphasized that such initiatives build trust, instill patriotism, and raise awareness about the role of security forces. Local residents, officials, and media praised the efforts and requested more such programs in the future.

headline: Martyrs Day observed at SAIL, RSP
article:
SAIL, Rourkela Steel Plant joined the rest of the nation in observing Martyrs Day on 30th January 2024.  Atanu Bhowmick, Director In-Charge, RSP with Additional Charge of Bokaro Steel Plant led the solemn observance at DIC Secretariat at 11.00 AM on the blowing of the plant siren.

 

Silence was observed at the same time in the offices of ED (Works), ED (Projects), ED (MM), ED (M&HS), ED (P&A), ED (Mines) and ED (F&A). S.R. Suryawanshi, ED (Works), P K Sahoo, ED (Projects),  Somnath Tripathy, ED (MM), Dr. B K Hota, ED (M&HS),  Alok Verma, ED (Mines) and A K Behuria, ED (F&A) led the memorial observance at their respective offices. Similar programmes were organised in various offices across the plant.
summary: SAIL, Rourkela Steel Plant observed Martyrs Day on 30th January 2024, joining the nation in paying tribute to the martyrs. Atanu Bhowmick, Director In-Charge, RSP and Bokaro Steel Plant, led the solemn observance at the DIC Secretariat at 11:00 AM marked by the blowing of the plant siren. Silence was observed simultaneously in the offices of various Executive Directors, including ED (Works), ED (Projects), ED (MM), ED (M\&HS), ED (P\&A), ED (Mines) and ED (F\&A). Senior officials led the homage at their respective offices. Similar observances were held across the plant premises.

headline: 362 Games Village flats given for officials' accommodation
article:
NEW DELHI: To make adequate accommodation facility for senior officials, the Urban Development Ministry has enhanced its housing pool in higher categories in Delhi by adding 362 flats in the categories of Type V(B) and above.

The Delhi Development Authority (DDA) has recently handed over a total of 362 flats at the Commonwealth Games Village complex to the Directorate of Estates, said a senior ministry official. Earlier, DDA had handed over 16 such flats in 2013.

Urban Development Minister M Venkaiah Naidu has approved earmarking 100 of these flats for allocation to chairpersons and members of various tribunals and quasi-judicial bodies. Another 178 have been added to the General Pool Residential Accommodation, and 50 each to Tenure Officers Pool and Tenure Pool.
The latest acquisition by the Directorate of Estates comprises 248 Type-V(B) three-bedroom flats, 82 Type-VI(B) four-bedroom flats and 32 Type-VII five-bedroom flats.

DDA had handed over nine four-bedroom and seven five-bedroom flats in 2013.

According to the official, DDA handed over these 378 flats towards the cost of land provided by the ministry for the CWG Village.

There is a total of 61,523 houses in various categories ranging from Type I to Type VIII, and double- and single-suit hostel accommodation available in the national capital.
summary: The Urban Development Ministry has augmented its housing pool in higher categories in Delhi by adding 362 flats, ranging from Type V(B) and above. These flats, located in the Commonwealth Games Village complex, were handed over by the Delhi Development Authority (DDA) to the Directorate of Estates. Urban Development Minister M Venkaiah Naidu has allocated 100 flats to chairpersons and members of tribunals, while others have been distributed among different pools for government officials. This move aims to provide adequate accommodation for senior officials in the national capital.

headline: Exciting little discovery
article:
It has become rather fashionable to blame former Finance Minister P Chidambaram for a lot of things. But one thing that those of us who write about cars can rightly accuse Chidambaram of is having inadvertently given birth to the Compact Sedan segment. By keeping cars below four metres in length in a lower excise category in a budget about a decade ago, Chidambaram thought he was promoting small hatchbacks. But Tata Motors developed the Indigo CS, a sedan with a boot that came in at under 4,000 millimetres in length, enough to get some excise benefits. This spurred several manufacturers to come up with something similar. Maruti Suzuki first made a sedan out of the Swift, the Dzire, and in the second-generation of the Dzire, it created what is by far one of the most successful cars ever made in India. The second-generation Dzire became the small taxi of choice across the length and breadth of the country. And other manufacturers cottoned onto this as well, which gave us the Hyundai Xcent, Honda Amaze and Ford Aspire.

But let me be honest, early design attempts at Compact Sedans were, well, pretty terrible. Designers stuck inside a tightly confined box, which just took a meat cleaver to the back-end of the car. Either that or they just added a little ‘third box’ to the hatchbacks, making you scratch your head when looking at the cars. To call them aesthetically pleasing would mean that one’s sense of aesthetics have gone awry. However, as they got more used to the restrictions and managed to work around the entire vehicle, they became better. The third-generation Dzire and second-generation Amaze along with the Tata Tiago and Ford Aspire are smart-looking cars. Yes, there is that sense that they’re trying to fit into a shirt, one size too small, but compared to previous iterations, they are clearly way better.

Then there is Hyundai and the new Aura. While I was never a fan of the original Santro’s look, and Hyundai has had some strange cars after that, I am looking at Eon as contemporary Hyundai cars are  extremely attractive. From the Venue to the Verna, the forthcoming Tucson and the third-generation i20, which will be showcased at the Auto Expo 2020, Hyundai’s design language has evolved to a nice place. My long-term car right now is the refreshed Hyundai Elantra as it stands out with its very sharp looks. But this is about the Aura, and I am afraid to say that the rear-end of the car is well, strange! I don’t understand the need for the blacked-out C-pillar and the reflector strip through the boot. While I would not be so extreme as to call this an aesthetic assault, let us just leave this here by saying that I am not a fan. Which is a pity because I really do like the i10 Nios hatchback that the Aura is based on.

But when you drive the Aura, specifically the one with 1.0 litre Turbo, you forget the way the car looks because it suddenly proves that Compact Sedans can move. Sure, there have been 100 horsepower compact sedans before but those have been diesel. And while I do not want to get into a debate on the merits of diesel and petrol right now, it suffices to say that petrol engines are more responsive that diesel ones. I have driven the Venue with the same turbo engine and just like in the Aura, Hyundai’s powertrain engineers have managed to work out the kinks leaving almost no perceptible turbo-lag.

This is a properly nice engine and when it is coupled to a car with great ride and superb handling, you forget about the rear-end. On the roads that lead to the Jam Gate outside Mhow, which is the entrance through the pass onto the fertile plains of Malwa, you begin to have some fun. And this was with three people and a lot of equipment in the car, which cannot be called a light load. It took all the corners with aplomb and while you do need to mash the gears in the lower end of the powerband, once you hit the sweet spot, it is a very rewarding powerband. Despite the ‘fun’, non-economical, I had driven the Aura, which still delivered a quite surprising 13 kilometres to the litre. The lightweight and good road handling qualities helped in delivering a decent fuel economy even when you want to have some fun.

Compact Sedans were born out of a lacunae in the rules. They have become a practical solution for those who wanted the convenience of a boot and there is a reason the taxi segment adopted it en masse. But Compact Sedans were never ‘fun’ and I never thought that I would see the day when I could describe one of them as fun. But the Aura Turbo is actually a fun car that is not just nice to drive but practical as well. And there are variants with a 1.2 BS6 diesel and a 1.2 BS6 petrol, which, though not as peppy as the turbo, share the great ride and handling characteristics. Having said that, the managing director of Hyundai India, SS Kim told me that almost a third of Venue sales have been of the car equipped with the same Turbo engine. We also know that Hyundai is fitting the same engine in the Nios and that the i20 could come up with an even more powerful power unit. And to deliver power and fun at a decent ex-showroom price — Rs 8.54 lakh — the Aura Turbo could be a game changer. Personally, I’d stick to a hatchback and can’t wait for the Turbo Nios.
summary: The text discusses the origin and evolution of the Compact Sedan segment in the Indian automotive market. It credits former Finance Minister P Chidambaram for inadvertently creating this segment by implementing excise benefits for cars under four meters in length. The text highlights the initial design challenges faced by manufacturers but acknowledges the improvement in aesthetics over time. It critiques the design of the Hyundai Aura but praises its performance, especially the 1.0 litre Turbo engine variant. Despite initial reservations about Compact Sedans being "fun" to drive, the author finds the Aura Turbo enjoyable and practical. The text concludes by discussing the potential impact of the Aura Turbo on the market and hints at future developments in the segment.

headline: Masks probably may never even go, says ICMR chief Balram Bhargava
article:
New Delhi: Hours after two vaccines were approved under restricted use and emergency use authorisation by Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA), Dr Balram Bhargava, Director General of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), on Sunday said masks may never go out of regular usage.

"I think it's a great day for India, it's a great day for humanity at large. Two vaccines have been approved under restricted use and emergency use authorisation and it has been done following discussions by SEC. This is wonderful news for India and all of us," Bhargava told ANI.

However, he said that it is unknown how long vaccine is going to be effective. "We don't know how much of the population we'll have to vaccinate to break the virus transmission. What we know is that we've been able to control the pandemic in the country by following COVID-19 appropriate behaviour... I am of the opinion that masks will probably be the last to go and probably may never even go."

Talking about the new variant of Crornavirus creating 'havoc' in the UK, the ICMR chief informed that scientists of the National Institute of Virology (NIV) have successfully isolated the new virus strain and it will be tested against different vaccines soon.

"New virus variant which is now more than 60 per cent infective and creating havoc in the UK, is worrisome. There are 29 patients in India with the same variant for which we should be cautious. We were able to isolate the new virus very early," he stated.

"NIV scientists have successfully isolated the new virus strain and this will be tested against different vaccines," he said and added that he hopes "potentially Bharat Biotech vaccine will have some advantages over other vaccines on this new strain because it is a whole virus."

ICMR on Saturday said India has successfully isolated and cultured the UK-variant of Sars-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19 disease. It is to mention that no other country has yet reported successful isolation and culture of the UK-variant of SARS-CoV-2 and added that vero cell lines of the virus were used by the scientists of ICMR-NIV to culture the UK-variant of the virus.

COVID-19 vaccines of Serum Institute of India and Bharat Biotech have been granted permission for restricted use in an emergency situation, said Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) on Sunday.

Notably, COVAXIN is an indigenously developed coronavirus vaccine manufactured by Bharat Biotech in collaboration with the ICMR.
summary:
Dr. Balram Bhargava, Director General of the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), stated that masks may continue to be a regular part of life even after the COVID-19 vaccination drive. While expressing optimism about the approval of two vaccines in India, Bhargava highlighted the uncertainty regarding the duration of vaccine effectiveness and the need to vaccinate a significant portion of the population to break virus transmission. He suggested that masks might be the last COVID-19 precautionary measure to be discontinued and may even continue indefinitely.

Regarding the new variant of the virus causing concern in the UK, Bhargava mentioned that scientists at the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in India have successfully isolated the new strain. The isolated virus will be tested against different vaccines to assess their effectiveness. Bhargava expressed hope that Bharat Biotech's COVAXIN might have advantages against the new strain as it is a whole-virus vaccine. India has reported 29 cases with the new variant, and precautions are being taken to monitor its spread.

headline: One dies in fire accident in Koloriang
article:
KOLORIANG, 3 Jan: One person was charred to death in a fire mishap that occurred here in Kurung Kumey district in the intervening night of 2 and 3 January.

Koloriang Police Station OC Inspector Gejum Basar informed that the fire was so devastating that it burnt down the house and all personal belongings of the family.

The deceased has been identified as 48-year-old Nangram Tache, who was a staffer of the PHED.

After registering a case of unnatural death (No 01/2022 u/s 174 CrPC) at the Koloriang police station and completing all legal formalities, including postmortem, the body was handed over to the family members for the last rites, the OC said.


“Since the matter is under investigation, as of now nothing can be said about the cause of the fire accident,” the OC added.

The DC, the SP and other officers visited the spot and consoled the bereaved family members.
summary: A tragic fire incident in Koloriang, Kurung Kumey district, claimed the life of 48-year-old Nangram Tache, a PHED staffer. The fire, which occurred overnight on January 2-3, engulfed their house and all belongings. Koloriang Police Station OC Inspector Gejum Basar confirmed the fatality and stated that investigations are ongoing to determine the cause. The district administration, including the DC and SP, visited the site to offer condolences and support to the grieving family. Legal procedures, including postmortem, were completed, and the body was handed over to the family for final rites.

headline: Rain, cyclone drag down day temp 9 degrees below normal
article:
Cyclone Michaung fourth December cyclone to hit Andhra Pradesh Cost. 

Nearly 60 cyclones have hit Andhra Pradesh in the last five decades, with about 40 forming in October and November. Severe cyclonic storm Michaung is expected to make landfall in the Machilipatnam area. The Bay of Bengal is known as a cyclone hotbed, with most cyclones occurring in October and November. However, experts suggest that more weather systems are brewing in December due to rising temperatures or climate change. Andhra Pradesh, vulnerable to cyclones, has about 3.3 million people residing within 5 km of the coastline.

Cyclone Michaung-affected trains to resume normal schedule

Indian Railways resumes train services after Cyclone Michaung. Train No. 12615: Dr MGR Chennai Central New Delhi Grand Trunk Express departs from MGR Chennai Central at 6.40pm on December 5. Train No. 12616: New Delhi MGR Chennai Central Grand Trunk Express departs from New Delhi at 4.10pm on December 7. Railway services return to normalcy post cyclone impact.

Michaung dumped more rain than 2015 cyclone

The impact of Monday's cyclone in Chennai brought back memories of the December 2015 floods. The cyclone Michaung dumped more rain than the floods in 2015, with Nungambakkam and Meenambakkam observatories recording 53cm and 52cm of rain respectively. The highest rainfall was recorded in areas on the western and northern fringes of the city, such as Poonamallee, Avadi, and Kattupakkam. The storm remained stationary near Chennai for over eight hours, intensifying intensifying into a severe cyclonic storm and bringing heavy downpour. Eventually, the cyclone made landfall near Bapatla around 375km from Chennai, on Tuesday afternoon.
summary: The recent rain and cyclone activity have caused a significant drop in daytime temperatures, with levels plummeting 9 degrees below the normal average. This weather phenomenon has led to a sudden and noticeable decrease in temperature across the affected regions. The combination of rain and cyclone has disrupted the usual weather patterns, resulting in cooler conditions. The deviation from the normal average temperature is significant and has likely impacted daily life and activities in the affected areas. It is important for residents to be aware of these changes and take necessary precautions to adapt to the cooler temperatures until the weather stabilizes.

headline: Meet Vaibhav Suryavanshi: The 12-Year-Old Who Made His First Class Debut For Bihar vs Mumbai In Ranji Trophy
article:
Vaibhav became the most talked player at the moment in Indian cricket after creating history at 12 years of age.
The young prodigy from Bihar grabbed the headlines during the ongoing Ranji Trophy 2023-24 match between the hosts and Mumbai at Moin-ul-Haq Stadium in Patna.

The teenager Vaibhav Suryavanshi marked his senior debut for Bihar in the Ranji Trophy match against Mumbai. The 12-year-old made it to history book of records as among the youngest Indian debutants in first-class cricket, breaking early milestones set by Indian cricket legends Sachin Tendulkar and Yuvraj Singh.


Vaibhav became the most talked player at the moment in Indian crick
creating history at 12 years of age. At the age of 12, most of the budding cricketers play in U-16 and U-19 tournaments. However, Bihar's young prodigy went one step ahead and represented his state team in Ranji Trophy, which is the most prestigious tournament in Indian domestic cricket.

Vaibhav Suryavanshi had a decent start to his Ranji Trophy debut as he scored 19 off 28 balls at a strike rate of 67.86. He hit 4 fours and faced the likes of Mohit Avasathi, Shivam Dube and Shams Mulani of Mumbai's bowling attack.


Vaibhav shot to fame in Vinoo Mankad Trophy

Vaibhav Suryavanshi's talent was display during the last season of Vinoo Mankad trophy. The left-hand batter amassed 393 runs, including 78.60 and strike rate of 106.16 in five innings.

The 12-year-old was in the run for India U-19 World Cup following his impressive performances in the Vinoo Mankad Trophy. Unfortunately, Vaibhav was not picked in India squad for the U-19 World Cup, slated to take place in South Africa later this month.

Vaibhav Suryavanshi received his maiden U-19 national call-up for Challenger Trophy and Quadrangular, involving England and Bangladesh. In the Quadrangular U-19, Bihar batter impressed with his talent, scoring 177 runs, including two half-centuries, in six innings.

In an interview with Times of India, Vaibhav received early cricket guidance from his father, Sanjeev, and started playing the sport at the age of 9. He is known for playing pull shot, the famous trademark shot by Rohit Sharma and Ricky Ponting. The young cricketer has already making waves in Indian cricket.
summary:
Vaibhav Suryavanshi, a 12-year-old cricket prodigy from Bihar, has made history by becoming one of the youngest players ever to debut in first-class cricket during a Ranji Trophy 2023–24 match against Mumbai at Patna's Moin-ul-Haq Stadium. In doing so, he surpassed early milestones set by Indian legends like Sachin Tendulkar and Yuvraj Singh.

Vaibhav scored 19 runs off 28 balls, hitting four boundaries against Mumbai’s strong bowling lineup. Unlike most cricketers his age who play in U-16 or U-19 formats, Vaibhav has leapfrogged into senior domestic cricket, making him a viral sensation in Indian sports circles.

He first rose to prominence in the Vinoo Mankad Trophy, scoring 393 runs in five innings at an average of 78.60. Though not picked for the U-19 World Cup, he was selected for the Challenger Trophy and Quadrangular U-19 series, where he scored 177 runs, including two fifties, further showcasing his immense potential.

headline: Kangana Ranaut commences filming for ‘Chandramukhi 2'
article:
Actor Kangana Ranaut has started shooting for “Chandramukhi 2”, the sequel to superstar Rajinikanth's 2005 Tamil movie.

The actor took to her Instagram story on Tuesday evening and posted a picture of clapboard from the movie's sets.

"Started filming for Chandramukhi 2 today,” Ranaut said in the post.

The upcoming movie is a follow-up to Rajinikanth and Jyothika's smash hit comedy horror “Chandramukhi” from director P Vasu. The filmmaker is also helming the new movie.

In the second part, Ranaut will essay the role of a dancer in the king's court, who was known for her beauty and dance skills.

Tamil actor-director Raghava Lawrence will play male lead opposite Ranaut.

The actor will be next seen in “Tejas”, in which she plays the role of an Air Force Pilot, a political drama “Emergency” and biopic on Bengali theatre legend Binodini Dasi.
summary: Actor Kangana Ranaut has begun shooting for *Chandramukhi 2*, the sequel to Rajinikanth's 2005 Tamil hit *Chandramukhi*. She shared the update via an Instagram story featuring a clapboard from the set, announcing the start of filming. Directed by P. Vasu, who also helmed the original, the film will see Ranaut portray a royal court dancer famed for her beauty and dance. Tamil actor-director Raghava Lawrence will star opposite her. Apart from this project, Ranaut will also appear in *Tejas* as an Air Force pilot, the political drama *Emergency*, and a biopic on Bengali theatre legend Binodini Dasi.

headline: For all the fans of arcade-style gaming, Ball Shot is the only game you need
article:
Ball Shot
Game for iOS & Android;
Get It For: Free

Ball shot is an arcade-style endless game where you have to fling a basketball from one basket to the next.

Simply swipe to select the direction, angle, and force of the fling — depending on where the next basket is.

You can bounce off the walls if required. Since you have to fling the ball upwards to the next basket, you need to be precise with calculating the angle and force.

One mistake and the ball falls to an electrified barrier which results in a game over.

As you play through the game, you collect diamonds — these can be used to unlock additional ball characters.

You can also unlock all characters via an in-game purchase of `160. While the game is entertaining, it is riddled with ads.

There is a constant banner ad at the bottom and full-screen ads pop-up every now and then.

These ads can be removed with an in-app payment of Rs 80.
summary: "Ball Shot" is an arcade-style endless game available for iOS and Android. In this game, players fling a basketball from one basket to the next by swiping to select the direction, angle, and force of the fling. Precise calculations are crucial to avoid the electrified barrier that leads to a game over. The objective is to collect diamonds during gameplay, which can be used to unlock additional ball characters. While the game is free, it contains banner ads at the bottom and occasional full-screen ads. Players have the option to remove ads through an in-app payment of Rs 80. Additionally, there is an option to unlock all characters for Rs 160 through an in-game purchase.

headline: Dr Batra was conferred the ‘Global Indian of the Year 2013’ Award at the 4th Annual India Leadership Conclave & Indian Affairs Business Leadership Awards 2013 in Mumbai
article:
Homeopath Dr Mukesh Batra, Founder-Chairman, Dr Batra’s, was conferred the ‘Global Indian of the Year 2013’ Award at the 4th Annual India Leadership Conclave & Indian Affairs Business Leadership Awards 2013 held in Mumbai recently.

A jury comprising eminent personalities declared Dr Batra the winner in the Global Indian of the Year 2013 category for his contribution in the Healthcare space through homeopathy. Ratan Tata, Mukesh Ambani and Priyanka Chopra were some of the other eminent personalities who were the recipients of the prestigious titles at the conclave.

Receiving his award, Dr Batra said, “I thank the organisers for an award that accords due recognition to homeopathy. In the past decade, homeopathy has been growing from strength to strength across the world. It is fast becoming the first choice of treatment for an increasing number of people in India.”
summary: Dr. Mukesh Batra, Founder-Chairman of Dr. Batra’s, received the 'Global Indian of the Year 2013' Award at the India Leadership Conclave for his contribution to healthcare through homeopathy. The jury recognized his impact in the field, alongside other notable recipients like Ratan Tata and Mukesh Ambani. Dr. Batra expressed gratitude for the acknowledgment, highlighting the growing popularity of homeopathy globally and its increasing acceptance in India.

headline: Over 2.43 lakh POCSO cases pending in fast-track courts till Jan 2023; 3% conviction rate in 2022: Report
article: More than 2.43 lakh cases under the POCSO Act were pending in fast-track special courts (FTSCs) as of January 31 this year despite the central government’s robust policy and financial commitment, according to a research paper published by an NGO. In 2022, the number of such cases that resulted in conviction remained a mere three per cent nationally, it said. The research paper — ‘Justice Awaits: An Analysis of the Efficacy of Justice Delivery Mechanisms in Cases of Child Sexual Abuse in India’ – released by India Child Protection Fund (ICPF) said that even if no new cases are added to the list, the country will need at least nine years to clear this backlog. In some states such as Arunachal Pradesh and Bihar, it could take more than 25 years to bring the pending cases to closure. The findings of the paper cast a huge question mark on the efficacy of the country’s judicial system, despite the central government’s 2019 landmark decision to set up fast-track special courts to provide justice to child sexual abuse victims and despite the government pumping in crores of rupees every year to ensure justice for every child. The paper further states that given the present scenario, while Arunachal Pradesh would take 30 years to complete the trials of cases pending under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act as of January 2023, Delhi will take 27 years, West Bengal 25, Meghalaya 21, Bihar 26, and Uttar Pradesh 22 years to clear the backlog. The fast-track courts, set up in 2019, were supposed to deliver the legal mandate for the completion of trial of such cases within one year and yet out of the total 2,68,038 cases that were under trial, only 8,909 cases resulted in conviction. The central government recently approved the continuation of FTSCs as a centrally sponsored scheme till 2026 with a budgetary allocation of more than Rs1,900 crore. The study highlights that each FTSC in the country on average disposes just 28 cases per year, which means the expenditure in one conviction is around Rs9 lakh. The report is based on data from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Ministry of Women and Child Development and the National Crime Records Bureau. “Each FTSC was expected to dispose of 41-42 cases in a quarter and at least 165 in a year. The data suggests that FTSCs are unable to achieve the set targets even after three years of the launch of the scheme,” the paper stated. Citing the Supreme Court’s judgement, the report further said that child marriage is child rape and as per the Census of 2011, a staggering 4,442 minor girls were married every day, which means every minute, three children were pushed into child marriage. However, only three child marriages are reported every day, as per the latest National Crime Records Bureau data. Emphasizing that despite having a robust policy, strict laws and ample financial commitment, the minuscule rate of conviction is a matter of grave concern, ICPF founder Bhuwan Ribhu said, “The spirit of law needs to be translated into justice for every child There can be no legal deterrence when mere three per cent of the people accused of sexual offences against children are convicted.”
summary: A research paper by India Child Protection Fund reveals over 2.43 lakh pending POCSO Act cases in fast-track courts as of January 2023, with only 3% resulting in convictions in 2022. Despite government efforts and funding, the backlog casts doubt on judicial efficacy, with some states facing over 25-year delays.

headline: Koffee With Karan 8: Janhvi Kapoor recalls Khushi comforting her after Sridevi's death, says, 'I have never seen her...'
article:
The Kapoor sisters graced the latest Koffee With Karan season 8 episode – Janhvi Kapoor and Khushi Kapoor. While the episode was filled with several lighthearted moments, the siblings also opened up on the impact of losing their mother Sridevi on them.

During the conversation, Janhvi shared that despite Khushi being the younger sibling, she was the person, who consoled her.

Recalling the moment, the Dhadak actress said, “The thing that I remember is that when I got the call, I was in my room. I could hear wailing from Khushi’s room. I think I barged into her room howling and crying. But what I do remember, Karan, is that the minute she looked at me, she just stopped crying. She just sat next to me and started comforting me. I have never seen her cry about it since.”

headline: Soon, Naga heritages to be lost forever
article:
The open site of the Bada Akhada Mutt is a welcome sight for the  sore eyes of those who support the mutt demolishing being done in Puri.  As promised, the small temple, the Gadi of the Mahant, and the kitchen inside the mutt were left intact.

Mahant Harinarayan Das has been incommunicado since the demolition, a few of the initiates and disciples were wandering around with lost expressions.

I met Atmatatvananda, who told me that they had no option other than surrendering. The mutt will be allocated land elsewhere, he said, but the historic values, the chaitanya and the heritage is lost forever.

The Langali Mutt at Cuttack was one such place for the Naga Sadhus. It was built sometime in the 1870’s, on the embankment of the Kathjori, just off the Puri Ghat. Today, the only visible sign of the old mutt is a small arched entrance about 100 metres away from the Puri Ghat Police Station. 

The Nagas looked fierce and formidable with their ash-smeared body, long matted hair and intense eyes. The locals used to keep a safe distance, the Nagas had quick tempers and there were many cases of skirmishes. Their nudity, chillums and aggressive behaviour instilled fear and bewilderment among the people.

Another Naga mutt on the Old Jagannath Sadak was the Lacchman Mutt in Balakati on the banks of the Daya river, the remains of which can still be seen.

The Nagas were unwelcome in the mutts of Puri, so they left for the Rath Yatra just a couple of days earlier, to reach just in time.

The Nabakalebar of 1950 witnessed violent clashes between the Naga Sadhus and the police. In the struggle, 200 Sadhus and 14 policemen were injured. It is also believed that a dozen Nagas were killed; the bodies were removed and buried. In 1954, during the Rath Yatra, a wheel of Lord Jagannath’s chariot gave way, and the chariots were stranded midway.

The next day, a group of armed Nagas forcefully climbed the Chariot of Lord Balabhadra and attacked the policemen of duty.  In the clash, 190 Nagas were injured and hospitalised and many priests and policemen too were injured.

Since then, the entry of the Nagas has been banned in Puri.

The Langali mutt at Katak  is under disputed ownership. The section which has the two temples is in a very bad condition. The entire complex is on the verge of collapse. The Lacchman Mutt at Balkati is an abandoned structure near the bank of the river. 

It is used to store cow-dung patties by the nearby locals. These important vestiges of the Old Jagannath Sadak should be properly restored.
summary: The article discusses the demolition of the Bada Akhada Mutt in Puri and the impact on the Naga Sadhus who resided there. The mutt's open site remains, and while a small temple, the Gadi of the Mahant, and the kitchen were spared, the heritage and historic values are perceived as lost forever. The piece also recounts the history of Naga Sadhus in Puri, mentioning other mutts like the Langali Mutt in Cuttack and the Lacchman Mutt in Balakati on the banks of the Daya river. The ban on Nagas' entry into Puri is highlighted, along with past clashes and violence during events like the Nabakalebar of 1950. The author advocates for the proper restoration of the remaining structures for their historical significance.

headline: ISRO achieves milestone with successful space docking experiment launch
article:
"So, as far as we are concerned, the rocket has placed the spacecraft in the right orbit and the SpaDeX satellites have moved one behind the other, and over the period of time, it will pick up further distance, travel about 20 km away and then the rendezvous and docking process will start.
"And we hope that the docking process can happen in another week and the nominal time is going to be approximately January 7," he said in his address from the Mission Control Centre. In this mission, the very important part is the POEM-4 with 24 payloads from startups, industries, academia and also from ISRO centres, he said. These are scheduled to be fired on Tuesday morning. Scientists would work through the night to ensure that the POEM-4 reaches the desired orbit level to perform the operation, Somanath said.
Later, talking to reporters at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre, Somanath said the PSLV-C60 mission placed the two SpaDeX satellites weighing 220kg in a circular orbit and 475 km as against the projected 470 km and this mission also has the POEM-4 which has 24 payloads to perform research and development. "They are payloads and are not satellites. They are going to be attached to the fourth stage (of the PSLV rocket) for conducting experiments over the next two months. The upper stage of the PSLV rocket will be brought down to a lowered orbit to 350 km and that process is currently going on. After that, we will have many activities to continue," Somanath, also the Secretary, Department of Space, said
On the Space Docking Experiment, he said the scientists would have many operations from December 31 at the ISTRAC Bengaluru and he expected that the docking condition 'possibly on January 7'. "So, we will be able to see that from the Control Centre, ISTRAC, Bengaluru. All those activities of docking, including telecasting of the onboard images from the camera of the docking processes," he said. Somanath, flanked by SpaDeX Project Director N Surendran, Mission Director M Jayakumar and Directors of the various Centre said ISRO was 'very proud' of this accomplishment and expressed hope that the SpaDeX mission's objective can be achieved in the coming days. "Really important mission for us, this you know, with the space sector reforms, and expansion of space activities. Then we have human space flight programmes, building space stations etc. This (Monday's) mission is so critical for us to work on future missions like the Chandrayaan-4, missions to the Moon as well," he said. "I believe this is not the first SpaDeX and there will be many more SpaDeX varieties including complex versions of docking systems in the coming days," he said. Mission Director M Jayakumar said, "Hearty congratulations to the team ISRO for venturing into the exciting domain of Space Docking and this Mission once again has POEM-4. We have 24 payloads, and some interesting experiments in POEM-4 like debris capture, and biological experiments are there." "We had two launches of the PSLV from the same launch pad that is the first launch pad in December. So, after the first launch (on December 5 for PSLV-C59/Proba-3 mission), the Satish Dhawan Space Centre team was quick in raising to the occasion (for Monday's mission)," he said. Surendran said, "I would like to congratulate the PSLV team for the successive successful launch of PSLV in a month, it is a record, we have also placed our twin babies in a perfectly circular orbit, as per our requirement. "I am happy to say that our solar panels are successfully deployed and the spacecraft are on their journey and holding their wings towards the docking and it is expected to happen around January first week," he said. As you are aware the space sector is going through a phase to enable private players to meet the growing demands, as per the policy guidelines, SpaDeX was assembled and integrated here for the first time, he said. Dubbed as a prelude to the ISRO setting up its own Space Station by 2035, the PSLV-C60 mission would also make India join an elite club in achieving this feat which is expected to take place in the coming days. The 44.5-metre-tall rocket carried two spacecraft -- Spacecraft A and B, each weighing 220 kg which would help in space docking, satellite servicing and interplanetary missions. After the culmination of the 25-hour countdown which commenced on Sunday, the rocket lifted off at 10 pm from the First Launch Pad at this spaceport, emanating thick orange-coloured fumes and thunderous sound in the island, located about 135 km east of Chennai. According to ISRO scientists, the two spacecraft-Spacecraft A (SDX01) or the 'Chaser' and Spacecraft B (SDX02) or the 'Target' would be merged together later at an altitude of about 470 km after travelling at the same speed and distance. By mastering the docking technologies, ISRO is set to enhance its operational flexibility and also expand its mission horizons. This technology is essential for some of India's space ambitions like Indian on the Moon, getting samples from the Moon (Chandrayaan-4 mission), and building and operating the Bharatiya Antariksh Station. "In-space docking technology is essential when multiple rocket launches are required to achieve common mission objectives. Through this mission, India is marching towards becoming the fourth country in the world to have space docking technology," ISRO said. The others to achieve this technological feat are China, Russia and the US
summary:
ISRO's PSLV-C60 mission successfully placed two SpaDeX satellites, Spacecraft A and B, into a precise circular orbit of 475 km, exceeding expectations. These satellites aim to demonstrate space docking technology, crucial for satellite servicing, interplanetary missions, and India's ambitious space projects like Chandrayaan-4 and Bharatiya Antariksh Station. Docking operations are expected by January 7, 2024, monitored from ISTRAC, Bengaluru.  

The mission also carried POEM-4 with 24 payloads for experiments in debris capture, biological studies, and more. SpaDeX marks India's step toward becoming the fourth country to achieve in-space docking, essential for future missions requiring multi-launch operations and private-sector involvement.

headline: "Atomic Bomb Dropped on Hiroshima; Great Damage Done; Casualties Heavy."
article:
The Hindustan Times reported on the atomic bomb assault against Japan on August 6, 1945, under the headline "Atomic Bomb Dropped on Hiroshima; Great Damage Done; Casualties Heavy." The article described the bombing as "a new and terrible weapon of war" and said that "the damage is so great that it is difficult to estimate." The article also quoted eyewitness accounts of the bombing, which described "a blinding flash of light followed by a deafening roar" and "a huge mushroom cloud rising into the sky."

The Hindustan Times' coverage of the atomic bomb attack was largely sympathetic to Japan. The article described the bombing as "a wanton act of barbarity" and said that "it is difficult to believe that civilized nations could resort to such methods of warfare." The article also quoted Japanese officials who condemned the bombing as "an act of terrorism."

The Hindustan Times' coverage of the atomic bomb attack was significant because it was one of the few Indian newspapers to report on the bombing in a critical light. Most Indian newspapers at the time were supportive of the Allied war effort and did not criticize the use of atomic bombs. The Hindustan Times' coverage helped to raise awareness of the human cost of the atomic bomb attack and to challenge the prevailing narrative that the bombing was necessary to end the war.
summary: The Hindustan Times reported on the atomic bomb attack on Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. The newspaper described the bombing as a "wanton act of barbarity" and said that it was difficult to believe that civilized nations could resort to such methods of warfare. The Hindustan Times' coverage was sympathetic to Japan and helped to raise awareness of the human cost of the atomic bomb attack.

headline: India independent
article: August 15th, 1947 will go down in history as one of the most memorable dates, not for India alone but for Asia and the world. For India, it marks the end of an old era and the beginning of a new age. For Asia, it gives a new leader, a new outlook, a new future. For the world, it gives a new India and a new method. India has attained her independence in a unique manner, with unique weapons, and along unique lines. She has shown the world that a subject country, however docile, can still organise itself into a powerful fighting unit by sheer force of will and without resort to the sword, defy the most formidable imperialist power on Earth, render its striking power ineffective, and wrench and preserve freedom with peace as its mantra and satyagraha as its means. Through mainly the inspiration and instrumentality of Mahatma Gandhi, who embodies all that is best and noblest in India, this country has reached its goal without violence. The Indian National Congress which constituted the spearhead of India’s struggle for freedom, has in the course of a little over half a century, won for the country the greatest of all assets, independence. The names of the heroes thrown up in the process are legion; those who died for it are many and those who remain are not few. To all those who have striven, the consummation must come as a prize and an emblem. India is at last free. That this freedom is temporarily fissured and broken does not alter the fact that the heritage is common, that the future is yet to be made. The task before Indians therefore is to preserve the common heritage and to shape the future. Reconstruction and unity must be the aim. It is possible that it may take long to materialize, but that should be no cause for regret. Did not even America, with less complexities, take well-nigh a century to realise her goal of unity? One should hope, however, that India will achieve it much earlier. And while hoping it is worth remembering that just as the past belongs to India and Pakistan alike, the future too belongs to both. It should be remembered also that the country has achieved its freedom at a time when the whole world is at the cross-roads, between life and death, wandering between archaic colonialism and empire philosophy on the one hand and liberty on the other. That the people in this continent have a special role to play in it cannot be overlooked. But to fulfil the mission, Indians have to achieve unity and peace among themselves so that they may help to bring about peace and goodwill among the nations of the world that are now rent by mutual jealousies and suspicion. In the circumstances, a sense of responsibility is as important as resources of mind and character. It is the essence of national self-discipline and Pandit Nehru gave expression to the right sentiment, when, inaugurating the Liberty Week he laid great stress on these qualities. The strength of a chain being the strength of its weakest link; the effort admits of no relaxation. While therefore we should aim at strength and solidarity and ensure good government for realisation of future destiny we should also remember that self-government is not to be an instrument of power alone but an opportunity of service. It is in the spirit of service today that India enters the comity of nations as a free and self-reliant entity. She does so as a nation not weak and embittered by a prolonged struggle for freedom but as a nation resurgent, a power with untold potentialities for good. She realises that not only herself, but along with her the whole of Asia has risen; large parts of which are liberated already, others are in the process of liberation. In such an eventuality India will utilise her freedom not merely for her own material interests much less for domination over others, but to lead and help Asia, nay the whole world. She remembers only too well that, for this, she has to repair her own economy, her own damaged freedom. But with her present leaders still in trim, she feels confident that with a little more effort, she can achieve her purpose. The partition of the country must go, tension must disappear, progressive understanding of the need for space and concord must be promoted unceasingly, common action in mutual interest being always in mind. The need also for citizens to identify self with the State being important, every citizen must live for India just as India must live for all. To adapt great words to a great occasion, India expects every man to do his duty do the same
summary:
August 15th, 1947, is a historic date, not just for India but for Asia and the world. It signifies the end of an era and the dawn of a new age. India's unique path to independence, guided by Mahatma Gandhi's principles of non-violence, stands as a testament to the country's will and determination. The Indian National Congress played a pivotal role in achieving this freedom after a struggle spanning over half a century.
Despite temporary challenges, the common heritage shared by India and Pakistan should be preserved for a unified future. Reconstruction and unity are crucial objectives, acknowledging that the journey might take time. India, gaining freedom in a world at a crossroads, has a significant role to play in promoting peace and goodwill among nations. This responsibility necessitates a sense of national self-discipline and a commitment to service.
Entering the global stage as a free and self-reliant nation, India recognizes the potential for positive contributions. The spirit of service guides India to utilize its freedom not for self-interest or dominance but to lead and assist Asia and the world. The focus remains on repairing the economy, fostering understanding, eliminating tension, and promoting mutual cooperation. The call for citizens to identify with the State emphasizes the collective responsibility for the nation's well-being. As India moves forward, every citizen is urged to do their duty for the country.

headline: Partition Of Assets on population basis
article:
THE Partition Committee, it is learnt, has today decided that
the allocation of the assets and liabilities should be on the
population basis. that is in the ratio of 63.5 to 36.5 as between
Madras and Andhra area.
Premier Kumaraswamy Raja presiding. the Committee met today at about
2-15 p.m. and the meeting lasted till
5-15 in the evening.
It is understood the Committee completed consideration of the Finance
gub-Comm1ttee's report and came to
agreed conclusions on the broad principles that should govern the allocation of
assets and liabilities. The details oi the
formula will be gradually worked out by
the Departments concerned.
As regards the 'common assets' in the
City of Madras officially called "Head-
quarters Buildings". wherein many Pro-
vicinal Government offices and Government House are located—a different
formula has been agreed upon, it is
gathered. Under this arrangement,
Madras Province may be asked to make

summary: The Partition Committee, chaired by Premier Kumaraswamy Raja, has decided to allocate assets and liabilities between Madras and Andhra areas based on population proportions, with a ratio of 63.5 to 36.5. The committee met from 2:15 pm to 5:15 pm and finalized principles for asset allocation based on the Finance Subcommittee's report. Details of the formula will be determined gradually by relevant departments. For "common assets" like the Headquarters Buildings in Madras, a different formula has been agreed upon. Madras Province may be required to make a lump sum payment of one crore rupees to Andhra, clarifying that the new province will have no further involvement with Madras City assets.

headline: Commission In Madras
article:
Mr. D. L. Mazumdar, member-secretary of the Fiscal Commission, returned to Delhi today froın Calcutta after further discus- sions with trade interests in connection with the Commission's enquiry there.

Over the week-end, Mr. Mazumdar met representatives of the Indian Mining Cor- poration and the Indian Colliery Owners Association and other trade organisations, whom the Commission, as a whole, was un- able to examine during its session there.

The next session of the Commission is scheduled to commence in Madras from Jan. 6.

During its session in Calcutta, the ad- ministration of some of the industrial and commercial controls and the Central and Provincial Governments' present attitude towards them are stated to have come in for some general comments. The consen- sus of opinion favoured a gradual loosen- ing of the rigidity of controls over commo- dities whose present supply position justi- fled such relaxation. In regard to controls in respect of coal,

particularly the distribution control, it was felt that a comprehensive review of the

position needed to be now undertaken by a competent body. There was, however,

general agreement that coal was a category by itself and that nationalisation of that

industry could be effectively carried out only if a national coal commission. was

set up without delay.

While there was discontent over the working of commercial and exchange con- trols, s, the general view seemed to be that a consistent and co-ordinated policy would be impossible till the whole field of indus- trial and commercial administration was integrated through a coherent and com- prehensive policy. The absence of such a machinery at present was commented upon and the majority of the chambers and pro- minent individuals were understood to have emphasised the need to set up a central machinery for administrative co-ordination for example, a ministry for economic affairs and a similar machinery for the overall economic planning, E.G. a planning com-

mission. Detailed control and regulation of indus- tries were uniformly opposed and the view was expressed that the main function of the Planning Commission should be the formulation of the pattern of the coun- try's industrial and agricultural develop- ment and the general direction of the eco- nomic forces towards the achievement of that pattern. The Ministry of Economic Affairs would be primarily concerned with securing day-to-day administrative co-or- dination within the framework of the pat-

tern evolved by the Planning Commission. It was generally felt that fiscal policy

by itself could not function in isolation from the other measures to secure com-

mercial and industrial progress, Fiscal policy must form part of an integrated

industrial and commercial policy.

A suggestion was made to the Commis- sion that the Tariff Board should consti- co tute one wing of a more comprehensive planning organisation which should also consist of sections responsible for progress- ing the recommendations of the Tariff Board and for the promotion and develop- ment of the industrial potential of the country.-P.Τ.Ι.
summary: Mr. D. L. Mazumdar, member-secretary of the Fiscal Commission, returned to Delhi from Calcutta after discussing trade matters. Views from various trade bodies favored easing commodity controls, especially coal, and advocated for a national coal commission. Integrated economic policies, including fiscal, were deemed essential, with suggestions for a central planning machinery.

by the armed Pakistan nationals on the

fire lasting for an hour. says an Offcial

Government today.

fruit or joint defence committees. which
are now being formed all along the

nationals from across the border sweep-
ed down on the villages of Kheri. Kothi.
Ratnal. and Chakra, an of them situat-
ed at a distance of six miles from the
cease-fire line. They unleashed a volley
ot gunnre to terrorise the population
unaware of the fact that in the past

summary: On the night of December 30, armed Pakistan nationals launched a coordinated attack on Urriia villages in Kashmir. However, the local population effectively repelled the invaders after an hour-long exchange of fire. The Kashmir Government issued an official communique describing this incident as the result of joint defense committees formed along the Pakistan border. Well-armed militants from across the border targeted villages including Kheri, Kothi, Ratnal, and Chakra, all situated six miles from the cease-fire line. Unaware that the villagers had recently been equipped with modern firearms by the Government, the attackers unleashed gunfire to terrorize the population. In retaliation, the villagers engaged in a brisk exchange of bullets for an hour, forcing the raiders to withdraw in confusion. Fortunately, the communique reported no casualties as a result of this incident, highlighting the successful defense by the local residents against the armed infiltration.

headline: DARUL ISLAM TERROIRSTS ATTACK INDONESIAN ARMY POSTS
article:

attacked Indonesian army posts and temporarily seized a
Government headquarters at Brebes, 25 miles from Cheribon,
North Java, last night usually reliable military sources said today.
This was the first
co-ordinated
attack on Indonesian army positions since
proclamation of the U.S.I. on Dec. 27.
The Muslim groups launched a drive
against the army outposts shortly be-
Office as well as Government Post quarters.
Government forces drove them out in a
determined
counter-attack later in
the night.
Fighting was
reported to have continued desultorily throughout the day
before the terrorists withdrew.
The reports were brought to Cheribon

summary: Two groups of Darul Islam terrorists, each consisting of a thousand fighters, attacked Indonesian army posts and temporarily seized a government headquarters in Brebes, 25 miles from Cheribon in North Java, last night, according to reliable military sources. This marks the first coordinated attack on Indonesian army positions since the proclamation of the United States of Indonesia (U.S.I.) on December 27. The Muslim groups launched their assault against army outposts and government offices. However, government forces managed to drive them out in a determined counter-attack later that night. Sporadic fighting continued throughout the day before the terrorists eventually withdrew. The reports were brought to Cheribon by refugees from Brebes.

headline: The New Einstein Theory
article:

summary: In a significant scientific development, Dr. Albert Einstein has unveiled his latest theory, a generalized theory of gravitation, during the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in New York. At 70 years old, Einstein expresses faith in a harmonious and ordered universe, rejecting the idea that "God plays dice with the world." The new theory aims to unify the fields of gravitational and electromagnetic forces, providing a comprehensive explanation for all physical motion in the universe. Despite the lack of practical testing methods, Einstein sees this theory as a key to understanding fundamental questions about elementary particles, charge, and gravitational fields. Although he acknowledges the challenges of proving his hypothesis, Einstein remains committed to his lifelong ambition of harmonizing the Quantum theory and the Relativity theory, which are foundational to humanity's understanding of the cosmos.

headline: WAFD Victory in Egypt
article:
The Nationalistic Wafd Party won Egypt's first post-war general election.
capturing at least 160 of the 319 seats. The Wafdists led by veteran statesman Mustafa eI Nahas Pasha. boycotted the
last general election after King Farouk
had dismissed Nahas Pasha from Pre-
miership.
Nahas pasha had declared that if
his party did not obtain a majority in
the present election it would not join
other parties in a coalition or corporate in any way.
As results came in today -the Wafdists
went ahead by leaps and bounds to an
absolute majority in the new Chamber
Of Deputies. in which the number of
seats was increased to 315 from. the
figure of 260 before Ring Farouk dis-
solved the old house in November
When the Wafdists. according to official
figures. had secured 147 seats. the
wafdists had won 12. the Liberal Constitution party ten Nationalists tour
Socialists one. Independents one and
the Kotla Party nil.
Later detailed figures for other par-
ties when the Wafdists reached 160 were
awaited.
summary: In Egypt's first post-war general election, the Nationalistic Wafd Party, led by veteran statesman Mustafa el Nahas Pasha, secured a significant victory, capturing at least 160 of the 319 seats in the new Chamber of Deputies. The Wafdists had boycotted the previous general election after King Farouk dismissed Nahas Pasha from the Premiership. Nahas Pasha had declared that his party would not join any coalition or cooperate in any way if they did not obtain a majority in the present election. The Wafdists achieved an absolute majority as the number of seats increased to 315 from the previous 260. Detailed figures for other parties were awaited, but the Wafdists' success marked a substantial political triumph.

headline: United Front For Merger With India
article:
A fervent appeal to the people of
Pondicherry and Karaikal to sink
personal and local political differences
at this hour of trial and put
united front for merger With India
was made by Mr. K. Kamaraj Nadar,
President Tamilnad , Provincial Congress Committee in a press interview today.
           Mr. Kamaraj said: "I welcome the
formation of the merger committee in
which all parties and groups have joined to work for the merger of Pondicherry Karaikal and the other two
French Settlements with the mother
country. I am also glad that Mr. Chellam
Naicker has been unanimously elected
the Chairman of the Merger Commit-
tee. The referendum to decide the future of these settlements till take place.
in March or April. There is not much.
time left. We have to put our heart
and soul and organize the people to
see that the referendum resulted over-
whelming in Favour of India as in
Chandernagore. "
Mr. Kamaraj added: "No doubt there
will be so many impediments in the way
and our people would have to undergo
great many travails caused by foreigners and their agents here. I am confident that the Merger Committee
would so organize as to keep up the
morale of the people and see that they
all voted solidly for India in the coming referendum. There is no room for
these foreign *pockets on our soil. It
would be a great shame if the people
of Pondicherry and Karaikal failed to
combine together on this occasion and
throw off the foreign yoke and be-
come one with the mother India in realizing their long-cherished wish."
summary:
In a press interview, Mr. K. Kamaraj Nadar, President of the Tamilnad Provincial Congress Committee, passionately appealed to the people of Pondicherry and Karaikal to set aside personal and local political differences. He urged them to unite at this critical moment and support the merger of Pondicherry, Karaikal, and the other two French Settlements with India. Mr. Kamaraj welcomed the formation of a merger committee, emphasizing the need for collaboration among all parties and groups. He expressed satisfaction with the unanimous election of Mr. Chellam Naicker as the Chairman of the Merger Committee.

Highlighting the urgency of the situation, Mr. Kamaraj mentioned the upcoming referendum in March or April to decide the future of the settlements. He stressed the importance of organizing and mobilizing the people to ensure a favorable outcome, drawing parallels with the successful referendum in Chandernagore. Despite anticipating challenges and opposition from foreigners and their agents, Mr. Kamaraj expressed confidence in the Merger Committee's ability to maintain the morale of the people. He emphasized the historical significance of shedding the foreign yoke and urged the residents of Pondicherry and Karaikal to join forces in realizing their long-cherished wish of becoming an integral part of mother India.

headline: More Women M.P.s
article:
It is understood Pandit Nehru.
Prime Minister. has sent a circular to
all the Premiers of Provinces suggesting
that as many women as possible might
be allowed to participate in parliamentary activities.
This suggestion. it is gathered. has
been made in connection with the bye-
election to Parliament.
The circular letter was received by the
Premier o: Madras on Thursday.
There was also a suggestion in the
circular letter, it is learnt. that there
should be no objection if only women
member of the Provincial Legislature
desires to go to Parliament and if necessary the relevant rules might be relaxed.
WOMEN'S PROTEST
The Executive Committee Ot the
Madras Branch of the All-India
Women's Conference which met today
passed the following resolution.
"This meeting records its emphatic
protest against the non-inclusion 01
women for election to the Union Parliament. It further deplores the attitude of the Five-Man Committee appointed for the purpose in having
completely ignored the legitimate
rights of women for a place in the
Parliament and thereby denying them
their due share in the administration
of the Government of the country"
summary: Prime Minister Pandit Nehru has reportedly sent a circular to all provincial Premiers, suggesting increased participation of women in parliamentary activities, particularly in the context of an upcoming bye-election to Parliament. The circular, received by the Premier of Madras, proposes that no objection should be raised if a woman member of the Provincial Legislature wishes to go to Parliament, and relevant rules could be relaxed if needed. In response, the Executive Committee of the Madras Branch of the All-India Women's Conference has passed a resolution vehemently protesting the exclusion of women from Union Parliament elections. The committee deplores the Five-Man Committee's attitude, accusing it of ignoring the legitimate rights of women and denying them their rightful share in the country's government administration.

headline: SHIPPING CLAUSE FOR ALL FUTURE TREATIES
article:
India's treaties • with any other
country will henceforth include a
Shipping Clause. by which both the
countries Will bear 50 per cent of the
shipping cargo under Government
agreement o: export and import.
This is reported to be of the main
decision of Shipping
Conference held here this week.
The arrangements. it is pointed out.
Will not be rigid and will be mutually.
adjustable on different terms
different countries.
The Conference has also recommended to the Government of India to
take steps to transfer the greater
share of the Indian coastal trade from
British to Indian companies. It was
learnt.
The Conference is reported to have
suggested that. in order to achieve this
end. the Controller of Indian Shipping
should issue no new licenses to British
ships to operate on the Indian coast.
and should in fact cancel the existing
licenses or some of the British ships.
British shipping companies at pre-
sent control 60 per cent o! the coastal
trade. and this will be sought to be
reduced to ten. or at the most 15 per
cent. Indian companies stated they
were already in a position to handle
85 per cent of the trade. and were
prepared to charter more ships it
necessary.
The Government of India appear to
have given an assurance to the Indian
companies that they would give them
Government cargo as far as possible.
The Conference also suggested
the present method of issuing licenses
for specified number Of ships should
be revised and hereafter licenses
should be issued for specifically named ships
summary: India has made a significant decision following a Shipping Conference, stating that future treaties with other countries will include a Shipping Clause, where both nations will equally share 50% of the shipping cargo under Government agreements for export and import. The arrangements are flexible and can be adjusted mutually based on terms agreed upon by different countries. The conference also recommended transferring the majority of Indian coastal trade from British to Indian companies. To achieve this, it proposed that the Controller of Indian Shipping should refrain from issuing new licenses to British ships for operations on the Indian coast, and even cancel existing licenses for some British vessels. Currently, British shipping companies control 60% of the coastal trade, and the goal is to reduce this to 10-15%, with Indian companies expressing readiness to handle 85% of the trade and charter additional ships if needed. The Indian government is reported to have assured Indian companies of receiving government cargo whenever possible. The conference also advised revising the current method of issuing licenses for a specified number of ships, suggesting that licenses should be granted for specifically named ships.

headline: CONGRESSMEN URGE TO UNITE
article:
Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. Deputy
Minster. before returning to Delhi this
morning issued statement appealing to
Congressmen to compose their differences
by mutual adjustments in the spirit of
friendliness and goodwill having regard to
the larger interests of the organization as
well as the country."
He said: "I came to Lucknow to help In
an amicable and satisfactory solution of the
controversies that have unfortunately raged
round the question of selection of candidates for the Constituent Assembly. It was
With no intention of dictating any course
action, but motivated entirely With a
desire to place the disposal of the local
organization my advice and help that I
approached my task. I listened with deep
attention. but also with deep distress. to
the respective view points or the two groups
Of the Provincial Congress. It was not long
for me to realize that the reasons for divergence of  views were related not to any
intrinsic fundamental organizational principles. but to those quite extraneous to the
interests and welfare of the organization to
which we all have the honour and privilege
to belong. It is no consolation, therefore.
to reflect that organizationally it is as bad
as or a little better than other provinces.
When I compared what I heard and saw
now With What I had heard and seen in the
happier and better days, it made me even
sadder than ever felt before at the race
in deterioration which the provincial organization seem to be having.
During the discussions tendered to my
U.P. friends the advice that the subject
which they were discussing was comparatively trivial. having regard to the larger
interests of the organization as well as the
country that It behooved them as responsible
men of a great organization to compose
their differences by mutual adjustments in
the spirit of friendliness and goodwill and
that. they were prompted by these considerations, they would not find it difficult
to form Committee of selection which
would inspire an-round confidence. I also
expressed my surprise that, Inspite of Jawaharlal's two visits to the province during
the last SIX months. a group-mentality still
existed. contrary to the impression given
to him. as well as to the general public
that they had done away with the idea of
group formation.
summary: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, the Deputy Minister, issued a statement in Lucknow urging Congress members to reconcile their differences through mutual adjustments, fostering friendliness and goodwill. Patel expressed his intention to facilitate a solution to controversies surrounding the selection of candidates for the Constituent Assembly. He emphasized the need for unity in the larger interests of the organization and the country. Patel observed that the disagreements were not rooted in fundamental organizational principles but extraneous factors detrimental to the organization's welfare. Despite advising that the issue was relatively trivial, he urged responsible action, expressing sadness at the perceived deterioration of the provincial organization. Patel recommended forming a selection committee based on mutual trust and highlighted the persistence of group mentalities despite efforts to dispel such notions.

headline: SURGING CROWDS GREET NEHRU
article:
Pandit Nehru is the talk of the town.
The Commonwealth Conference is con-
sidered only secondary by the people ot
Colombo and surrounding areas. There
are surging crowds wherever he goes,
and they greet him .with deafening
cheers.
Repeated appeals in English. Tamil
and Sinhalese were made by the Indian
High Commissioner in Ceylon, Mr. V. V.
Giri. in a broadcast from Radio Ceylon
to Ceylonese and Indians not to let
their enthusiasm over the presence of
Pandit Nehru to interfere with the
smooth flow ot tramc and security ar-
rangements made for the visiting states-
men.
The P.T.I. correspondent says the
appeals became necessary as police
found great diffculty in controlling the
vast crowds which gathered. particularly
inside Colombo city, to greet the Indian
Prime Minister when he drove from
Katunayake aerodrome to the Gover-
nor-General's residence
summary: Pandit Nehru's presence is causing a stir in Colombo, overshadowing the significance of the Commonwealth Conference for locals. Crowds enthusiastically gather wherever Nehru goes, cheering loudly. The Indian High Commissioner in Ceylon, Mr. V. V. Giri, issued appeals in English, Tamil, and Sinhalese through a Radio Ceylon broadcast, urging people not to let their excitement disrupt traffic and security arrangements. Police faced challenges in controlling the large crowds, particularly in Colombo, as Nehru drove from Katunayake aerodrome to the Governor-General's residence.

headline: Remission of land tax, if necessary
article:
The Government have
in Press note yesterday:
*The Government note that the North
East Monsoon has failed for a third year
In succession In certain parts Ot the ro-
Vince particularly in certain southern and
Central districts and are Informed that
widespread failure o: crops has occurred In
these areas. The Government have called
for special reports from -the collectors o:
Chingleput. South Arcot, North Arcot. Tiru-
chirapalli Salem. Mathurai. Ramnad and
Tirunelveli regarding the condition Ot Croos
in these districts. These Collectors have been
asked to submit proposals for the grant ot
remission, necessary. through the Board
of Revenue. In order to afford immediate re-
itet to the agriculturists the Board has
been instructed to order the postponement
ot the connection of kist Wherever necessary.
The Government will consider the question
ot granting remission ot laud revenue tn ail
the affected parts. on receipt o: detailed
re orts from the Collectors and the Board.
representation has been made to coveru-
ment that well digging and tank renova-
tion works should be immediately launched
on an extensive scale and that famine relief
works Should be opened. The Government
have instructed the Board to launch a special drive to complete as many wens under
the News Wells Subsidy Scheme as possible
before the end ot the current financial year.
A five-year scheme ror the improvement o:
irrigation tanks In the province was sanctioned and execution o: works under the

summary: The government issued a press note acknowledging the third consecutive failure of the North East Monsoon in certain southern and central districts of the province, resulting in widespread crop failures. Collectors from specific districts were directed to submit reports on crop conditions, with instructions to propose remission through the Board of Revenue. Immediate relief measures were initiated, including the postponement of kist collection where necessary. The government expressed intent to consider remission of land revenue for affected areas upon receiving detailed reports. Concerns regarding well digging, tank renovation, and famine relief prompted the government to instruct the Board to launch extensive initiatives, particularly under the New Wells Subsidy Scheme. A five-year scheme for irrigation tank improvement was sanctioned, and related works had already commenced. Additionally, infrastructure projects such as roads were slated for implementation by Collectors to generate employment opportunities for laborers.

for lowering the prestige 01 Pakistan
State by sending false reports to the

Reports from rural areas show that

redress at police stations.
Another method used to coerce Hindus is to Islamise education. History
text-books are being re-written to
eulogise all that is Muslim and con-
demn all that is non-Muslim. At the
terminal examination of high schools

"Give a short account of  Kamar Kumar." meaning Maharaja. Nanda Kumar
summary: In Dacca, a Hindu house was demolished to make way for a mosque under the order of the District Magistrate. After a house-owner successfully got his place released, his home was burnt down by a group of hooligans. A seventy-year-old man, Prahlad Saha, who complained to the police, was taken to the police station in handcuffs, accused of lowering the prestige of the Pakistan State through false reports. Reports from rural areas indicate the forceful collection of standing crops owned by Hindus by Muslims, with little redress at police stations. Additionally, there are efforts to coerce Hindus by Islamizing education, rewriting history textbooks to glorify Muslim contributions and condemn non-Muslim aspects. The high school history exam in Dacca district included questions about the role of "kafirs" in battles with the British to acquire territory in India and a short account of "Kamar Kumar," referring to Maharaja Nanda Kumar.

article:
Various suggestions for composing the

Another member suggested periodical

Summing up the discussion, Sardar
