summary: During a meeting of Congress members, various suggestions were proposed to address internal differences. One member emphasized that the disagreements were not widespread among Congress members but were primarily among the leadership. He recommended that the Premier, along with key figures like Mr. P. C. Sen, Food Minister, Dr. P. C. Ghosh, and Mr. Surendra Mohan Ghosh, should collaborate to find solutions. Another member suggested regular joint meetings between the Provincial Congress Executive and the Congress Assembly Party to keep them informed and offer suggestions for Ministry consideration. This member expressed dissatisfaction with the lack of consultation with the Congress Assembly Party on important issues. Sardar Pavel concluded the discussion, urging the congressmen to resolve differences internally without external assistance. He emphasized the need for unity to strengthen the Congress organization and collaborate with the Ministry in addressing the country's current challenges.

headline: Common Problems
article:
Pandit Nehru, who was addressing
well over 20.000 Ceylonese and Indians
gathered 'n Ceylon's vast race course
ground this evening. said the problem
before India and Ceylon today was to
bring about economic advancement or
the masses of people and at the same
time maintain the democratic struc-
ture of society.
Pandit Nehru. said: "If you have 8
democratic structure which does not
bring that advance. then that demo-
cracy has failed Sust as much as any
other political structure which fails to
give political freedom to people would
Elso have failed."
It was one of the biggest public
gatherings seen in Ceylon. Panditji was
listened to in rapt attention for nearly
an hour.
With Pandit Nehru on the platform
was the Prime Minister of Ceylon. Mr.
Senanayake.
at one stage crowd of several hun-
dred people who had climbed on to the
roof of sheds in the public enclosure
were panicked when the roof threaten-
ed to collapse. Many jumped to the
ground in fright but the roof held.
Pandit Nehru noticed the incident and
referred humorously to it saying.
"that often happens at my meetings.
and sometimes even the platform col-
lapses and I disappear."
summary: Pandit Nehru addressed a large gathering of over 20,000 Ceylonese and Indians at Ceylon's race course ground, emphasizing the challenge of achieving economic progress for the masses while preserving democratic structures. He asserted that a democratic system failing to bring about such advancement is as much a failure as any political structure denying political freedom. The event, one of the largest public gatherings in Ceylon, featured Pandit Nehru speaking for nearly an hour, with the Prime Minister of Ceylon, Mr. Senanayake, present on the platform. During the address, a temporary scare occurred when a crowd on a shed roof faced a potential collapse, but Pandit Nehru addressed it humorously, mentioning similar incidents at his meetings.

article:

Incomes ot primary producers.
The agenda Includes labour inspecting.
workers' welfare facilities. the cooperative

ment services and training.
A member of the Indian delegation told
P. T. I. , India was specially Interested in
the projected regulation Ot and increase in

one-year survey oc working conditions and
wages of Indian term labour was already
went under way and the Government 01

summary: Lord Soulbury, the Governor-General of Ceylon, called on world labor leaders, employers, and governments to work towards the "abolition of economic slavery in Asia's millions." Speaking at the inaugural session of the conference, he expressed the hope that historians would document the abolition of economic slavery in the 20th century, following the political slavery abolition in the 19th century. The conference, attended by 250 delegates and various international observers, is the first full-scale Asian regional conference of the International Labour Organization (I.L.O.). Mr. B. Jayah, Ceylon's Minister for Labour, is expected to be elected president. The primary focus of the conference is to improve the conditions of Asia's agricultural workers. The delegates plan to establish a working committee to assess agricultural incomes, regulate wages, and increase the incomes of primary producers. The agenda includes discussions on labor inspection, workers' welfare facilities, the cooperative movement, and the development of employment services and training. A member of the Indian delegation highlighted India's specific interest in regulating and increasing agricultural workers' wages, noting that a one-year survey of working conditions and wages for Indian farm labor was already underway. The Indian government aims to lead Asian countries in implementing regulations for agricultural laborers' wages.

headline: Shooting Incident during Nehru's visit
article:
Mirnal Ranti Chatterjee: a 17-yéar
old Calcutta student. accused in the,
Brigade Parade Ground shooting case
was today convicted by the Speciai
Judge Mr. N. C. Chakravarti under
Sec. 307 1 P. C. (attempt to murder)
and 19 F. of the Indian Arms Act.
and sentenced to seven and nve years
R. r. on these two counts. respectively.
Both the sentences are to run con-
currently.
The judgment was delivered at the
Presidency Jail, Alipore. where the
accused is now on a hunger-strike for
the past few days.
Chatterjee was arrested on July 14
last when he had fired three revolver
shots at a Deputy Commissioner of
Police. Special Branch. ora duty at a
public meeting on the Brigade Parade
Ground. which was addressed by
Prime Minister Pandit Nehru. When
arrested he was found to be in posses-
Sion of revolver loaded with three
live and three fired cartridges. A
cardboard box containing six more
cartridges was also recovered from a
pocket of his trousers.
summary: Mirnal Ranti Chatterjee, a 17-year-old Calcutta student, has been convicted in the Brigade Parade Ground shooting case. The Special Judge, Mr. N. C. Chakravarti, found him guilty under Sec. 307 of the Indian Penal Code (attempt to murder) and Section 19 F of the Indian Arms Act. He has been sentenced to seven and five years rigorous imprisonment on these two counts, respectively, with the sentences running concurrently. The judgment was delivered at the Presidency Jail, Alipore, where the accused is currently on a hunger strike. Chatterjee was arrested on July 14 for firing three revolver shots at a Deputy Commissioner of Police during a public meeting on Brigade Parade Ground, addressed by Prime Minister Pandit Nehru. At the time of his arrest, he was found in possession of a revolver loaded with three live and three fired cartridges, along with a cardboard box containing six more cartridges recovered from his trousers' pocket.

headline: PENDING FILES WOULD BE TAKEN UP NOW
article:
Mr. R. Chandramouli Minister for
Local Administration. said that, though
the formation of the Andhra Province
might be postponed. the province was.
the General elections. He added that
many files, the consideration of which
had been kept pending the formation
of the Andhra Province, would now be
taken up and speedily attended to.
Mr. B. Gopala Reddi. Finance Minis-
ter pointed out that the formation of
the Andhra Province had only been de-
layed and not given up and that noth-
ing precluded its being taken up at a
convenient time. He felt that the pro-
ceedings relating to the formation of
the Andhra Province could be released
to the legislators by way of reply to
interpellation.
Mr. N. Sanjiva Reddi, Minister for
Prohibition said that it was now definite
that the Andhra Province was not com-
ing before Jan. 26. In his view the
province would not come even before
 The Minister added that it would be
better that both the Press and the pub-
lic should refrain from discussing this
question for some time at least.
summary: Mr. R. Chandramouli, the Minister for Local Administration, acknowledged that the formation of the Andhra Province might be postponed but assured that it remains a priority despite the delay due to General elections. He mentioned that several pending files related to the Andhra Province would be promptly addressed. Finance Minister, Mr. B. Gopala Reddi, clarified that the formation of the Andhra Province was merely delayed, not abandoned, and could be revisited at a convenient time. He suggested providing legislators with information on the proceedings through replies to interpellation. Minister for Prohibition, Mr. N. Sanjiva Reddi, confirmed that the Andhra Province would not be formed before January 26 and likely not even by April. He recommended refraining from public discussions on the matter for the time being.

headline: Higher Pay For Aided Elementary School Teachers Proposed
article:
Over 120,000 elementary school teachers will benefit under a scheme. now under consideration by the Madras Government, to raise the minimum salary of teachers working in aided elementary schools, from Rs. 25 (the present rate) to Rs. 30 per mensem.

The expenditure of about seventy-five lakhs of rupees, involved in this scheme, is proposed to be borne by the Government.

The scheme, in case it is approved, 1s to come into effect from April 1, 1950. It may be mentioned that teachers working in elementary schools run by the local bodies and by the Govern- ment are already having a minimunı salary of Rs. 30 per mensem.

The present scheme proposes to place teachers in aided elementary schools on a par with those working in the other categories of elementary schools.
summary: The Madras Government is considering a scheme to raise the minimum salary of teachers in aided elementary schools from Rs. 25 to Rs. 30 per month, benefiting over 120,000 teachers. The scheme, which involves an expenditure of approximately seventy-five lakhs of rupees, is proposed to be funded by the Government. If approved, it will come into effect from April 1, 1950. This initiative aims to align the salaries of teachers in aided elementary schools with those in elementary schools run by local bodies and the Government, who already receive a minimum salary of Rs. 30 per month.

headline: Statutory Planning Body For India : Congress Executive's Recommendation
article:
The Congress Working Committee today adopted a resolution recommending to the Government of India the appointment of a statutory Planning Commission. It is proposed that suitable boards of experts should be appointed to assist the Planning Commission.
The duties of the Commission would include the determination of priorities, securing full and all-round coordination in the process of planning and in the execution of the plan and laying down the various stages, each covering a de- fined period, for the development of the country's economy.
Following is the text of the resolution:
"Recognition of the vital role of planning in the development of our national economy and the realization of the people's aspirations for social justice and progress led to the appointment of the National Planning Committee in the year 1938. Working under the limitations, inseparable from the political conditions of the period in which it functioned, the Committee achieved valuable results in making the conception of planning familiar in the country and in carrying through a great deal of spade work.
"In modern country conditions of life no can hope to administer its affairs with success or with any degree of satisfaction to the mass of the people without recourse to the powerful instrument of social and economic planning. The need for a comprehensive plan has become a matter of compelling urgency in India now owing to the ravages of the Second World War and the economic and political consequences of the partition of the country which followed in the wake of the achievement of freedom, and the steady worsening of the economic situation in India and the world.
"The tasks of a planning body for India have already been set by the course of the country's struggle for freedom. What the economic content of the people's freedom should be has been indicated in general terms in the resolutions and manifestoes of the Indian National Congress, in the pronouncements of Mahatma Gandhi and other Congress leaders and in the Congress economic programme. 
"The vision which inspired the people of India through the various phases of the non-violent revolution which made the country free was of a land from which poverty, unemployment, ignorance, inequality and exploitation would be banished and in which every person would find work suitable to his talents and capacity and have the wherewithal of a decent life. With the achievement of complete independence it becomes the paramount duty of the Congress to take immediate steps for the fulfilment of its solemn pledges and for producing the conditions in which the people's creative energies and enthusiasm can be evoked and harnessed in the fullest measure in the great endeavour to bring into being a just and progressive social order. 
The Constitution which the people of India have just adopted embodies certain directive principles of State policy which have also an intimate earing on the forms of social and economic organization to be evolved and which must be rendered in terms of programmes of action to be formulated by the planning authority.
"In order that the declarations of the Congress and the directive principles of the Constitution are made effective in as short a time as possible, it is desirable that a statutory Planning Commission be set up. by the Government of India. "
The Planning Commission should be a compact body composed of persons. whose selection is made primarily with the view that the outlook of the Commission is in harmony with the basic ideas which should govern the plan and that it possesses a comprehensive. understanding of the administrative, social, political and economic needs and conditions of the country.
"The Commission should be assisted by boards of experts who may together be able to provide it with all the information and advice necessary for the adequate performance of its functions. The Commission should be equipped with a special statistical organisation and should be in a position to make use of the administrative machinery of the country for the collection of the requisite statistical and factual material. In order to bring the plan and its
execution into tune with the needs and aspirations of the people the Commission should devise measures to secure their association and co-operation at all levels."
OBJECTIVES
The principal objectives to be realised through such a plan are:
(1) The establishment of a just order of society, providing for: (a) the operation of the principles of decentralisation, co-operation, and individual freedom to the utmost feasible extent; (b) Equal opportunity for all; (c) adequate means of living for all; (d)just and humane conditions of work; (e) full and suitable employment, and (f) the growth of the human personality in all its aspects;
(2) Adequate and expanding volume of production to secure a progressive rise in the standard of living and the achievement of a national minimum in respect of all the essentials for physical and social well-being, within a period.
(3) The best utilisation of the material and human resources of the nation and the improvement of the skill and the productive capacity of its manpower by suitable technical education and training;
(4) As near an approach to national and regional self-sufficiency as would be compatible with the requirements of an adequate standard of living and the country's internal and external security.
COMMISSION'S DUTIES
"The Planning Commission should have the following duties:
(1) To make a full assessment of the resources and the requirements of the nation;
(2) To determine priorities, to work out a proper allocation and distribution
of the resources and their constant adjustments to the changing requirements with a view to obtaining the speediest and the maximum realisation of the objectives of the plan;
(3) To lay down the various stages, each covering a defined period, for the development of the country's economy and to undertake the necessary preparatory work in connection with each stage and
(4) To secure full and all-round coordination in the process of planning and in the execution of the plan.
"In the context of the present needs and the circumstances of the country and in view of the acute economic difficulties which are being experienced, the commission should devise immediate measures: (a) to reduce to the minimum the dependence of the country on foreign sources in the matters of consumer goods, to bring about a speedy elimination of the import of luxury goods and such other articles as are not indispensable regardless of the inconvenience that may be felt by any section of the population; (b) to secure the necessary capital goods for increasing the internal production of the needed articles as quickly as possible; (c) and to maximise the production of  the essential primary goods, specially foodstuffs and raw materials for the principal industries, in the shortest
time possible; (d) to speed up projects for increasing the irrigation facilities and power supply of the country, which are the basis of its prosperity and progress."
The Working Committee will discuss organisational matters tomorrow and conclude its four-day session.-----PTI
summary:
The Congress Working Committee has passed a resolution recommending the establishment of a statutory Planning Commission in India. The proposed commission would be responsible for determining priorities, coordinating planning efforts, and outlining stages of economic development. It suggests the appointment of expert boards to assist the Planning Commission in its duties.

The resolution acknowledges the importance of planning in achieving social justice, progress, and economic stability. It highlights the need for comprehensive planning in India due to the aftermath of World War II, partition, and worsening economic conditions. The resolution aligns with the visions expressed by the Indian National Congress and leaders like Mahatma Gandhi, focusing on eradicating poverty, unemployment, inequality, and exploitation.

The resolution emphasizes the establishment of a just society, equal opportunities, adequate living standards, suitable employment, and overall individual growth. It also emphasizes the efficient utilization of resources, improving the nation's skill and productive capacity through technical education, and striving for self-sufficiency while maintaining a decent standard of living and national security.

Immediate measures are suggested to reduce dependence on foreign sources, increase domestic production, maximize essential goods production, and accelerate projects related to irrigation and power supply.

Organizational matters of the proposed Planning Commission will be discussed in subsequent sessions.

summary: Maulana Mahomed Sayed, the General Secretary of the Jammu and Kashmir National Conference, expressed that January 26 would be a compelling reason for Kashmir's continued association with India. He stated that on this day, Republican India would be born, aligning its ideals with the traditional aspirations of the Kashmiri people. summary: Mr. Frank Stuart, a Scotsman living in Essex, has created a life-size robot elephant capable of walking at 28 mph, waving its trunk, and flapping its ears. Driven by a petrol engine, the innovative toy is designed with legs that leave the ground as the elephant moves. Mr. Stuart, known for making stage scenery and carnival masks, is currently in negotiations for a potential order of 500 elephants from America. The idea for this unique creation struck him while observing donkeys on the seaside, leading to two years of experimentation. Initially, he produced an electric motor-driven elephant on wheels but was dissatisfied, prompting him to construct a steel-skeleton elephant with legs imitating walking motion, covered in a toughened paper hide.

headline: COUNTRYWIDE PHONE RACKET UNEARTHED
article:
A country-wide racket to use
long-distance telephones Without
paying full char{es
has been un-
earthed by the telephone authori—
ties. it is learnt here.
Members or the gang, said to
be speculators on New York Cot—
ton futures. worked on the
understanding between them that
calling up persons of particular
names meant rise or fall in the
opening or closing prices of New
York Cotton. For instance, in
Surat, a member of the gang used
to receive particular person calls:
if the person at the Bombay end
wanted "Patel" the price was
found to have risen; if "Kapadia"
was wanted, the market was
found to have gone down.
The code seems to nave been
perfected to such an extent that
addition Of first names signified
the extent of the rise or fall in
the prices.
The particular person called, It
is learnt, was invariably found
absent: as a result the person
booking the call from Bombay
paid only 25 per cent of the ordi-
nary call rate.
A check-up, it is learnt. has
revealed that similar codes have
been used by the gang between
various cities in India.
summary: A nationwide scheme involving the unauthorized use of long-distance telephones without paying full charges has been uncovered by telephone authorities. The operation involved a group of individuals, reportedly speculators in New York Cotton futures. The gang members utilized a coded understanding wherein calling persons with specific names indicated the potential rise or fall in the opening or closing prices of New York Cotton. For instance, in Surat, receiving calls for a particular person signaled changes in market prices. The code was sophisticated, with additional first names representing the extent of price fluctuations. The called individuals were consistently found absent, allowing the person booking the call from Bombay to pay only 25% of the regular call rate. Investigations revealed similar codes were employed by the gang between various cities in India.

headline: HT This Day: January 25, 1950 -- Indonesian Republic President in Delhi
article:
The Governor-General Mr Rajagopalachari, and the Prime Minister, Pandit Nehru, received President Soekarno and Mrs Soekarno at Willingdon airport as they got from a Dakota which was flying the flag of the new Republic.
NEW DELHI-A rousing reception was given to Dr Soekarno, President of the Indonesian Republic, on his arrival here this afternoon

A screengrab of the Hindustan Times on January 25, 1950
A screengrab of the Hindustan Times on January 25, 1950
The Governor-General. Mr Rajagopalachari, and the Prime Minister, Pandit Nehru, received President Soekarno and Mrs Soekarno at Willingdon airport as they got from a Dakota which was flying the flag of the new Republic.

Hindustan Times - your fastest source for breaking news! Read now.
Looking pretty in her pale-brown national costume, Mrs Soekarno and her husband, who was wearing the full star-studded uniform of the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces of Indonesia, were first received by their old friend, Pandit Nehru, who introduced them to the Governor-General. Pandit Nehru and Dr Soekarno embraced each other affectionately and the Governor-General clasped the Indoneslan leader’s hand with touching warmth. Mrs Soekarno received a bouquet of roses from Mrs Soedarsono, wife of the Indonesian Charge d’Affaires here in Delhi.

Rajkumari Amrit Kau,. India’s Minister of Health, Sheikh Abdullah, the Kashmir Premier; Mr Lamping. Netherlands Ambassador who is the Doyen of the Diplomatic Corps! and his wife; Mr Gollan, Australian High Commissioner, Mr Ismail Kamel Bay, E ptian Ambassador; Sardar NajibKhan. Afghan Ambassador; Mr Mohd. Salim Al-Radi, Minister for Iraq; Mr Emmanuel Abraham, Minister for Ethiopia; and Dr Casco Vieira Garin, Minister for Portugal; and Dr P. Subbaroyan. Indian Ambassador to Indonesia, were also present.

An enthusiastic friend of Indonesia, Pandit Nehru, arrived several minutes before the landing of the plane and was seen busy arranging people collected to receive President Soekarno in rows. But these vanished almost immediately as everybody rushed toward the plane as soon as it halted.

Dr Soekarno and party are staying at Government House. Dr Soekarno is visiting Agra on January 28 and will leave for Karachi on January 29.

A member of Indonesian Information Ministry said that Dr Seokarno’s visit to India was purely a goodwill and courtesy visit and that he had no definite subjects to discuss with the Government of India. He was here to participate in the celebrations marking the inauguration of the Indian Republic, he added.

Dr Soekarno will lay a wreath on Mahatma Gandhi’s samadhi at Rajghat on January 27, and will also address the staff and students of the Delhi University at 11-30 a.m. Pandit Nehru will also be present.
summary: On January 25, 1950, Dr. Soekarno, the President of Indonesia, arrived in New Delhi to a warm reception from Indian dignitaries, including Governor-General Mr. Rajagopalachari and Prime Minister Pandit Nehru. Dr. Soekarno, dressed in his military uniform, and his wife, in traditional attire, were greeted with affection. Pandit Nehru, an old friend, introduced them to the Governor-General. The visit, described as a goodwill gesture, included plans to visit Agra and participate in India's Republic Day celebrations. Dr. Soekarno also laid a wreath at Mahatma Gandhi's memorial and addressed Delhi University students.

summary: Today, the members of India's Constituent Assembly signed the country's constitution, a weighty document exceeding 10 pounds. Printed on durable vellum parchment paper, it comprises 289 pages detailing Articles and Schedules, expected to endure for over a millennium. In addition to this main volume, two other handwritten volumes by skilled calligraphists are in progress. These volumes, adorned with gold-like Moghul paintings, come in English and Hindi. They will be sent to Santinekatan for artistic embellishments under the guidance of Nandalal Bose, depicting various periods in Indian history on the initial pages of each chapter and schedule.

headline: HT archives: News clippings from first Republic Day
article:
India’s first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru receiving Indonesian president Dr Soekarno, guest of honour for India’s first Republic Day. Also in the photo are Dorothy Norman, American writer and Purushottam Das Tandon.On 24th January 1950, the constituent assembly met at the constitution hall in New Delhi, for its last session, at 11 o’ clock on a Tuesday, with India’s first president Dr Rajendra Prasad in the chair.

Dr Prasad made the following statement with regard to the national anthem.

“The composition consisting of the words and music known as Jana Gana Mana is the National Anthem of India, subject to such alterations in the words as the Government may authorise as occasion arises; and the song Vande Mataram, which has played a historic part in the struggle for Indian freedom, shall be honoured equally with Jana Gana Mana and shall have equal status with it. (Applause). I hope this will satisfy the Members.”
summary:
On January 24, 1950, India's Constituent Assembly, led by President Dr. Rajendra Prasad, concluded its final session in New Delhi. Indonesian President Dr. Soekarno graced the occasion as the guest of honor for India's first Republic Day. Among the distinguished attendees were Jawaharlal Nehru, India's inaugural Prime Minister, American writer Dorothy Norman, and Purushottam Das Tandon.

In a momentous declaration, Dr. Prasad affirmed "Jana Gana Mana" as India's National Anthem, subject to government-authorized alterations. Notably, he underscored that "Vande Mataram," a song integral to India's freedom struggle, would share equal status with "Jana Gana Mana." The announcement resonated with applause, marking a pivotal juncture in India's transition to a republic, symbolizing unity through its national anthems.

headline: A Republic is born: The Hindu Editorial on January 26, 1950
article:
The inauguration of the Republic of India is an act of high faith in the people of this country, a gesture of dedication of all the nation’s talent and resources to the realisation of worthy purposes. It amounts to an implicit pledge on the part of every Indian that he will to the extent of his strength and capacity uphold the honour of his country, augment her strength for good and persuasively convey to a distracted world her immemorial message of abhaya . A democratic Republic, which is what our Constitution aims to build, is one in which the worth of the individual is not submerged in the collective will but sustains it. In such a polity no man may walk on crutches or regard public business as no concern of his. Every citizen must remember that if matters go wrong with the State it is he that is ultimately responsible. He must, therefore, not only acquire by study enough familiarity with the working of the machinery of Government through which democracy functions. He must understand the basic problems which have to be tackled if the good life is to be realised here and now. He must have the strength of character which alone is a nation’s true capital. And above all he must have the will to put his shoulder to the wheel and push and pull, never getting out of step with his fellows, never seeking short cuts, never succumbing to the temptation to find scapegoats.

The special Supplement which we are issuing to-day is intended to give our readers an idea of the onerousness as well as the grandeur of the great adventure on which the people of India are setting out. Nearly a hundred and seventy contributors, drawn not only from every part of India and from every walk of life, but also from other countries, notably Britain and America, have with ready courtesy responded to our invitation to write. (Unfortunately some of the contributions were received too late to be included in the Supplement; but we are printing most of them in to-day’s issue). Each is an acknowledged expert in his field and offers not only a synoptic survey of such achievements as we may legitimately claim but also an indication of the leeway that must be made up and of the methods which are likely to lead us swiftly to the goal. The poverty as well as the potentialities of our economy, the urgent need for tapping our inexhaustible human wealth, the power of education for unfreezing the spirit after its age-long sleep, the lessons as well as the warnings that we must draw from the successes and failures of other self-reliant peoples — all these matters, as set out in these hundred odd pages, will, it is hoped, provide the reader with a coherent picture of the social and cultural pattern which is in the making on the loom of time.
summary: The inauguration of the Republic of India symbolizes dedication to national progress and individual responsibility. It pledges every citizen to uphold the nation's honor, strengthen its democracy, and address societal challenges. A democratic Republic values individual worth while engaging collective efforts. A diverse group of contributors, including experts from India, Britain, and America, highlight achievements and challenges in a special supplement. They emphasize economic poverty, human potential, education, and lessons from other nations. The supplement aims to offer insights into India's evolving social and cultural landscape, urging citizens to actively contribute to the nation's advancement and refrain from seeking shortcuts or scapegoats.

The poverty as well as the potentialities of our economy, the urgent need for tapping our inexhaustible human wealth, the power of education for unfreezing the spirit after its age-long sleep, the lessons as well as the warnings that we must draw from the successes and failures of other self-reliant peoples — all these matters, as set out in these hundred odd pages, will, it is hoped, provide the reader with a coherent picture of the social and cultural pattern which is in the making on the loom of time.
summary: The inauguration of the Republic of India symbolizes a profound commitment to the nation's people, their talents, and resources towards noble goals. It signifies an implicit promise from every Indian to uphold the country's honor, strengthen it for good, and share its timeless message with the world. A democratic Republic, as envisioned by the Constitution, upholds the worth of individuals while sustaining collective will. In such a system, every citizen bears responsibility for the state's well-being. They must understand governance, grasp fundamental issues, possess strong character, and exhibit willingness to contribute to societal progress. A special supplement, featuring contributions from experts across India and abroad, offers insights into the challenges and achievements of the nation. It highlights economic challenges, the importance of human capital, the transformative power of education, and lessons from other self-reliant nations. Through these discussions, readers gain a comprehensive understanding of India's evolving social and cultural landscape and the collective efforts required to shape its future.

headline: January 26, 1950: How India observed its first Republic Day
article:
On the eve of the 75th Republic Day, we look back at the chilly January morning in 1950, when India became a republic.
On January 26, 1950, the Republic of India was born. More than two years after Independence, and after nearly a century of nationalist struggle, India was finally a sovereign, democratic republic, free to chart its own course into the future.

On the eve of the 75th Republic Day, we remember the chilly January morning in 1950 when India became a republic.
Dominion to republic
Although British rule in India ended on August 15, 1947, India was yet to sever all ties with the Empire. For over two years after Independence, India remained a British dominion, governed by the British-era Government of India Act of 1935, and officially still owing allegiance to the Crown.


All this changed on January 26, 1950. On that day, the newly drafted Constitution of India came into effect, replacing the Act of 1935 as the supreme governing document of the country. Dr Rajendra Prasad began his first term as the President of India, replacing the British monarch as the ceremonial head of the state.

And finally, the Constituent Assembly, which had drafted the constitution over a period of roughly three years, became the Parliament of India until the first general elections would take place in 1951-52.
summary: The Republic of India was established on January 26, 1950, marking the culmination of over a century of nationalist struggle and more than two years after gaining independence from British rule. Prior to this, India had been a British dominion, governed by the Government of India Act of 1935. The newly drafted Constitution of India came into effect on this day, replacing the British-era act as the supreme governing document. Dr. Rajendra Prasad became the first President of India, and the Constituent Assembly transitioned into the Parliament until the first general elections were held in 1951-52. This momentous occasion marked India's sovereignty as a democratic republic, free to determine its own path forward.

headline: A Republic is born: The Hindu Editorial on January 26, 1950
article: The inauguration of the Republic of India is an act of high faith in the people of this country, a gesture of dedication of all the nation’s talent and resources to the realisation of worthy purposes. It amounts to an implicit pledge on the part of every Indian that he will to the extent of his strength and capacity uphold the honour of his country, augment her strength for good and persuasively convey to a distracted world her immemorial message of abhaya . A democratic Republic, which is what our Constitution aims to build, is one in which the worth of the individual is not submerged in the collective will but sustains it. In such a polity no man may walk on crutches or regard public business as no concern of his. Every citizen must remember that if matters go wrong with the State it is he that is ultimately responsible. He must, therefore, not only acquire by study enough familiarity with the working of the machinery of Government through which democracy functions. He must understand the basic problems which have to be tackled if the good life is to be realised here and now. He must have the strength of character which alone is a nation’s true capital. And above all he must have the will to put his shoulder to the wheel and push and pull, never getting out of step with his fellows, never seeking short cuts, never succumbing to the temptation to find scapegoats.
summary: The Republic of India's inauguration symbolizes faith in its people, dedicating talents and resources to noble goals. It implies a commitment from every citizen to uphold the nation's honor, strengthen it for the greater good, and convey its timeless message. In a democratic Republic, individual worth sustains collective will, emphasizing citizen responsibility, understanding of governance, and a commitment to the common good.

headline: HT archives: News clippings from first Republic Day
article:
On the occasion of India’s 67th Republic Day, here’s a look at the major headlines of Hindustan Times before and after January 26, 1950.
On the occasion of India’s 67th Republic Day, here’s a look at the major headlines of Hindustan Times before and after January 26, 1950.

India’s first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru receiving Indonesian president Dr Soekarno, guest of honour for India’s first Republic Day. Also in the photo are Dorothy Norman, American writer and Purushottam Das Tandon.
India’s first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru receiving Indonesian president Dr Soekarno, guest of honour for India’s first Republic Day. Also in the photo are Dorothy Norman, American writer and Purushottam Das Tandon.
Last constituent assembly session

Hindustan Times - your fastest source for breaking news! Read now.
On 24th January 1950, the constituent assembly met at the constitution hall in New Delhi, for its last session, at 11 o’ clock on a Tuesday, with India’s first president Dr Rajendra Prasad in the chair.

Dr Prasad made the following statement with regard to the national anthem.

“The composition consisting of the words and music known as Jana Gana Mana is the National Anthem of India, subject to such alterations in the words as the Government may authorise as occasion arises; and the song Vande Mataram, which has played a historic part in the struggle for Indian freedom, shall be honoured equally with Jana Gana Mana and shall have equal status with it. (Applause). I hope this will satisfy the Members.”

Here is a news clipping of a front page article from Hindustan Times reporting the event on the next day - 25th January 1960.


Another news clipping published on the same day highlights the point that ‘Vande Mataram’ was given equal status with ‘Jana Gana Mana’.


Read moment by moment what happened in the constitution hall two before the first Republic Day here.

First chief guest

President Sukarno of Indonesia was guest of honour for India’s first Republic Day celebrations in 1950. The below article describes the rousing reception given to the Indonesian president and also jots down his itinerary in India.


The following article, published on 25th January 1950, describes in detail, how Delhi prepared for the first Republic Day celebrations. According to The Hindu, in the beginning the parade did not start from Rajpath and proceed to Old Delhi but was held at the erstwhile Irwin Stadium, New Delhi, with a 21-gun salute.


Read more about the first parade here.

A HT photo shows Dr Rajendra Prasad being sworn in as the president of India at exactly 10.24 am on January 26, 1950, six minutes after India was declared a Sovereign Democratic Republic. This ceremony was held in a brilliantly lit and high domed Durbar Hall at the Government House.


Read more about what happened on the first Republic Day here.

A HT photo shows India’s first president Dr Rajendra Prasad in a chariot at the Parliament Street.


First Param Vir Chakra

“The enemy is only 50 yards from us. We are heavily outnumbered. We are under devastating fire. I shall not withdraw an inch but will fight to the last man and the last round.”

That was Major Somnath Sharma’s last message to brigade headquarters in November 1947.

Shortly afterwards, the young officer was killed while leading his men on a fighting patrol to Badgam village in Kashmir while evicting Pakistani raiders from Srinagar airport.

For his exceptional bravery under duress, the native of Dadh village in Himachal Pradesh was posthumously awarded the country’s first Param Vir Chakra, India’s highest gallantry award.

Here is a news item published on 27th January 1950 about the award.


Read more about the Martyr’s village here.

A set of eight photos published on 27th January 1950 depict how the national capital celebrated the first Republic Day.


Another set of eight photos show well lit fountains and clock towers in Delhi on the night of the first Republic Day.
summary: On the occasion of India’s 67th Republic Day, Hindustan Times highlighted major headlines from before and after January 26, 1950. The coverage included the last session of the constituent assembly, India’s first president Dr Rajendra Prasad’s swearing-in, and the arrival of Indonesia’s president Sukarno as the first chief guest for Republic Day celebrations. The coverage also featured the first Param Vir Chakra awarded to Major Somnath Sharma and the celebrations in Delhi on the night of the first Republic Day.

headline: Synthetic Drug May Help Cure Some Arthritis
article:
The statement suggests that a synthetic drug shows potential for treating certain types of arthritis. Arthritis is a group of inflammatory joint diseases that cause pain, swelling, and stiffness, affecting millions of people worldwide. Traditional treatments often include pain relievers, anti-inflammatory drugs, and disease-modifying medications, but they may not always be effective for all patients or may come with side effects.

The synthetic drug being studied offers a promising alternative. Developed through scientific research, this drug is designed to target specific pathways involved in the inflammatory response associated with arthritis. By modulating these pathways, the drug aims to reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms associated with arthritis.

Clinical trials and studies are likely underway to assess the safety and efficacy of the synthetic drug in treating arthritis. If successful, this drug could provide a much-needed treatment option for individuals with arthritis, offering relief from pain and improving quality of life.

Overall, the development of synthetic drugs for arthritis represents a significant advancement in medical research and could potentially revolutionize the treatment of this debilitating condition. However, further research and clinical trials are needed to fully understand the drug's effectiveness and safety profile before it can be widely used as a treatment for arthritis.
summary: A synthetic drug is under investigation for its potential to treat certain forms of arthritis, offering a promising alternative to traditional therapies. Arthritis, characterized by joint inflammation and pain, affects millions globally, necessitating effective treatment options. Developed through scientific research, this drug targets specific inflammatory pathways implicated in arthritis pathogenesis. By modulating these pathways, the drug aims to mitigate inflammation and alleviate associated symptoms. Clinical trials and studies are likely underway to assess the drug's safety and efficacy in arthritis management. If successful, the drug could offer relief to individuals with arthritis, enhancing their quality of life and providing an alternative to existing treatments. This development signifies a significant advancement in medical research, potentially revolutionizing arthritis treatment approaches. However, further research is essential to comprehensively understand the drug's effectiveness and safety profile before widespread clinical use. Overall, the investigation into synthetic drugs for arthritis underscores ongoing efforts to address unmet medical needs and improve patient outcomes in inflammatory joint diseases.

headline: How India observed its first Republic Day
article:
On January 26, 1950, the Republic of India was born. More than two years after Independence, and after nearly a century of nationalist struggle, India was finally a sovereign, democratic republic, free to chart its own course into the future.
On the eve of the 75th Republic Day, we remember the chilly January morning in 1950 when India became a republic.

Dominion to republic
Although British rule in India ended on August 15, 1947, India was yet to sever all ties with the Empire. For over two years after Independence, India remained a British dominion, governed by the British-era Government of India Act of 1935, and officially still owing allegiance to the Crown.
All this changed on January 26, 1950. On that day, the newly drafted Constitution of India came into effect, replacing the Act of 1935 as the supreme governing document of the country. Dr Rajendra Prasad began his first term as the President of India, replacing the British monarch as the ceremonial head of the state.

And finally, the Constituent Assembly, which had drafted the constitution over a period of roughly three years, became the Parliament of India until the first general elections would take place in 1951-52.

A ceremonial parade
Military parades are symbolic expressions of state authority and prestige. During the British Raj, royal parades and processions were common occurrences, projecting colonial power to Indians and the world.

The new republic decided to continue with this tradition — and reclaim it for Indians. Thus, since 1950, Republic Day celebrations have been headlined by a military parade in New Delhi, which has become ever grander and more spectacular over the years.
summary: On January 26, 1950, India transitioned from a British dominion to a sovereign democratic republic with the implementation of its newly drafted Constitution, replacing colonial governance with indigenous authority. Dr. Rajendra Prasad became the first President of India, marking the ceremonial shift from British monarchy. The Constituent Assembly transformed into the Parliament until general elections were held in 1951-52. Continuing the tradition of military parades, Republic Day celebrations commenced, symbolizing Indian authority and reclaiming a colonial symbol for national pride.

headline: When India became a republic: Front page of The Indian Express (January 28, 1950)
article:
When India became a republic: Front page of The Indian Express (January 28, 1950)

The Indian Express - January 28, 1950 - India becomes a Republic

There’s a difference in knowing from a history book and learning via a historical source. Accounts from a time when an historical event happened and later day interpretations by historians have a different flavour and a blend of both is necessary.

Most of us know about January 26, 1950 (and many don’t), but for me the knowledge was mostly through history books. Reading a newspaper account of the events of India’s first Republic Day revealed many dimensions of the day that I was never aware of.

I had read and heard accounts of what the Indian communists did during the 1962 Indo-China War, but wasn’t aware that the commies were also opposed to the idea of India becoming a republic (I wasn’t a history student for long). Discovered this through a news item on violent anti-Republic Day demonstrations by the communists in different parts of the country, on the front page of the January 28, 1950 edition of The Indian Express, Madras.

Also that one BG Keshkar attempted to assassinate the Nizam of Hyderabad the same day.

But what is more captivating is the account of the Republic Day events, as described in the newspaper (January 26, 1950 was a national holiday so there was no Indian Express dated January 27, 1950 and therefore the accounts of the Republic Day were published on the January 28, 1950 edition).

INDIA PROCLAIMED SOVEREIGN DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC

RAJENDRA PRASAD SWORN IN AS PRESIDENT

Proclamation Read Out By Retiring Governor-General

NEW DELHI, Jan. 26.
The birth of the Indian sovereign democratic Republic was proclaimed at 10-18 this morning by the country’s last Governor-General Mr. Chakravarti Rajagopalachari at the Durbar Hall at Government House in the capital and the Republic’s first President Dr. Rajendra Prasad took the oath of office to the boom of a salute of 31 guns at a most brilliant ceremony.

Until 1976, India was constitutionally described only as a “sovereign democratic Republic,” the words “socialist” and “secular” were added by the 42nd Constitutional amendment in 1976. The Government House is what we now knows as the Rashtrapati Bhawan.

The language of news journalism has changed so much over decades. Back then, when there was no 24×7 television news, the language of print was more visual than analytical. Read and you can feel being transported to an India six decades ago.

Front page of The Indian Express, Madras on January 28, 1950
summary: The article discusses the unique perspective gained by reading a newspaper account from January 28, 1950, about India's transition to a republic. The author highlights lesser-known aspects, such as the opposition to the republic by Indian communists, evidenced by violent demonstrations on Republic Day. The newspaper also reported an attempted assassination of the Nizam of Hyderabad on the same day. The main focus is on the detailed account of the Republic Day events, including the proclamation of India as a sovereign democratic republic by the last Governor-General, Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, and the swearing-in of the first President, Dr. Rajendra Prasad. The historical significance is underscored by noting that until 1976, India was constitutionally described as a "sovereign democratic Republic," with the terms "socialist" and "secular" added later. The article reflects on the evolving language of news journalism and the vivid description that transports readers to India's historical moment six decades ago.

headline: India goes gay on Republic Day
article: Unforgettable scenes of enthusiasm and rejoicing marked the beginning of a new era in the history of India yesterday when the Republic of India was born with the swearing in of Dr Rajendra Prasad as its first President. The glittering ceremony in the Durbar Hall of Government House, the excitement of hundreds of thousands of people lining the five-mile route through which the President drove in State and the spectacularly colourfull parade at Irwin Stadium where the President hoisted the National Flag and took the Republic salute will remain in people’s memory for long. It was the people’s day, and they left no one in doubt about it. They crowded the streets, roofs and all available vantage points all along the route right from Government House to Irwin Stadium. Even though they could not watch the President, the Prime Minister and the Cabinet Ministers being sworn in they associated themselves with the ceremony by rushing into the forecourt of Government House and expressing their joy at the inauguration of the Republic. The swearing-in ceremony at Government House and the accompanying functions were most impressive. They took about two hours and went off exactly as planned. The audience in the Durbar Hall felt thrilled first when Rajaji read out the Proclamation establishing the Republic and next when the President took the oath of office in the national language and also made his brief speech first in Hindi and then in English. (Details of this function are published elsewhere in this issue.)While crowds were awaiting expectantly, the President in white cap, black achkan and white pyjamas, stepped down the Durbar Hall steps to the State Coach accompanied by his Private Secretary, his Military Secretary, and two picturesquely dressed A.D.C.s. The 35-year-old coach specially renovated for the occasion, bearing the new State emblem of Asoka’s Capitol, and drawn by six sturdy Australian valours had already pulled up at the foot of the steps. The trappings of its saddlery had also been changed from crowns to Asoka Capitols. As Dr Rajendra Prasad stepped into the coach and the two A.D.C.s took their seats facing him there were shouts of joy and crowds once again made a rush through the cordons. The Coach drove out of Government House at a slow trot escorted by the President’s Body Guards.
summary: The swearing-in ceremony of Dr. Rajendra Prasad as the first President of the Republic of India marked a momentous occasion filled with enthusiasm and jubilation. The glittering ceremony at the Durbar Hall of Government House, followed by a grand parade at Irwin Stadium where the President hoisted the National Flag, left an indelible impression on the people's memory. Hundreds of thousands of people lined the five-mile route, eagerly awaiting the President's procession. Although many couldn't witness the swearing-in ceremony, they expressed their joy by crowding the streets and rooftops along the route. The ceremony proceeded smoothly as planned, with Dr. Rajendra Prasad taking the oath of office in the national language, followed by a brief speech in Hindi and English. Dressed in white attire, he stepped into the specially renovated State Coach, adorned with the new State emblem, Asoka's Capitol. The coach, drawn by six sturdy Australian valours, proceeded slowly escorted by the President's Body Guards, amidst shouts of joy from the crowd. Overall, the inauguration of the Republic of India was a historic and unforgettable event, symbolizing the dawn of a new era in the country's history.

headline: India goes gay on Republic Day
article:
Unforgettable scenes of enthusiasm and rejoicing marked the beginning of a new era in the history of India yesterday when the Republic of India was born with the swearing in of Dr Rajendra Prasad as its first President. The glittering ceremony in the Durbar Hall of Government House, the excitement of hundreds of thousands of people lining the five-mile route through which the President drove in State and the spectacularly colourful parade at Irwin Stadium where the President hoisted the National Flag and took the Republic salute will remain in people’s memory for long. It was the people’s day, and they left no one in doubt about it. They crowded the streets, roofs and all available vantage points all along the route right from Government House to Irwin Stadium. Even though they could not watch the President, the Prime Minister and the Cabinet Ministers being sworn in they associated themselves with the ceremony by rushing into the forecourt of Government House and expressing their joy at the inauguration of the Republic. The swearing-in ceremony at Government House and the accompanying functions were most impressive. They took about two hours and went off exactly as planned. The audience in the Durbar Hall felt thrilled first when Rajaji read out the Proclamation establishing the Republic and next when the President took the oath of office in the national language and also made his brief speech first in Hindi and then in English. (Details of this function are published elsewhere in this issue.) While crowds were awaiting expectantly, the President in white cap, black achkan and white pyjamas, stepped down the Durbar Hall steps to the State Coach accompanied by his Private Secretary, his Military Secretary, and two picturesquely dressed A.D.C.s. The 35-year-old coach specially renovated for the occasion, bearing the new State emblem of Asoka’s Capitol, and drawn by six sturdy Australian valours had already pulled up at the foot of the steps. The trappings of its saddlery had also been changed from crowns to Asoka Capitols. As Dr Rajendra Prasad stepped into the coach and the two A.D.C.s took their seats facing him there were shouts of joy and crowds once again made a rush through the cordons. The Coach drove out of Government House at a slow trot escorted by the President’s Body Guards. All along the route the President was welcomed by shouts of joy. The President responded to the greetings of the people by bowing to them with folded hands. The drive, which began exactly at 2:30 p.m., ended exactly at 3:45 p.m. at Irwin Stadium where 3,000 officers and men of the three Services and the police with massed bands had taken position for a ceremonial parade. The Stadium was packed with visitors, with National Flags and the new flags of the Services fluttering all around the Stadium, it presented a site of splendour, the colourfulness of the scene being heightened by the drab walls of the historic Purana Qila in the background.

FANFARE OF TRUMPETS

A fanfare of trumpet announced the arrival of the President and there was loud cheering as he stepped down from the coach, and was received by the Defence Minister, Sardar Balder Singh. The three Service Chiefs were then presented to the President, who accompanied by the Defence Minister and the Service Chiefs, went to the Saluting Base. The parade gave the national salute to the President, the National Flag was broken at mast and while the whole assembly stood massed bands played the National Anthem. A brightly-painted jeep took the President and the Commander of the Parade. Brig. Dhillon, round the units on parade. The inspection over, the President returned to the base of the dais and a salute of 31 guns was fired in three instalments. In between the parade fired a fes-de-joie thrice. The most exciting moment came when the parade gave the President three jais while a flight of I.A.F. Liberators roared past over the Stadium.

The march-past now began and the admiring crowds cheered each unit as it crossed the base. It was a smart turn-out and among those who received specially loud cheers were the Air Force, the Gurkhas and the boys of the Punjab Regiment. The massed bands were the last to march past and were cheered equally loudly. On the President’s departure from the Parade Ground there was another sound of trumpets and one of the most impressive ceremonies seen in years came to an end. The President drove from Irwin Stadium to Government House at 4:30 p.m. The crowds had swelled the route through Kingsway and they cheered the President all along.

Historic in its significance, it was an unforgettable day. It was a day of joy and the ruminations all over the Capital at night showed how happily and enthusiastically the people welcomed the advent of the Republic.

P.T.I. reports: A spectacular parade of the Defence Services climaxed the five-mile-long Presidential procession. Twenty thousand spectators, including President Soekarno of Indonesia, Pandit Nehru, the Deputy Prime Minister, Sardar Patel, and other Cabinet Ministers, members of the diplomatic corps, members of Parliament and men, and women and children from all walks of life watched the President take the National Salute. Tricolours, a huge Asoka capitol placed in the main stadium, the flags of the three Services, the multicoloured berets, caps, turbans and buckles, the gorgeous costumes of the massed bandsmen, the picturesque uniforms of the President’s Bodyguard escorting the President’s coach-and-six, the saffron and red decorations--everything contributed to a feast of colour and pageantry befitting the first ceremonial parade held in the capital of the new Republic.

A tremendous cheer went up as they sighted the President’s coach, drawn by six chestnut horses and escorted by his mounted Bodyguard in scarlet tunics and a detachment of the Gwalior Lancers. Liveried footmen held aloft a red and gold umbrella. A fanfare of trumpets heralded his arrival. Dr Rajendra Prasad, wearing black achkan and churiders and Gandhi cap, bowed smilingly in acknowledgment of the cheers of the multitude. The parade-the Navy as the seniormost Service formed to the left, the Army in ochre green in the centre and the Air Force, boys of the Punjab Regiment and the police to the right then gave the President the National Salute, which replaced the old Royal salute. The National Flag was broken at half-mast and massed bands played Rabindranath Tagore’s Jana Gana Mana.

Conducted by the Officer Commanding the parade, Brig. J. S. Dhillon, Dr Prasad then inspected the parade from a green-painted jeep flying the Presidents Flag.

As the President returned to the dais 31 guns boomed and the men assembled in parade cracked their rifles thrice, firing feu-de-joie. each volley followed by the National Anthem. The parade gave the President three vigorous jais as the artillery smoke hid the view for the spectators perched precariously on top of the crumbling walls of the Purana Qila.
summary: The Republic of India was inaugurated with great enthusiasm and celebration as Dr. Rajendra Prasad was sworn in as its first President. The event, which took place at Government House and Irwin Stadium, witnessed a spectacular parade and drew crowds of hundreds of thousands. The President's procession through the streets was met with joyous cheers from the people. The ceremony featured impressive moments, including the Proclamation reading, the President taking the oath in the national language, and the parade saluting the President. The day was marked by colorful displays, fanfare, and a festive atmosphere. It was a historic and unforgettable occasion, celebrating India's transition to a republic.

headline: MPs pledge allegiance to new Constitution
article:
New Delhi- Though without any spectacular ceremonial, the opening of the first Parliament of the sovereign Democratic Republic of India this morning was impressively solemn. Members were in a happy mood and excitedly cheered the Prime Minister and other Ministers as they pledged allegiance to the Constitution the keynote, however, was simplicity.The House, in spite of the predominance of familiar faces, presented a new appearance. Members were dressed soberly, but with obvious care. There were warm hand-shakings and even affectionate embraces as M.P.s met one another. A new woman member was warmly welcomed by Shrimati Amrit Kaur.

“Freshers” in the House went about paying their respects to the “elders,” including some Ministers and the Congress President. The silvery beard of Babu Ram Narain Singh, a feature acquired by him since the last session, and the lounge suit of the usually dhoti-clad Mr. Ram Narain Goenka were noticed as novelties.When the Speaker’s arrival was announced there was an excited hush. Ministers hurriedly stepped to their seats. Maulana Azad, who had arrived simultaneously with the Speaker, must have been embarrassed while going to his seat as the House stood. The Prime Minister was not in his seat when Mr. Mavlankar sat down after bowing to all sides of the House.

Before the Speaker could open the proceedings Mr. B. Das shouted Bande Matram and the House repeated the salutation after him. Mr. Balkrishna Sharma used his bass voice to lead the House in shouting Mahatma Gandhi Ki Jai. Though not in the programme these expressions of the members’ joy and gratitude provided a fitting start for the proceedings.

The Speaker next called upon the House to stand in silence for two minutes. It was, he said, fit and proper that the first Parliament of the Republic should begin with two minutes of prayerful silence. The members and along with them the visitors in the galleries stood up and there was complete silence for two minutes.
summary: The first Parliament of India opened today in New Delhi. The atmosphere was somber but also hopeful, as members pledged allegiance to the Constitution. The House presented a new appearance, with members dressed soberly and excited to be part of this historic event. The Speaker opened the proceedings by calling for two minutes of silence, and the members stood in respect.

headline: Judiciary’s vital role in nation’s progress
article:
New Delhi- After the ushering in, on Thursday, of the sovereign Republic of India, the people’s highest court in the land under the new democratic Constitution - the Supreme Court opened today for its inaugural sitting in its high oak-panelled, semicircular chamber in Parliament House.


The occasion was solemn and dignified, as befits the legal luminaries and among those assembled were Ambassadors and Ministers of various countries, the Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Minister and other Cabinet Ministers, Chief Justices and Advocates-General of the various States of the Indian Union, and eminent jurists and parliamentarians.

Above the seats of the six Judges of the Supreme Court, near the ceiling where the Royal British insignia was mounted on the wall a huge Tricolour was stretched hiding the emblem from view.

The replica of the Court’s seal, the Asoka Chakra -in gold on a red background, was set on the wall behind the Judges’ seats with the inscription “Satyameva Jayate” in Sanskrit.

The Chief Justice, Mr. Harilal Kania wearing his striking deep-red Peshwa cap, pledged that the Supreme Court “will stand firm and aloof from party politics and political theories.”“It is unconcerned,” he added “with the changes in the Government. The Court stands to administer the law which is in force, has goodwill and sympathy for all, but is allied to none.”
summary: The Supreme Court of the newly established Republic of India held its inaugural sitting in Parliament House in New Delhi. The ceremony was dignified, with the presence of legal luminaries, ambassadors, ministers, and other dignitaries. The six Judges of the Supreme Court took their seats beneath a large Tricolour, replacing the Royal British insignia. The court's seal, featuring the Asoka Chakra in gold on a red background with the inscription "Satyameva Jayate" in Sanskrit, adorned the wall. Chief Justice Harilal Kania, wearing a deep-red Peshwa cap, pledged that the Supreme Court would remain aloof from party politics and political theories, focusing on administering the law with goodwill and sympathy for all.
