headline: July 17, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Rao In Moscow
article: Pakistan figured prominently in the two rounds of talks between External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao and the Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko with both countries expressing their common concern over the arming of Pakistan by the US. The two foreign ministers shared the view that the large-scale supply of arms to Islamabad would lead to instability in South Asia. Rao declined to disclose the details of the talks over China. The Indian foreign minister confirmed that he had delivered a message from Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to his Russian counterpart. He said that the question of Mrs Gandhi’s visit to Moscow was not discussed. Gromyko said that the discussions had helped the two countries understand each other’s viewpoint on international affairs
summary:
Summary:
Pakistan featured prominently in two rounds of talks between India's External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko, where both countries expressed concerns about the US arming Pakistan. Both ministers agreed that excessive arms supply to Pakistan could lead to instability in South Asia. Rao refrained from disclosing details about discussions concerning China. However, he confirmed delivering a message from Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to his Russian counterpart, without discussing Gandhi's potential visit to Moscow. Gromyko remarked that the discussions facilitated a better understanding of each other's perspectives on international affairs.

headline: July 19, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Bus mishap in Jaipur
article: Forty-five persons were drowned when a bus was swept by the flooded about 30 km from Jaipur. Unprecedented rainfall has claimed 18 more lives in other parts of the state. The ill-fated Rajasthan Road Transport Corporation bus carrying 65 passengers was washed away by the swirling waters of the Bandi river on the Jaipur-Phagi road. The bus was traveling from Kekri in Ajmer district to Jaipur. Chief Minister Shiv Charan Mathur has announced a cash relief of Rs 5,000 for the families of the victims. This is the biggest accident in the history of the Corporation which has announced a cash relief of Rs 1,000 for the victims’ families.
summary:
Summary:
Tragedy struck as forty-five individuals drowned when a bus was swept away by floodwaters approximately 30 km from Jaipur. Unprecedented rainfall also resulted in the loss of 18 lives in other areas of the state. The Rajasthan Road Transport Corporation bus, carrying 65 passengers from Kekri in Ajmer district to Jaipur, was engulfed by the swollen Bandi river on the Jaipur-Phagi road. Chief Minister Shiv Charan Mathur announced a cash relief of Rs 5,000 for the families of the victims, marking it as the biggest accident in the history of the Corporation, which also declared a cash relief of Rs 1,000 for the victims' families

headline: August 2, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Flood Woes
article: Floods in the major rivers of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar had by the night of August 1 engulfed 37 districts in the two states, while in Assam the deluge compelled the authorities to seek the help of the army in Dibrugarh subdivision for relief and rescue work. According to official reports, about 9.3 million people were in distress in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar caused by heavy rains and floods which have destroyed crops, flattened or washed away houses and breached roads. The Army was called out to assist the civil authorities in Telpani area of the Dibrugarh subdivision. The surging waters of the Buridihing washed away 200 metres of the embankment on July 31.
summary:
Summary:
Severe floods hit multiple districts in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, affecting 37 districts in total by August 1. In Assam, the situation compelled authorities to seek army assistance in Dibrugarh subdivision for relief and rescue efforts. Heavy rains and floods caused distress to approximately 9.3 million people in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, resulting in crop destruction, damage to homes, and road breaches. The army was deployed to aid civil authorities in the Telpani area of Dibrugarh subdivision after the Buridihing River washed away a significant portion of the embankment on July 31.

headline: August 4, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Progress on Assam
article: The Centre and the Assam agitation leaders had made substantial progress towards a solution of the foreign nationals’ issue as they adjourned their two-day informal talks in Shillong. The venue of the next round is yet to be decided. The date will be finalised at the next meeting of the AASU-AAGSP executive committees. However, the agitation leadership has decided to go ahead with the programme of resuming the agitation beginning with a protest day on August 13, followed by a bandh in the state on August 14. The government is willing to advance the cut-off year from the proposed 1967 to 1966 to facilitate a settlement of the foreign nationals’ issue.
summary:
Summary:
Substantial progress was made between the Centre and Assam agitation leaders regarding the foreign nationals' issue during their two-day informal talks in Shillong. The venue for the next round of talks is yet to be determined, with the date to be finalized at the next meeting of the AASU-AAGSP executive committees. Despite this progress, the agitation leadership has decided to proceed with their planned agitation, starting with a protest day on August 13, followed by a state-wide bandh on August 14. The government has shown willingness to advance the proposed cut-off year from 1967 to 1966 in order to facilitate a resolution of the foreign nationals' issue.

headline: August 7, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Sanjay Crash Probe
article: An unintentional spin and delay in initiation of recovery action was the probable cause of the crash of the Pitts aircraft in which Sanjay Gandhi and his co-pilot died last year. This is the finding of the departmental inquiry by the inspector of accident, after a nearly a year-long investigation. An official announcement of the acceptance of the findings of the report and a summary of its finding was made on August 6. Lack of experience and confusion between the two copilots as to who would handle the situation caused by the entry of the aircraft “into an unintentional spin”
summary:
Summary:
The crash of the Pitts aircraft, resulting in the deaths of Sanjay Gandhi and his co-pilot, was likely caused by an unintentional spin and delay in recovery action. This conclusion was reached after a nearly year-long investigation conducted by the inspector of accident through a departmental inquiry. The findings were officially accepted and announced on August 6. Lack of experience and confusion between the co-pilots regarding handling the situation contributed to the crash

headline: August 10, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Bureaucrats Moved
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has carried out a major reshuffle of secretaries in her government. At least three senior secretaries have been reverted to other states. Twelve other ministries will have new secretaries. The government has decided to appoint T N Chaturvedi as Home Secretary. He will succeed S M H Burney who will take over as Governor of Nagaland and Manipur. Chaturvedi is Education secretary at present. The new commerce secretary will be Abid Hussain now with the Asian Development Bank. The government will have IAS officers as secretaries for the first time. They will be Anna George Malhotra who will be education secretary and Sarla Grewal, the social welfare secretary.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has conducted a significant reshuffle of secretaries within her government, with three senior secretaries being reassigned to other states and twelve ministries receiving new secretaries. T.N. Chaturvedi has been appointed as the new Home Secretary, succeeding S.M.H. Burney who will become the Governor of Nagaland and Manipur. Chaturvedi, currently serving as the Education Secretary, will be replaced by Abid Hussain, who is currently with the Asian Development Bank. Notably, for the first time, the government will appoint IAS officers as secretaries, including Anna George Malhotra as the Education Secretary and Sarla Grewal as the Social Welfare Secretary.

headline: August 16, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM’s Warning
article: The Prime Minister has warned that measures would be taken to curb anti-social and anti-national practices like hoarding, profiteering and black marketing. Speaking on the 54th anniversary of Independence, Mrs Gandhi asserted that the people asked for stern measures against anti-social elements but when such measures were introduced, some others came out protesting against them. Nevertheless, the government was determined to deal strictly with anti-social elements. “We have a good harvest at the moment,” Mrs Gandhi said and went on to pose the question, why there should be food imports. Imports had been ordered to counteract the moves of those who were planning to hoard stocks to jack up prices
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi warned against anti-social and anti-national practices like hoarding, profiteering, and black marketing on the 54th anniversary of Independence. She expressed determination to take stern measures against such elements, despite protests. Gandhi questioned the need for food imports, citing a good harvest, and suggested that imports were ordered to counteract hoarding aimed at inflating prices.

headline: August 17, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Bitter fight ahead
article: On the eve of the Monsoon Session of Parliament, the government and Opposition appeared all set for a confrontation over the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance promulgated last month. While Prime Minister Indira Gandhi warned the Congress (I) Parliamentary Party meeting of a stormy session ahead, Opposition leaders got together in a hurry to chalk out a floor coordination programme to oppose tooth and nail the government on the utter failure on the price front. A symposium on television, “Issues before Parliament” also gave an indication of things to come when the tone and tenor of the spokesperson of the two sides made it abundantly clear that there would be a bitter fight over these issues. Leaders of major communist and non-communist parties met on August 16 and decided to mount a united attack on the government.
summary:
Summary:
On the eve of the Monsoon Session of Parliament, tensions escalated between the government and the Opposition over the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance recently promulgated. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi cautioned of a stormy session ahead at a Congress (I) Parliamentary Party meeting, while Opposition leaders hastily coordinated to oppose the government on the price front. A symposium on television titled "Issues before Parliament" foreshadowed a bitter confrontation, as spokespersons from both sides indicated a fierce battle over these contentious issues. Leaders from major communist and non-communist parties convened on August 16, agreeing to mount a united attack on the government

headline: August 18, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Lanka violence
article: President J R Jayewardene on August 17 declared an island-wide emergency in Sri Lanka following a spate of violence, looting and arson in the last 10 days. Earlier the police reported to the President that there have been seven deaths because of violence, 196 incidents of arson, 35 incidents of looting and 15 incidents of robbery. Unofficial figures are much higher. The incidents have been reported from parts of the country with Tamils being the worst affected, a spokesperson of the Tamil United Liberation Front said. Under the emergency, the government has special powers to deal with the situation. There has been no announcement of curfew, but a government spokesperson said that the police could impose curfew in troubled areas.
summary:
Summary:
President J.R. Jayewardene declared an island-wide emergency in Sri Lanka on August 17 due to a surge in violence, looting, and arson over the past 10 days. Official reports cited seven deaths, 196 arson incidents, 35 instances of looting, and 15 robberies, though unofficial figures are believed to be higher. The violence has primarily affected Tamils, according to a spokesperson from the Tamil United Liberation Front. The emergency grants the government special powers to address the situation, including the authority for police to impose curfews in troubled areas

headline: August 21, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Poll Reforms Rejected
article: After a tumultuous five-hour debate, marked by pandemonium and acrimony, the Lok Sabha on August 20 rejected by a voice vote a motion moved by Madhu Dandavate (Janata) calling for urgent poll reforms to make elections free of shortcomings. While the fate of the motion was more or less a foregone conclusion, the intensity displayed by most of the speakers took everyone by surprise. Towards the end, it assumed shocking dimensions when a Congress (I) member Bhagwan Dev tore up certain photographs of the Garhwal poll tabled by Harkesh Bahadur of the DSF. For 10 minutes, total pandemonium prevailed in the House with members from both sides converging on the central table and the photographs strewn on the carpet.
summary:
Summary:
The Lok Sabha on August 20 rejected a motion by Madhu Dandavate (Janata) calling for urgent poll reforms to ensure fair elections after a tumultuous five-hour debate marked by chaos and bitterness. While the motion's defeat was expected, the passion exhibited by most speakers surprised many. Tensions escalated when Congress (I) member Bhagwan Dev tore up photographs of the Garhwal poll tabled by Harkesh Bahadur of the DSF, leading to ten minutes of total chaos in the House with members from both sides converging on the central table and the torn photographs scattered on the floor.

headline: August 23, 1981, Forty Years Ago: J&K Non-cooperation
article: Jammu and Kashmir’s ruling party, National Conference, has pledged “to seek non-cooperation on Central laws that are detrimental to the interests of the state’s autonomy”. The second day’s session of the three-day annual meet of the party presided over by Farooq Abdullah, at which the Chief Minister Sheikh Abdullah was present, called upon all sections of “patriotic opinion” in the state to affirm their faith in the basic requirements “of building our state to accord it the distinct place of honour due to it”. A resolution passed by a voice vote of over 4,000 delegates said that the post-1975 story of Jammu and Kashmir was one of ending the politics of drift and lack of direction and more significantly, putting an end to any further encroachment of the state’s “right to be ruled by its own constitution”
summary:
Summary:
During the three-day annual meeting of the National Conference in Jammu and Kashmir, the ruling party pledged to resist Central laws that threaten the state's autonomy. Led by Farooq Abdullah and attended by Chief Minister Sheikh Abdullah, the party urged all patriotic voices in the state to support efforts to uphold its distinct identity. A resolution passed by over 4,000 delegates emphasized the need to end the era of political indecision and prevent further encroachment on the state's constitutional rights.

headline: August 24, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Assam stalemate
article: The talks between the Assam agitators and the government on the foreigners’ issue were adjourned for a week on August 23. The next round of talks will be held in Delhi. The four agitation leaders who participated in the talks will fly back to Gauhati to report to the All Assam Students Union and the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad executives. This was the 13th round of talks between the two sides. The main obstacle seems to be that the government wants to keep some of the entrants to the state in the period between 1961 and 1971 due to the commitments made earlier. The stand of the agitators is that all of them should be dispersed.
summary:
Summary:
Talks between the Assam agitators and the government regarding the foreigners' issue were adjourned for a week on August 23, with the next round scheduled to take place in Delhi. The four agitation leaders involved in the talks will return to Gauhati to brief the executives of the All Assam Students Union and the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad. This marked the 13th round of discussions between the two sides. The main point of contention revolves around the government's desire to retain some individuals who entered the state between 1961 and 1971, citing previous commitments. However, the agitators insist on the dispersal of all such entrants

headline: August 25, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Urs offers to quit
article: Congress (U) president Devraj Urs bowed to the wishes of a powerful section of the party leadership when he offered his resignation at a meeting of the working committee. The committee has, however, put off a decision on Urs’s offer for a day. Though the anti-Urs lobby in the working committee is in favour of electing an acting president, a section of the party leadership would want Urs to continue until the next AICC(U) meet in October. Urs, who had sensed the mood of many members, took them by surprise by his offer. He read out a statement in which he said that there was a feeling in the party that he should step down.
summary:
Summary:
Congress (U) president Devraj Urs, yielding to pressure from a significant faction of the party leadership, tendered his resignation during a meeting of the working committee. However, the committee deferred a decision on Urs's resignation for a day. While some members of the working committee advocate electing an acting president, others prefer Urs to remain in office until the next AICC(U) meeting in October. Urs surprised many by offering his resignation, citing a perceived sentiment within the party for him to step down.

headline: August 26, 1981, Forty Years Ago: DA Uncertain
article: Union finance minister R Venkataraman refused to give a firm commitment on the payment of instalment of dear allowance due to Central government employees. Replying to a question in the Rajya Sabha, he said that the government has been making payments of DA as a matter of policy. It’s not a contractual obligation. Therefore, there is no question of automatic payment whenever there was a rise in the cost of the living index. The question was tabled by Dharamchand Jain. Replying to supplementary questions, the finance minister said that the state of finances will have to be taken into consideration. The government has paid DA up to February, this year. Kalyansundaram of the CPI said DA was linked to cost of living index and not to government revenue or budget proposals.
summary:
Summary:
Union Finance Minister R. Venkataraman declined to commit to the payment of the next installment of Dearness Allowance (DA) owed to Central government employees during a session in the Rajya Sabha. He clarified that while the government has traditionally made DA payments as a policy, it's not a contractual obligation and isn't automatically guaranteed with rises in the cost of living index. The response came during questioning by Dharamchand Jain. Addressing supplementary queries, the minister emphasized the need to consider the state of finances. He noted that DA had been paid up to February of the current year. Kalyansundaram of the CPI argued that DA should be linked to the cost of living index rather than government revenue or budget proposals.

headline: August 27, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Mirage Deal
article: France is expected to sign a deal with India for the supply of the latest version of the multipurpose Mirage jets, according to French sources. When the negotiations are completed, India, will, for the present, receive 150 aircraft of which 40 will be built in France, 65 in India, and 45 partly in France and India. The value of the contract is not known. But the Times of London has said that preliminary arrangements had been made, running into about 900 million pounds. The mode of payment is yet to be negotiated. A draft of the agreement will be drawn when an Indian military mission visits Paris next month. The final agreement may be signed within two months.
summary:
Summary:
France is poised to finalize a deal with India for the supply of the latest version of multipurpose Mirage jets, as per French sources. Under the anticipated agreement, India is set to receive 150 aircraft, with 40 to be manufactured in France, 65 in India, and 45 jointly in both countries. Although the contract's value remains undisclosed, preliminary arrangements, estimated at around 900 million pounds, have been reported by The Times of London. The mode of payment is yet to be determined, with a draft agreement expected to be crafted during an upcoming Indian military mission to Paris. The final agreement may be signed within two months.

headline: August 28, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Import Policy
article: The policy of importing essential commodities came under attack by Opposition members in Rajya Sabha on August 27. But Finance Minister R Venkataraman was firm in saying that imports were necessary to augment supplies, check prices and build buffer stocks. He, however, agreed with members that self-reliance was necessary. He was replying to a four-hour discussion on the price situation and the steps taken by the government. Congress (I) members held the previous government of Morarji Desai and Charan Singh responsible for the rising prices. One of the members, however, said the government had no right to freeze wages if it could not hold the price line. The Opposition members emphasised the need for taking strong measures to curb black marketeers, hoarders and speculators. They thought the government was not doing enough.
summary:
Summary:
In the Rajya Sabha on August 27, the policy of importing essential commodities faced criticism from Opposition members, while Finance Minister R. Venkataraman defended the necessity of imports to bolster supplies, control prices, and establish buffer stocks. Venkataraman acknowledged the importance of self-reliance but maintained the need for imports. Congress (I) members attributed rising prices to the previous governments of Morarji Desai and Charan Singh. Concerns were raised about the government's authority to freeze wages if it failed to control prices. Opposition members stressed the importance of taking stringent actions against black marketeers, hoarders, and speculators, expressing dissatisfaction with the government's efforts in this regard.

headline: August 31, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Tehran bombing
article: A powerful bomb rocked the prime minister’s office in Central Tehran on August 31 wounding the President Mohammad Ali Rajai and the Prime Minister Mohammad Javed Bahonar, the official Iranian media reported. Pars, the official Iranian news agency, reported that at least five persons were killed with some and 15 wounded with some of the bodies burnt beyond recognition. The Iranian cabinet held an “emergency meeting” and adopted certain decisions to cope with the blast’s aftermath and condemned the episode as a “last ditch attempt by American hirelings”. The blast, which sent a fire raging through the building, appeared to be the most serious in Iran since a bomb killed more than 70 of the Iran’s religious and political leaders in Tehran.
summary:
Summary:
On August 31, a powerful bomb exploded in the prime minister's office in Central Tehran, injuring President Mohammad Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammad Javed Bahonar, as reported by official Iranian media. The blast resulted in at least five fatalities and 15 injuries, with some bodies badly burned. Following the incident, the Iranian cabinet convened an emergency meeting and took measures to address the aftermath of the explosion, condemning it as a desperate act by agents of the United States. The explosion, which ignited a fire in the building, was deemed one of the most serious incidents in Iran since a bomb attack that killed over 70 religious and political leaders in Tehran.

headline: September 1, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Scandal rocks House
article: The reported collection of huge sums of money by a chief minister in the name of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi rocked both Houses of Parliament, culminating in a walkout in the Lok Sabha when the Speaker refused to admit an adjournment motion on the the subject. In the Rajya Sabha, the Deputy Chairman, Shyam Lal Yadav, gave an indication that he would allow a call attention motion on Tuesday. For well over 30 minutes, the Opposition in both Houses jointly demanded a detailed discussion on what it termed the “scandal of the century and the detestable attempt to use the prime minister as a “commodity of corruption”. Almost all Opposition members carried copies of The Indian Express, which gave details of the money collected by A R Antulay from business houses and cooperative societies.
summary:
Summary:
Both Houses of Parliament were rocked by allegations of a chief minister collecting large sums of money in the name of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. The Lok Sabha witnessed a walkout when the Speaker refused to allow an adjournment motion on the issue, while in the Rajya Sabha, the Deputy Chairman hinted at permitting a call attention motion. Opposition members in both Houses jointly demanded a detailed discussion on what they termed the "scandal of the century" and a reprehensible attempt to use the prime minister as a "commodity of corruption." Members carried copies of The Indian Express, which provided details of the money collected by A.R. Antulay from business houses and cooperative societies.

headline: September 2, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Uproar Continues
article: Corruption charges against A R Antulay, Chief Minister of Maharashtra, rocked both Houses of Parliament for the second day in succession and shot out the entire Question Hour in the Rajya Sabha on Tuesday. There will be fuller discussions on Wednesday when two Call Attention motions are taken up, but the Opposition fought for 100 minutes in the Rajya Sabha and won its point — that the discussion should begin on Tuesday itself as agreed to on Monday. In the Lok Sabha, an unsuccessful bid was made to get an adjournment motion admitted. Even then, a quarter of question time was blocked. Congress (I) members added fuel to the fire by making charges against Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Charan Singh and George Fernandes. Opposition speakers took serious objection to the distribution of some papers among Congress (I) members by the Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs Sitaram Kesri.
summary:
Summary:
Corruption charges against A.R. Antulay, Chief Minister of Maharashtra, continued to stir controversy in both Houses of Parliament for a second consecutive day, disrupting proceedings. In the Rajya Sabha, the entire Question Hour was lost as the Opposition demanded immediate discussion, leading to a 100-minute debate. The Opposition's insistence on starting discussions on Tuesday was honored, with fuller debates scheduled for Wednesday through Call Attention motions. In the Lok Sabha, attempts to admit an adjournment motion failed, but a quarter of question time was obstructed. Congress (I) members exacerbated tensions by levelling accusations against Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Charan Singh, and George Fernandes. Opposition members criticized the distribution of certain papers to Congress (I) members by Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs Sitaram Kesri.

headline: September 3, 1981, Forty Years Ago: No Probe On Antulay
article: Finance Minister R Venkataraman informed the two houses of Parliament that he had known from a “reliable authority” that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had not inaugurated the Indira Pratibha Pratisthan, a trust formed by A R Antulay for which crores of rupees have been collected from different sources. He rejected the Opposition demand for a high-level probe into the affairs of the trust because no improprieties have been committed by it. Venkataraman denied that the money had been used for party activities. If that happened, he assured the Opposition, the trust would lose all exemptions granted to it by the income tax department. During the discussion in both houses of Parliament the government admitted that government departments had been very efficient in disposing off applications of the trust.
summary:
Summary:
Finance Minister R. Venkataraman informed both houses of Parliament that, based on a "reliable authority," Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had not inaugurated the Indira Pratibha Pratisthan, a trust established by A.R. Antulay, which had collected significant sums from various sources. He dismissed the Opposition's call for a high-level investigation into the trust, asserting that no improprieties had occurred. Venkataraman assured the Opposition that if the funds were used for party activities, the trust would lose its tax exemptions. Additionally, during parliamentary discussions, the government acknowledged the efficiency of government departments in processing applications from the trust.

newspaper_name: September 4, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Debate On Sick Firms
headline: September 4, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Debate On Sick Firms
article: Finance Minister R Venkataraman has indicated that the government might reverse the policy of taking over sick units. He could not understand the philosophy of letting the private sector pocket all profits while the going was good and the government stepping in to take their units when they became sick, the minister told the Lok Sabha. The 250-minute debate, though thinly attended, was one of the calmest in recent days. Speakers were heard in rapt attention and, barring a few, everybody spoke economics rather than politics. The crux of the Opposition’s charge was that the minister was finding refuge behind the maze of statistics, and unless the ruling party changed its basic policy it would not be able to control the spiraling prices.
summary:
Summary:
Finance Minister R. Venkataraman hinted at a potential reversal of the government's policy regarding the takeover of financially troubled units. Speaking in the Lok Sabha, he questioned the rationale behind allowing the private sector to enjoy profits during prosperous times, only for the government to intervene and take over their units when they faltered. Despite being thinly attended, the 250-minute debate was notably calm, with speakers focusing on economics rather than politics. The crux of the Opposition's argument was that the minister relied too heavily on statistics and that a fundamental shift in policy was needed to address escalating prices.

headline: September 6, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM Flags Crisis
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has warned that the country is in a difficult phase economically, politically and militarily and these challenges call for a greater sense of national purpose. The prime minister mentioned this at a meeting of the secretaries to the government and added that the challenge was not just for those in politics but also for those in government as well. Speaking of a “crisis, which is an Indian crisis and an international crisis,” Indira Gandhi said that there was a major attempt to denigrate India at international fora. “It is only when we stand firm that respect for us increases It is wrong to think that when we give in, there will be goodwill for us,” she said. Assuring bureaucrats and civil servants, she said that she did not think all civil servants are bureaucratic.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi cautioned that India is facing significant challenges economically, politically, and militarily, stressing the need for a unified national purpose. Speaking at a meeting of government secretaries, she emphasized that the crisis extended beyond politics to encompass all aspects of governance. Gandhi highlighted both domestic and international pressures on India, warning against conceding ground to denigration. She asserted that standing firm would garner greater respect rather than appeasement. Gandhi reassured bureaucrats and civil servants, expressing her belief that not all civil servants are bureaucratic in nature.

headline: September 8, 1981, Forty Years Ago: FM exonerated
article: The Speaker Balram Jakhar ruled in the Lok Sabha that by informing the House on September 2 that Mrs Gandhi had not inaugurated the Maharashtra Pratibha Pratishthan, the Finance Minister R Venkataraman had not misled the house, and, therefore, had not committed any breach of privilege. Disallowing a number of privilege motions by George Fernandes (LD), Atal Bihari Vajpayee (BJP), Jyotirmoy Basu (CPM), Maniram Bagri (DSF), and Madhu Dandavate (Janata Dal), Jakhar said that he had accepted Venkataraman’s explanation that the photograph published in various newspapers and submitted as documentary evidence by the Opposition was of the PM signing a document bearing the caption Pratibha Pratishthan Maharashtra, and not the Indira Pratibha Pratishthan. The fact that several newspapers and publications had given a wrong caption cannot alter the fact that the document signed by the PM referred only to Pratibha Pratishthan Maharashtra.
summary:
Summary:
Speaker Balram Jakhar ruled in the Lok Sabha that Finance Minister R. Venkataraman had not misled the House when he stated that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had not inaugurated the Maharashtra Pratibha Pratishthan. Jakhar rejected several privilege motions from various members, including George Fernandes, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Jyotirmoy Basu, Maniram Bagri, and Madhu Dandavate, stating that the photograph submitted by the Opposition depicted the PM signing a document related to Pratibha Pratishthan Maharashtra, not the Indira Pratibha Pratishthan. Jakhar emphasized that the document signed by the PM only referenced Pratibha Pratishthan Maharashtra, despite incorrect captions in newspapers and publications.

headline: September 10, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Antulay Responds
article: The Maharashtra Chief Minister A R Antulay told the Legislative Assembly on August 9 that he had submitted his resignation letter to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi the very day the controversy started over the collection of funds for the Indira Gandhi Pratibha Pratishthan and other trusts. In his 50-minute speech in reply to the five-hour debate on the charges of corruption raised by the Opposition, the CM did not refer to several specific points. He concentrated his attack on the former chief minister Sharad Pawar, the BJP leader Hashu Advani and Mr Goenka (an obvious reference to Ramnath Goenka, Chairman of The Indian Express Newspapers). Referring to the allegations levelled by the Opposition, he said that when they were in power, “their deeds outmatched” his.
summary:
Summary:
Maharashtra Chief Minister A.R. Antulay informed the Legislative Assembly on August 9 that he had tendered his resignation to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on the very day the controversy erupted regarding the collection of funds for the Indira Gandhi Pratibha Pratishthan and other trusts. During his 50-minute address in response to the five-hour debate on corruption charges raised by the Opposition, Antulay did not directly address several specific points but focused his criticism on former Chief Minister Sharad Pawar, BJP leader Hashu Advani, and Mr. Goenka (likely referring to Ramnath Goenka, Chairman of The Indian Express Newspapers). He countered allegations by asserting that the misdeeds of the Opposition during their tenure surpassed his own.

headline: September 14, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Report on riots
article: The report of the three-member judicial commission headed by Jitendra Narain, former judge of the Patna High Court, which probed the April 1979 communal riots in Jamshedpur bristles with strident strictures against the RSS, top district officials and the Bihar Military Police (BMP). Set up on May 15, 979, when the Janata Party was in power, the commission submitted its report to the government on August 31. The two others who served on it are K Ghosh, former chairman of the Tripura Public Service Commission and S Q Rizvi, former IG of police, Bihar. The riot which rocked Jamshedpur on April 11 and 12 took a toll of 108 lives. Releasing the report, Bihar Chief Minister Jagannath Mishra said he would invite the attention of the Union government to the findings of the commission on the activities of the RSS, Jana Sangh (now BJP) and its labour wing, the Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh.
summary:
Summary:
The report of the three-member judicial commission, led by Jitendra Narain, former judge of the Patna High Court, investigating the April 1979 communal riots in Jamshedpur, contains severe criticisms against the RSS, top district officials, and the Bihar Military Police (BMP). Established on May 15, 1979, during the Janata Party's governance, the commission submitted its findings to the government on August 31. Alongside Narain, K. Ghosh, former chairman of the Tripura Public Service Commission, and S.Q. Rizvi, former IG of police, Bihar, served on the commission. The riots, which occurred on April 11 and 12, resulted in 108 fatalities. Bihar Chief Minister Jagannath Mishra announced plans to draw the Union government's attention to the commission's findings concerning the activities of the RSS, Jana Sangh (now BJP), and its labor arm, the Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh.

headline: September 15, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Ruckus in Lok Sabha
article: The Lok Sabha witnessed unruly scenes for 45 minutes on September 14 with treasury benches demanding discussion on gold auction during the Janata regime and the Opposition seeking a debate on the privilege motion against Finance Minister R Venkataraman and Arun Shourie of The Indian Express. In addition, K C Haldar (CPM) and K K Goel (BJP) moved adjournment motions against the escape of the chief culprit in the Aligarh riots to Pakistan allegedly with the help of Arif Mohammad Khan of the Congress. The Deputy speaker, who was in the chair, rejected all the adjournment motions. For a change, the treasury benches kept the chair under pressure on a day which began with Union minister of state for home, Venkatasubbaiah, urging the Deputy Speaker to apply rules equally to both the sides.
summary:
Summary:
The Lok Sabha witnessed chaos for 45 minutes on September 14, with the treasury benches demanding discussion on gold auctions during the Janata regime, while the Opposition sought a debate on the privilege motion against Finance Minister R. Venkataraman and Arun Shourie of The Indian Express. Additionally, adjournment motions were moved by K.C. Haldar (CPM) and K.K. Goel (BJP) regarding the escape of the main suspect in the Aligarh riots to Pakistan, allegedly with the assistance of Arif Mohammad Khan of the Congress. However, the Deputy Speaker, presiding over the session, rejected all adjournment motions. Notably, the treasury benches exerted pressure on the chair throughout the day, with Union Minister of State for Home, Venkatasubbaiah, urging the Deputy Speaker to ensure equal application of rules to both sides.

headline: September 16, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Essential Services Bill
article: The Lok Sabha’s marathon voting on the Essential Services Maintenance Bill went into late hours as the Opposition fought the measure all the way. Earlier, the House gave its consent to take up the bill for consideration after a 14-day resistance spread over three days. Before moving to the second stage, the House rejected by 216 votes to 69 a statutory resolution seeking disapproval of the ordinance which the Bill seeks to replace. With amendments exceeding 500, the Opposition forced the House to divide repeatedly for one hour just to decide, whether or not to take up the consideration of the clauses. The Opposition lost its battle after 40 minutes to stall the extension of the strike ban coverage to a wide spectrum of private and public sector industries. Home Minister Giani Zail Singh made light of the Opposition amendments saying they were “reasonable but not acceptable”.
summary: The Lok Sabha engaged in a prolonged voting session on the Essential Services Maintenance Bill, with the Opposition vehemently opposing the measure. Despite a 14-day resistance spanning three days, the House eventually agreed to consider the bill. Prior to advancing to the next stage, the House rejected a statutory resolution seeking disapproval of the ordinance being replaced by the bill, with a vote of 216 against 69. The Opposition compelled the House to repeatedly divide for one hour over amendments exceeding 500, challenging the consideration of the clauses. After a 40-minute struggle, the Opposition failed to block the extension of the strike ban coverage to various private and public sector industries. Home Minister Giani Zail Singh dismissed Opposition amendments as "reasonable but not acceptable."

headline: Sempteber 17, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Confidence Motion
article: Major Opposition parties in the Lok Sabha have decided to bring a no-confidence motion against the Indira Gandhi government. Opposition members gave notice for a one-line motion. It is expected to be taken up on September 17. Through the censure motion, the Opposition members hope to achieve what has eluded them so far — a discussion on the Antulay affair. An Opposition member said that they were driven to this course following the Speakers’ firm refusal to allow Opposition members to make their submissions on the privilege issue relating to the Antulay affair before rejecting the notice. Under rules of business, a no-confidence motion gets top priority after question hour. If 50 Opposition members rise in support of it, the motion is admitted for discussion.
summary:
Summary:
Major Opposition parties in the Lok Sabha have announced their decision to bring a no-confidence motion against the Indira Gandhi government. Notice for a one-line motion has been submitted, expected to be taken up on September 17. The motion is seen as a means for the Opposition to initiate a discussion on the Antulay affair, which they have been unable to do through other avenues. This decision follows the Speaker's refusal to allow Opposition members to present their case on the privilege issue related to the Antulay affair before rejecting the notice. According to parliamentary rules, a no-confidence motion takes precedence after question hour, and if supported by 50 Opposition members, it is admitted for discussion.

headline: Antulay Trust Scandal: PM hits back
article:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on Friday hit back at the Opposition for its attack on her government over the Antulay Trust scandal. She said that the Opposition was trying to create a "scare" and that there was no substance to the allegations against her and her son Sanjay Gandhi.
 
 The Antulay Trust scandal was a political scandal that erupted in India in 1981. The scandal involved allegations of corruption against Abdul Rahman Antulay, the Chief Minister of Maharashtra. Antulay was accused of using his position to raise money for the Antulay Trust, a charitable organization that he had founded.
 
 The allegations against Antulay led to a major political crisis in Maharashtra. The Opposition demanded his resignation, but Antulay refused to quit. He was eventually forced to step down as Chief Minister in January 1982.
 
 The Antulay Trust scandal also damaged the reputation of Indira Gandhi and her government. The Opposition accused her of protecting Antulay and of being involved in corruption herself.
 
 In her speech on September 18, 1981, Indira Gandhi defended herself and her government against the allegations of corruption. She said that the Opposition was trying to create a "scare" and that there was no substance to the allegations against her and her son Sanjay Gandhi.
 
 She also said that the government was committed to fighting corruption and that it would take action against anyone who was found guilty of corruption.
 ion against anyone who was found guilty of corruption.
summary: The Antulay Trust scandal was a major political scandal in India in 1981. The scandal involved allegations of corruption against Abdul Rahman Antulay, the Chief Minister of Maharashtra. Antulay was accused of using his position to raise money for the Antulay Trust, a charitable organization that he had founded. The allegations against Antulay led to a major political crisis in Maharashtra.

headline: September 18, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM Hits Back
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has said that while she agrees with the objectives of the trust floated by A R Antulay, she had told him to not use her name with it. She said that her government stood for the highest standards in public life. Replying to a 10-hour debate on the no-trust motion by the Opposition against her government, the Prime Minister who was in a aggressive mood, said that the frustrated leaders of the Opposition were trying to create despair amongst people. The house rejected the motion by 194 to 83 votes after a stormy and, at times, tumultuous discussion.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stated that while she supports the objectives of the trust established by A.R. Antulay, she had advised him against using her name for it. Asserting her government's commitment to high standards in public life, Gandhi responded to a 10-hour debate on the no-confidence motion by the Opposition against her government. In an assertive demeanor, she accused frustrated Opposition leaders of attempting to sow despair among the people. The motion was ultimately rejected by the House with 194 votes against and 83 in favor, following a stormy and tumultuous discussion.

headline: September 20, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM on Nuclear Tests
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has said that India would carry out Pokharan type nuclear tests if necessary but would not manufacture the atomic bomb even if Pakistan did so. Mrs Gandhi emphasised that India was developing nuclear capacity solely for developmental purposes. She spelt out India’s nuclear policy in an interview to a correspondent of the Age magazine in Australia. Asked how long it would take India to change from nuclear energy for peaceful purposes to developing a bomb should the need arise, the PM said that this was a question that scientists would be able to answer. She said that India had to consider what was the real danger before it, that type of war or more convention warfare. Mrs Gandhi said India had to consider what the real danger was, “whether it would be that type of danger or a more conventional type.”
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stated that India would conduct nuclear tests akin to those in Pokhran if deemed necessary, but clarified that India would not produce atomic bombs even if Pakistan did so. Gandhi emphasized that India's nuclear development was solely for peaceful purposes. She outlined India's nuclear policy in an interview with a correspondent from the Age magazine in Australia. Responding to a query about the timeframe for India to transition from peaceful nuclear energy to bomb development if needed, Gandhi deferred to scientists for an answer. She underscored the need for India to assess the real threat, whether it be nuclear warfare or conventional conflict.

headline: September 22, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM on Punjab
article: The Prime Minister is going to Chandigarh on September 22 to study the situation in Punjab after the violence two days ago in the wake of the arrest of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale. She has kept herself in touch with developments in the state on Monday through intelligence reports. Home Minister Giani Zail Singh discussed the situation with the cabinet and home secretaries. He apprised Mrs Gandhi of the latest developments. The PM, it is believed, has doubts on whether Chief Minister Darbara Singh will be able to handle the situation. She is also worried because she will be on an 18-day tour abroad. She has, therefore, asked the Chief Minister to call an all-party meeting on Tuesday to seek the cooperation of the Opposition in maintaining peace and harmony in the state. She also wants to take the Opposition into confidence in dealing with the situation.
summary:
Summary:
The Prime Minister is planning to visit Chandigarh on September 22 to assess the situation in Punjab following recent violence sparked by the arrest of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale. She has stayed informed about developments through intelligence reports and discussions with Home Minister Giani Zail Singh. Concerned about Chief Minister Darbara Singh's ability to handle the situation, especially in her absence during an upcoming 18-day foreign tour, she has instructed him to convene an all-party meeting to seek cooperation from the Opposition in maintaining peace and harmony in the state. She aims to involve the Opposition in addressing the crisis effectively.

headline: September 23, 1981, Forty Years Ago: US On IMF Loans
article: The US Treasury Secretary Donald Regan, who favours stricter IMF conditionalities about loans, says that his country still has questions about $ 5 million SDR loan to India. In general Regan wants the IMF to be stricter about giving loans. The problems about India, he said, include continuing domestic and international deficits, failure to control the money supply and a general “inability to get their house in order.” The Reagan administration’s tough attitude towards the World Bank and other lending institutions— also stressed by Regan on Monday—has been known for a long time. It is being further developed in a detailed study, parts of which have already been leaked presumably.
summary:
Summary:
US Treasury Secretary Donald Regan, advocating for stricter IMF conditionalities on loans, has expressed reservations about a $5 million SDR loan to India. He emphasizes the need for IMF to impose stricter criteria for loan approval. Regan cites India's persistent domestic and international deficits, failure to control money supply, and overall inability to address internal economic challenges as reasons for concern. The Reagan administration's tough stance towards global lending institutions, including the World Bank, is well-known and is being further articulated in a detailed study, some parts of which have already been leaked.

headline: September 25, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Kampuchea Question
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi strongly defended the decision to recognise the Heng Samrin government in Kampuchea. Addressing a press conference in Jakarta, she recalled that her party had decided to recognise the Heng Samrin government even before the general elections of January 1980. Sharply reacting to a correspondent’s question on what India had gained from it, she said, “We do not take these decisions on the basis of deriving any benefit”. “The general applied by India was that any government that was operating de facto should be recognised”. Asked whether Kampuchean question figured in here discussions with President Suharto, and if there were differences with him, Mrs Gandhi said with a smile, “We both agreed that the situation should be resolved. There are bound to be differences between nations and leaders”.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi defended India's decision to recognize the Heng Samrin government in Kampuchea, emphasizing that India's policy was to recognize de facto governments. She stated that India had decided to recognize the Heng Samrin government even before the general elections of January 1980 and rejected the notion of deriving benefits from such decisions. Gandhi, addressing a press conference in Jakarta, indicated that the Kampuchean issue was discussed during her talks with President Suharto, but differences between nations and leaders were natural.

headline: The Indian government has brushed aside reports from Dhaka that 18 Bangladesh citizens had been killed within Bangladesh borders in an attack by Indian security personnel earlier this week. No Indian security person was involved in the reported incident, a spokesperson of the Union external affairs ministry said. The spokesperson said that there has been no request from the Bangladeshi government in response to the request from local Indian officials for a meeting to sort out the problem. He said about 5,000 people belonging to tribal communities had crossed into India from Bangladesh in the last few days. Meanwhile, the Bangladesh government had lodged a strong protest with India alleging border violations by 500 miscreants in the Chittagong Hill Tract Areas.
article: The Indian government has brushed aside reports from Dhaka that 18 Bangladesh citizens had been killed within Bangladesh borders in an attack by Indian security personnel earlier this week. No Indian security person was involved in the reported incident, a spokesperson of the Union external affairs ministry said. The spokesperson said that there has been no request from the Bangladeshi government in response to the request from local Indian officials for a meeting to sort out the problem. He said about 5,000 people belonging to tribal communities had crossed into India from Bangladesh in the last few days. Meanwhile, the Bangladesh government had lodged a strong protest with India alleging border violations by 500 miscreants in the Chittagong Hill Tract Areas.
summary:
Summary:
The Indian government has dismissed reports from Dhaka claiming that 18 Bangladeshi citizens were killed by Indian security personnel within Bangladesh's borders. A spokesperson from the Union External Affairs Ministry stated that no Indian security personnel were involved in the incident. Additionally, there has been no request from the Bangladeshi government for a meeting to address the issue, despite requests from local Indian officials. The spokesperson mentioned that around 5,000 people from tribal communities had crossed into India from Bangladesh in recent days. In contrast, Bangladesh lodged a strong protest against India, alleging border violations by 500 miscreants in the Chittagong Hill Tract Areas.

headline: September 28, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Clashes in Tehran
article: Several armed demonstrations against the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini erupted in Tehran, leaving at least seven people dead and more than 40 injured, and forcing a strict security clampdown in the Iranian capital. The security measures, which originally affected only three areas impacted by the chaos, quickly spread around government offices, parliament and the presidency in Tehran. People’s Mujahideen members distributed leaflets and torched seven buses. Intense exchanges of gunfire followed as a huge contingent of revolutionary guards arrived. The official Pars News Agency blamed the clashes on “three groups of up to 10-20 people belonging to the People’s Mujahideen and other pro-American groups”.
summary:
Summary:
Tehran witnessed armed demonstrations against Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's regime, resulting in at least seven deaths and over 40 injuries, prompting a stringent security crackdown. Initially contained to three areas affected by the unrest, security measures swiftly expanded to encompass government offices, parliament, and the presidency. Members of the People's Mujahideen distributed leaflets and set fire to seven buses, leading to intense gunfire exchanges upon the arrival of a large contingent of revolutionary guards. The clashes were attributed by the official Pars News Agency to "three groups of up to 10-20 people belonging to the People's Mujahideen and other pro-American groups."

headline: Fugitive hijacker of 1981 IA flight reveals Pak location via social media
article:
On September 29, 1981, an Indian Airlines Boeing 737 domestic passenger flight from the Delhi's Palam Airport to the Amritsar's Raja Sansi Airport was hijacked by five militants of the Dal Khalsa led by Gajinder Singh and was taken to Lahore Airport in Pakistan. The plane had 111 passengers and 6 crew members on board.
The Dal Khalsa had been demanding a separate Sikh homeland of Khalistan.
Gajinder Singh, talked to Natwar Singh, the then India's ambassador in Pakistan, and put forward their demands.
They had demanded the release of Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale and other fanatics from the Khalistan movement, and a sum of $500,000 in cash.
The hijackers faced trial in Pakistan and they were sentenced to life imprisonment. However, after spending 14 years in prison, they were all freed in October 1994. The Indian government has repeatedly tabled requests to Islamabad seeking his deportation.
Gajinder Singh's name was on India's list of the 20 most wanted terrorists in 2002.
summary:
Summary:
On September 29, 1981, a domestic Indian Airlines Boeing 737 flight from Delhi to Amritsar was hijacked by five militants of the Dal Khalsa, led by Gajinder Singh, and diverted to Lahore Airport in Pakistan. The hijackers, demanding a separate Sikh homeland of Khalistan, communicated their demands to Natwar Singh, then India's ambassador in Pakistan, which included the release of Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale and other Khalistan movement leaders, along with a cash sum of $500,000. After trial in Pakistan, the hijackers were sentenced to life imprisonment but were released in October 1994 after serving 14 years. Gajinder Singh was later listed as one of India's 20 most wanted terrorists in 2002. The Indian government has continuously sought his deportation from Pakistan.

headline: September 30, 1981, Forty Years Ago: IA Plane Hijacked
article: Hijackers of the Indian Airlines Boeing 737 set a deadline of 10.30 am on September 30 for the fulfillment of their demands, including release of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, suspect in the Jagat Narain murder case, and leaders of the Khalistan movement. They also demanded the repatriation of all imprisoned Sikh leaders to Pakistan. “We will announce our next step only after 10 am tomorrow,” Gajinder Singh, leader of the hijackers, told the Indian Ambassador to Pakistan, Natwar Singh. In a face-to-face meeting with Natwar Singh in the VIP lounge of the Lahore Airport, the Dal Khalsa supreme panchayat member, sought a contribution of $ 5 lakh for the Khalistani movement from the government of India.
summary:
Summary:
The hijackers of the Indian Airlines Boeing 737 set a deadline of 10:30 am on September 30 for the fulfillment of their demands, which included the release of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale and other Khalistan movement leaders, as well as the repatriation of imprisoned Sikh leaders to Pakistan. Gajinder Singh, the leader of the hijackers, conveyed this to Indian Ambassador Natwar Singh during a face-to-face meeting at Lahore Airport's VIP lounge. Additionally, Gajinder Singh requested a $5 lakh contribution from the Indian government for the Khalistani movement.

headline: Hijacked Passengers Safe Home
article:
The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 was a major incident. It was the first time that an Indian Airlines plane had been hijacked. The hijacking also came at a time of heightened tensions between India and Pakistan.

The safe release of all of the hostages is a relief. It is also a testament to the cooperation between the Indian and Pakistani governments.

The hijacking is a reminder of the dangers of terrorism. It is also a reminder of the importance of international cooperation in combating terrorism.

The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 was the first major hijacking incident in India since 1971. The hijackers were members of the Al-Zulfikar group, a Kashmiri militant organization.

The hijacking caused a major diplomatic crisis between India and Pakistan. The Indian government initially refused to negotiate with the hijackers, but it eventually agreed to release four Kashmiri militants in exchange for the safe release of the hostages.

The hijacking also had a significant impact on the Indian aviation industry. The Indian government implemented a number of new security measures after the hijacking, including baggage checks and metal detectors.

The hijacking of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 is a reminder of the dangers of terrorism and the importance of international cooperation in combating terrorism.
summary:
All 238 passengers and crew members of the Indian Airlines Airbus A300 that was hijacked on September 29 have been safely released. The plane was hijacked by six armed men who demanded the release of Kashmiri militants. The plane was flown to Lahore, Pakistan, where the hijackers surrendered to Pakistani authorities after 17 hours in captivity.

All of the passengers and crew members are safe and sound, and they are expected to be returned to India soon. The Indian government has thanked the Pakistani government for its cooperation in securing the release of the hostages.

headline: October 1, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Pak To The Rescue
article: In a swift and efficient rescue operation, Pakistani security forces stormed the hijacked Indian Airlines Boeing 737 at Lahore airport early on Wednesday morning, two hours before the deadline, and freed 39 passengers and six members of the crew held hostage since Tuesday afternoon. The five hijackers were over-powered and arrested by Pakistani commandos and are now being detained in Lahore. No one was hurt in the commando operation. The entire operation took not more than 10 minutes leaving the hijackers nonplussed. Radio Pakistan said in its morning broadcast that this “daring action by the commandos was taken entirely at the initiative of the Pakistan government”.
summary:
Summary:
Pakistani security forces conducted a swift and efficient rescue operation at Lahore airport, storming the hijacked Indian Airlines Boeing 737 two hours before the deadline. The operation successfully freed 39 passengers and six crew members who had been held hostage since Tuesday afternoon. Pakistani commandos overpowered and arrested the five hijackers, who are now detained in Lahore. Remarkably, no one was injured during the commando operation, which lasted no more than 10 minutes and left the hijackers bewildered. Radio Pakistan attributed the "daring action" to the initiative of the Pakistan government.

headline: October 2, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Rift At CHOGM
article: Sharp differences characterised the deliberations on the world political situation at a closed door meeting of the Commonwealth leaders particularly with respect to Afghanistan, Kampuchea and the Indian Ocean. The cleavage of opinion on these issues was more marked than in February at the Non-Aligned foreign ministers meet at Delhi, which is seen as natural since most of the participants here are very closely aligned with the West. While Prime Minister Indira Gandhi’s powerful espousal of India’s stand on a number of issues elicited powerful support from several leaders including Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia and Julius Nyerere of Tanzania, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of the UK struck a strong dissenting note.
summary:
Summary:
Sharp differences arose during closed-door deliberations among Commonwealth leaders regarding the world political situation, particularly concerning Afghanistan, Kampuchea, and the Indian Ocean. These divisions were more pronounced than those observed at the Non-Aligned foreign ministers' meeting in Delhi in February, attributed to the close alignment of most participants with the West. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi staunchly advocated India's position on various issues, receiving strong support from leaders like Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia and Julius Nyerere of Tanzania. However, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of the UK voiced strong dissenting opinions.

headline: October 4, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Collective Stand
article: Commonwealth leaders succeeded in hammering out a consensus on key economic issues particularly on aid to developing nations like India hit hard by oil imports. Indications were that the 43 Commonwealth countries were in sight of a collective stand on bridging the gap between the rich and developing nations. The views of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on the immediate economic problems of oil-importing countries received wide support during the informal discussions between the leaders. She pleaded for urgent financial assistance by international agencies for development of energy resources in the country. She drew the attention of other leaders to the burden imposed because of oil imports. A collective Commonwealth stand on North South issues is considered important in view of the Cancun summit which is less than three weeks away.
summary:
Summary:
Commonwealth leaders achieved consensus on key economic issues, particularly regarding aid to developing nations like India that were severely impacted by oil imports. It was indicated that the 43 Commonwealth countries were close to reaching a collective stance on bridging the gap between rich and developing nations. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's views on the immediate economic challenges faced by oil-importing countries garnered widespread support during informal discussions among leaders. She emphasized the urgent need for financial assistance from international agencies to develop energy resources in India and highlighted the burden imposed by oil imports. A unified Commonwealth position on North-South issues is deemed crucial ahead of the upcoming Cancun summit, scheduled in less than three weeks.

headline: October 5, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM blames Pak
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared in Canberra that India would not allow itself to be “caught napping” by Pakistan, which had jumped “a decade ahead of us” by acquiring sophisticated armaments. She said that she could not face people or Parliament if they thought that India, which had been invaded five times in three decades and which had been “ caught napping” twice, was not fully prepared to meet any eventuality. Mrs Gandhi’s remarks came in response to a question about how she reconciled her call for halt to the arms race with the fact that she was going to Paris next month to sign an agreement for the purchase of 150 Mirage-2000 planes.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, speaking in Canberra, emphasized that India would not allow itself to be unprepared in the face of Pakistan's advancements in acquiring sophisticated armaments. She expressed concern that Pakistan had surged "a decade ahead" in this regard. Gandhi acknowledged the imperative for India to remain fully prepared to address any potential threats, especially considering India's history of invasions and being caught unprepared in the past. Her remarks were made in response to questions about the apparent contradiction between her call to halt the arms race and India's agreement to purchase 150 Mirage-2000 planes from France, which she was due to sign in Paris the following month.

headline: October 6, 1981, Forty Years Ago: IMF loan
article: Economic Affairs Secretary R N Malhotra is optimistic that India’s application for a $ 5.7 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will go through. He bases this optimism on two factors: The negotiations have been completed to the satisfaction of India as well as the IMF management. Secondly, the US officials have told India that the Reagan administration has not prejudged the loan request. Malhotra, who returned to New Delhi from Washington after attending the joint annual meetings of the World Bank and the IMF, also denied that India was asked to scale down the quantum of loan it was seeking.
summary:
Summary:
Economic Affairs Secretary R N Malhotra expressed optimism regarding India's application for a $5.7 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He cited two factors for his optimism: successful negotiations between India and the IMF management, and assurance from US officials that the Reagan administration had not precluded the loan request. Malhotra, who attended the joint annual meetings of the World Bank and the IMF in Washington, denied rumors that India was asked to reduce the loan amount it was seeking.

headline: October 7, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Sadat Assassinated
article: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt was killed on Tuesday by a group of Egyptian soldiers who attacked his reviewing stand with grenades and assault rifles during a military parade in Cairo. An official in the President’s office said he died in hospital after the shooting. Sadat was 62. The official in the presidency said he had lived several hours after being hit in the shooting. At least two other persons were killed and many others — including diplomats from Australia and Belgium — were injured. An official said many foreign ministry officials were wounded. Three members of a US military delegation were wounded, the US Defence Department announced in Washington. The Egyptian cabinet met in the afternoon under the chairmanship of the Vice-President, Hosni Mubarak — who apparently suffered only slight injuries in the attack.
summary:
Summary:
President Anwar Sadat of Egypt was assassinated on Tuesday by a group of Egyptian soldiers who attacked his reviewing stand with grenades and assault rifles during a military parade in Cairo. He died in the hospital at the age of 62. At least two other individuals were killed, and numerous others, including diplomats from Australia and Belgium, were injured. Several foreign ministry officials and three members of a US military delegation were also wounded. The Egyptian cabinet convened under the chairmanship of Vice-President Hosni Mubarak, who reportedly sustained only minor injuries in the attack.

headline: October 7, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Sadat Assassinated
article: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt was killed on Tuesday by a group of Egyptian soldiers who attacked his reviewing stand with grenades and assault rifles during a military parade in Cairo. An official in the President’s office said he died in hospital after the shooting. Sadat was 62. The official in the presidency said he had lived several hours after being hit in the shooting. Three members of a US military delegation were wounded, the US Defence Department announced in Washington. The Egyptian cabinet met in the afternoon under the chairmanship of the Vice-President, Hosni Mubarak — who apparently suffered only slight injuries in the attack.
summary:
Summary:
President Anwar Sadat of Egypt was assassinated by a group of Egyptian soldiers during a military parade in Cairo. Sadat, aged 62, died in the hospital after being hit by grenades and assault rifle fire. At least two others were killed, and many, including diplomats from Australia and Belgium, were injured. Several foreign ministry officials and three members of a US military delegation were also wounded. Vice-President Hosni Mubarak, who chaired the Egyptian cabinet meeting in the afternoon, reportedly suffered only minor injuries in the attack.

headline: October 9, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM in Manila
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on Thursday assured ASEAN nations that India considered them an important factor in ensuring peace and stability in the sensitive South-East Asian region. India’s affinity with South-East Asia impelled it to have a dialogue with each of the five members of ASEAN, Mrs Gandhi said in a speech at a state dinner hosted in her honour by President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines in Manila on the first day of her two-day state visit. Mrs Gandhi told ASEAN nations, with whom India has differing perceptions on certain issues, notably Kampuchea, that, “India is next door and history makes us, if I may so, an honorary member of your region.”
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi reassured ASEAN nations of India's recognition of their importance in maintaining peace and stability in Southeast Asia. During a state dinner hosted by President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, Gandhi emphasized India's affinity with Southeast Asia and its commitment to dialogue with each ASEAN member. Despite differing perceptions on issues such as Kampuchea, Gandhi highlighted India's geographical proximity and historical ties to the region, suggesting India's honorary membership in Southeast Asia.

Prakash had beaten Jian in the semi-final of the Masters Badminton tourney on Sept. 25. article: Prakash today was at his artistic, stylish best. This was the second successive victory by the 27-year-old Bangalore based Bank officer, over the top ranked Chinese within a fortnight. Prakash had beaten Jian in the semi-final of the Masters Badminton tourney on Sept. 25. But his today’s victory was certainly more impressive than the previous, where Prakash had won 11-15, 15-3, 15-8. Prakash was in his elements today and wrapped up the first game without dropping a point. The aggressive Han was never given a chance to dictate play as Prakash took points with some beautiful cross-court shots and net-play. The graceful Prakash had to fight in a thrilling second game as Han’s smashes began to win points but his greater array of shots proved the telling factor and he took the game 18-16 on fourth match point.
summary:
Summary:
Prakash, a 27-year-old bank officer from Bangalore, showcased his artistic and stylish play in a badminton match, securing his second successive victory over the top-ranked Chinese player within two weeks. In the previous encounter, Prakash defeated Jian in the semi-final of the Masters Badminton tourney on September 25. However, today's victory was more impressive, with Prakash dominating the first game without dropping a point. He thwarted the aggressive Han's attempts to dictate play with beautiful cross-court shots and net-play. Despite a thrilling second game where Han's smashes earned points, Prakash's varied shots ultimately secured him the game 18-16 on the fourth match point.

headline: October 14, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM-Akali Talks
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will meet the Akali delegation on October 16. Besides the Akalis, Mrs Gandhi will also meet important Hindu leaders of Punjab before her departure on a 10-day-tour abroad. The PM’s secretariat is busy arranging her meeting with the Akali leaders. Mrs Gandhi is not depending on the advice of either Home Minister Zail Singh or Punjab CM Darbara Singh. While Zail Singh has been in favour of a dialogue with the Akalis, Darbara Singh was not too keen on this. Mrs Gandhi is aware of the views of these two leaders. She may, therefore, seek the guidance of Swaran Singh, former minister of external affairs, to solve the Punjab tangle. It is possible that the Hindu leaders may be invited either on October 16 or even earlier. This is considered necessary, especially after the assassination of Lala Jagat Narain, which had generated a lot of tension in the state.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is scheduled to meet with an Akali delegation on October 16, along with important Hindu leaders from Punjab, before her departure on a 10-day tour abroad. The PM's secretariat is organizing the meeting with the Akali leaders, and Mrs. Gandhi is not relying on the advice of either Home Minister Zail Singh or Punjab CM Darbara Singh, as they hold differing views on dialogue with the Akalis. Instead, she may seek guidance from Swaran Singh, former Minister of External Affairs, to address the Punjab issue. The invitation of Hindu leaders, possibly on October 16 or earlier, is deemed necessary following the assassination of Lala Jagat Narain, which heightened tensions in the state.

headline: October 15, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Punjab Firing
article: Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, arrested in connection with the assassination of Lala Jagat Narain will be released on October 15, according to Akali sources. The state government will also announce on October 15 a judicial inquiry into the police firing on Chowk Mehta on September 20, the burning of two buses in Ohandu Kalan, the lathi charge in Amritsar Khalsa College and the firing at Madhuban, near Karnal before the talks between the Akalis and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi begin on October 16. There will be two separate judicial inquiries — one by the Punjab government and the other by the Haryana government — into the firing incidents. These were the two pre-conditions set by the Akalis for talks with Mrs Gandhi. The Akalis, who arrived in Delhi on October 13, conveyed their wishes to the prime minister through Congress-I MP from Patiala Amrinder Singh.
summary:
Summary:
According to Akali sources, Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, arrested in connection with the assassination of Lala Jagat Narain, will be released on October 15. Additionally, the state government plans to announce a judicial inquiry into several incidents, including police firing in Chowk Mehta, burning of buses in Ohandu Kalan, lathi charge in Amritsar Khalsa College, and firing in Madhuban near Karnal, before talks between the Akalis and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi commence on October 16. Two separate judicial inquiries, by the Punjab and Haryana governments, respectively, will be conducted into the firing incidents, meeting the Akalis' pre-conditions for talks with Mrs. Gandhi. The Akalis conveyed their wishes to the prime minister through Congress-I MP from Patiala, Amrinder Singh, upon their arrival in Delhi on October 13.

headline: October 18, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Akali demands
article:
The civil disobedience movement of the Akali Dal (L) has been postponed till November 30. A decision to this effect was taken after a two-hour meeting of the Dal (L) working committee members, district presidents, party legislators and advisors. The party chief, Sant Harchand Singh Longowal, presided over the meeting.

Briefing newsmen after the meeting, Longowal said the movement had been postponed to provide ample time to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, to examine the party’s demands. The meeting condemned the state government for arresting Sikh student leaders on one pretext or the other. It demanded immediate and unconditional release of all arrested student leaders. Through another resolution, the meeting congratulated Sant Longowal for securing the release of Jamail Singh Bhindranwale.
summary:
Summary:
The civil disobedience movement of the Akali Dal (L) has been postponed until November 30, following a two-hour meeting of the party's working committee members, district presidents, legislators, and advisors. The party chief, Sant Harchand Singh Longowal, chaired the meeting.

Sant Longowal stated that the movement's postponement aimed to allow Prime Minister Indira Gandhi sufficient time to consider the party's demands. The meeting also criticized the state government for the arbitrary arrests of Sikh student leaders and called for their immediate and unconditional release. Additionally, a resolution congratulated Sant Longowal for securing the release of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale

headline: October 25, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Cancun Summit Fails
article: The two-day summit of 21 leaders from the industrialised world and developing countries has failed to produce anything concrete on the gut issue of global negotiations. The summit ended on October 23. The outcome was so disappointing that Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau said that it evaded the major questions. The outcome was predictable given the American insistence on making only small concessions. Developing nations struggled for hours to make the US budge but it would not.
