The only part of the discussions on which there was an agreement was the following: “The heads of states and governments confirmed the desirability of supporting at the UN a consensus to launch a global negotiation on a basis to be mutually agreed upon and in circumstances offering the prospect of meaningful progress with a sense of urgency”.
summary:
Summary:
The two-day summit involving 21 leaders from both industrialized and developing countries concluded on October 23 without achieving substantial progress on global negotiations. Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau expressed disappointment, stating that the summit failed to address major issues. The outcome was largely predictable, with the US showing reluctance to make significant concessions. Developing nations exerted efforts to persuade the US to compromise, but without success. The only consensus reached was on the desirability of supporting, at the UN, a consensus to initiate global negotiations under mutually agreeable terms, with a sense of urgency and the prospect of meaningful progress.

headline: October 26, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Zail Singh’s warning
article: Union Home Minister Giani Zail Singh said that the government would not encourage secessionists and extremists to vitiate the peaceful atmosphere in Punjab or any other part of the country. He warned extremists not to underestimate the strength of the Centre to deal with secessionist elements. Addressing a public meeting to mark the 20th anniversary of the dedication of the Bhakra Nangal Dam to the nation, he said that the government was sufficiently prepared to deal with the secessionists sternly. He admitted that there was some delay in taking action against these forces but said that the government was aware of its duty. He said that a war with Pakistan cannot be ruled out despite the best intentions of the people and the Government of India towards Pakistan.
summary:
Summary:
Union Home Minister Giani Zail Singh emphasized that the government would not tolerate secessionist and extremist activities aimed at disrupting peace in Punjab or any other part of the country. He cautioned extremists against underestimating the central government's capability to address such threats. Speaking at a public event commemorating the 20th anniversary of the dedication of the Bhakra Nangal Dam, Singh assured that the government was prepared to deal firmly with secessionist elements. While acknowledging some delay in taking action against these forces, he affirmed the government's commitment to its responsibilities. Additionally, Singh acknowledged the possibility of a war with Pakistan despite India's goodwill intentions toward the neighboring country.

headline: October 27, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Meitei outfits banned
article: The Union government has declared as unlawful associations the “People’s Liberation Army” (PLA), Prepak and their offshoots such as the Red Army for participating in secessionist activities and for ongoing armed attacks on civilians and security forces. The order banning the Meitei organisations in Manipur was under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act of 1967. The notification said that the Metei outfits mentioned in the order have openly declared as their objective, “the creation of an independent Manipur comprising the state of Manipur” and “have resorted to violent activities in pursuit of their objective to bring about the secession of the said state from the Union of India”. The order also noted that the organisations have made some efforts to resume contacts with foreign countries for securing assistance by way of arms and training”.
summary:
Summary:
The Union government has declared several organizations, including the "People's Liberation Army" (PLA), Prepak, and their offshoots such as the Red Army, as unlawful associations under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act of 1967. The ban on Meitei organizations in Manipur was imposed due to their involvement in secessionist activities and armed attacks on civilians and security forces. The notification stated that these organizations openly advocate for the creation of an independent Manipur and have engaged in violent activities to achieve this goal. Additionally, the organizations have attempted to establish contacts with foreign countries to obtain assistance in terms of arms and training.

headline: October 28, 1981, Forty Years Ago
article:
Close to Mirage deal

A high-level Indian delegation to Paris left for home after moving closer to signing a $ 3.3 billion agreement for the purchase of Mirage 200 jets and other armaments. Indian officials who declined to be identified said that the deal had not been completed but might be formalised by the time Prime Minister Indira Gandhi visits France on November 12. The Indian mission was led by P K Kaul, defence secretary, and included Air Force Chief of Staff, Air Marshal Dilbagh Singh. A French Defence Ministry statement said that the talks had been held to facilitate the continuation of an agreement. When the deal is finalised, India is expected to terminate the final part of a $ 1.3 billion deal to buy Jaguar jets with British Aerospace.
summary:
Summary:
A high-level Indian delegation in Paris moved closer to finalizing a $3.3 billion agreement for the purchase of Mirage 2000 jets and other armaments. While the deal had not been completed, Indian officials suggested it might be formalized by the time Prime Minister Indira Gandhi visits France on November 12. Led by Defence Secretary P K Kaul, the Indian mission also included Air Force Chief of Staff, Air Marshal Dilbagh Singh. A statement from the French Defence Ministry indicated talks aimed at facilitating the continuation of an agreement. Upon finalization, India is expected to terminate the remaining part of a $1.3 billion deal to buy Jaguar jets from British Aerospace

headline: November 1, 1981, Forty Years Ago
article:
VIP Train Robbery

Eight armed train robbers looted valuables worth Rs 5 lakhs from passengers from passengers of an air-conditioned two-tier coach of the Delhi-bound Lucknow mail, popularly known as the VIP Train, near Sandila in Hardoi district, about 70 km from Lucknow. Three of the robbers were nabbed after an exchange of fire on the Baghauli crossing on the Lucknow Hardoi road. Most of the looted property was recovered including 16 watches, three cameras, gold necklaces and bangles. Kalpanath Sonkar and Mahavir Singh, two MPs travelling in the train, got back their watches. Later one of the dacoits succumbed to his injuries.
summary:
Summary:
Eight armed train robbers looted valuables worth Rs 5 lakhs from passengers aboard an air-conditioned two-tier coach of the Delhi-bound Lucknow mail, known as the VIP Train, near Sandila in Hardoi district, approximately 70 km from Lucknow. Following an exchange of fire on the Baghauli crossing on the Lucknow-Hardoi road, three of the robbers were apprehended. Most of the stolen property, including 16 watches, three cameras, gold necklaces, and bangles, was recovered. Kalpanath Sonkar and Mahavir Singh, two MPs traveling on the train, retrieved their watches. Subsequently, one of the dacoits succumbed to his injuries.

headline: November 2, 1981, Forty Years Ago
article:
Gujarat Cyclone

Over 1,400 fishermen from Gujarat and Maharashtra have been reported missing in the Arabian Sea, a fishermen’s colony of over 100 huts in Rajapur port town has been swept away and four persons were feared drowned as the Saurashtra coast reeled under a severe cyclonic storm. At least two cargo vessels sank, several boats capsized and the communication network was crippled. The storm was expected to cross the coast between Veraval and Porbandar by midnight on November 1 and re-emerge as a cyclone in the Gulf of Kutch on November 2. Earlier in the day, a bauxite-laden ship sank near Veraval.
summary:
Summary:
A severe cyclonic storm hit the Saurashtra coast, causing widespread devastation. Over 1,400 fishermen from Gujarat and Maharashtra were reported missing in the Arabian Sea, while a fishermen's colony in Rajapur port town was swept away. Four individuals were feared drowned, and two cargo vessels sank, with several boats capsizing. Additionally, a bauxite-laden ship sank near Veraval. The storm was expected to cross the coast between Veraval and Porbandar by midnight on November 1, re-emerging as a cyclone in the Gulf of Kutch on November 2. The communication network was severely disrupted due to the cyclone.

headline: November 3, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Jail staff sacked
article: The services of 1200 striking temporary jail employees were terminated and notices were issued to permanent employees for necessary action. The government issued the deterrent action of terminating the temporary and probationary employees after the striking workers did not return to work. Home secretary R C Takru said that the government was determined to not reinstate the employees. He said that recruitment to fill in the vacancies had been initiated and added that preference would be given to Home Guards who were already working in jails. He said that as a result of the tough measures, 15 to 40 per cent employees had returned to work. He described the situation as peaceful and under control.
summary:
Summary:
The services of 1200 striking temporary jail employees were terminated by the government, with notices issued to permanent employees for necessary action. The decision came after the striking workers failed to return to work. Home Secretary R C Takru stated that the government was resolute in not reinstating the employees and had initiated recruitment to fill the vacancies. Preference would be given to Home Guards already working in jails. Takru noted that due to the tough measures, 15 to 40 percent of employees had returned to work, describing the situation as peaceful and under control.

headline: November 6, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Warnings From Assam
article: The Assam government leaders warned of fresh agitation if the government failed to disperse foreigners who had entered the state during the 1961-1971 period. At a press conference in Guwahati, they said that they were no longer interested in informal talks. If the government wants further talks, it should be at the ministerial level, they said. But before that, it must clarify its stand on the foreigners. The movement leaders who included representatives of the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad and the All Assam Students Union, however, said that any decision on future talks with the government will be taken by the executive committees of their organisations. The two outfits would jointly sponsor a peaceful rally on November 10 to explain to the people their future course of action.
summary:
Summary:
Leaders of the Assam government warned of a potential new agitation if the government failed to address the issue of foreigners who entered the state between 1961 and 1971. They stated that informal talks were no longer satisfactory and demanded ministerial-level discussions with clarity on the government's stance regarding foreigners. The movement leaders, representing organizations like the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad and the All Assam Students Union, stated that decisions regarding future talks would be made by the executive committees of their respective organizations. Additionally, they announced plans for a joint peaceful rally on November 10 to inform the public about their future course of action.

headline: Forty Years Ago, November 9, 1981: Delhi Paris London
article: The visit of External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao to London in response to Lord Carrington’s long-standing invitation is likely to have a direct bearing on Prime Minister Indira Gandhi’s four-day stay in Paris. India’s politico-economic role in the Third World and non-aligned countries is recognised as vital both by France and Britain against the background of the situation in West Asia, South Asia and Southwest Asian countries, with particular reference to the developments in Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan. Since Mitterrand was elected President, France and India have established close relationships. This is, perhaps, because the French President’s views on many matters are similar to those held by Mrs Gandhi. But there is hardly any issue of significance on which London and New Delhi agree despite the fact that the two countries have traditional friendship.
summary:
Summary:
External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao's visit to London, in response to Lord Carrington's invitation, is expected to influence Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's four-day stay in Paris. Both France and Britain recognize India's crucial politico-economic role in the Third World and non-aligned countries, especially in light of developments in West Asia, South Asia, and Southwest Asian countries like Iran, Afghanistan, and Pakistan. France and India have developed close ties since Mitterrand's presidency, largely due to similarities in their leaders' views. However, there is little agreement between London and New Delhi on significant issues, despite their longstanding friendship.

headline: Forty Years Ago, November 10, 1981: Defiance in Assam
article: Troops marched through the main streets of Gauhati and a battalion of the CRPF dug in at the Judges Field, the venue of the proposed mass rally of the AASU and AAGSP and the Assam agitators prepared for a major battle. The Army has been told to remain in a state of speedy reinforcements. The agitators are firm on defying the prohibitory orders despite the heavy police, CRPF and BSF bandobust. The government is not likely to make a last-minute change in its position to permit the rally. In all likelihood, the steering committee of the agitators will give a call for defiance of the prohibitory orders.
summary:
Summary:
Tensions escalated in Gauhati as troops marched through the main streets and a battalion of the CRPF positioned itself at Judges Field, the planned venue for a mass rally by AASU and AAGSP. Assam agitators braced for confrontation, with the Army on standby for rapid reinforcement. Despite heavy police, CRPF, and BSF presence, the agitators remained determined to defy prohibitory orders. The government showed no indication of reversing its decision to ban the rally, prompting expectations that the agitators' steering committee would call for defiance of the orders.

headline: November 13, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Indo-French Talks
article: India and France have begun in right earnest the search for a strategy to promote their hitherto neglected bilateral economic relations avoiding altogether any reference to the controversial Mirage deal. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who had an hour long discussion with French President Francois Mitterrand immediately after her arrival in Paris, told reporters that they did not discuss the Mirage deal. The situation in Europe, Afghanistan, Poland and West Africa were some of the topics on which the two leaders were understood to have exchanged their views. President Mitterrand is believed to have given his assessment of the events in Poland.
summary:
Summary:
India and France have initiated efforts to strengthen their bilateral economic relations, with a focus on avoiding discussion of the contentious Mirage deal. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, following an hour-long discussion with French President Francois Mitterrand upon her arrival in Paris, clarified that the Mirage deal was not addressed. Instead, they discussed various topics including the situation in Europe, Afghanistan, Poland, and West Africa. President Mitterrand reportedly provided his assessment of events in Poland during the discussion.

headline: November 16, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Garhwal repoll
article: Opposition party leaders met the President Sanjiva Reddy to protest against the cancellation of the repoll in the Garhwal parliamentary constituency scheduled for November 22. They also submitted a memorandum to the President demanding a judicial enquiry by a serving judge of the Supreme Court to look into the circumstances leading to the cancellation of the repoll. They wanted responsibility to be fixed on those bent on subverting the Constitution. The memorandum urged the President to take steps for holding the Garhwal repoll immediately. It alleged that the cancellation was a direct attack on democracy. They alleged that even without an Emergency there was a constitutional breakdown.
summary:
Summary:
Opposition party leaders met President Sanjiva Reddy to protest the cancellation of the repoll in the Garhwal parliamentary constituency scheduled for November 22. They submitted a memorandum demanding a judicial inquiry by a serving Supreme Court judge to investigate the circumstances leading to the cancellation and hold those responsible for subverting the Constitution accountable. The memorandum urged the President to take immediate steps for holding the Garhwal repoll. The opposition alleged that the cancellation was a direct attack on democracy and highlighted concerns about a constitutional breakdown even without an Emergency.

headline: November 18, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Mitterrand’s Views
article: France’s socialist President Francois Mitterrand said that his country would fiercely guard its autonomy and would not re-enter NATO. In a 40-minute interview to The Indian Express, the French president answered a wide-range of questions about East-West relations, the North-South dialogue, his domestic problems, relations with India and his intellectual pursuits. He was very conscious of North-South problems and France’s determination to do something about them. Asked if France was not following a harder line towards the Soviet Union, he replied, “Yes, perhaps I am disappointed by the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. I cannot say I approve of it. I disapprove of it”. This, however, will not preclude France from following good relations with the Soviet Union, the French president said.
summary:
Summary:
French President Francois Mitterrand affirmed his country's commitment to autonomy and stated that France would not re-enter NATO. In an interview with The Indian Express lasting 40 minutes, Mitterrand discussed various topics including East-West relations, the North-South dialogue, domestic issues, relations with India, and his intellectual pursuits. He emphasized France's determination to address North-South problems. Regarding relations with the Soviet Union, Mitterrand expressed disappointment over the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan but noted that this would not prevent France from maintaining good relations with the Soviet Union.

headline: November 19, 1981, Forty Years Ago: ESMA In Assam
article: On the eve of the 36-hour bandh in Assam as part of the revival of the agitation against foreigners, the Centre issued an order banning strikes in essential services like railways postal departments and services connected with the operation and maintenance of aerodromes in the state. The Centre invoked the sweeping powers given to it by the Essential Services Maintenance Act after a meeting of the Union Cabinet. The blanket order covers production, supply and distribution of coal, power, steel, fertilisers, petroleum and petroleum products and all defence installations, transport, banking and air and hospital services. Employees in Central undertakings, engaged in purchase, procurement, storage, supply or distribution of foodgrains have also been bought under the purview of the order.
summary:
Summary:
On the eve of a 36-hour bandh in Assam to revive agitation against foreigners, the Centre issued an order banning strikes in essential services such as railways, postal departments, and aerodrome operations in the state. The decision was made after a Union Cabinet meeting, invoking powers under the Essential Services Maintenance Act. The order extends to various sectors including coal, power, steel, fertilizers, petroleum, defense installations, transport, banking, air and hospital services. Additionally, employees in Central undertakings involved in food grain procurement, storage, and distribution are also covered by the order.

headline: November 20, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Assam bandh
article: One person was killed at the Dhing railway station in Assam’s Nowgong district when the CRPF fired four rounds to disperse a stone throwing mob. The firing was preceded by a lathi charge. The authorities claimed that the situation was under control. A powerful explosive device was recovered from the railway track at Kamakhya near Gauhati and was defused by the army. But for these incidents and some minor incidents of violence, the 36-hour Assam Bandh called by the AASU and AAGSP passed off peacefully. The Bandh was peaceful in the Valley, except for the border district of Goalpara, where several shops were open and cinema halls functioned. Over 500 persons were taken into custody in the state. North Lakhimpur had the highest tally of arrests.
summary:
Summary:
During the 36-hour Assam Bandh called by AASU and AAGSP, one person was killed at Dhing railway station in Assam's Nowgong district as CRPF fired to disperse a stone-throwing mob. The firing followed a lathi charge. Despite this, authorities claimed the situation was under control. A powerful explosive device was found and defused near Kamakhya railway track. Overall, the bandh was peaceful in the Valley, except for minor incidents in Goalpara district where some shops were open and cinema halls functioned. Over 500 people were arrested, with North Lakhimpur recording the highest number of arrests.

headline: November 30, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Gurdwara explosion
article: Three persons were killed on Sunday in an explosion in Gurdwara Gurdarshan Prakash at Mehta Chowk, headquarters of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale. At the time of the explosion, the Sant was away in Barer village in Gurdaspur district. He returned to his headquarters, about 40 km from Amritsar, on hearing about the incident. The explosion brought down a major part of the gurdwara complex. The three dead were disciples of Sant Bhindranwale. A case under section 302 IPC and section 4 of the Indian Explosives Act was registered on a complaint lodged by Dhara Singh, a confidant of the Sant and establishment in-charge at the gurdwara. The explosion, which occurred at 12.30 pm, killed Jaswant Singh (20), Sukhmandhir Singh (13) and Gajjan Singh (27). It destroyed the community kitchen in the gurdwara.
summary:
Summary:
An explosion at Gurdwara Gurdarshan Prakash in Mehta Chowk, headquarters of Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, resulted in the deaths of three individuals. The explosion, which occurred while Sant Bhindranwale was away, brought down a major part of the gurdwara complex and killed three of his disciples. A case was registered under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and the Explosives Act, and the incident destroyed the community kitchen in the gurdwara.

headline: December 1, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Assam Blockade
article: One person was killed when police opened fire to disperse a violent crowd of pickets, who attacked a convoy of trucks Vellowguri, near Nowgong town on Monday afternoon, an official spokesperson said. Police fired two rounds to disperse the crowd which attempted to stall road traffic in response to a call by the AASU and the AAGSP as part of their resumed agitation on the foreigners issue. Police also fired at a crowd at Besaria near Tezpur but nobody was injured. Curfew has been imposed on both towns. A wooden bridge between Neamatighat and Jorhat in Sibsagar district was set on fire by miscreants. An attempt was also made to burn another bridge near Mangaldol, a subdivisional town, in Darrang district.
summary:
Summary:
During a resumed agitation on the foreigners issue called by the AASU and the AAGSP, one person was killed when police opened fire to disperse a violent crowd of pickets attacking a convoy of trucks near Nowgong town. Police also fired at a crowd near Tezpur, imposing curfew in both towns. Additionally, miscreants set a wooden bridge on fire between Neamatighat and Jorhat in Sibsagar district, and attempted to burn another bridge near Mangaldol in Darrang district.

headline: December 2, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Debate On Punjab
article: Union Home Minister Zail Singh expressed himself against any blanket ban on entry of police into places of worship and sought the cooperation of Opposition parties in handling the prevailing situation in Punjab. The Home Minister, who was replying to a five-hour debate in the Lok Sabha on the Khalistan and other secessionist agitations in the country, said such a ban on the entry of police will interfere with law enforcement. He also appealed to religious leaders to not drag religion into politics. He said that the Canadian government had been informed over the Indian government’s unhappiness over grant of asylum in Canada to persons “carrying Khalistan passports”. He said he had told Canada’s Communications Minister that this was objectionable.
summary:
Summary:
Union Home Minister Zail Singh opposed a blanket ban on police entry into places of worship, stating that it would hinder law enforcement efforts. He appealed to religious leaders to keep religion separate from politics. Additionally, he expressed India's dissatisfaction to the Canadian government over granting asylum to individuals with "Khalistan passports."

headline: December 4, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Waldheim Withdraws
article: UN Secretary General Kurt Waldheim withdrew his candidacy for a third term in office. In a letter to the president of the Security Council Olara Utunnu, Waldheim asked him not to include his name in the further ballots the Council may decide on the next nominee for the post. Waldheim said in the letter that his decision was motivated by the desire to facilitate the Security Council’s task. The letter came after several ballots to choose between him, and Salim Ahmed Salim resulted in a stalemate. Waldheim obtained the majority support required from the 15-nation security council, but his candidature was vetoed by China.
summary:
Summary:
UN Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has withdrawn his candidacy for a third term in office. In a letter to the president of the Security Council, he requested that his name not be included in future ballots for the next nominee. Waldheim stated that his decision was aimed at easing the Security Council's task. The withdrawal followed a stalemate between him and Salim Ahmed Salim, with Waldheim gaining majority support but being vetoed by China.

headline: December 10, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Flyover collapse
article: A huge chunk of the flyover under construction near Sewa Nagar for the Asian Games in Delhi crashed, injuring at least 17 labourers. Four have been admitted to the All India Institute of Medical Sciences. The rest were given first-aid and discharged. This is the second incident in an Asian Games project site in two days. A labourer was killed on December 7 when a mound of earth fell on him. The workers were too dazed to give a coherent account of what happened to them. The fire brigade and other rescue officials took time to reach the spot. In the meantime, the residents pulled the injured workers from the debris.
summary:
Summary:
A portion of the flyover being constructed near Sewa Nagar for the Asian Games in Delhi collapsed, injuring 17 laborers. Four were admitted to the All India Institute of Medical Sciences, while the others received first-aid and were discharged. This incident follows another at an Asian Games project site where a laborer was killed by a falling mound of earth. The workers were unable to provide details of the collapse, and rescue officials arrived after local residents had already pulled the injured from the debris.

headline: December 11, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Sino-India talks
article: India and China held a day long dialogue with a declared objective to settle the border issue and improve relations. It is not known whether the delegations led by Eric Gonsalves, secretary, External Affairs Ministry and by the Chinese vice foreign minister Han Nianlong had an agreed agenda or format for the talks, the first formal discussions in 21 years. The Indian Ambassador, KS Bajpai said the talks would probably last till Sunday. Sources said the talks were held in a “cordial and purposeful” atmosphere and at the outset, both sides expressed a desire to settle the border problem and expand bilateral relations.
summary:
Summary:
India and China engaged in day-long dialogue aimed at resolving the border issue and enhancing bilateral relations. Led by Eric Gonsalves, Secretary of the External Affairs Ministry for India, and Han Nianlong, Vice Foreign Minister for China, it marked the first formal discussions in 21 years. The talks, held in a cordial and purposeful atmosphere, aimed to settle the border problem and expand bilateral ties. The delegations likely discussed a range of issues, although specific details of the agenda were not disclosed.

headline: December 17, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Poland crackdown
article: Violent clashes between workers and strike-breaking military authorities were reported from Poland but Warsaw Radio insisted the country was calm and generally hard at work. The military government said union leader Lech Walesa was broken and weeping. The French Premier, Pierre Mauroy, has been told by diplomatic sources there have been 45,000 arrests in Poland and nine people killed in incidents since the military take-over, a French union leader said. Reports reaching Western diplomats in Bonn said water cannon and baton charges were used against supporters of the Solidarity free trade union by army authorities administering the martial law imposed on Sunday. The diplomats said troops and police were brought in to break strikes in Warsaw, Katowice and Gdansk.
summary:
Summary:
Violent clashes between workers and strike-breaking military authorities were reported in Poland, despite Warsaw Radio's claims of calm. The military government asserted that union leader Lech Walesa was broken and weeping. According to French diplomatic sources, there were 45,000 arrests and nine deaths since the military takeover. Reports from Western diplomats in Bonn described the use of water cannons and baton charges against Solidarity supporters by army authorities enforcing martial law. Strikes in Warsaw, Katowice, and Gdansk were reportedly broken by troops and police.

headline: December 18, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Rao on China
article: External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao informed Parliament that “although fairly wide differences” persisted between India and China on the border question, there was hope of a better understanding on each other’s positions. Making a statement on the official-level talks between the two countries last week, Rao said it was a positive step. Rao reiterated that it was the desire of the government to normalise relations fully with China. “This is only possible when we bring about a complete resolution of our problems as well as a stable relationship in all fields.” Rao also explained India’s position on the Polish crisis and the annexation of the Golan Heights by Israel. The Polish government-Solidarity confrontation leading to the clamping of martial law in that country was described as “primarily the concern of its government and people”.
summary:
Summary:
External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao informed Parliament about the official-level talks between India and China, stating that while significant differences on the border issue persisted, there was hope for better understanding. He expressed the government's desire to fully normalize relations with China by resolving all outstanding issues. Rao also discussed India's stance on the Polish crisis and Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights, emphasizing that the Polish government's confrontation with Solidarity was primarily an internal matter.

headline: December 21, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Solidarity Strike
article: Solidarity union militants are holding 1,300 miners hostage in a mine in Southern Poland, the Soviet news agency Tass said. The sabotaging of the mine followed a call by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa for mass strikes and passive resistance against martial law. Tass, in a dispatch from Warsaw, said there was similar resistance elsewhere in Polish industry although the official Polish news agency PAP said that 95 per cent of the industry was working normally. The mine where the miners were being held is at Ziemovit at Katowice where seven miners were killed in clashes with security forces last week.
summary:
Summary:
Solidarity union militants in Poland are reported to be holding 1,300 miners hostage in a mine in Southern Poland, following a call by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa for mass strikes and passive resistance against martial law. Despite official reports suggesting normalcy in most of the industry, resistance against martial law is reported in various parts of the country.

headline: December 22, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Jathedar Shot Dead
article: Jathedar Santokh Singh, 52, president of the Delhi Gurudwara Prabhandak Committee was shot dead by a DGPC member Sohan Singh Sandhi from the Singh Sabha Gurudwara in Delhi’s Vishnu Garden. Immediately after Sohan Singh was shot dead by the Jathedar’s bodyguard. Though police and eyewitness accounts were nebulous regarding the incident which took place a few seconds, preliminary investigations reveal that the Jathedar who was travelling in a white Ambassador car was shot thrice by Sandhu, a few yards from the gurudwara. He had come to attend a function at the gurudwara. Santokh Singh and Sohan Singh Sandhu were declared dead upon arrival at the hospital. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has expressed shock at the Jathedar’s murder.
summary:
Summary:
Jathedar Santokh Singh, the president of the Delhi Gurudwara Prabhandak Committee, was shot dead by a member of the committee, Sohan Singh Sandhi, near the Singh Sabha Gurudwara in Delhi's Vishnu Garden. The incident occurred while Santokh Singh was traveling in his car to attend a function at the gurudwara. Sandhu shot Singh three times before being killed by Singh's bodyguard. Both Singh and Sandhu were declared dead upon arrival at the hospital. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed shock at Singh's murder.

headline: December 23, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Sikh Leader’s Murder
article: The .38 bore revolver used to gun down Santokh Singh, president of the Delhi Gurudwara Prabhandak Committee is missing, according to the police. The Delhi Police Commissioner P S Bhinder has ordered the crime branch to take over investigation of the case. A senior police officer said investigations are on to find out if the assailant Sohan Singh Sandhu who was killed by Santokh Singh’s bodyguard was alone or had some accomplices, “though his chances of his being there with accomplices were very remote”. Dhanna Singh, the bodyguard of the Jathedar, who was the only other eyewitness besides the driver and another companion said he heard shots being fired from other directions also. Dhanna Singh said that he fired in the air to “scare away people” as there was danger to his life after the Jathedar was shot.
summary:
Summary:
The .38 bore revolver used to kill Santokh Singh, president of the Delhi Gurudwara Prabhandak Committee, is missing, according to the police. Delhi Police Commissioner P S Bhinder has ordered the crime branch to take over the investigation. Investigations are ongoing to determine if the assailant, Sohan Singh Sandhu, acted alone or had accomplices. Dhanna Singh, the bodyguard of the Jathedar, reported hearing shots fired from other directions and fired in the air to protect himself after Singh was shot.

headline: December 24, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Congress (S) Splits
article: The split in the Congress (S) in Kerala was complete when a faction in the party led by the state president A K Antony became a partner of the Congress (I)-led United Democratic Front, in total defiance of the Congress (S) working committee directives and warnings from party president Sharad Pawar. The KPCC-S executive and the Congress (S) legislature party at a joint meeting earlier decided to join the United Front in line with aspirations of Congressmen. V M Sudheeran, general secretary of the party, told newsmen that the unity of democratic parties was more important than the formation of the ministry. Congress (I) leader K Karunakaran said that the decision to form a government will be taken on Christmas day.
summary:
Summary:
The Congress (S) in Kerala experienced a split as a faction led by state president A K Antony defied directives from the party's working committee and warnings from party president Sharad Pawar to join the Congress (I)-led United Democratic Front. The decision was made despite objections from Congress (S) leaders and the legislature party. V M Sudheeran, a general secretary of the party, emphasized the importance of unity among democratic parties. Meanwhile, Congress (I) leader K Karunakaran announced that the decision to form a government would be made on Christmas day.

headline: December 25, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Shahi To Visit India
article: Pakistan president Zia-ul-Haq has announced that Foreign Minister Agha Shahi would visit India soon for “important consultations” which he hoped would lead to better understanding between the two countries. Pakistan was studying an Indian communication on a no-war pact offer handed over by ambassador Natwar Singh. While some aspects of the Indian response to Pakistan’s offer was positive, others needed clarification, General Zia said. Stating that Shahi had received an invitation from External Affairs Minister P Narasimha Rao to visit India for consultations, the Pakistani ruler said, “these consultations are important not only for Pakistan but also for the one billion people of the region”. General Zia said his country “wanted a tension-free atmosphere and friendly relations with all countries”.
summary:
Summary:
Pakistan's President Zia-ul-Haq has announced that Foreign Minister Agha Shahi will soon visit India for crucial consultations aimed at fostering better understanding between the two countries. This announcement follows Pakistan's consideration of India's proposal for a no-war pact, which was delivered by Ambassador Natwar Singh. While aspects of India's response were seen positively by Pakistan, some points required further clarification. President Zia emphasized the significance of these consultations, stating that they were vital for Pakistan and the entire region's one billion people. He expressed Pakistan's desire for a tension-free atmosphere and friendly relations with all countries.

headline: December 27, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Swearing-in
article: The 12th ministry of Kerala headed by Congress (I) leader K Karunakaran was sworn in on December 26. The governor, Jyothi Vencatachallam accepted the United Democratic Front’s  (UDF) claim of majority and formally invited Karunakaran to form a government. Though firmly disputed by the CPM-led Left Democratic Front, the governor said she was convinced of the UDF claim, but left it to be proved on the floor of the assembly as offered by the UDF. The minister is to be sworn with the former chief minister CM Mohammed Koya of the Muslim League as Deputy Chief Minister. It will have eight members. The UDF convenor P Joseph said that the ministry will be expanded later. The assembly will be convened as early as possible, he said.
summary:
Summary:
The 12th ministry of Kerala, led by Congress (I) leader K. Karunakaran, was sworn in on December 26. Governor Jyothi Vencatachallam accepted the United Democratic Front's (UDF) claim of majority and invited Karunakaran to form the government, despite objections from the CPM-led Left Democratic Front. The cabinet will include former Chief Minister CM Mohammed Koya of the Muslim League as Deputy Chief Minister and will initially consist of eight members, with plans for expansion later. The assembly will be convened promptly.

headline: "UDF minstry in Kerala to be sworn in tomorrow"
article:
The headline "UDF minstry in Kerala to be sworn in tomorrow" - Dec 27, 1981 from The Indian President's Rule in Kerala and the formation of a new United Democratic Front (UDF) government in the state.

The UDF is a coalition of political parties in Kerala that is led by the Indian National Congress. The UDF had won the 1980 Kerala Legislative Assembly election, but it had fallen short of a majority. As a result, President's Rule was imposed in the state.

In December 1981, the UDF was able to secure the support of an independent MLA, which gave it a majority in the state assembly. The UDF then formed a new government, which was sworn in on December 28, 1981.

The formation of the UDF government in Kerala was a significant event in Indian politics. It marked the end of President's Rule in the state and the return of democracy. It also showed that the UDF was able to unite and form a government despite its differences.

The UDF government in Kerala was led by K. Karunakaran. He had served as the Chief Minister of Kerala from 1977 to 1979. The UDF government was able to achieve some success in areas such as education, healthcare, and land reforms. However, it was also criticized for its corruption and nepotism.

The UDF government was defeated in the 1984 Kerala Legislative Assembly election by the Left Democratic Front (LDF), which was led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM).
summary: The UDF, a coalition of political parties in Kerala led by the Indian National Congress, formed a new government in the state on December 28, 1981, after securing the support of an independent MLA. This marked the end of President's Rule in Kerala and the return of democracy. The UDF government was led by K. Karunakaran and achieved some success in areas such as education, healthcare, and land reforms, but it was also criticized for its corruption and nepotism. The UDF government was defeated in the 1984 Kerala Legislative Assembly election by the Left Democratic Front (LDF).

headline: December 28, 1981, Forty Years Ago: No war pact
article: India has made it clear to Pakistan that a no-war pact between them could be in continuation and recognition of all elements of the Simla Agreement. The two countries could sign a no-war agreement provided Pakistan accepts the seven principles stipulated by India in an aide memoire to Pakistan. One of the important elements suggested by India for a no-war pact is that Pakistan should revert to bilateralism in all issues as provided for in the Simla Pact. Also Pakistan should take all steps to avert an arms race in the subcontinent. Adherence to non-alignment, respect for each other’s territorial integrity and settlement of all issues bilaterally were other key points of India’s missive. India is awaiting word from Pakistan about the dates of foreign minister Agha Shahi’s visit to Delhi.
summary:
Summary:
India has communicated to Pakistan that a potential no-war pact between them should adhere to all aspects of the Simla Agreement. India outlined seven principles in an aide memoire to Pakistan, including a return to bilateralism as outlined in the Simla Pact, efforts to prevent an arms race in the region, adherence to non-alignment, and respect for each other's territorial integrity. India awaits confirmation from Pakistan regarding the dates for Foreign Minister Agha Shahi's visit to Delhi.

headline: December 29, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Plan priorities
article: The Planning Commission has decided upon a reordering of plan priorities and reallocation of resources. In taking this decision, the commission had in view the demands of the areas for higher financial allocation — petroleum exploration and power generation. The sixth plan provides for an indigenous crude production of only 2.6 million tonnes by the last year of the Sixth Plan. Recently, while seeking the massive IMF loan, the government had assured a crude production of 30 million tonnes by the end of the plan period. This called for an increase in the allocation for this sector. The government is also committed to increase the allocation in some other core areas like steel and cement if imports are to be cut.
summary:
Summary:
The Planning Commission has decided to reorder plan priorities and reallocate resources, considering demands for higher financial allocation in areas such as petroleum exploration and power generation. The sixth plan initially projected indigenous crude production of 2.6 million tonnes by its end, but the government, in seeking a massive IMF loan, pledged to increase crude production to 30 million tonnes by then. This necessitates increased allocation for the petroleum sector. Additionally, the government aims to boost allocation in sectors like steel and cement to reduce imports.

headline: December 30, 1981, Forty Years Ago: PM on wars
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said that in the past, India had been attacked “without reason or logic” and it was thus extremely difficult to prophesise if there would be war in 1982. Addressing a press conference at Raj Bhavan during her one-day visit to West Bengal, the PM said it was imperative for India to have full defence preparedness. “A lot of people are talking peace but are getting ready for war”. She said India had been attacked five or six times and except for one occasion, the attacks had come from Pakistan. Besides, India had a vast coastline to guard. “India has never committed any aggression,” Mrs Gandhi said.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, during a press conference in West Bengal, stated that India had been attacked multiple times in the past without justification, making it difficult to predict the possibility of war in 1982. She emphasized the importance of maintaining full defense preparedness, noting that many nations speak of peace while preparing for war. Gandhi highlighted India's history of being attacked, primarily by Pakistan, and emphasized India's commitment to peace, stating that the country had never initiated aggression.

headline: December 31, 1981, Forty Years Ago: Judges’ case verdict
article:
The Supreme Court dismissed all writ petitions in the judges’ case and by a majority of 4-3 upheld the actions of the Union government on the three main questions involved. The transfer of Chief Justice K B N Singh of the Patna High Court, the government decision not to extend the term of the additional judge of the Delhi HC S N Kumar and the Law Minister’s circular to chief ministers to obtain the consent of transfer anywhere of those who wanted to be permanent judges, were held valid. Justices A C Gupta, V D Tulzapurkar, Justice K
S Pathak, and Justice E S Venkataramiah held that the transfer of the Patna Chief Justice was valid. However, Justice P N Bhagwati, presiding judge, Justice D A Desai and Justice Murtaza Fazal Ali, held that the transfer was in the nature of a punishment and it was in the case of Justice Singh that the Chief Justice of India filed an affidavit of his own to clarify the stages of consultation between him and Justice Singh. The Patna judge had contradicted the statements of the Chief Justice of India.
summary:
Summary:
The Supreme Court dismissed all writ petitions related to the judges' case, upholding the actions of the Union government on three main issues. By a majority of 4-3, the court affirmed the validity of Chief Justice K B N Singh's transfer from the Patna High Court, the government's decision regarding the extension of the term of additional judge S N Kumar of the Delhi High Court, and the Law Minister's circular regarding the transfer of judges. Justices A C Gupta, V D Tulzapurkar, K S Pathak, and E S Venkataramiah deemed the transfer of the Patna Chief Justice valid, while Justice P N Bhagwati, Justice D A Desai, and Justice Murtaza Fazal Ali viewed it as punitive. The disagreement stemmed from conflicting statements between the Chief Justice of India and Justice Singh regarding consultation processes.

headline: January 3, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Indira Blames Left
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi charged Marxists with using the administrative machinery in Kerala to strengthen their party. Inaugurating the plenary session of the state Congress (I), the prime minister said it was dangerous when a party used administrative machinery to strengthen itself. The Congress never resorted to this practice. She said that Kerala would not have been in an economic crisis had the Marxists not used the power for furthering their political end. She said her party was subjected to a continuous onslaught from both the left and the right. However, the stand of the Congress (I) was vindicated. Even the right parties had now accepted socialism and broadly supported her foreign policy. Even the Communists were following broadly Congress policies.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi accused the Marxists in Kerala of utilizing the administrative machinery to bolster their party's influence. Speaking at the plenary session of the state Congress (I), she criticized the practice, stating that the Congress never engaged in such tactics. Gandhi asserted that Kerala's economic crisis could have been avoided if the Marxists hadn't used their power for political gains. Despite facing opposition from both the left and the right, she claimed that the Congress (I)'s stance had been validated, with even right-wing parties now endorsing socialism and supporting her foreign policy. Gandhi remarked that even the Communists were aligning with Congress policies to some extent.

headline: January 7, 1982, Forty Years Ago: SC Attack Worries
article: Uttar Pradesh CM V P Singh disclosed that confidential reports of conspiracies to re-enact the Sadhopur carnage in the eastern districts of the state had been received. The government sounded a state-wide alert and ordered intensive police patrolling to protect Harijans. The CM stated that the reports had been received from the Varanasi and Gorakhpur ranges. He quoted B S Bedi, deputy inspector-general of the Gorakhpur range and the district magistrate of Deoria as having informed him about the conspiracies. He said he would not hesitate to order the arrests, under the National Security Act, of the elements involved on the possession of first evidence. He reiterated the commitment of his government to protect the lives and property of the Harijans.
summary:
Summary:
Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister V P Singh revealed that confidential reports have been received about conspiracies to replicate the Sadhopur carnage in the state's eastern districts. In response, the government has issued a statewide alert and ordered heightened police patrolling to safeguard Harijans. The reports, originating from the Varanasi and Gorakhpur ranges, were communicated by B S Bedi, the deputy inspector-general of the Gorakhpur range, and the district magistrate of Deoria. Singh emphasized the government's commitment to protecting the lives and property of Harijans and warned of arrests under the National Security Act if necessary evidence is found.

headline: January 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Unions On ESMA
article: The national campaign committee of trade unions has categorically told the government that it would consider postponement of the January 19 country wide general strike only if the government agreed to repeal the Essential Services Maintenance Act (ESMA). After a hurriedly convened meeting following their talks with the Union Labour Minister N D Tiwari, the committee issued a statement setting conditions for a positive response to the Minister’s appeal to them to cancel or defer the strike in the interest of the national economy. The statement said the national campaign committee had considered the Labour Minister’s appeal to withdraw or postpone the January 19 industrial general strike decision. The trade union leaders said that they were prepared to relegate 12 of the 13 demands for negotiation in the interests of avoiding a confrontation if the government was prepared to repeal ESMA.
summary:
Summary:
The national campaign committee of trade unions has conveyed to the government that they would only consider postponing the scheduled January 19 nationwide general strike if the government agreed to repeal the Essential Services Maintenance Act (ESMA). Following discussions with Union Labour Minister N D Tiwari, the committee issued a statement outlining their conditions for a possible response to the Minister's plea to cancel or delay the strike in the interest of the national economy. They expressed readiness to negotiate on 12 out of 13 demands if the government was willing to repeal ESMA.

headline: The real shootout at Wadala
article:
Sub-inspector Issac Bagwan, one of the branch’s ace detectives, had received a tip-off from one of his ‘khabris’ (informers) that gangster Manya Surve, who had eluded the cops for long, was likely to show up near Ambedkar College at Wadala in north-central Mumbai the next morning.


Little did Bagwan know, as he discussed the details of the tip-off with his colleagues, that their plan to trap Surve would lead to the first ever police encounter, a term that spawned a culture of its own in the Mumbai police force.

Bagwan told his colleagues that Manya had instructed the informer, a vehicle thief who had once spent a year with the gangster in Arthur Road jail, to leave a stolen car for him in the parking lot at Ambedkar College. “Manya wanted to use the car to rob a bank in Navi Mumbai,” Bagwan, who retired in 2011 as assistant commissioner of police (ACP), recalled.
summary:
Summary:
Sub-inspector Issac Bagwan, a renowned detective, received a tip-off from an informer about gangster Manya Surve's potential presence near Ambedkar College in Mumbai. Bagwan, unaware of the significance of the operation, discussed the plan with his colleagues. The plan aimed to trap Surve, who had evaded capture for some time. Surve had allegedly instructed the informer to leave a stolen car for him at the college parking lot, intending to use it for a bank robbery in Navi Mumbai.

headline: January 11, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Assam protests
article: The first day of the 36-hour civil disobedience passed off more or less peacefully with reports of only minor acts of sabotage and sporadic attempts at ticketless travel from different parts of the Brahmaputra valley. About 200 persons were arrested from all over the region. Of these, about 70 were preventive arrests and the remaining for attempting to travel ticketless. The All Assam Students Union and the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad had given a call for a 36-hour ticketless travel in government buses, trains and ferries, non-payment of entertainment tax in cinema halls and boycott of financial transactions in post offices.
summary:
Summary:
The first day of the 36-hour civil disobedience in Assam passed relatively peacefully, with minor incidents reported, such as sporadic attempts at ticketless travel and acts of sabotage. Around 200 people were arrested, with 70 taken preventively and the rest for attempting ticketless travel. The All Assam Students Union and the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad had called for various forms of civil disobedience, including ticketless travel, non-payment of entertainment tax in cinemas, and boycott of financial transactions in post offices.

headline: January 12, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Polish turmoil
article: Violent clashes between workers and strike-breaking military authorities were reported from Poland but Warsaw radio indicated that the country was calm and hard at work. The military government said union leader Lech Walesa was broken and weeping. The French Premier, Pierre Mauroy, has been told that there have been 45,000 arrests in Poland and 17 people killed in incidents since the military take over. Reports reaching Western diplomats in Bonn said that water cannon and baton charges were used against supporters of the Solidarity union. The diplomats said troops were brought to break strikes in Warsaw, Katowice and Gdansk, where there were unconfirmed reports of violence when the troops move in to clear the shipyards.
summary:
Summary:
Violent clashes erupted between workers and military authorities in Poland, despite Warsaw radio portraying a calm situation. The military government claimed that union leader Lech Walesa was subdued and emotional. French Premier Pierre Mauroy was informed of 45,000 arrests and 17 deaths since the military takeover. Reports from Western diplomats in Bonn indicated the use of water cannons and baton charges against Solidarity union supporters. Troops were deployed to quell strikes in Warsaw, Katowice, and Gdansk, with reports of violence in the shipyards as troops intervened.

headline: January 13, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Antulay resigns
article: Chief Minister of Maharashtra A R Antulay resigned on Tuesday night following the verdict against him by the Bombay High Court in the cement allotment case. Antulay submitted his letter of resignation to Maharashtra Governor O P Mehra. The governor accepted the chief minister’s resignation but has requested Antulay to continue in office until alternative arrangements are made, the Raj Bhavan announced. In his judgment, Justice B Lentin of the Bombay High Court held as justified the allegations that Antulay had arbitrarily allotted cement from the ad hoc quota to certain builders in consideration for donations to two trusts floated by him.
summary:
Summary:
Chief Minister of Maharashtra, A R Antulay, resigned following a verdict against him by the Bombay High Court in the cement allotment case. Antulay submitted his resignation to Governor O P Mehra, who accepted it but requested Antulay to continue until alternative arrangements were made. Justice B Lentin of the Bombay High Court upheld allegations that Antulay had arbitrarily allotted cement from the ad hoc quota to builders in exchange for donations to trusts he had established.

headline: January 14, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Assam Has New CM
article: Keshab Chandra Gogoi was sworn in as the new Chief Minister of Assam ending 197 days of President’s rule. He was sworn in by Governor Prakash Mehrotra at a simple ceremony at Raj Bhavan minutes after it was known in a surprise announcement that the governor had accepted Gogoi’s claim that he had the backing of 63 of the 125 members of the state assembly. Earlier, President N Sanjiva Reddy issued a proclamation revoking Governor’s rule imposed on Assam on June 30 last year and extending for another term of six months. Central rule was imposed when the government of Anwara Taimur failed to get the Assam appropriation bill passed by the assembly.
summary:
Summary:
Keshab Chandra Gogoi was sworn in as the new Chief Minister of Assam, ending 197 days of President's rule. Governor Prakash Mehrotra administered the oath of office to Gogoi in a simple ceremony at Raj Bhavan after it was announced that the governor had accepted Gogoi's claim of having the support of 63 out of 125 members of the state assembly. President N Sanjiva Reddy revoked Governor's rule, which was imposed on Assam on June 30 the previous year due to the failure of Anwara Taimur's government to pass the Assam appropriation bill.

headline: January 15, 1982, Forty Years Ago: 20 Point Programme
article: The PM has announced a recast and redefined 20-point programme. It has been dovetailed into an overall programme of development. Mrs Gandhi shared the details of the programme while marking two years in office since her return to power. The revision of the programme was necessary because of the accomplishment of some of its targets and new challenges. She reminded people how she had cautioned them not to expect miracles when she had first announced the programme in 1975. Then, as now, there was only one magic that could remove poverty — hard work backed by a clear sense of purpose. She told the nation to adopt the motto, “Satyamev jayate (truth will be victorious)”. To which she added, “Shramev jayate”.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has announced a revamp and redefinition of the 20-point program, integrating it into an overarching development agenda. This announcement coincides with her two years in office since returning to power. The revision was prompted by the achievement of some targets and the emergence of new challenges. Gandhi emphasized the need for hard work and a clear sense of purpose to alleviate poverty, echoing her stance when she first introduced the program in 1975. She urged the nation to adopt the motto "Satyamev Jayate" (truth will be victorious) and added "Shramev Jayate" (hard work will be victorious).

headline: January 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Trade union strike
article: Union Labour Minister Bhagwat Jha Azad has appealed to workers to desist from striking on January 19. Addressing his first press conference, Azad said he was trying to contact trade union leaders for a fresh round of talks on all pending issues, including the demands for which the strike was called for. The minister said that the government did not want a confrontation with the workers. He said the government was prepared to discuss all issues on the table and there was no need to stop the wheels of production at a time when production in farms and factories had started to pick up. Referring to the Essential Services Maintenance Act, Azad said that the Prime Minister has clarified that it will only be an enabling measure to be used in an emergency.
summary:
Summary:
Union Labour Minister Bhagwat Jha Azad has urged workers to refrain from participating in the strike scheduled for January 19. In his first press conference, Azad expressed his intention to initiate fresh talks with trade union leaders to address all pending issues, including those for which the strike was called. He emphasized the government's willingness to discuss all concerns and highlighted the importance of maintaining production momentum in farms and factories. Regarding the Essential Services Maintenance Act, Azad clarified that it would only be invoked in emergencies as an enabling measure.

headline: January 18, 1982, Forty Years Ago: NSA against strikers
article: Two days before the proposed industrial strike on January 19, at least four state governments on began preventive arrests. In Andhra Pradesh, six persons, deluding’ state BJP president P Chalapathi Rao and Mayor of Visakhapatnam N S Reddy, were arrested under the National Security Act. The others arrested were Visakhapatnam BJP president K S A N Gaju, CPI leader M V Bhadram and CITU leaders P. Kashi Bushan Rao and S Gangadhar Reddy. The Jammu and Kashmir government arrested a large number of people including Qazi Abdul Hahid, general secretary of Jammu and Kashmir Panthers. A government spokesman said that all arrangements had been made to ensure normal work in offices and factories.
summary:
Summary:
Two days before the scheduled industrial strike on January 19, several state governments initiated preventive arrests. In Andhra Pradesh, six individuals, including state BJP president P Chalapathi Rao and Visakhapatnam Mayor N S Reddy, were arrested under the National Security Act. Other arrested individuals included Visakhapatnam BJP president K S A N Gaju, CPI leader M V Bhadram, and CITU leaders P. Kashi Bushan Rao and S Gangadhar Reddy. Additionally, the Jammu and Kashmir government arrested numerous individuals, including Qazi Abdul Hahid, general secretary of Jammu and Kashmir Panthers. The governments stated that arrangements were in place to ensure normal functioning in offices and factories.

headline: January 19, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Trade union strike
article: Thousands of trade union leaders all over the country were taken into preventive custody on the eve of the nationwide industrial strike. Many union leaders went underground to avoid arrest while making final arrangements for the strike. The leaders of eight trade unions owing allegiance to left and right parties issued a final appeal to the working class to join the strike. The nationwide campaign committee of the trade unions which has called the strike to register a protest against the “anti-working class policies of Mrs Gandhi’s government, particularly laws such as ESMA and NSA” was convinced that all central trade unions except those affiliated to INTUC would participate in the strike. The impact of the strike is expected to be in public sector undertakings and private industries since services such as the railways, airlines, ports, docks, posts and telegraph and hospitals have been exempted from the strike.
summary:
Summary:
On the eve of the nationwide industrial strike, thousands of trade union leaders across the country were detained as a preventive measure. Some union leaders went into hiding to evade arrest while finalizing preparations for the strike. Leaders of eight trade unions affiliated with both left and right parties issued a final appeal for workers to participate in the strike. The strike, organized by the nationwide campaign committee of trade unions, aims to protest against the "anti-working class policies" of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's government, particularly laws such as the Essential Services Maintenance Act (ESMA) and the National Security Act (NSA). It is expected that all central trade unions, except those affiliated with INTUC, will participate in the strike. The strike's impact is anticipated to be felt in public sector undertakings and private industries, as services like railways, airlines, ports, docks, posts and telegraph, and hospitals have been exempted from the strike.

headline: January 21, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Assam Barrier
article: The first round of tripartite talks on foreigners in Assam ended on Wednesday without any agreement on the contentious issue of the detection formula. However, some progress was made when the meeting agreed on steps to strengthen the border with Bangladesh. The government agreed to erect a physical barrier line, a road all along the border and a zone “free of human habitation” on the Indian side of the international border in Assam. This is aimed at preventing infiltration in future. The government and the movement leaders will resume talks on February 8 with the help of the leaders of five major opposition parties to continue their search for a solution.
summary:
Summary:
The first round of tripartite talks on the issue of foreigners in Assam concluded without reaching an agreement on the detection formula. However, progress was made as the meeting agreed on measures to enhance border security with Bangladesh. These measures include the construction of a physical barrier along the border, the establishment of a road along the border, and the creation of a "free of human habitation" zone on the Indian side to prevent future infiltration. Talks will resume on February 8, with the assistance of leaders from five major opposition parties, in an effort to find a solution to the ongoing issue.

headline: January 22, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Attack On Darbara
article: Punjab Chief Minister Darbara Singh escaped an attack on his life when a Sikh youth pounced on him and hit him on the neck at Panchatta village, 45 kms from Jullundur. The assailant tried to take out a sharp-edged weapon but was overpowered by the police and public. The weapon was seized from him, the police said. Singh had gone to the village to inaugurate a one-day convention on national integration and communal harmony at Guru Nanak Navbharati College. About 40 people including film actor Raj Kapoor, Punjab Congress (I) Darshan Singh Kapurthala and Punjabi singer Surinder Kaur were sitting on the dais when the Punjab CM was assaulted. The youth believed to be a Dal Khalsa member has been identified as Iqbal Singh of Mangal Jandla village in Hoshiarpur.
summary:
Summary:
Punjab Chief Minister Darbara Singh narrowly escaped an assassination attempt when a Sikh youth attacked him at Panchatta village during an event on national integration and communal harmony. The assailant, identified as Iqbal Singh, attempted to strike Singh on the neck with a sharp-edged weapon but was subdued by police and attendees. Singh was unharmed, and the weapon was seized from the attacker. The incident occurred in the presence of notable figures including actor Raj Kapoor, Congress leader Darshan Singh Kapurthala, and singer Surinder Kaur. The attacker is believed to be affiliated with the Dal Khalsa group.

headline: January 24, 1982, Forty Years Ago: India-Europe Trade
article: The European Commission will remove the obstacles coming in the way of efforts to improve trade between India and the European Economic Community (EEC). However, it was for businessmen of both sides to take advantage of the political decisions according to Wilhelm Haferkamp, vice president of the Commission of the EEC. He was speaking after signing a document with the Commerce Minister Shivraj Patil at the end of the meeting of the Indo-EEC commission. Haferkamp repeated his insistence on the removal of obstacles but sidestepped a specific question on whether he considered the quota system on the entry of Indian textiles into the markets of 10 EEC countries as an obstacle or an irritant. He said textiles was a special issue and was the only such issue because of the unemployment in the textile industry in Europe.
summary:
Summary:
The European Commission expressed its commitment to removing obstacles hindering trade between India and the European Economic Community (EEC) during a meeting with Commerce Minister Shivraj Patil. Vice President Wilhelm Haferkamp emphasized the importance of political decisions but refrained from addressing the specific issue of quotas on Indian textile exports to EEC countries. Haferkamp acknowledged textiles as a sensitive issue due to unemployment concerns in Europe's textile industry.

headline: January 25, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Leh violence
article: One person was killed, and four others were injured when police opened fire to disperse a mob at Leh.The mob set fire to seven government buildings and government vehicles, according to an official report. The state Deputy Minister for Protocol, Sonam Wangchuk, who was negotiating with the agitators in the town had a narrow escape when the mob attacked him. According to the Divisional Commissioner of Kashmir G N Naik, about 3,000 people gathered in Leh and indulged in snow throwing at the police and the Central Reserve Police Force. The buildings the mob set on fire include the employment exchange, district information centre and the Central Reserve Police Force. The agitation was led by Congress (I) MP, Namgyal.
summary:
Summary:
Violence erupted in Leh, resulting in one fatality and four injuries, as police opened fire to disperse a mob that set fire to several government buildings and vehicles. The mob, led by Congress (I) MP Namgyal, engaged in snow throwing at police and Central Reserve Police Force personnel. State Deputy Minister for Protocol Sonam Wangchuk narrowly escaped an attack by the mob while negotiating with them. About 3,000 people participated in the agitation, according to Divisional Commissioner G N Naik.

headline: January 26, 1982, Forty Years Ago: President’s message
article: Addressing the nation on the eve of the 33rd Republic Day, President N Sanjiva Reddy expressed his concern over the recent instances of atrocities on the weaker sections and the disregard for moral values in public life. Reddy said he had chosen to speak on the disturbing features of the national scene as unless immediate action was taken to address the breakdown of moral values in public life, people’s faith in the political system would be undermined with consequences too frightening to contemplate. He appealed to all political parties to do some heart-searching. The spirit prevailing in the country was the antithesis of the noble spirit that animated the nation two decades ago. He said people might be willing to put up with more hardship if they saw a climate of greater austerity.
summary:
Summary:
President N Sanjiva Reddy, in his address on the eve of the 33rd Republic Day, expressed concern over recent instances of atrocities on weaker sections and the decline of moral values in public life. He emphasized the need for immediate action to address this breakdown, warning of dire consequences otherwise. Reddy called for introspection by political parties and highlighted a decline in the noble spirit that once animated the nation. He suggested that people might endure more hardship if they witnessed greater austerity.

headline: January 27, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Ranga’s Plea
article: Ranga whose execution is set for January 31 has filed another petition in the Supreme Court requesting it to review its latest decision. He has also sent another petition to the president seeking to do some hard work in the jail and requesting him to delink his case from that of Billa, the other accused in the gruesome Chopra murder case. In his fifth attempt to get a reduced sentence, Ranga has drawn attention to the role press played in the legal battle in this case. In November, Chief Justice Y V Chandrachud at a special sitting in his house admitted Ranga’s petition. There was a barrage of articles in the press criticising the move.
summary:
Summary:
Ranga, facing execution on January 31 for his involvement in the Chopra murder case, has filed another petition in the Supreme Court seeking a review of its latest decision. Additionally, he has petitioned the president to allow him to engage in hard work in jail and to separate his case from that of Billa, the other accused. This marks Ranga's fifth attempt to secure a reduced sentence, and he has highlighted the role of the press in his legal battle. Chief Justice Y V Chandrachud previously admitted Ranga's petition in November, which attracted criticism from the press.

headline: January 28, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Train Accident
article: Sixty-one persons died in a head-on collision between the Delhi-bound Dakshin Express and a stationary goods train outside Agra cantonment. Twenty-three persons were injured, five seriously. The accident occurred at 4.15 am within the Southern Express coming from Secunderabad on the wrong track leading to the goods yard and the goods train at considerable speed. Ten of its 14 bogies were derailed. The engines of the two trains collided, smashing the first bogie of the Express and completely compressing it to one-third of its actual size. All the dead and most of the injured were from this bogie. Fifty eight bodies were recovered from this mass of twisted metal and till 6 pm rescue teams were still at work to extricate three more bodies trapped inside. This bogie, attached to the engine, comprised the Railway Mail Service personnel, the luggage-cum-brake van and a small second-class unreserved compartment.
summary:
Summary:
A tragic accident occurred near Agra cantonment involving the Delhi-bound Dakshin Express and a stationary goods train, resulting in 61 fatalities and 23 injuries. The accident happened when the Dakshin Express, traveling from Secunderabad, mistakenly took the wrong track leading to the goods yard and collided with the goods train. Ten of the Express's bogies derailed upon impact, with the engines of both trains colliding. The first bogie of the Express, housing Railway Mail Service personnel and luggage, suffered the most damage, with 58 bodies recovered from the wreckage. Rescue efforts were ongoing to extricate three more trapped bodies.

headline: January 31, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Peace with Pak
article: The Prime Minister has offered to sign a treaty of peace and friendship with Pakistan. Surprisingly, Mrs Gandhi made her offer at the end of her hour-long meeting with Pakistani journalists and not at the formal Indo-Pakistan talks that began on January 30. While Indian officials were attaching considerable importance to Mrs Gandhi’s remarks, the Pakistani delegation did not appear to be impressed by it. Pakistani journalists, who heard Mrs Gandhi, said her offer came too casually and in response to a question by journalist on the Indo-Soviet friendship treaty. It’s possible that Prime Minister Gandhi made the offer to see how the Pakistani side would react to it. Perhaps, it was an attempt to recover lost ground after initial opposition to talks on Pakistan’s proposal for a no-war pact.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi surprised many by offering to sign a treaty of peace and friendship with Pakistan during a meeting with Pakistani journalists, rather than at the formal Indo-Pakistan talks. The offer was made casually in response to a question about the Indo-Soviet friendship treaty. While Indian officials viewed the offer with significance, the Pakistani delegation seemed unimpressed. It's speculated that Gandhi's offer may have been aimed at gauging Pakistan's reaction and possibly to regain ground after initial opposition to talks on Pakistan's proposal for a no-war pact.

headline: February 2, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Kerala Assembly
article: On a day of high drama in the Kerala Assembly, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker resigned to join the ranks of the opposition and the Janata Legislature Party split to give a one-vote edge to the ruling side. The Assembly, which met in the morning adjourned abruptly, as the speaker, A P Kurian, a motion for whose removal was listed first on the agenda, made the dramatic announcement of his resignation. The Deputy Speaker, Zakaria Saif, who accepted the resignation and took the chair, announced the adjournment of the House and his own intention to resign. Minutes before the Assemby session started, the five-member Janata Legislature Party split formally, with three members — Mr P Bhaskaran, Mr P C Thomas and Mrs Kamalam — walking out to offer their support to the one-month-old Karunakaran ministry, in defiance of the party high command’s directive.
summary:
Summary:
In a dramatic turn of events in the Kerala Assembly, both the Speaker and Deputy Speaker resigned, joining the opposition ranks. Additionally, the Janata Legislature Party split, with three members defecting to support the ruling Karunakaran ministry against the party's directive. The Assembly session adjourned abruptly following these developments.

headline: February 3, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Bad Behaviour
article: M L Jadam, leader of the Indian contingent to the Mini-Commonwealth Games in Brisbane, Australia, last year, has explained to the Indian Olympic Association (IOA) that a delegation of uninvited officials of the Asian Games not only usurped the facilities meant for the team but lowered the prestige of the country by their behaviour. In particular, Jadam was embarrassed by an unseemly wrangle in front of he foreign sports representatives as to who was heading the delegation. Two overzealous members of the Asian Games Organising COmmittee, S S Gill and C M Muthiah, insisted that the Delhi MP and non-sportsman, KHL Bhagat was the team leader and should be given the honour of awarding medals. The puzzled representatives of the International Wrestling Association did not know what to make of this confusion, since various team managers claimed that the IOA had appointed Jadam to the post.
summary:
Summary:
M.L.
