Jadam, leader of the Indian contingent to the Mini-Commonwealth Games in Brisbane, Australia, reported to the Indian Olympic Association (IOA) about uninvited officials from the Asian Games disrupting their operations and causing embarrassment. Specifically, two members of the Asian Games Organising Committee, S.S. Gill and C.M. Muthiah, created confusion by insisting that Delhi MP K.H.L. Bhagat was the team leader, leading to an unseemly wrangle in front of foreign sports representatives.

headline: "Kerala no-trust move taken up amid uproar"
article:
The headline "Kerala no-trust move taken up amid uproar" - Feb 4, 1982 from The Indian Express refers to the start of a no-confidence motion against the government of K. Karunakaran, the then-Chief Minister of Kerala. The motion was brought by the opposition parties in Kerala, which were led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM).

The no-confidence motion was a closely watched event, as it was seen as a test of the Karunakaran government's strength in the Assembly. The UDF had a majority of one vote in the Assembly, but two UDF MLAs had rebelled and were supporting the no-confidence motion.

The debate on the no-confidence motion began on February 4, 1982. The opposition parties accused the Karunakaran government of corruption, nepotism, and economic mismanagement. The government defended its record and argued that it had done its best to improve the lives of the people of Kerala.

The debate on the no-confidence motion was marked by uproar and protests from both sides. The Speaker of the Assembly, A.C. Jose, had to repeatedly intervene to restore order.

The debate on the no-confidence motion continued for two days. On February 5, 1982, the motion was put to vote. The motion was defeated by a single vote, thanks to the casting vote of the Speaker.

The defeat of the no-confidence motion was a significant victory for the Karunakaran government. It showed that the government had the support of the majority of MLAs in the Assembly. It also showed that the UDF was able to unite and defeat the opposition challenge.
summary: The no-confidence motion against the government of K. Karunakaran, the then-Chief Minister of Kerala, was taken up amid uproar on February 4, 1982. The motion was brought by the opposition parties in Kerala, which were led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM). The debate on the motion was marked by uproar and protests from both sides. The motion was defeated by a single vote on February 5, 1982, thanks to the casting vote of the Speaker. The defeat of the motion was a significant victory for the Karunakaran government.

headline: February 4, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Kerala Crisis
article: The ruling side and the Opposition fought every inch of the ground as the assembly began its two-day debate on the no-confidence motion against the 38-day old Karunakaran ministry. The debate started immediately after the new Speaker A C Jose was elected uncontested and was installed. It progressed through a series of bitter procedural wrangles and arguments over proprieties. It’s expected to end with the crucial voting on February 4. The Opposition’s main point was that the government still did not have a majority, that the governor had committed impropriety in installing it, that the Government was the child of political immorality propped up by defections and that the casting vote of the speaker could not sustain a government. The government side countered this by saying that the misrule of the Marxist-led government had forced the democratic forces to come together.
summary:
Summary:
The Kerala Assembly commenced its two-day debate on a no-confidence motion against the 38-day old Karunakaran ministry, marked by intense battles between the ruling side and the Opposition. The debate, initiated immediately after the election of the new Speaker A.C. Jose, involved bitter procedural disputes and arguments over propriety. The voting on the motion is scheduled for February 4. The Opposition criticized the government's lack of majority, alleged impropriety in its installation by the governor, and denounced it as a product of political immorality. In response, the government defended its formation as a response to the misrule of the Marxist-led government.

headline: "Speaker's vote saves Karunakaran Govt"
article:
The headline "Speaker's vote saves Karunakaran Govt" - Feb 5, 1982 from The Indian Express refers to the outcome of a no-confidence motion that was brought against the government of K. Karunakaran, the then-Chief Minister of Kerala. The motion was defeated by a single vote, thanks to the casting vote of the Speaker of the Assembly.

The no-confidence motion was brought by the opposition parties in Kerala, which were led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM). The opposition parties had accused the Karunakaran government of corruption, nepotism, and economic mismanagement.

The no-confidence motion was a closely fought battle. The ruling United Democratic Front (UDF) had a majority of one vote in the Assembly. However, two UDF MLAs voted against the government, while three others were suspended from the party for defying the party whip. As a result, the UDF and the opposition were tied at 70 votes each.

The Speaker of the Assembly, A.C. Jose, then cast his vote against the no-confidence motion, saving the Karunakaran government. Jose was a member of the Congress (S), a constituent party of the UDF.

The defeat of the no-confidence motion was a significant victory for the Karunakaran government. It showed that the government had the support of the majority of MLAs in the Assembly. It also showed that the UDF was able to unite and defeat the opposition challenge.

The Karunakaran government went on to complete its full term in office. However, it was defeated in the 1984 Kerala Legislative Assembly election by the Left Democratic Front (LDF), which was led by the CPM.
summary: A no-confidence motion brought against the government of K. Karunakaran, the then-Chief Minister of Kerala, was defeated by a single vote on February 5, 1982, thanks to the casting vote of the Speaker of the Assembly. This was a significant victory for the Karunakaran government, as it showed that it had the support of the majority of MLAs in the Assembly and that the UDF was able to unite and defeat the opposition challenge.

This was a significant victory for the Karunakaran government, as it showed that it had the support of the majority of MLAs in the Assembly and that the UDF was able to unite and defeat the opposition challenge.

headline: February 5, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Speaker Saves Govt
article: The 39-day-old United Democratic Front Ministry, headed by Congress (I) leader K Karunakaran, survived its first trial of strength in the Assembly, defeating a no-confidence motion with the help of the casting vote of the Speaker and the vote of a nominated member. In the voting which followed 12 hours of acrimonious debate spread over two days, the ruling side and the opposition were tied at 70 each. A G Jose, who belonged to the Congress (S) until his election as Speaker on Wednesday, then exercised his casting vote against the no-confidence motion. Two members of the Janata Party voted against the government, while three others who were suspended from the party, voted for it. The lone independent member of the House, K K Nair, also voted for the government.
summary:
Summary:
The 39-day-old United Democratic Front Ministry in Kerala, led by Congress (I) leader K. Karunakaran, survived a no-confidence motion in the Assembly. After 12 hours of heated debate over two days, the ruling side and the opposition tied at 70 votes each. Speaker A.G. Jose, formerly of Congress (S), cast the deciding vote against the motion, while a nominated member also supported the government. Two Janata Party members voted against the government, while three suspended members voted in its favor. Additionally, the lone independent member of the House supported the government.

headline: February 7, 1982, Forty Years Ago: PM’s Concern
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed serious concern over the country’s prospects of foreign economic aid and said: “We are going to face increasing difficulties.” Mrs Gandhi, who was addressing a press conference in Ahmedabad at the end of her two-day visit to Gujarat, made this remark when she was asked about the World Bank decision to cut aid to this country. Asked if she saw in the World Bank decision an indication of the US economic offensive against this country, she said: “It is for you to judge.” The prime minister is understood to have taken a grim view of the economic situation facing the country.
summary:
Summary:
During a press conference in Ahmedabad at the end of her visit to Gujarat, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed serious concern about the country's prospects of receiving foreign economic aid, particularly in light of the World Bank's decision to reduce aid. When asked about the implications of this decision and whether it signaled a broader economic offensive against India, Gandhi declined to comment directly, leaving it to the interpretation of the public. However, she conveyed a grim view of the economic situation facing the country.

headline: February 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Air Force crash
article: Twenty-three military personnel and crew were killed when an Air Force Packet aircraft crashed in blinding snow and rain in the Lohi Malhar hilly area in Kathua, 136 km northeast of Jammu. Police and rescue parties, which went to the accident site, found 15 mutilated bodies. Search for more bodies was abandoned because of approaching darkness, and heavy rain and snowfall. According to a senior Air Force official, the aircraft left Pathankot in the morning for Leh with supplies of troops in forward areas and servicemen returning from leave. An official source said the crash occurred when the pilot on encountering rough weather tried to return to base but lost radio contact. A police picket which saw the aircraft crash informed the Kathua police.
summary:
Summary:
A tragic incident occurred when an Air Force Packet aircraft crashed in the Lohi Malhar hilly area in Kathua, resulting in the deaths of twenty-three military personnel and crew members. The crash happened amid blinding snow and rain, making rescue operations challenging. The aircraft, which was carrying troops and servicemen returning from leave, departed from Pathankot but encountered rough weather, leading to the tragic accident. Despite efforts by police and rescue teams, only 15 bodies were recovered due to adverse weather conditions.

headline: February 9, 1982, Forty Years Ago: NSA imposed
article: The Union Ministry notified a list of 16 categories of services and supplies as essential to the community under the National Security Act. This empowers the government to detain any person with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of these essential supplies and services. A notification has been issued under Section 3 of the National Security Act to overcome any objection raised by the Supreme Court in its jurisdiction on three writ petitions challenging detentions under the Act. The Supreme Court had ruled that no person can be detained with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community, unless by a law or notification issued well in advance.
summary:
Summary:
The Union Ministry issued a notification listing 16 categories of services and supplies as essential to the community under the National Security Act. This move grants the government the authority to detain individuals to prevent them from acting in ways detrimental to the maintenance of these essential services. The notification was issued to address objections raised by the Supreme Court in response to writ petitions challenging detentions under the Act. The Supreme Court had previously ruled that detentions under the Act could only occur in accordance with a law or notification issued well in advance.

headline: February 1, 1982, Forty Years Ago The suggestion to set up a joint commission was made by the PM when Pakistan Foreign Minister Agha Shahi met her.
article: While the talks on a no-war pact are not making any headway, India and Pakistan agreed to set up a joint commission to tackle bilateral problems. The suggestion to set up a joint commission was made by the PM when Pakistan Foreign Minister Agha Shahi met her. Shahi accepted the proposal immediately. While details about the composition of commission — its mandate and how often it should meet — are yet to be discussed by the two governments, the foreign ministers of the two countries are likely to be its co-chairmen. Both India and Pakistan have joint commission arrangements with many countries, but this is the first time the two countries will be setting up an institutional mechanism to tackle nagging bilateral problems. Problems concerning Indo-Pak trade, travel facilities, communications, cultural exchanges and perhaps the settlement of a maritime boundary are likely to be referred to the proposed joint commission.
summary:
Summary:
India and Pakistan have agreed to establish a joint commission to address bilateral issues, following a suggestion by Indian Prime Minister during a meeting with Pakistan's Foreign Minister Agha Shahi. Shahi promptly accepted the proposal. While details such as the composition, mandate, and frequency of meetings are yet to be discussed, it's anticipated that the foreign ministers of both countries will co-chair the commission. This marks the first time the two nations will have an institutional mechanism to address persistent bilateral issues, including trade, travel, communication, cultural exchanges, and potentially the settlement of maritime boundaries.

headline: February 10, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Snap polls
article: The Congress-I high command is thinking in terms of snap polls for the Andhra Pradesh Assembly. In the normal course, the state is due to go for polls in February next year, along with Karnataka. However, the high command seems to favour early polls in both states along with West Bengal, Haryana and Himachal Pradesh. Kerala may also be clubbed if the high command feels the Karunakaran ministry will survive. Though the idea of early polls was considered, a decision was not taken by the high command as it was awaiting the decision of the Election Commission on the allegedly inflated voters’ list in West Bengal.
summary:
Summary:
The Congress-I high command is contemplating the possibility of holding snap polls for the Andhra Pradesh Assembly. While the state is scheduled for elections in February next year, the high command is leaning towards early polls along with Karnataka, West Bengal, Haryana, and Himachal Pradesh. There is also consideration for including Kerala if the Karunakaran ministry remains stable. However, a final decision has not been made as the high command awaits the Election Commission's decision on the alleged inflation of the voters' list in West Bengal.

headline: February 11, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Assam Talks Fail
article: The second round of tripartite talks on the future of foreigners in Assam ended in a deadlock. After a four-and-a-half-hour marathon meeting, official sources and movement leaders reported the virtual failure of their renewed efforts to evolve an acceptable principle for the detection of foreign nationals. Talks were adjourned without fixing any fresh dates for the next round. The home minister reportedly assured the meeting that he would fix the dates soon. What led to a breakdown of the talks was the conflicting views on the definition of a foreigner and the government’s insistence to adhere to the “policy instructions” issued by it in 1965 under which a large number of Hindu refugees crossed over to India from East Pakistan after the Indo-Pak conflict.
summary:
Summary:
The second round of tripartite talks on the issue of foreigners in Assam ended in a deadlock, with conflicting views on the definition of a foreigner and the government's adherence to policy instructions from 1965 being major sticking points. After a lengthy meeting, efforts to reach an acceptable principle for the detection of foreign nationals failed, leading to the adjournment of talks without setting fresh dates for further discussions. The home minister indicated that he would schedule future meetings soon.

headline: February 12, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Turmoil in Dhaka
article: Bangladesh President Abdus Sattar has dissolved the 42-member council of ministers in the face of the “grave crisis facing the nation” and to rid the administration of “corruption and inertness”. The dissolution of the 77-day-old ministry was announced by the President in an unscheduled address to the nation over radio and TV. The 77-year old Sattar who got a massive mandate from the people in the November presidential election to succeed Ziaur Rahman assured the nation that a smaller council of ministers will be formed in a day. He said he had decided to dissolve the ministry because doubts seemed to have arisen in people’s minds over the honesty and integrity of some of the ministers. He appealed to the people to cooperate with the government in removing corruption.
summary:
Summary:
Bangladesh President Abdus Sattar dissolved the 42-member council of ministers due to the "grave crisis facing the nation" and to address concerns regarding corruption and inefficiency in the administration. The announcement came unexpectedly through a radio and TV address to the nation. President Sattar, who succeeded Ziaur Rahman after a massive mandate in the November presidential election, assured the formation of a smaller council of ministers within a day. He emphasized the need to tackle corruption and called for cooperation from the public in this endeavor.

headline: February 14, 1982, Forty Years Ago: No Mid-term Polls
article: Mrs Gandhi has ruled out the possibility of mid-term elections in any state. Elections will, however, be held in states where they are due, she told reporters in Bhopal. The Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh was not being asked to step down nor were there plans for any leadership change in other states, she said. Radical improvement was called for in the judiciary and administration and the system of education to realise the goal of a socialist and egalitarian society. Whatever the form of government, there was a scope for better, she said when asked whether there were efforts to shift to the presidential system.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has dismissed the possibility of mid-term elections in any state, affirming that elections will take place only where they are due. She clarified that there were no plans for the Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh to step down or for leadership changes in other states. Mrs. Gandhi emphasized the need for significant improvements in the judiciary, administration, and education system to achieve the goal of a socialist and egalitarian society. When questioned about a potential shift to the presidential system, she stated that regardless of the form of government, there is room for improvement.

headline: February 15, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Charan and Jagjivan
article: Charan Singh and Jagjivan Ram on Sunday commenced their political ride together with a joint appearance at a huge public meeting in Hissar. The two leaders, whose differences contributed to the disintegration of the Janata Party, came in the same car from Delhi to Hissar where they were given a tumultuous welcome by workers of the Lok Dal and the Congress (J). But they said their appearance together should not be construed as an understanding for forthcoming assembly elections or a precursor to the merger of the Lok Dal and the Congress (J). The two leaders said the present circumstances had forced them to come together.
summary:
Summary:
Charan Singh and Jagjivan Ram made a joint appearance at a large public meeting in Hissar, signaling the start of their political collaboration. Despite their past differences that led to the breakup of the Janata Party, they arrived together in the same car from Delhi to Hissar, where they received a warm welcome from Lok Dal and Congress (J) workers. However, they clarified that their joint appearance should not be seen as an indication of an understanding for upcoming assembly elections or a prelude to the merger of Lok Dal and Congress (J). Instead, they attributed their collaboration to current circumstances.

headline: February 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Anjiah To Quit
article: Within minutes of the arrival of the Union Industries Minister N D Tiwari and the AICC(I) general secretary G K Moopanar in Hyderabad, T Anjiah announced that he had informed the party high command of his desire to step down as chief minister. The two observers from Delhi drove from the Lake View guesthouse to the Praja Bhawan, the official residence of the CM for consultations. Emerging from the room while the discussions were on, Anjiah beckoned the reporters and made the announcement. He said that he communicated his desire to step down two days ago. He is likely to submit his resignation to the governor after the observers submit their report.
summary:
Summary:
Union Industries Minister N D Tiwari and AICC(I) General Secretary G K Moopanar arrived in Hyderabad, prompting Chief Minister T Anjiah to announce his intention to step down. Anjiah informed the party high command of his decision and made the announcement to reporters during consultations with the observers. He is expected to submit his resignation to the governor after the observers submit their report.

headline: February 19, 1982, Forty Years Ago: President Talks Amity
article: The President N Sanjiva Reddy urged parliamentarians to ensure that differences between them do not degenerate into discord. Political differences are bound to exist in a democracy but the good of the nation is an objective for which all the members must learn to cooperate, transcending principles. Addressing a Joint Sitting of the two Houses, the President observed that the first two years of the Sixth Plan should be regarded as the years of consolidation. In his eight page long speech which will be his last in Parliament — he retires in July — Reddy spoke of the achievements of the government. He referred to the 20 Point Programme four times.
summary:
Summary:
President N Sanjiva Reddy addressed a Joint Sitting of Parliament, urging parliamentarians to ensure that political differences do not lead to discord. He emphasized the importance of cooperation for the good of the nation, highlighting the achievements of the government and referring to the 20 Point Programme multiple times. This speech, likely his last in Parliament as he retires in July, also emphasized the consolidation phase of the Sixth Plan during its first two years.

headline: February 22, 1982, Forty Years Ago: India-Tanzania Talks
article: India and Tanzania expressed grave concern at the building up of military arsenals in the Indian Ocean and resolved to work together to make the Ocean a zone of peace. Speaking at the banquet organised for the visiting Tanzanian President Julius Nyeyrere, the President N Sanjiva Reddy said that the Indian Ocean was now bristling with lethal weaponry and it was essential to strengthen efforts to reduce tension and create peace. Nyeyrere who had arrived earlier on February 21 said that India and Tanzania were collaborating to make the Indian Ocean a zone of peace. He criticised South Africa for its continued defiance of international public opinion and sanctions against its “odious racist policies”. Reddy said India was proud to link with friends in the struggle for justice.
summary:
Summary:
President N Sanjiva Reddy addressed a Joint Sitting of Parliament, urging parliamentarians to ensure that political differences do not lead to discord. He emphasized the importance of cooperation for the good of the nation, highlighting the achievements of the government and referring to the 20 Point Programme multiple times. This speech, likely his last in Parliament as he retires in July, also emphasized the consolidation phase of the Sixth Plan during its first two years.

headline: February 23, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Delhi summit
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stressed the need for agreement on immediate global negotiations “to make international economic cooperation more efficacious”. Inaugurating a three-day meeting of 44 developing countries in New Delhi, Mrs Gandhi said, “We cannot remain silent spectators and must exert ourselves to arrest the visible deterioration in the global economy. Unchecked, this disturbing trend could have disastrous consequences for mankind.” The need for an agreement on the immediate launching of global negotiations was the first of the nine points she underlined for consideration by the delegates, whose agenda, she said, “deals with issues concerning the functioning of a viable system of global economic co-operation”.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi emphasized the urgency of initiating global negotiations to enhance international economic cooperation during the inauguration of a three-day meeting of 44 developing countries in New Delhi. Stressing the potential disastrous consequences of the deteriorating global economy, she outlined nine points for consideration by the delegates, focusing on the need to address issues related to a viable system of global economic cooperation.

headline: February 26, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Rao Talks Tough
article: External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao told the Rajya Sabha that Agha Hilaly’s objectionable statements in the Human Rights Commission had vitiated the atmosphere for further talks on the specifics of the no-war pact and a treaty of peace and friendship. Making a statement in response to a call in attention motion by H C Rawat, Rao said by his contentious reference to Jammu and Kashmir, the Pakistani delegate had done a disservice to the proposed talks between foreign secretaries. He said it will take much time to undo the damage created by the Pakistani diplomat’s speech. In this vitiated atmosphere nothing will be served by the foreign secretary’s visit to Pakistan. Pakistan ambassador Abdus Sattar was in the visitor’s gallery when Rao was delivering his speech.
summary:
Summary:
External Affairs Minister P V Narasimha Rao informed the Rajya Sabha that objectionable statements made by Agha Hilaly at the Human Rights Commission had disrupted the atmosphere for further talks on a no-war pact and a treaty of peace and friendship. Rao stated that Hilaly's remarks on Jammu and Kashmir had harmed the prospects of proposed talks between foreign secretaries, and as a result, the visit by India's Foreign Secretary to Pakistan would be postponed. Pakistan's ambassador Abdus Sattar was present in the visitor's gallery during Rao's speech.

headline: February 28, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Taxes and relief
article: Inland letters, envelopes, cement, tyres and sophisticated electronic equipment will cost more following a heavy dose of taxation – Rs 533 crore net – proposed by Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee in the Union Budget. The reliefs announced by him are concessions to the individual taxpayer and pensioners, small tax relief for incremental exports, help for construction projects abroad, rationalisation of capital gains and reduction of excise duty on consumer items such as ballpoint pens, pencils, thermos flasks, erasers, water coolers and toothbrushes, braille typewriters, invalid carriages, and helmets. The Finance Minister gave some minor incentives to people from lower-income groups concerning house construction. He announced a wealth tax on tea and coffee plantations.
summary:
Summary:
Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee proposed significant taxation increases, totaling Rs 533 crore, affecting items like inland letters, envelopes, cement, tyres, and sophisticated electronic equipment in the Union Budget. However, he also announced reliefs for individual taxpayers, pensioners, and small tax relief for incremental exports. Additionally, concessions were provided for construction projects abroad, rationalization of capital gains, and reduced excise duty on consumer items like ballpoint pens, pencils, thermos flasks, erasers, water coolers, toothbrushes, braille typewriters, invalid carriages, and helmets. Minor incentives for lower-income groups related to house construction were also introduced, along with the announcement of a wealth tax on tea and coffee plantations.

headline: March 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Merger Talks
article: The Lok Dal has decided to make the last bid for its unification with the Congress (S) and the Janata Party within the next five weeks. The national executive of the party, which adopted a resolution to this effect, however, gave an ultimatum to the two parties that the Lok Dal would go ahead with its independent identity if they failed to agree on the merger by mid-April. Some members, however, criticised party president Charan Singh’s action in “unilaterally” dissolving the coordination committee comprising nominees of the Janata Party, the Congress (S ) and the Lok Dal, set up to facilitate their unification. Charan Singh is reported to have explained that the committee had outlived its utility.
summary:
Summary:
The Lok Dal has decided to pursue the unification with the Congress (S) and the Janata Party within the next five weeks. However, the party has issued an ultimatum to the two parties, stating that if they fail to agree on the merger by mid-April, the Lok Dal will maintain its independent identity. Some members criticized party president Charan Singh for dissolving the coordination committee without consultation, but Singh defended his action, stating that the committee had served its purpose.

headline: March 9, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Secret Letter
article: The Central government’s secret policy instructions on grant of citizenship to refugees from erstwhile East Pakistan early and to confer special privileges on entrants belonging to minority communities. It is now these instructions over which the Assam talks have stalled. Some of these instructions were contained in secret letter No. 4/366/63-IC of June 16, 1965. It said: “…the question of registration as Indian citizens of members or the minority communities who have, recently, migrated from East Pakistan, has been under consideration… It has been decided that such of the migrants (where they live come with or without migration certificates or travel documents) as have severed their ties and connections with Pakistan and have settled in service, trade or profession in India, may be registered as Indian citizens.
summary:
Summary:
The Assam talks have hit a deadlock due to the Central government's secret policy instructions regarding the grant of citizenship to refugees from former East Pakistan and conferring special privileges on minority communities. These instructions, outlined in a secret letter from 1965, detail the criteria for registering migrants from East Pakistan as Indian citizens, emphasizing severance of ties with Pakistan and settlement in India.

headline: March 10, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Anti-liquor Violence
article: In a major outbreak of violence, anti-liquor agitators indulging in looting, clashed with the police in Anantnag town in Kashmir, leaving at least 65 people injured. The police fired several rounds in the air to disperse unruly supporters of the pro-Pakistan Peoples League who took to the streets for the second day and forced shopkeepers to close their shops. The police swung into action with firearms after lathi-charge and tear gas had little effect on the mob demanding a ban on the sale of liquor. Infuriated at the police action to re-open the closed shops, pickets of the Peoples League looted several wine shops, threw liquor bottles on the roadside and stoned police personnel.
summary:
Summary:
In Anantnag town, Kashmir, clashes erupted between anti-liquor protesters and police, resulting in at least 65 injuries. Pro-Pakistan Peoples League supporters demanded a liquor ban, leading to the closure of shops. Despite police attempts to disperse the crowd with lathi-charges and tear gas, firearms were eventually used after shop re-openings prompted looting and violence.

headline: March 11, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Arson In Kashmir
article: In a major outbreak of violence, anti-liquor agitators indulging in looting clashed with the police on Tuesday in Anantnag town, 50 km from Srinagar leaving at least 65 persons injured including a magistrate and some senior police officers. The police fired several rounds in the air to disperse unruly supporters of the pro-Pakistan People’s League who took to the street for the second day and forced shopkeepers to down their shutters. The police swung into action with firearms after lathicharge had little effect on the mob demanding a ban on sale of liquor. Infuriated by the police action to re-open the closed shops, threw liquor bottles on the roadside and stoned police personnel in the roadside.
summary:
Summary:
Violent clashes erupted in Anantnag town, Kashmir, between anti-liquor protesters and police, resulting in at least 65 injuries, including a magistrate and senior police officers. Pro-Pakistan People's League supporters demanded a liquor ban, prompting shop closures. Despite initial attempts at dispersal with lathi-charges, police resorted to firearms after escalating violence, including looting and attacks on personnel.

headline: March 14, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Ustinov’s Visit
article: The chief of the army staff General V K Krishna Rao is believed to have postponed indefinitely his visit to France in view of the next visit by Soviet Defence Minister Marshall Dmitri Ustinov who is arriving in Delhi on March 15. Chief of the Air Staff Air Marshall Dilbagh Singh is cutting short his current visit to Britain by a couple of days to be available in time for the Soviet Defence Minister’s visit. General Rao will meet Dmitri Ustinov on the evening of March 15. Ustinov is not only the head of the massive Soviet defence machinery, he is also one of the most senior party leaders and a member of the politburo, who despite his 70 years is considered among the potential successors of President Brezhnev.
summary:
Summary:
The Chief of the Army Staff, General V K Krishna Rao, has reportedly postponed his visit to France indefinitely due to the upcoming visit of Soviet Defence Minister Marshall Dmitri Ustinov to Delhi on March 15. Air Marshal Dilbagh Singh is also cutting short his visit to Britain to be available for Ustinov's visit. General Rao is scheduled to meet Ustinov on the evening of March 15. Ustinov, a senior party leader and member of the politburo, is considered a potential successor to President Brezhnev.

headline: March 15, 1982, Forty Years Ago: 20-point programme
article: The National Development Council gave its stamp of approval to the prime minister’s 20-point programme. According to Planning Minister S B Chavan, the approval was given with one state, Tripura, expressing reservation. West Bengal Chief Minister Jyoti-Basu had also expressed reservations with certain aspects of the programme but was not present when the resolution was adopted. The CMs of the other two Opposition states — Jammu Kashmir and Tamil Nadu — stayed away from the meeting, sending instead their finance ministers. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi admitted that progress on meeting the targets of the Sixth Plan had suffered but blamed the state governments.
summary:
Summary:
The National Development Council (NDC) approved Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's 20-point program, with only Tripura expressing reservations. West Bengal Chief Minister Jyoti Basu had reservations but was absent during the adoption of the resolution. The Chief Ministers of Jammu and Kashmir and Tamil Nadu were also absent, with their finance ministers attending instead. Indira Gandhi acknowledged that progress on meeting the targets of the Sixth Plan had suffered, attributing it to the state governments.

headline: "4 DA instalments to be paid; arrears for PF"
article:
The headline "4 DA instalments to be paid; arrears for PF" - March 16, 1982 from The Indian Express refers to the Indian government's decision to pay four instalments of dearness allowance (DA) to its employees, as well as arrears for provident fund (PF) contributions. This was a significant decision, as it came at a time of high inflation and economic hardship.

DA is a type of allowance that is paid to government employees in India to compensate them for the rising cost of living. PF is a retirement savings scheme that is mandatory for all government employees.

The Indian government's decision to pay four instalments of DA and arrears for PF was welcomed by government employees. It was seen as a sign of the government's commitment to the welfare of its employees.

The decision also had a positive impact on the Indian economy. It boosted the purchasing power of government employees, which led to increased consumption and economic growth.

The payment of four instalments of DA and arrears for PF also had a positive impact on the morale of government employees. It showed that the government was concerned about their well-being and was willing to take steps to improve their financial situation.

Overall, the Indian government's decision to pay four instalments of DA and arrears for PF was a positive one. It benefited both government employees and the Indian economy.
summary: The Indian government's decision to pay four instalments of dearness allowance (DA) and arrears for provident fund (PF) contributions in 1982 was a significant one. It came at a time of high inflation and economic hardship, and it was welcomed by government employees. The decision also had a positive impact on the Indian economy, boosting the purchasing power of government employees and leading to increased consumption and economic growth. Finally, the decision also had a positive impact on the morale of government employees, showing that the government was concerned about their well-being.

headline: March 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Brezhnev on nukes
article:
Soviet president Leonid Brezhnev declared his government’s decision to freeze the deployment of medium range nuclear armaments in the European part of USSR. Addressing the congress of the Soviet Union, Brezhnev, however warned of retaliatory steps failing western reciprocation to the Soviet decision.

“The leadership has taken a decision to introduce unilaterally a moratorium on the deployment of medium range nuclear armaments in the European part of the Soviet Union,” Brezhnev said. He said the moratorium would be in force either until an agreement was reached with the United States or until the time the US leaders undertook practical preparations to deploy Pershing-2 and Cruise missiles in europe.
summary:
Summary:
Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev announced a unilateral decision to freeze the deployment of medium-range nuclear weapons in the European part of the USSR. Addressing the Soviet Union congress, Brezhnev warned of retaliatory measures if the West did not reciprocate to the Soviet initiative. The moratorium would remain in place until an agreement was reached with the United States or until US leaders made practical preparations to deploy Pershing-2 and Cruise missiles in Europe.

headline: March 18, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Union Rule In Kerala
article: Kerala was placed under President’s rule on March 17. A proclamation under Article 356 to this effect has been issued. The Union cabinet met in the evening and decided to recommend to the President placing the state under Centre’s jurisdiction in pursuance of the Governor’s recommendation. Governor Jyoti Vencatachellum dissolved the state assembly after the resignation of the 80-day old Karunakaran ministry following the withdrawal of support by a ruling front member, Lonapan Nambiar. This is the second time that Kerala has been placed under President’s rule in the last two years. Elections to the state assembly were held in January 1980. Chief Minister Karunakaran advised the governor to dissolve the assembly even though he did not enjoy a majority in it.
summary:
Summary:
Kerala has been placed under President's rule following the dissolution of the state assembly by Governor Jyoti Vencatachellum. The decision came after the resignation of the Karunakaran ministry, prompted by the withdrawal of support from a ruling front member. This marks the second time in two years that Kerala has been placed under President's rule. The assembly was dissolved despite Chief Minister Karunakaran not having a majority.

headline: March 21, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Dacoits strike in UP
article: Justice Chandra Shekhar Pratap Singh, elder brother of UP Chief Minister V P Singh, his teenage son and a servant were gunned down by dacoits on the border of Allahabad and Banda. Five persons, including the 12-year old second son of Justice Singh and the son of the former ruler of Shankargarh, were injured. Justice Singh, 52, was a senior judge of the Allahabad High Court. Justice Singh and his two sons were on a hunting excursion to Bargarh forests. They were accompanied by three servants and the driver of the jeep that was driven by Justice Singh himself. At Shankargarh, they were the guests of the former ruler Kamlakar Singh.
summary:
Summary:
Justice Chandra Shekhar Pratap Singh, along with his teenage son and a servant, was killed by dacoits near the border of Allahabad and Banda. The incident also left five others injured, including Justice Singh's younger son and the son of a former ruler. Justice Singh, aged 52 and a senior judge of the Allahabad High Court, was on a hunting trip to the Bargarh forests with his family and servants. They were guests at Shankargarh, hosted by the former ruler Kamlakar Singh.

headline: March 23, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Gandhi & Thatcher
article: The cordiality and warmth exhibited by Mrs Margaret Thatcher to Mrs Indira Gandhi on Sunday night at Heathrow airport remained unabated on Monday when they met alone to discuss “everything and anything under the sun” and then jointly spoke about bilateral economic relations at the official level meeting. It is not known what the two prime ministers discussed when they met alone for over an hour. An official spokesman would simply say that they discussed international relations affecting the world in general and the two countries in particular. However, British officials have privately indicated that they merely reviewed the world political and economic situation. But if what Mrs Gandhi told a BBC TV interviewer is any indication, it is unlikely that either of them had budged from their original stand, especially in regard to Afghanistan, South Asia and happenings in Latin America.
summary:
Summary:
Following their cordial meeting at Heathrow airport, Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher and Indira Gandhi continued their discussions on various topics, including bilateral economic relations, during an official meeting. Although the details of their private conversation were not disclosed, they were reported to have discussed international relations affecting both countries. However, it is suggested that neither leader changed their stance, particularly on issues such as Afghanistan, South Asia, and events in Latin America.

headline: March 24, 1982, Forty Years Ago: India-China Ties
article: Cautious Indian optimism about the prospects of improving relations with China is reflected in the annual report of the Ministry of External Affairs. Recalling the talks during the visit of the Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua in June last year and the visit of the Indian delegation led by Eric Gonsalves to Beijing in December, the ministry stressed that the boundary question is central to the relationship and an early settlement is desirable. “It is our hope that this dialogue will lead to the settlement of the outstanding problems which will enable full normalisation and further improvement in the ties between the two countries,” the document states. Elsewhere, the report talks of the lack of substantive progress in the border talks.
summary:
Summary:
The annual report of the Indian Ministry of External Affairs reflects cautious optimism regarding the potential for improving relations with China. It highlights recent talks between Indian and Chinese officials, emphasizing that the boundary question remains a central issue. The report expresses hope that ongoing dialogue will lead to the settlement of outstanding problems and pave the way for normalization and further improvement in bilateral ties. However, it also notes the lack of substantive progress in border talks.

headline: March 25, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Coup In Bangladesh
article: After three years of civil administration, Bangladesh is back under military rule as Lt General HM Ershad, chief of the army, took over power in a swift and bloodless coup. Ershad has designated himself the chief marshal law administrator of the strife-ridden 11-year old republic. The nation on the brink of an army takeover since the assassination of President Zia-ur-Rahman in May last year saw the exit of the four month government of President Abdus Sattar and Prime Minister Azizur Rahman with a categorical declaration by General Ershad that the armed forces have taken over power to save the country from social, economic and political bankruptcy. The general said that he was not a politician and had never nourished any political ambition.
summary:
Summary:
Bangladesh has returned to military rule under Lt General HM Ershad, who swiftly assumed power in a bloodless coup after three years of civilian administration. Ershad, chief of the army, declared himself the chief martial law administrator of the nation, following the exit of President Abdus Sattar and Prime Minister Azizur Rahman. General Ershad justified the military takeover as necessary to save the country from social, economic, and political crises, emphasizing that he has no political ambitions.

headline: March 26, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Bangla martial law
article: Bangladesh was peaceful as the Chief Martial Law administrator, Lt General Ershad, armed himself with drastic powers to forestall any opposition to his takeover. Ershad issued martial law regulations giving himself the power to constitute a martial law tribunal and special and summary martial trial courts in such areas as might be specified in his notification. The administration has put a blanket ban on all political activities. Ershad has appointed a three-member council to advise him. Judgments of the martial law court cannot be challenged in the Supreme Court. There have been no reports of violence on the second day of military rule.
summary:
Summary:
Following his swift assumption of power in Bangladesh, Chief Martial Law Administrator Lt General Ershad has consolidated his authority by issuing martial law regulations granting himself extensive powers. These include the establishment of martial law tribunals and special courts, and a ban on all political activities. Ershad has appointed a three-member council to advise him, and judgments from martial law courts cannot be appealed to the Supreme Court. Despite the imposition of martial law, there have been no reports of violence on the second day of military rule.

headline: March 28, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Indira vs Maneka
article: Describing the Lucknow convention in support of Sanjay Gandhi’s five-point programme as an “anti-party act” and especially against her, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on said it was sad that those who were supposed to have been close to Sanjay Gandhi wanted to destroy his image. Addressing a press conference within minutes of her arrival from London at Delhi airport, Mrs Gandhi said what she had said about the convention applied equally to the decision of Maneka Gandhi to attend it. Mrs Gandhi, however, said there was no question of her giving any call to her partymen to boycott the conference. About the convention, she said it was like the RSS and the BJP using the name of Gandhiji to further their ends. The convention was being encouraged by the very people who were against Sanjay Gandhi and had done everything in their attempt to destroy him.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi condemned the Lucknow convention in support of Sanjay Gandhi's five-point program as an "anti-party act," stating that it aimed to tarnish his image. She expressed disappointment that individuals close to Sanjay Gandhi were involved in such efforts. Mrs. Gandhi criticized Maneka Gandhi's decision to attend the convention, likening it to the RSS and BJP using Gandhi's name for their agendas. However, she clarified that she wouldn't call for a boycott of the conference. Mrs. Gandhi emphasized that those behind the convention were against Sanjay Gandhi and had worked to undermine him.

headline: March 29, 1983: Why India’s win against West Indies in Berbice still remains special
article:
Ask any cricket fan to pick their choice of India’s greatest one day international (ODI) performance, and the answers will come thick and fast. And will vary. Many will point to the 1983 World Cup final, some younger ones would go for the 2011 World Cup victory, others will point out to the clinical demolition of the competition in the 1985 WCC, and a few will go for that amazing day when India defended 126 against Pakistan at Sharjah in 1985.

But perhaps the biggest win of them all came on this very date of the month almost 40 years ago. On March 29, 1983, India shocked the world champions, the world and perhaps even themselves.
summary:
Summary:
On March 29, 1983, India achieved a historic victory in a one day international (ODI) cricket match by defeating the reigning world champions, the West Indies. This victory is considered one of India's greatest ODI performances and is significant as it occurred during the 1983 Cricket World Cup. The win is widely celebrated in Indian cricket history.

headline: March 30, 1982, Forty Years Ago: RS Poll Results
article: Despite cross-voting in two states in the final round, the Congress (I) emerged with a marginal gain in the Rajya Sabha biennial elections by capturing a total of 47 seats from 14 states against the retirement of 46 party members. With this tally, the party’s strength goes to 120 in the Upper House with an effective strength of 234. Four members are to be nominated to the House by the president, but six other seats will still be vacant. The third and final leg of polling involved 45 seats from nine states. The Congress (I) took 36 seats against equal number of retiring members. Of these, nine were from UP, five each from Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra, three from Rajasthan, two from Punjab and one each from Haryana and Himachal Pradesh.
summary:
Summary:
In the final round of the Rajya Sabha biennial elections, the Congress (I) secured a marginal gain, capturing a total of 47 seats across 14 states, surpassing the retirement of 46 party members. This brings the party's strength to 120 in the Upper House, out of an effective strength of 234. Despite cross-voting in two states, the Congress (I) won 36 seats in the third and final leg of polling, with significant victories in states like Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, and Maharashtra.

headline: March 31, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Maneka Ousted
article: Indira Gandhi personally asked Maneka Gandhi to “get out” of 1 Safdarjung Road immediately after Monday’s elections to the Rajya Sabha were over around 2 pm, Sanjay Gandhi’s widow told this newspaper. Maneka Gandhi said that the PM called her to her outer office and in the presence of several persons asked her to leave. She said she begged for two days’ time to quit as she had no house to go to and her son Varun was running a fever. But Mrs Gandhi was adamant, she said. She said her unceremonious dismissal from the house she came to as a bridge more than seven years ago had taken her completely by surprise.
summary:
Summary:
After the Rajya Sabha elections, Indira Gandhi personally asked Maneka Gandhi to vacate 1 Safdarjung Road immediately. Maneka Gandhi recounted that the Prime Minister called her to her outer office and, in the presence of several people, requested her to leave. Despite Maneka's plea for two days' time due to her son's illness and lack of alternative accommodation, Mrs. Gandhi insisted on her departure. Maneka expressed surprise and disappointment at her sudden dismissal from the house where she had resided for over seven years.

headline: HT This Day: April 3 1982 -- Argentina seizes Falklands
article:
Navy sources said the operation was a complete “success” and that British Governor Rex Hunt had surrendered. Navy press Chief Hugo De Pierro confirmed that one Argentine naval officer died and two soldiers were injured during the fight.

Hindustan Times - your fastest source for breaking news! Read now.
There was no word of British casualties.

Argentina’s military Government later announced that the country’s armed forces had “recovered” the British-administered Malvinas (Falklands), South Georgia and South Sandwich islands “through a successful military operation”, adds AP, Reuter.

“The exercise of Argentine sovereignty over all the island territory and air and sea space has been assured,” the Government said in a communique.

The Government called on the country’s citizens to “understand the deep and unmistakable national sentiment” in the decision to “convert into reality a legitimate right of the Argentine people which has been postponed, patiently and prudently, nearly 150 years.”
summary:
Summary:
Argentine military forces have successfully seized control of the British-administered Malvinas (Falklands), South Georgia, and South Sandwich Islands. Governor Rex Hunt surrendered to the Argentine forces, with no reported British casualties. One Argentine naval officer died, and two soldiers were injured during the operation. Argentina's military government announced the recovery of the islands, asserting sovereignty over the territory and calling on citizens to support the decision, citing a long-standing national sentiment.

headline: April 6, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Liberal Import Policy
article: The government has announced a liberal import policy that seeks to put industrial exporters to an efficiency test. Many things have been made easier to get including raw materials and capital goods. Access to technology abroad has been given special attention. At the same time, the performance of industry will be judged by how well it will absorb these incentives and produce for export while competing with other countries. Abid Hussain commerce secretary said emphasis will be placed on efficiency, competitiveness and productivity. Besides productivity, the other main aim of the policy is a quantum jump in the production capacity of small-scale units. Among the major steps proposed in the policy to speed up production are facilities for the grant of automatic import licence and their extension even after one year.
summary:
Summary:
The government has introduced a liberal import policy aimed at enhancing the efficiency and competitiveness of industrial exporters. The policy aims to simplify access to raw materials, capital goods, and technology from abroad. Emphasis will be placed on productivity and competitiveness, with a focus on increasing production capacity, particularly in small-scale units. Major steps include granting automatic import licenses and extending them beyond one year to facilitate faster production.

headline: April 7, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Charan Singh Resigns
article: The 80-year old Lok Dal President Charan Singh dramatically announced his retirement from active politics in a desperate bid to put down a revolt by party colleagues, including Devi Lal and Biju Patnaik, on the question of Opposition unity. The announcement was made by him about the same time as Devi Lal was introduced at the Janata Party headquarters as the chairman of the reception committee for the April 13 convention of the Janata, Lok Dal and Congress (S) leaders and workers at Chandigarh to take a decision on a joint programme of action on the coming Assembly elections in several states. Charan Singh, however, dropped hints that his action was neither irrevocable nor motivated by the desire to promote Opposition unity.
summary:
Summary:
Lok Dal President Charan Singh, aged 80, has announced his retirement from active politics amidst a revolt by party colleagues, including Devi Lal and Biju Patnaik, regarding Opposition unity. The announcement coincided with Devi Lal's introduction as the chairman of the reception committee for an upcoming convention involving Janata Party, Lok Dal, and Congress (S) leaders and workers in Chandigarh. While Charan Singh hinted that his retirement may not be final and was not solely aimed at promoting Opposition unity, the move reflects internal tensions within the Lok Dal.

headline: April 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: State Polls
article: Elections will be held on May 19 for the assemblies of Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, West Bengal and Kerala and the Lok Sabha seat of Garhwal in Uttar Pradesh. The Chief Election Commissioner announced the election programme  said that it would be possible to constitute the assemblies by May 24. Elections could also be held in the assemblies of Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka if they were dissolved by April 15, he said. The EC said that the commission was not holding elections in Assam . About the Garhwal repoll, the EC said he had no doubt that the state government will cooperate.
summary:
Summary:
The Chief Election Commissioner announced election dates for assemblies in Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, West Bengal, and Kerala, along with the Lok Sabha seat of Garhwal in Uttar Pradesh, scheduled for May 19. If Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka assemblies are dissolved by April 15, elections could also be held there. However, elections will not be held in Assam. The EC expressed confidence in the cooperation of the state government for the Garhwal repoll.

headline: April 9, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Lok Dal Split
article: Lok Dal president Charan Singh, who said he had retired from politics, suspended Biju Patnaik, Devi Lal and Kumbha Ram Arya from the primary membership of the party to force the fourth split in the Lok Dal since the January 1980 Lok Sabha elections. The 80-year-old leader’s action is certain to wipe out the Lok Dal in Orissa, and severely reduce its strength in Rajasthan and Haryana. With only the UP and Bihar units with Charan Singh, the party is likely to be brought down to the status of a regional party. With 41 seats, it had emerged as the biggest opposition group in the Lok Sabha after the 1980 elections.
summary:
Summary:
Lok Dal president Charan Singh, despite announcing retirement from politics, suspended Biju Patnaik, Devi Lal, and Kumbha Ram Arya from the party, leading to the fourth split in the Lok Dal since the January 1980 Lok Sabha elections. This action is expected to diminish Lok Dal's presence in Orissa, Rajasthan, and Haryana, leaving it primarily confined to Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. Previously, Lok Dal had emerged as the largest opposition group in the Lok Sabha with 41 seats after the 1980 elections.

headline: April 14, 1982, Forty Years Ago: PLA Extremists Killed
article: Eleven persons, including the last of the Lhasa-trained and eight other top PLA extremists and two army personnel were killed in a major encounter in Kodompopki about 10 km from Imphal. The four-hour operation, army authorities said, will spell the liquidation of the insurgents. The PLA had suffered a severe jolt in July last year when seven insurgents were killed and its top leader Bisweswar Singh was captured in an encounter. According to army sources, the 11 PLA insurgents had got training in China and all of them have been either killed or captured. Five extremists were captured, including four with serious injuries.
summary:
Summary:
In a significant encounter in Kodompopki near Imphal, eleven individuals, including the last of the Lhasa-trained and eight other top PLA extremists, were killed, along with two army personnel. The four-hour operation, according to army authorities, dealt a major blow to the insurgents, marking their liquidation. The PLA had suffered a previous setback in July when seven insurgents were killed and their top leader, Bisweswar Singh, was captured. All 11 PLA insurgents in the recent encounter, who had received training in China, were either killed or captured, with five extremists apprehended, including four with serious injuries.

headline: April 16, 1982, Forty Years Ago Charan Singh’s re-entry into politics after a nine-day sanyas threatens to throw his truncated Lok Dal into a fresh crisis.
article: The call for a credible alternative to the Congress-I through a programme of joint action received overwhelming support on the opening day of the convention of the Janata Party, the Congress S and a faction of the Lok Dal. The resolution incorporating the joint action programme rallied for the establishment of a unified leadership with a “common electoral strategy” to fight the coming elections. The resolution was moved by Madhu Dandavate (Janata) and seconded by Ambika Soni (Congress-S). Nearly 11,000 delegates are participating at the convention. Dandavate said that those who are opposed to Mrs Gandhi have not been able to unite. She will finish them individually.
summary:
Summary:
On the opening day of the convention of the Janata Party, Congress-S, and a faction of the Lok Dal, there was overwhelming support for a credible alternative to the Congress-I through a joint action programme. A resolution was passed advocating the establishment of a unified leadership with a common electoral strategy for the upcoming elections. The resolution was moved by Madhu Dandavate (Janata) and seconded by Ambika Soni (Congress-S). The convention saw participation from nearly 11,000 delegates, and Dandavate emphasized the need for unity among those opposed to Mrs. Gandhi.

headline: April 27, 1982, Forty Years Ago: UK’s Assault
article:
The commander of the Argentine forces on the Falkland dependency of South Georgia surrendered after the British forces captured the island’s two main ports, UK Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons. She said some 180 Argentines have been taken prisoners during the assault that began on April 25 with a landing on the largest port, Grytviken followed by the securing of the Leith labour on April 26. Mrs Thatcher said that the British forces were told to use minimum force. As a result, she said, there’s been a serious injury to only one Argentine seaman.

Judicial Reforms
Indicating that major changes in the judicial system were in the offing, Union Law Minister Jagannath Kaushal announced in the Rajya Sabha that as a start, he hoped to set up administrative tribunals in the not so distant future. Speaking at the end of a day-long discussion on the working of the Union of Ministry of Law, Justice and Company Affairs, Kaushal said that there was a strong need for decentralisation.

Message From Pak

Pakistan Foreign Minister Yaqub Khan has sent a message to the external affairs minister P V Narasimha Rao saying that Islamabad is keen to go ahead with the talks aimed at evolving a no-war pact between the two countries. Khan is believed to have expressed his country’s appreciation of the several statements by the external affairs minister expressing India’s desire to improve ties.

Dacoits In Delhi
A 75-year-old man was killed and 10 were seriously injured by four armed dacoits who looted two houses in East Delhi, and tried to enter a third. The dacoities were committed in Nirman Vihar and Swasthya Vihar.
summary:
In the Falkland Islands conflict, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher informed the House of Commons that the Argentine commander in South Georgia surrendered after British forces captured the island's main ports. The assault began on April 25 with the landing at Grytviken, followed by the securing of Leith Harbor on April 26. The operation aimed to use minimal force, resulting in only one Argentine seaman being seriously injured, with around 180 Argentines taken as prisoners.

Union Law Minister Jagannath Kaushal announced significant judicial reforms in India, with plans to establish administrative tribunals in the near future as part of a broader decentralization effort. This move signals a shift in the country's judicial system.

In international relations, Pakistan's Foreign Minister Yaqub Khan expressed a willingness to proceed with talks aimed at creating a no-war pact between Pakistan and India. This development follows India's expressed desire to improve bilateral ties, as conveyed by External Affairs Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao.

In a domestic incident, four armed dacoits targeted houses in East Delhi, resulting in the death of a 75-year-old man and serious injuries to 10 individuals. The dacoities occurred in Nirman Vihar and Swasthya Vihar.

headline: April 29, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Britain Steps Up Heat
article: Britain has set the stage for a military showdown with Argentina by announcing that a full sea and air blockade would be imposed on the Falkland Islands in the next 48 hours. The Defence Ministry said any Argentine ship or aircraft found in the 200-mile radius “no-go” zone declared around the South Atlantic islands would be regarded as hostile. Official British sources said friendly governments were being kept informed of Britain’s moves to regain the colony. Sources close to Prime Minister Thatcher said: “We haven’t declared war on Argentina and we shall not do so. But I wouldn’t exactly describe us as being in a state of peace at the moment”.
summary:
Summary:
Britain has escalated tensions with Argentina by announcing plans to impose a full sea and air blockade on the Falkland Islands within 48 hours. The Defence Ministry stated that any Argentine ships or aircraft found within the declared 200-mile "no-go" zone around the islands would be treated as hostile. While Britain has not declared war on Argentina, it is taking significant measures to regain control of the colony. Friendly governments have been informed of these developments.

headline: May 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Preliminary Talks
article: A 30-minute preliminary exchange of views between the leader of the Indian delegation, Eric Gonsalves, and the leader of the Chinese delegation, Fu Hao, and the conciliatory speeches they made at the dinner Gonsalves hosted in honour of the visitors set the tone for the tone for the Sino-Indian talks opening the next day. Both Gonsalves and Fu, in their carefully prepared speeches warmly expressed their governments’ desire to improve relations. And significantly, both of them underscored the understanding the two governments have already arrived at that the border dispute is the central issue the resolution of which is important for the normalisation of relations between India and China. The problems that India and China faced in today’s world can be better faced if they devised a basis for cooperation and fully normal relations, Gonsalves said.
summary:
Summary: 
The Sino-Indian talks commenced with a 30-minute exchange of views between Eric Gonsalves, the leader of the Indian delegation, and Fu Hao, the leader of the Chinese delegation. Both leaders expressed their governments' desire to improve relations and emphasized the centrality of resolving the border dispute for normalization. They highlighted the importance of cooperation and fully normal relations in addressing the challenges faced by both countries in the contemporary world.

headline: May 19, 1982, Forty Years Ago: State Polls
article: The Congress (I) is facing its toughest challenge since it returned to power in 1980 when about 52 million voters line up at the polling booth on May 19 to elect state governments in Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, West Bengal and Kerala. While the Lok Dal-BJP is fighting the keenest battle for 90 seats in Haryana and 68 in Haryana, the Marxist-led Left Front is making all-out efforts to defeat the United Democratic Front in Kerala. In West Bengal, the Congress (I)’s objective is limited to reducing the Left Front’s strength in the 294-member house. PM Indira Gandhi has spent four days in each state.
summary:
Summary: 
The Congress (I) is facing significant challenges as voters in Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, West Bengal, and Kerala prepare to elect state governments on May 19. The Lok Dal-BJP alliance is particularly competitive in Haryana, while the Left Front aims to retain power in Kerala. In West Bengal, the Congress (I) seeks to diminish the Left Front's dominance in the state legislature. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has personally campaigned in each of these states for four days.

headline: May 20, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Polls Peaceful
article: An enthusiastic turnout of voters marked the mini-general election on May 19 with four states and 22 Lok Sabha and assembly constituencies reporting moderate to heavy polling. Barring stray incidents of violence in West Bengal and Haryana, the polls passed off peacefully. Over 60 per cent of the 52 million voters exercised their franchise in the election which is Mrs Gandhi’s first major popularity test after her resounding victory in the 1982 General Elections. While Kerala recorded a characteristically heavy turnout of 70 per cent, about 65 per cent voters cast their vote in Haryana and West Bengal. Voting struck a dull note in Garhwal where the Democratic Socialist Party candidate H N Bahuguna is making a bid to re-enter Parliament.
summary:
Summary: 
The mini-general election held on May 19 saw a high turnout of voters in four states and 22 Lok Sabha and assembly constituencies, with moderate to heavy polling reported. Apart from minor incidents of violence in West Bengal and Haryana, the elections were largely peaceful. Over 60% of the 52 million eligible voters participated, marking Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's first major popularity test since the 1982 General Elections. Kerala witnessed a high turnout of 70%, while Haryana and West Bengal saw around 65% voter participation. However, voting was subdued in Garhwal, where Democratic Socialist Party candidate H.N. Bahuguna aimed to return to Parliament.

headline: May 23, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Bahuguna sure to win
article: H N Bahuguna, chairman of the Democratic Socialist Party romped home in the elections to Garhwal Lok Sabha seat defeating his Congress (I)-rival Chandra Mohan Singh, minister of state for hill development, in one of the prestigious by-elections. According to provisional figures available at the state headquarters, Bahuguna led his Congress (I) rival by over 20,000 votes. Postal results are yet to be counted and the results are likely to be declared in a day. Bahuguna was elected from the Congress (I) in a victory with a big margin over his Janata Party rival in the Lok Sabha polls. However, the seven-month honeymoon with the Congress (I) came to an abrupt end on the eve of the elections to the assembly elections to the Garhwal assembly constituency. Bahuguna’s men won from all the constituencies making him desert the Congress (I) and seek re-election.
summary:
Summary: 
H.N. Bahuguna, the chairman of the Democratic Socialist Party, won the elections for the Garhwal Lok Sabha seat, defeating his Congress (I) rival Chandra Mohan Singh by over 20,000 votes. Bahuguna, who had previously been elected from the Congress (I), parted ways with the party and sought re-election after a seven-month stint. His victory marked a significant turnaround in the prestigious by-election, with postal votes yet to be counted.

headline: May 24, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Bhajan Lal is CM
article: In a two hour drama on May 23, Bhajan Lal was sworn in as the Chief Minister by the Haryana Governor, B D Tapase, for being the leader of the “largest single party” in the assembly. The swearing-in rendered infructuous the governor’s advice to the Lok Dal leader to parade his supporters at Raj Bhavan. Unaware, Devi Lal sat with his supporters at Kalka where they were being guarded against “political piracy of the Chief Minister” by a posse of nihangs. The governor has given the new chief minister a one month time period to prove his majority on the floor of the House. Bhajan Lal told reporters that the Haryana Assembly will be called to session before June 30. Lok Dal members stormed the governor’s office to protest against the decision.
summary:
Summary:
 Bhajan Lal was sworn in as the Chief Minister of Haryana after being recognized as the leader of the "largest single party" in the assembly, despite Devi Lal's Lok Dal also claiming leadership. Devi Lal and his supporters, unaware of the decision, were stationed elsewhere, guarded against perceived political threats. The governor granted Bhajan Lal a one-month period to prove his majority in the assembly, prompting protests from Lok Dal members.

headline: May 27, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Reddy’s Displeasure
article: The President is believed to have expressed his displeasure to the Prime Minister. He told Mrs Gandhi that the governor’s invitation to Bhajan Lal to form the government was not proper and constitutional. According to informed sources, the prime minister was “excited” when the president made these observations. The President used these words while describing his interactions with the PM to a Haryana delegation. He suggested to the PM that an early session of the assembly should be called to test the strength of both sides. The PM has since then also expressed similar views. This was a result of his interactions with her, the President said. He told the Opposition that he was equally unhappy with their role.
summary:
Summary: 
The President expressed displeasure to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi regarding the governor's invitation to Bhajan Lal to form the government in Haryana, deeming it improper and unconstitutional. The Prime Minister, initially "excited," later agreed with the President's views and suggested an early session of the assembly to test both sides' strength. The President also conveyed dissatisfaction with the Opposition's role in the matter.

headline: June 3, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Peace Talks
article: Soon after the return of Natwar Singh, Secretary in the Ministry of External Affairs from Pakistan, New Delhi said on Wednesday that India had an interest in Pakistan’s stability, sovereignty and independence. “We in India have an abiding faith in peace and friendship with Pakistan and we are steadfast in our faith.”, an Indian Government spokesman said in a statement which was conciliatory in tone. The Indian government, he added, regarded as imperative that there should be peace, friendship and co-operation between the two nations. The spokesman pointed out that a no-war or non-war situation was only a part of an overall relationship which India was working towards.
summary:
Summary: 
Following the return of Natwar Singh, Secretary in the Ministry of External Affairs, from Pakistan, the Indian government expressed its interest in Pakistan's stability, sovereignty, and independence. A government spokesman emphasized India's commitment to peace, friendship, and cooperation with Pakistan, stating that these were imperative for the relationship between the two nations. The spokesman highlighted the importance of working towards an overall relationship beyond just a no-war or non-war situation.

headline: June 11, 1982, forty years ago: Antulay loses case
article: An appeal filed by the former Chief Minister, A.R. Antulay, and the state of Maharashtra against the judgement of Justice B. Lentin in the cement case was dismissed by a division bench of the Bombay High Court comprising Justice S.K. Desai and Justice B.J. Rele. Justice Rele’s indictment was even stronger than Justice Lentin’s judgement last January. Justice Desai was no less strong. He said that “the manner of allocating cement revealed, indicated and illustrated an assorted spectacle of unreasoned arbitrariness and capricious discretion resulting in unprincipled favouritism which remains unexplained and appears to be unjustified.” The bench upheld that nexus and quid pro quo had been established between allotments of cement to certain big builders and the donations made by them to the trust floated by Antulay, and ruled that both the former chief minister and the state had acted in an illegal, arbitrary and capricious manner “while distributing cement from the Mantralaya”.
summary:
Summary: 
The Bombay High Court, in a division bench comprising Justices S.K. Desai and B.J. Rele, dismissed an appeal filed by former Chief Minister A.R. Antulay and the state of Maharashtra against a judgement in the cement case. The bench upheld the judgement of Justice B. Lentin, stating that the allocation of cement demonstrated unreasoned arbitrariness and unjustified favoritism, indicating a nexus between cement allotments to certain builders and donations made to a trust floated by Antulay. The court ruled that both Antulay and the state had acted illegally and arbitrarily in distributing cement from the Mantralaya.

headline: June 14, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Israel’s fresh attack
article: Israeli jets repeatedly bombed and strafed Palestinian positions on both sides of Beirut’s crippled international airport as ground forces resumed bitter fighting in defiance of a day-old cease-fire. The Israeli dive-bombing attacks were on a smaller scale than the massive air raides on densely-populated residential areas that Lebanese officials said killed more than 400 persons in the 48 hours before Israel and PLO announced a cease-fire. PLO said Israeli bombardment from the air and from gunboats off-shore also struck the teeming Bourj el Barajneh Palestinian shanty town near the northern end of the runaway. Lebanese radio reports said some residential areas were also struck.
summary:
Summary:
 Israeli jets conducted bombing and strafing raids on Palestinian positions near Beirut's international airport, despite a recently declared cease-fire. The attacks, although smaller in scale compared to previous bombings, targeted densely populated areas and Palestinian shanty towns. Lebanese officials reported casualties, with over 400 people killed in the preceding 48 hours due to Israeli airstrikes. Residential areas were also hit during the attacks.

headline: June 16, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Argentina Surrenders
article: Argentina has surrendered. The Falklands have been liberated. The British pride, punctured by Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri by seizing control of the South Atlantic islands by force, has been retrieved. As the British Defence Ministry officially confirmed the news about the Argentinian surrender, the Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher was engulfed with messages of congratulations from every nook and corner of the country. There was great relief among the people that the war is over. Even her political rivals, Michael Foot, David Owen and David Steel, congratulated her in public for her success. The jubilation was so widespread that at one time Thatcher appeared to be attaining the stature of Winston Churchill.
