But, already within the country, people are openly saying that her hands are soaked with the blood of hundreds of young and innocent lives.
summary:
Summary:
 Argentina has surrendered, leading to the liberation of the Falkland Islands, ending the conflict with Britain. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher received numerous messages of congratulations from across the country, including from political rivals, for her success in the war. While there was widespread jubilation over the end of the war, some within the country criticized Thatcher, alleging that her actions resulted in the loss of many young and innocent lives.

headline: June 18, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Presidential Polls
article: Ten opposition parties have formally suggested to the Prime Minister that Vice-President M. Hidayatullah “offers a very good choice for a consensus candidate” for the presidency. In a letter to Indira Gandhi, leaders of the opposition parties expressed the hope that she would agree to their proposal. They said they had not sounded Hidayatullah before proposing his name because “we believe that the consensus candidate should be approached appropriately by the leader of the ruling party.” The opposition leaders told the Prime Minister that they were of the “considered opinion that the Vice-President has the first claim to the presidency unless he is considered unsuitable otherwise or unless there is a candidate who is generally held to be better.” They said that when the Vice-President happened to be a former Chief Justice of India, his claim to presidency “becomes greater”.
summary:
Summary: 
Ten opposition parties have formally suggested Vice-President M. Hidayatullah as a consensus candidate for the presidency to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. In a letter, they expressed their hope that she would agree to their proposal, stating that Hidayatullah's background as a former Chief Justice of India strengthens his claim to the presidency.

headline: June 20, 1982, Forty Years Ago: The Israeli invasion
article: Israeli helicopter-borne troops landed on Dahrai-Qadib ridge in north Lebanon, 60 km north of Beirut, reliable Lebanese sources said. The landing area was near the road linking Tripoli, the major town in the area on the coast with the Bekaa plain in central Lebanon. There were no details of the size of the Israeli forces landing in a region currently under the control of the Syrians in the Arab deterrent force, or its immediate objectives. Israeli troops immediately outside Beirut, who arrived from the south, were reported observing a ceasefire there. But authoritative military forces in Tel Aviv immediately denied reports of an Israeli landing. Shortly after landing, Israeli troops reportedly occupied the police station near Cedar village.
summary:
Summary:
 Israeli helicopter-borne troops allegedly landed on the Dahrai-Qadib ridge in north Lebanon, near Tripoli, according to Lebanese sources. The size of the Israeli forces and their objectives were not specified. However, Israeli military authorities in Tel Aviv denied reports of such a landing. The troops reportedly occupied the police station near Cedar village following the alleged landing.

headline: June 28, 1982, Forty Years Ago: The Israeli invasion
article: Israel’s invasion army warned the people of Beirut to use the two-day-old cease-fire to get out of the city. In leaflets dropped over the encircled capital, the Israeli army said its war against the Palestinians was not yet over. “The Israeli defence forces are continuing their war against the terrorists and have not yet used all their might,” the leaflets said. “Use the cease-fire to save your life,” the Arabic-language leaflets told Beirut residents. In response, the PLO vowed in a broadcast over its Voice of Palestine radio station to “fight to defend Beirut… and exact a heavy, very heavy price from the enemy for any attempt to storm the city.”
summary:
Summary: 
Israel's invasion army warned residents of Beirut to evacuate the city during a two-day-old cease-fire, stating that their war against the Palestinians was ongoing and they had not yet used all their might. Leaflets dropped over Beirut urged residents to use the cease-fire to save their lives. In response, the PLO vowed to defend Beirut and inflict heavy casualties on any attempt to storm the city.

headline: July 1, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Lal faces Obstacles
article: The Lok Dal leader, Devi Lal’s claim to the status of the leader of the Opposition in the Haryana Vidhan Sabha has not been accepted either by the Vidhan Sabha Secretariat or the state government so far. The matter has taken an interesting turn with a communication reportedly sent to Devi Lal by the Vidhan Sabha secretariat asking him to intimate the ideology and programme of the Lok Dal legislative party. The letter of the legislative party to the secretariat accepting Devi Lal as its leader was signed by all the 33 Lok Dal MLAs. According to rules, the support of only 10 members is sufficient to get a legislative party leader the status of the leader of the Opposition.
summary:
Summary: 
Devi Lal's claim to the status of the leader of the Opposition in the Haryana Vidhan Sabha has not been accepted by the Vidhan Sabha Secretariat or the state government. The Vidhan Sabha secretariat has reportedly asked Devi Lal to provide information about the ideology and program of the Lok Dal legislative party. However, the letter from the legislative party to the secretariat, accepting Devi Lal as its leader, was signed by all 33 Lok Dal MLAs, even though support from only 10 members is required to obtain the status of the leader of the Opposition.

headline: July 6, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Advertising policy
article: The Central Government has decided to apply the squeeze on big newspapers by effecting a change in its advertising policy. The policy, which has come in for drastic revision over the last five weeks, is now weighted overwhelmingly in favour of medium and small newspapers because the government feels that they are the best purveyors of its message to rural areas. Under the new policy, 80 per cent of the government’s advertisements will be released to language dallies and 20 per cent to English newspapers. The architect of this new policy is believed to be Arif Mohammad Khan, the Union Deputy Minister for Information and Broadcasting.
summary:
Summary: 
The Central Government has revised its advertising policy to favor medium and small newspapers over big ones, with a focus on reaching rural areas. Under the new policy, 80% of government advertisements will be allocated to language dailies, while 20% will go to English newspapers. Arif Mohammad Khan, the Union Deputy Minister for Information and Broadcasting, is believed to be the architect of this new policy.

headline: July 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Opposition Demands
article: Opposition parties will press for the introduction of an anti-defection bill during the forthcoming monsoon session of the Lok Sabha. At a meeting of representatives of nine opposition parties, it was agreed that there would be proper floor coordination of opposition parties in the Lok Sabha. The opposition will also press for the dissolution of the Haryana Assembly where it was felt the mandate of the electorate had been reversed through the misuse of the Governor’s authority and the politics of defections. The misuse of government machinery in the campaign for presidential election and the recent elections in some states will be taken up by the opposition in Parliament.
summary:
Summary: 
Opposition parties plan to push for the introduction of an anti-defection bill during the upcoming monsoon session of the Lok Sabha. Additionally, they aim to coordinate their efforts on the floor of the Lok Sabha and advocate for the dissolution of the Haryana Assembly, citing the misuse of the Governor's authority and defections. The opposition also intends to address the alleged misuse of government machinery in the presidential election campaign and recent state elections.

headline: July 15, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Himachal bus crash
article: A Himachal Pradesh State Transport Corporation bus carrying over 50 persons and going from Sawat in Kullu district to Kalka hurtled down the road into the Sutlej river near Luri village. There were no traces of any bodies or the bus which was washed away in the fast flowing river. The ill-fated bus was a 42-seater but reportedly carried over 50 passengers. Chief Minister Ram Lal has announced Rs 20,000 as relief to dependents of the dead passengers under the passenger insurance scheme. A member of each bereaved family will be offered employment in the organised sector. Injured passengers, if any, will be given Rs 5,000 each as relief, reports UNI.
summary:
Summary: 
A tragic accident occurred in Himachal Pradesh as a State Transport Corporation bus carrying over 50 passengers plunged into the Sutlej river near Luri village while traveling from Sawat in Kullu district to Kalka. There were no survivors or traces of the bus, which was washed away by the river's fast-flowing waters. Chief Minister Ram Lal announced relief measures, including Rs 20,000 for the families of the deceased under the passenger insurance scheme, employment opportunities for one member of each bereaved family, and Rs 5,000 for each injured passenger.

headline: August 8, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Press FreedomDebate
article: Home Minister R Venkataraman expressed himself against any exercise of unbridled freedom by the press and asserted that there was a need to regulate freedom of expression. Responding to a noisy discussion on the curtailment of press freedoms in states such as Bihar, he said that Article 19 (2) of the Constitution allows the state to impose reasonable restrictions. The Opposition leaders, in contrast, described the Bihar amendments to the penal code as a “black bill” passed by a corrupt government. Venkataraman said that the Bihar government’s decision owed to two incidents. The first was the allegation that the CM had bathed in the blood of 100 goats at a tantrik’s advice. The other was reports of a well in Bihar Sharif being poisoned.
summary:
Summary:
Home Minister R Venkataraman voiced his stance against unrestricted press freedom, advocating for the regulation of freedom of expression. He referenced Article 19(2) of the Constitution, which permits the state to impose reasonable restrictions. This statement came in response to a contentious discussion regarding press freedoms in states like Bihar. The opposition condemned Bihar's amendments to the penal code as a "black bill" passed by a corrupt government. Venkataraman cited two incidents that prompted the Bihar government's decision: allegations that the Chief Minister had bathed in the blood of 100 goats as per a tantrik's advice and reports of poisoning in a well in Bihar Sharif.

headline: August 9, 1982, Forty Years Ago: French uranium
article: France will not impose special conditions for supplying enriched uranium to the Tarapur plant nor will it exercise any control over the reprocessing of spent fuel by India under an agreement to be concluded shortly. The foreign minister of France said that there seems to be no difficulty because India is not averse to the safeguards envisaged by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). His government would only demand a guarantee that fissile material derived from the reprocessing be placed under the same IAEA safeguards to guard against the user country making an atom bomb. We are not going to control what is being done in India, he said.
summary:
Summary:
France announced that it would not impose any special conditions for supplying enriched uranium to India's Tarapur plant, nor would it exercise control over the reprocessing of spent fuel by India under an upcoming agreement. The French foreign minister stated that since India is not opposed to the safeguards proposed by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), there are no apparent difficulties. However, France would require a guarantee that fissile material derived from reprocessing be subjected to IAEA safeguards to prevent its misuse for nuclear weapons. The minister emphasized that France would not interfere with India's activities, stating, "We are not going to control what is being done in India."

headline: August 10, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Two Lok Dals
article: Two Lok Dals emerged on the political scene following the formalisation of the fourth and biggest split in Charan Singh’s party. The rebels led by Madhu Limaye, George Fernandes, Biju Patnaik, Devi Lai and Kumbha Ram Arya removed Charan Singh as president and elected Karpoori Thakur in his place. They declared themselves the “genuine” Lok Dal. Later at a workers’ convention, Fernandes was declared as the general secretary of the party which the convention felt should strive to unite the opposition to build a national alternative to the “authoritarian” Congress (I). The claims and counterclaims of the Singh and Thakur factions could not be immediately verified as they continued to woo each other’s supporters.
summary:
Summary:
Following the formalization of the fourth and largest split in Charan Singh's Lok Dal party, two separate factions emerged on the political scene. Rebels led by Madhu Limaye, George Fernandes, Biju Patnaik, Devi Lai, and Kumbha Ram Arya ousted Charan Singh as president and elected Karpoori Thakur as his replacement. They declared themselves the "genuine" Lok Dal. At a subsequent workers' convention, Fernandes was appointed as the general secretary of the party, which aimed to unite the opposition and create a national alternative to the "authoritarian" Congress (I). The claims and counterclaims between the Singh and Thakur factions remained unverified as they continued to court each other's supporters.

headline: August 11, 1982, Forty Years Ago: French Nuclear Fuel
article: France will impose no special conditions for supplying enriched uranium to the Tarapur plant nor will it exercise any control over the reprocessing of spent fuel by India, under an agreement to be concluded shortly. French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson gave this information at a crowded press conference during his 24-hour visit to New Delhi on August 8. He said there would be no difficulty if the same sort of safeguards as devised by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) were included in the agreement. His government only demanded that the fissile material be under IAEA safeguards to prevent its use in making an atomic bomb.
summary:
Summary:
During his 24-hour visit to New Delhi, French Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson announced that France would not impose any special conditions for supplying enriched uranium to the Tarapur plant in India, nor would it exercise control over the reprocessing of spent fuel. Cheysson emphasized that as long as safeguards similar to those proposed by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) were included in the agreement, there would be no difficulty. However, France insisted that fissile material be subjected to IAEA safeguards to prevent its misuse in the development of atomic weapons.

headline: P.M. calls for national unity in face of challenges
article:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today called for national unity in the face of the challenges facing the country. In her Independence Day address to the nation, she said that the country was facing a number of challenges, including economic problems, internal security issues, and ethnic unrest. However, she said that the country could overcome these challenges if the people remained united.
 
 Gandhi said that the government was committed to improving the economic conditions of the people. She said that the government was taking steps to boost agricultural production, increase employment opportunities, and reduce poverty.
 
 Gandhi also said that the government was committed to maintaining internal security and promoting ethnic harmony. She said that the government would not tolerate any violence or extremism.
 
 Gandhi's Independence Day address was a call for national unity in the face of the challenges facing the country. She said that the country could overcome these challenges if the people remained united.
summary: India was facing a number of challenges in 1982. The economy was in a bad state, there were internal security issues, and there was ethnic unrest. In her Independence Day address, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called for national unity in the face of these challenges. She said that the country could overcome these challenges if the people remained united.

headline: August 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Acrimony in House
article: The Lok Sabha rejected a no-confidence motion against the government after a stormy 10-hour debate which was marked by a lot of acrimony and bitter personal and political exchanges between the Opposition and the treasury benches. The motion was defeated by 327 votes to 110. The house adjourned sine die The marathon debate saw the opposition lash out at Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her government for “devaluing” democracy and its institutions while faring poorly on the economic front. Mrs Gandhi, in a devastating 40-minute intervention, denounced the Opposition as an irresponsible motley crowd which ought to first pass a motion of no-confidence against itself.
summary:
Summary:
The Lok Sabha rejected a no-confidence motion against the government following a heated 10-hour debate characterized by bitter exchanges between the Opposition and the ruling party. The motion was defeated by a significant margin, with 327 votes against and 110 in favor. The session adjourned sine die after the vote. During the debate, the opposition criticized Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's administration for undermining democracy and failing on economic matters. In response, Gandhi delivered a scathing 40-minute speech denouncing the opposition as irresponsible and suggesting they should first pass a motion of no-confidence against themselves.

headline: August 24, 1982, Forty Years Ago Normal life came to a standstill with shops, business establishments and cinema houses remaining closed in response to the call for a 12-hour Patna bandh in protest against the brutal police lathi-charge on a peaceful procession of Bihar journalists.
article: Normal life came to a standstill with shops, business establishments and cinema houses remaining closed in response to the call for a 12-hour Patna bandh in protest against the brutal police lathi-charge on a peaceful procession of Bihar journalists. The magnitude of the response to the bandh call exceeded all expectations. The movement of buses, private and state, and rickshaws thinned down to a trickle. Although hospitals, banks and government offices were not affected by the bandh, attendance was less than normal. The Patna university area and the busy shopping centre were deserted as students and teachers alike boycotted classes.
summary:
Summary:
Normal life in Patna was disrupted as shops, businesses, and cinemas remained closed in response to a 12-hour bandh (shutdown) called in protest against a police lathi-charge on a peaceful procession of Bihar journalists. The bandh saw a significant response, surpassing expectations, with minimal movement of buses, private vehicles, and rickshaws. Although hospitals, banks, and government offices were operational, attendance was lower than usual. Areas like the Patna University campus and busy shopping centers were deserted as students and teachers boycotted classes.

headline: August 29, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Parties Clash
article: There was a pandemonium at New Delhi railway station when a fight erupted between Congress (I) workers and Maneka Gandhi’s supporters who had gone to receive the latest addition to the Sanjay Gandhi Vichar Manch, Kalpanath Sonkar, till now a Congress (I) MP, from Uttar Pradesh. As frightened passengers fled in all directions, youths clad in kurta-pyjamas robbed a railway soft drinks stall of bottles and hurled them at each other. No one was injured. Afterwards, both parties registered complaints with the police who have filed two cases, of rioting agsint the Congress (I) workers and one of attempted murder and rioting against J N Mishra of the Manch.
summary:
Summary:
Chaos ensued at New Delhi railway station when a scuffle broke out between Congress (I) workers and supporters of Maneka Gandhi, who were there to welcome Kalpanath Sonkar, a former Congress (I) MP from Uttar Pradesh, to the Sanjay Gandhi Vichar Manch. Frightened passengers scattered as youths in kurta-pyjamas raided a railway soft drinks stall, hurling bottles at each other. Fortunately, no injuries were reported. Both groups filed complaints with the police, resulting in two cases of rioting against the Congress (I) workers and one case of attempted murder and rioting against J N Mishra of the Manch.

headline: SBI women's fortnight
article:
The State Bank of India observed “Women’s Fortnight” highlighting the important role played by women in the society and particularly, how they can augment their family income by taking up subsidiary occupations with assistance provided by State Bank.

During the fortnight which ended on June 30 loans had been sanctioned by its Branches in and around Shillong to over 20 women for a wide variety of business activities. The majority of the loans are being granted under the differential interest-rate scheme at a confessional rate of 4% p.a. At a brief function on July 3 the lances were handed over the sanction letters.
summary: The State Bank of India marked "Women’s Fortnight" to emphasize the significant role women play in society and highlight how they can enhance family income through subsidiary occupations with support from the bank. During the fortnight, which concluded on June 30, the bank's branches in and around Shillong sanctioned loans for various business activities to over 20 women. The loans are primarily granted under the differential interest-rate scheme at a concessional rate of 4% per annum. At a ceremony on July 3, sanction letters for the loans were handed over to the recipients.

headline: April 11, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Snag In Insat
article: ISRO scientists faced the first problem with Insat 1-A when their attempts to put it on a transfer orbit failed. The master control facility at Hassan announced that the apogee motor of the satellite failed to fire on command from the ground. The satellite, heralding the country’s most ambitious project, to take the benefits of space technology to 60,000 villages developed the snag two hours after it was placed in the transfer orbit of the Delta rocket. Consequently, the apogee motor firing maneuvre has been put off by a day. The control team at Hassan is now engaged in working out contingency operations. Insat 1-A, the first civilian satellite to combine the function of telecommunications, TV broadcasting and meteorology will have a life span of seven years.
summary:
Summary:
ISRO faced its first challenge with Insat 1-A as attempts to put it on a transfer orbit failed due to the apogee motor not firing on command. The snag occurred two hours after it was placed in the transfer orbit of the Delta rocket. As a result, the firing maneuver has been delayed by a day, and the control team at Hassan is working on contingency operations. Insat 1-A, aimed at bringing space technology benefits to 60,000 villages, is the first civilian satellite to integrate telecommunications, TV broadcasting, and meteorology functions, with a lifespan of seven years.

headline: August 16, 1982, Forty Years Ago: PM’s I-Day Speech
article: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called on the people on August 15 to stand firm before disruptive forces, which were weakening the nation’s unity. There was a need to rekindle the spirit of sacrifice and striving that characterised the freedom struggle. Speaking after unfurling the national flag at Delhi’s Red Fort to mark the country’s 36th Independence Day, the PM said no progress was possible in the absence of unity and hard work. The task of loosening poverty’s grip, lessening injustice and taking the benefits of independence down to everyone was gigantic. She admitted that despite all efforts, injustice, oppression and corruption continued to exist. But these problems could not be combated by a weak government.
summary:
Summary:
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, addressing the nation on India's 36th Independence Day, urged the people to remain steadfast against disruptive forces threatening the nation's unity. She emphasized the need to revive the spirit of sacrifice and dedication that characterized the freedom struggle. Gandhi highlighted the importance of unity and hard work for progress, acknowledging the ongoing challenges of poverty, injustice, and corruption. She stressed that combating these issues required a strong government and collective effort.

headline: September 20, 1982: Jalal-ud-Din takes first ever hat-trick in ODI cricket
article:
In the first of three one-dayers played at the Niaz Stadium, Hyderabad (Pakistan), the hosts batted first and scored 229/6 in their allotted 40 overs. Opener Mohsin Khan scored a century while there were decent contributions from other batsmen.


Chasing 230 to take a 1-0 lead in the series Australia got off to a good start with openers Brian Laird and Graham Wood adding over a 100 for the first wicket. Pakistan then got into the game after picking up the wicket of Wood and from there on picked up wickets at regular intervals.

The back of Australian batting was however broken by Jalal-ud Din. The then 23-year-old pacer first removed wicket-keeper Rodney Marsh for 1 and on the very next ball he had Bruce Yardley caught behind for a duck. The pacer completed his hat-trick with the wicket of Geoff Lawson who was also bowled.
summary:
Summary:
In the first of three one-dayers at Niaz Stadium, Hyderabad (Pakistan), the hosts Pakistan scored 229/6 in their 40 overs, with opener Mohsin Khan scoring a century and other batsmen contributing well. Chasing 230, Australia had a strong start with openers Brian Laird and Graham Wood adding over 100 runs. However, Pakistan made a comeback after picking up Wood's wicket and then took wickets regularly. The turning point came when 23-year-old pacer Jalal-ud Din took a hat-trick, dismissing Rodney Marsh, Bruce Yardley, and Geoff Lawson in consecutive deliveries.

headline: HT This Day: September 25, 1982 -- 22 planes take part in Jubilee air race
article:
In all, 22 planes of seven different types joined the point-to-point race that took them to Agra and to Jaipur before returning to Safdarjang. All the aircraft safely arrived in the afternoon and it was a smooth course all through.

Today’s event was the first phase of the race. In the second and concluding one tomorrow, the competitors will be put through a “ton-stop triangular run”, expected to last three to four hours. Performance in both the phases will determine the overall results.

Even though the race, as conceived, was devoid of any real thrills, a large number of people turned up at the aerodrome well in time for the flag-off by Deputy Defence Minister K. P. Singh Deo at 8 a.m. Many took position on the Safdarjang flyover for a grand view of the take-off of the aircraft at two-minute intervals. Originally, 29 aircraft had been entered for the race. Seven withdrew, mostly on technical grounds. Swami Dhirendra Brahmachari’s Maule M-5, which was to be pilot ed by Mr Gurdev Singh Cheema and Miss Anita Bhatia, pulled out at the eleventh hour.
summary:
Summary:
A point-to-point race involving 22 planes of seven different types was held, taking them to Agra and Jaipur before returning to Safdarjang. All aircraft safely arrived in the afternoon, with a smooth course throughout. Today's event marked the first phase of the race, with the second phase scheduled for the following day. The concluding phase, a "ton-stop triangular run," is expected to last three to four hours, with overall results determined by performance in both phases. Despite the lack of real thrills in the race, a large crowd gathered at the aerodrome to witness the flag-off by Deputy Defence Minister K.P. Singh Deo. Originally, 29 aircraft were entered, but seven withdrew, mostly due to technical reasons. Notably, Swami Dhirendra Brahmachari's Maule M-5, piloted by Mr Gurdev Singh Cheema and Miss Anita Bhatia, withdrew at the last minute.

headline: Golden Temple in Amritsar: The holiest of Sikh shrines
article:
It is the holiest of Sikh shrines, the core of a faith that has survived five centuries of vicissitude but continues to bare its militant face. The Golden Temple in Amritsar - commonly known as "Darbar Sahib" - with its gilded, jewel-like chambers and cupolas, rising out of a cool blue water tank and, girdled by vast marble terraces, is a place of complete tranquillity and devotion. Its doors are closed to no one; all can seek shelter inside its haloed precincts or sit cross-legged on the floor to eat at itslangar or free meal service.

Meticulously maintained for cleanliness, assiduously attended at its daily ritual services, scrupulously secular in its outlook, the foremost of Sikh gurudwaras is more than a symbol of religious faith. It is a symbol of the political aspiration of the Sikhs; more than a place of worship, it is a place for the community to endorse their ideological faith.

Casually-armed Sikhs, equipped with rifles, revolvers or a variety of swords and sabres sanctioned by their religion, can be seen walking around freely or resting inside the main shrine. Public offenders can misuse it by seeking asylum, for the police by convention does not enter it. In the eyes of the Sikhs, the Golden Temple is more than a shrine: it is a sanctuary, an affirmation of the community's sense of identity.
A close up of the Harimandir - the inner sanctum of the Golden Temple rising out of the tank of water
It is not only today that the Golden Temple has been used as a refuge. Just as Sikh leader Sant Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, charged with inciting lawlessness, has acquired immunity by living in the temple, thousands of Hindu and Muslim families were saved from annihilation by seeking refuge inside its portals during the savagery of the Sikh-Muslim riots that gripped Punjab during Partition. In few religions is a shrine sanctified enough to grant total political asylum, yet constitute the hub of all inter-party and interpersonal politics.
partan Code: The Sikh religion advocates that to be a true Khalsa - one of the chosen and chaste race of soldier-saints - the disciple must adopt a spartan code of conduct, abstaining from liquor, tobacco and narcotics; devote himself to a life of prayer and crusade for dharamayuddha - the battle for righteousness.
Sikh extremists who have lately unleashed a wave of hijackings, murders and bomb attacks, who demand a separate state exclusive to their religious community, see themselves as protagonists of such a dharamayuddha - their morchas, voluntary arrests and acts of violence being undertaken in the name of religion.
summary:
The Golden Temple, also known as Sri Harmandir Sahib, is a sacred and iconic Sikh shrine located in Amritsar, India. This magnificent temple is a symbol of peace, equality, and spiritual unity. Its striking architecture features a glistening golden facade surrounded by a serene pool known as the Amrit Sarovar.
Founded by Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru, the temple is a place of worship and pilgrimage for Sikhs from around the world. The central prayer hall houses the Guru Granth Sahib, the holy scripture of Sikhism, and the atmosphere is filled with devotional hymns.

The Golden Temple stands out not only for its architectural brilliance but also for its principles of community service and inclusivity. The langar, a free community kitchen, serves meals to thousands of visitors regardless of their background, promoting the Sikh values of selfless service and equality.
Every day, the temple attracts a multitude of visitors, fostering a sense of spiritual harmony. Illuminated beautifully at night, the Golden Temple is a symbol of the rich cultural and spiritual heritage of Sikhism, welcoming people from all walks of life to experience its beauty and embrace its message of unity and compassion.

headline: October 17, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Akali Resistance
article: Violence erupted as responding to party chief Sant Harchand Singh Longowal’s call, Akali satyagrahis lodged in various jails all over the state, resisted eviction from prison. Acting on the decision to release the Akali detainees taken at the prime minister’s behest, the Punjab government claimed it had succeeded in evicting 3,000 Akalis from six main jails. But reports from various prisons in the state suggested that police operations were in most cases met with stiff resistance and were only partially successful in others. While the 2,300 satyagrahis lodged in the Ludhiana central jail virtually seized control of the administration as jail staff deserted their posts, in Kapurthala over three dozen persons were injured when fighting broke out between forcibly evicted Akalis and the police. While an official spokesman said the clash took place outside the jail premises, injured Akali workers said they had been “attacked” by the police inside the jail.
summary:
Summary:
Violence erupted as Akali satyagrahis, responding to party chief Sant Harchand Singh Longowal's call, resisted eviction from jails across Punjab. The Punjab government claimed to have successfully evicted 3,000 Akalis from six main jails, but reports suggested police operations faced stiff resistance. In Ludhiana central jail, satyagrahis virtually seized control as jail staff deserted their posts, while in Kapurthala, over three dozen were injured in clashes between evicted Akalis and police. Officially, the clash occurred outside the jail, but injured Akali workers claimed police attacked them inside the jail.

headline: December 13, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Bombay Bandh
article: Trade union leader Datta Samant called upon workers belonging to his unions, including the striking mill-workers of the Maharashtra Girni Kamgar Union (MGKU), to make the “Bombay bandh” a success. Addressing a large rally of supporters at the Shivaji Park in Central Bombay, the president of the MGKU urged them to ensure total peace and non-violence during the one-day agitation. Other speakers, however, threatened that the workers would take the law into their hands if the police tried to suppress the agitators who were expressing solidarity with the striking mill workers, who have now been on strike for almost 11 months.
summary:
Summary:
Trade union leader Datta Samant rallied workers, including striking mill-workers of the Maharashtra Girni Kamgar Union (MGKU), to participate in a "Bombay bandh" and ensure its success. Speaking at a large rally in Central Bombay, Samant urged for peace and non-violence during the agitation. However, other speakers warned of potential retaliation if the police attempted to suppress the agitators expressing solidarity with the striking mill workers, who had been on strike for nearly 11 months.

headline: December 22, 1982, Forty Years Ago: An Indo-Pak commission
article:
India and Pakistan have already arrived at a compromise through diplomatic channels on the scope of the Indo-Pakistan joint commission they intend to set up after talks between the foreign secretaries of the two countries in New Delhi. The foreign ministers are likely to be the co-chairmen of the joint commission which will meet periodically to tackle various bilateral questions.

The Indian draft seeks to empower the commission to tackle questions relating to economic cooperation, cultural exchanges, trade, travel and visas. Pakistan is reported to have suggested that the commission should also take up political and military questions — a suggestion New Delhi has been averse to accepting.
summary:
Summary:
India and Pakistan have reached a compromise through diplomatic talks on the scope of the Indo-Pakistan joint commission they plan to establish. The commission is likely to be co-chaired by the foreign ministers of both countries and will meet periodically to address bilateral issues. While India's draft emphasizes economic cooperation, cultural exchanges, trade, travel, and visas, Pakistan has proposed including political and military matters, which India has been reluctant to accept.

headline: Asiad '82 in New Delhi comes to a glorious end
article:
The Asian Games '82 in New Delhi came to a glorious end on Friday evening, with India finishing second in the medals tally behind China. India won 93 medals, including 25 gold, 29 silver, and 39 bronze. China won 194 medals, including 92 gold, 63 silver, and 39 bronze.
 
 The Asiad '82 was a major success for India, both in terms of organization and performance. The Games were held on a grand scale, with state-of-the-art infrastructure and facilities. The Indian athletes performed well, winning medals in a variety of sports, including athletics, wrestling, shooting, and boxing.
 
 The Asiad '82 was a special event for India, as it marked the country's return to the Games after 16 years. The previous time India had hosted the Asiad was in 1966.
 
 The Asiad '82 is a reminder of India's sporting potential and its ability to organize major international events. It is also a reminder of the importance of sports in promoting national unity and pride.
summary: The 1982 Asian Games are a landmark event in Indian sporting history. They were the first major international sporting event to be held in India after independence, and they helped to raise the country's sporting profile on the world stage. The Games also inspired a new generation of Indian athletes, and helped to lay the foundation for India's success in future sporting events.

headline: January 4, 1983, Forty Years Ago: No Glitz For Film Fest
article: The Ninth International Film Festival got off to a traditional start with N K P Salve, Minister for Information and Broadcasting, lighting a huge brass lamp with the light handed over by the Bombay cine actress, Dipti Naval, at a somewhat stereotyped function at Asiad village auditorium. Outside, a group of accredited card-holders was seen demonstrating against the policy of apartheid followed by the Directorate of Film Festivals. There was very little colour and gaiety for an international event like this. A couple of regulars from the Bombay film world — Sunil Dutt, Rekha, Shashi Kapoor and Aparna Sen — were there.
summary:
Summary:
The Ninth International Film Festival began with N K P Salve, Minister for Information and Broadcasting, lighting a lamp at a traditional ceremony. However, the event lacked color and gaiety, with a group of accredited card-holders protesting outside against the apartheid policy of the Directorate of Film Festivals. Few notable figures from the Bombay film industry attended, including Sunil Dutt, Rekha, Shashi Kapoor, and Aparna Sen.

headline: February 7, 1983, Forty Years Ago: A Collegium of judges for appointments is proposed
article:
More than 60 judges of the high courts and the Supreme Court and several other leaders of the legal profession suggested a collegium of judges for appointment to the higher judiciary.

The committee, which studied the question of independence of judiciary at the silver jubilee conference of the Indian Law Institute in New Delhi, was of the view that executive control or interference in the matter of appointment of judges impaired judicial independence and should be eliminated. The question was how.

The committee which discussed the issues threadbare favoured the idea of collegium consisting of the Chief Justice and two or three senior judges arriving at the decision.
summary:
Summary:
Over 60 judges from high courts and the Supreme Court, along with leaders from the legal profession, proposed the establishment of a collegium of judges for appointments to the higher judiciary. They emphasized that executive control or interference in judicial appointments impairs judicial independence and should be eliminated. The suggested collegium would comprise the Chief Justice and two or three senior judges making decisions on appointments.

headline: February 20, 1983, Forty Years Ago: Massacre in Assam
article: In a ghastly replay of the Mandai massacre, at least 500 persons were killed by frenzied tribal hordes in a cluster of villages spreading north to the foothills around Nelli village near Jagiroad in Nowgong district. The violence continued through the night and fresh incidents were reported from the interior. With the situation getting out of control, four columns of army troops marched into the area in the evening and took over medical aid to the injured, to begin with, official sources said. On a visit to four of the 15 affected villages, 353 bodies were found. Five hundred would appear to be a conservative estimate.
summary:
Summary:
A horrific massacre occurred in several villages near Nelli village in Nowgong district, where tribal hordes killed at least 500 people. The violence continued overnight, with fresh incidents reported. The army deployed four columns to the area to provide medical aid to the injured. During a visit to four affected villages, 353 bodies were discovered, suggesting that the death toll could be even higher.

headline: February 27, 1983, Forty Years Ago: NAM to ban nukes; JNU closed sine die
article:
The seventh non-aligned conference taking place in New Delhi early next month will come out with an impassioned plea for nuclear disarmament. This is clear from the draft of the political declaration the non-aligned heads of government are going to issue at the end of their deliberations in New Delhi.

JNU closed: Jawaharlal Nehru University has been closed sine die. The hostel messes too have been closed and the resident students have been asked to vacate the hostels at the earliest. In his order closing the university, P N Srivastava, Acting Vice-Chancellor, said the decision had been taken in view of the deteriorating situation on the campus.
summary:
Summary:
The upcoming seventh non-aligned conference in New Delhi is expected to issue a strong plea for nuclear disarmament, according to a draft political declaration. Meanwhile, Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) has been closed indefinitely due to worsening conditions on campus, with hostel messes also shut down and residents asked to vacate.

headline: April 21, 1983, Forty Years Ago: No Akali Resolution
article: In spite of informal discussions with the Akali leader, Balwant Singh, through the CPM leader, Harkishan Singh Surjeet, and hectic political activities, there could be no final decision on the mode of talks with the Akalis till last evening. The Political Affairs Committee of the Union Cabinet considered the Punjab situation inconclusively. The committee is expected to meet again today on this issue. One view is that the government should await the arrival of the Haryana Chief Minister, Bhajan Lal, from the US next week before reaching a settlement with the Akalis on the territorial issue. Another opinion is that his views are known and the decision can be taken in light of those views.
summary:
Summary:
Despite informal discussions with Akali leader Balwant Singh via CPM leader Harkishan Singh Surjeet and intensive political activities, a final decision on the mode of talks with the Akalis had not been reached as of last evening. The Political Affairs Committee of the Union Cabinet discussed the Punjab situation inconclusively, with plans to reconvene on the matter today. One perspective suggests awaiting the return of Haryana Chief Minister Bhajan Lal from the US next week before settling the territorial issue with the Akalis, while another viewpoint suggests that his known views could inform the decision-making process without his physical presence.

headline: April 23, 1982, Forty Years Ago: Tax Relief
article: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee announced a number of minor tax concessions amounting to Rs 15.73 crore in the Lok Sabha. Moving the Finance BUI, which gives effect to his taxation proposals contained in the 1932-83 budget, Mukherjee announced reliefs in direct taxes totaling Rs 11.23 crore and a number of concessions in indirect taxes which are aimed at reducing the burden on small manufacturers. The total taxation effort made by the Finance Minister while presenting his budget amounted to Rs 589.33 crore. Prominent among the concessions is the increase in exemption limit for those who avail of leave encashment and extension of excise duty concession scheme to small assemblers of cassette tapes, parts of pens and ball-point pens.
summary:
Summary:
Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee announced minor tax concessions totaling Rs 15.73 crore during his speech in the Lok Sabha. These concessions include relief in direct taxes amounting to Rs 11.23 crore and various concessions in indirect taxes aimed at reducing the burden on small manufacturers. The total taxation effort outlined by the Finance Minister in his budget amounted to Rs 589.33 crore. Key concessions include an increase in the exemption limit for leave encashment and the extension of excise duty concession schemes to small assemblers of cassette tapes, pen parts, and ball-point pens.

headline: HT This Day: June 19, 1983 -- India beat Zimbabwe
article:
India collapsed to 17 for five in the first 13 overs against pacemen Peter Rawson and Kevin Curran, and were later reduced to 78 for seven, before Kapil Dev’s breathtaking rescue lifted the score to 266 for eight in the 60 overs.


Zimbabwe, struggling at one time at 113 for six, made a late burst through Kevin Curran, who hit a brilliant 71, to total 234 in 57 to Kevin at one stage raised his team’s hopes of another victory by sheer nature of his aggression. Of his eight boundaries six came in last 45 runs.

He was caught brilliantly by Shastri on second attempt off Madan Lal, who had come in for a heavy battering in the previous over.
summary: In a cricket match, India suffered a dismal start, collapsing to 17 for five within the first 13 overs against the pace bowlers Peter Rawson and Kevin Curran. Despite the early setbacks, India managed to recover, reaching 78 for seven before Kapil Dev's remarkable performance lifted the score to 266 for eight within 60 overs. Zimbabwe faced similar challenges, initially struggling at 113 for six. However, Kevin Curran's impressive innings, highlighted by a brilliant 71 runs, propelled Zimbabwe's total to 234 within 57 overs. Kevin Curran's aggressive batting raised hopes of victory for Zimbabwe, with six out of his eight boundaries coming in the last 45 runs. He was eventually caught by Shastri, with Madan Lal taking the crucial wicket after enduring a tough previous over.

headline: India create history, Kapil Dev’s team lift 1983 World Cup
article:
India not only won their first-ever World Cup, they ended West Indies’ domination in the limited-overs. West Indies had won the first two editions of the World Cups in 1975 and 1979.


Batting first in a 60-overs-per-side contest, India lost Sunil Gavaskar cheaply. However, the middle order showed a lot of gumption against West Indies’ feared bowling line-up which included Andy Roberts, Joel Garner, Malcolm Marshall and Michael Holding.

While several Indian batsmen scored in double digits, it was Krishnamachari Srikkanth’s 57-ball 38 with seven fours and one six was the best performance from any Indian with the bat as they reached 183

In response, the famed West Indies batting flopped, and Richards was the top run-getter with a quick 28-ball 33. Lal had him caught by Kapil at a crucial interval.
summary:
Summary:
India secured their maiden World Cup victory, ending West Indies' dominance in limited-overs cricket. Batting first in a 60-overs-per-side match, India faced a formidable West Indies bowling attack but displayed resilience with contributions from the middle order. Krishnamachari Srikkanth's innings of 38 runs off 57 balls stood out as India reached a total of 183 runs. In response, the West Indies batting lineup faltered, with Vivian Richards top-scoring with 33 runs off 28 balls before being dismissed by Madan Lal, a crucial moment in the match.

headline: India World Champions
article:
India scripted history at Lord's on Sunday as they lifted the Prudential World Cup for the first time, defeating the West Indies by 43 runs in the final.

India won the toss and elected to bat first. They were off to a steady start as Kris Srikkanth and Sunil Gavaskar put on 75 runs for the first wicket. However, the West Indies bowlers then struck back, taking three quick wickets to leave India reeling at 87 for 3.

But Kapil Dev and Mohinder Amarnath then put on a crucial partnership of 126 runs for the fourth wicket. Dev was dismissed for 66, but Amarnath went on to score a brilliant century (103). He was eventually dismissed for 103, but by then India had reached a respectable total of 183 runs.

The West Indies were the favorites to win the final, but they were undone by some excellent bowling from the Indian bowlers. Madan Lal and Roger Binny took three wickets each, while Kapil Dev and Ravi Shastri took two wickets each. The West Indies were bowled out for 140 runs in 52 overs, and India won the match by 43 runs.

India's victory in the World Cup was a historic moment for the country. It was the first time that India had won a major world title in cricket. The victory was also a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team.
summary:
India defeated the West Indies by 43 runs in the final of the 1983 Prudential World Cup to win the tournament for the first time. It was a historic moment for the country, and it was a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team.

India's victory in the World Cup was a historic moment for the country. It was the first time that India had won a major world title in cricket, and it was a testament to the skill and determination of the Indian team. The victory also had a significant impact on the country as a whole, inspiring a generation of cricketers and helping to make cricket the most popular sport in India.

headline: July 12, 1983, Forty Years Ago: Nepal PM Ousted
article: Nepalese Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa was voted out of office through a no-confidence motion. A special meeting of the national legislature (Rashtriya Panchayat) voted him out of power. The ouster had culminated from the motion presented by 40 members on June 24. The first-ever no-confidence motion moved and passed in the 20-year history of the Nepalese legislature was presented by the informal leader of the Opposition, Lokendra Bahadur Chand, who charged the Prime Minister of seeking to undermine the active leadership of the Crown, not carrying out the directives of King Birendra, for pursuing a wrong policy resulting in chaos in the economic scene and undermining social values.
summary:
Summary:
Nepalese Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa was ousted from office following a successful no-confidence motion in the national legislature (Rashtriya Panchayat). The motion, initiated by 40 members and led by Opposition figure Lokendra Bahadur Chand, accused Thapa of undermining the authority of the monarchy, disregarding directives from King Birendra, pursuing flawed economic policies, and eroding societal values. This marked the first-ever successful no-confidence motion in Nepal's two-decade legislative history.

headline: "Forty Years Ago: Message to Colombo"
article:
The Indian government to the Sri Lankan government on that day. The message was in response to the anti-Tamil riots that had taken place in Sri Lanka on August 5-6, 1983.

The anti-Tamil riots were a series of attacks on Tamils by Sinhalese mobs. The riots were sparked by the killing of 13 Sinhalese soldiers by Tamil militants. However, the violence quickly spread to other parts of Sri Lanka, and thousands of Tamils were killed, injured, or displaced.

The Indian government was deeply concerned about the anti-Tamil riots. India has a large Tamil population, and many Indians have close ties to Sri Lanka. The Indian government also feared that the violence could destabilize the region and lead to a wider conflict.

In its message to Colombo, the Indian government called on the Sri Lankan government to take steps to protect the Tamils and to bring the perpetrators of the violence to justice. The Indian government also warned the Sri Lankan government that it would not tolerate further violence against the Tamils.

The Sri Lankan government responded to the Indian message by promising to take steps to protect the Tamils and to bring the perpetrators of the violence to justice. However, the Sri Lankan government also accused the Indian government of interfering in Sri Lanka's internal affairs.

The anti-Tamil riots were a watershed moment in the Sri Lankan civil war. The riots led to a sharp increase in support for Tamil militancy, and the war ultimately lasted for over 25 years.
summary:
The headline "Forty Years Ago: Message to Colombo" from The Indian Express on August 12, 1983, refers to a message that was sent by the Indian government to the Sri Lankan government on that day. The message was in response to the anti-Tamil riots that had taken place in Sri Lanka on August 5-6, 1983.

The anti-Tamil riots were a series of attacks on Tamils by Sinhalese mobs. The riots were sparked by the killing of 13 Sinhalese soldiers by Tamil militants. However, the violence quickly spread to other parts of Sri Lanka, and thousands of Tamils were killed, injured, or displaced.

headline: HT on September 06: One dead, one caught
article: Mumbai’s first shoot-out in court was a sensational incident that marked the first high-profile strike by a small-time smuggler called Dawood Ibrahim.And it set off a string of repeat performances, the latest being Monday’s Kala Ghoda incident that killed police informer Amjad Khan and Himanshu Chaudhari.Here, a replay of that dramatic 1983 incident in which Isaque Bagwan, Police Sub-Inspector attached to the crime branch, managed to apprehend the culprit with some quick thinking.It was 11.30 am on September 6, 1983. Police Sub-Inspector Isaque Bagwan had just escorted dreaded gangster Amirzada Nawab Khan to Mumbai’s Sessions Court in connection with the murder of Shabbir Ibrahim, elder brother of Khan’s arch rival Dawood Ibrahim.The burly Amirzada, wearing a white T-shirt and blue trousers, strode into the prisoner’s enclosure inside the busy court. He was accompanied by Jaffar Jamal Siddique, an associate.
summary:
Summary:
The 1983 shoot-out in Mumbai's Sessions Court involved small-time smuggler Dawood Ibrahim and marked the beginning of a series of similar incidents. Police Sub-Inspector Isaque Bagwan apprehended gangster Amirzada Nawab Khan, who was accused of murdering Shabbir Ibrahim, Dawood's brother. The shoot-out set off a chain of similar events, including the recent Kala Ghoda incident.

headline: Women raise city’s problems before C.S.
article:
Representatives of various women’s organizations in Shillong aired some of the problems faced by the People of Shillong at a meeting convened by the Chief Secretary Mrs P.P. Trivedi here on Oct 5.

Focusing the city’s transport problems it was suggested that more public buses should be introduced to ease the problems of the commuters and to make provision for separate entry doors for the ladies.


The ladies expressed concern over the filthy and unhygienic conditions prevailing in and around Barabazar area and sought govt help to improve the despisable conditions.

Some of them urged the Govt to help in easing the acute water problem in some of the localities in the city. They, informed the Chief Secretary of the inferior quality of rice and other essential commodities being supplied through fair price shops.

The other problems which figured during the discussion were the unsatisfactory manner of handling the milk packets of the Town Milk Supply Scheme; the need for providing public convenience; regulating of parking system for vehicles. Locating “teer” stalls only in approved places; and checking of blackmarketing in cinema tickets.

Mrs Trivedi assured them of exploring the possibility of introduction of ladies special mini buses by the Meghalaya Transport Corporation. She also said the water supply and other problems was being reviewed by the Govt in order to reduce the drudgery of women.

The Additional Chief Secretary, Mr R.V. Lyngdoh, who is also Special Secretary for PHE, informed that by April-May next year the first phase of the Greater Shillong Water Supply Scheme was expected to be commissioned resulting in drastic improvement in the situation.
summary:
Representatives of various women's organizations in Shillong aired some of the problems faced by the People of Shillong at a meeting convened by the Chief Secretary Mrs P.P. Trivedi here on Oct 5. Focusing the city's transport problems it was suggested that more public buses should be introduced to ease the problems of the commuters and to make provision for separate entry doors for the ladies.
The ladies expressed concern over the filthy and unhygienic conditions prevailing in and around Barabazar area and sought govt help to improve the despisable conditions.
Some of them urged the Govt to help in easing the acute water problem in some of the localities in the city.

headline: Forty Years Ago: India slams invasion
article:
About 800 paratroopers of the US army’s 82nd airborne division landed in Grenada to reinforce the American invasion force fighting with Cuban and Grenadian troops on the tiny Caribbean island. India said the invasion of Grenada “cannot be justified and is inconsistent with the basic law of international behaviour.” It called for the immediate withdrawal of all foreign forces from Grenada.
Another assassination
A gunman pumped seven bullets into Jordan’s Ambassador to Italy in the second assassination attempt in two days against envoys from West Asia, police said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the shooting that seriously wounded ambassador Taysir Alaedin Toukan and his Egyptian driver Mohamed Hidar Baud. Both the driver and the 57-year-old ambassador underwent emergency operations.

NDA against tallow
Supporters of the National Democratic Alliance, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party president A B Vajpayee and the Lok Dal president Charan Singh, staged a day-long dharna at the Boat Club to protest against the addition of beef and pig tallow to vanaspati. The protestors spent the entire day listening to speeches delivered by various leaders from both parties.
No invite to Akalis
The government seems to have deferred its decision to send an invitation to the Akalis for resumption of talks in view of the unabated terrorist activities in the state. This was indicated by Home Minister P C Sethi when he said that no date had been fixed for sending the letter. He said as far as the government was concerned, its doors were always open for talks.
summary:
Approximately 800 paratroopers from the US Army's 82nd Airborne Division were deployed to Grenada to reinforce American forces involved in an invasion of the Caribbean island. This invasion was against Cuban and Grenadian troops. India strongly opposed this intervention, deeming it unjustifiable and inconsistent with international norms. India called for the immediate withdrawal of all foreign forces from Grenada.

Jordan's Ambassador to Italy, Taysir Alaedin Toukan, survived an assassination attempt when an unidentified gunman fired seven bullets at him and his Egyptian driver, Mohamed Hidar Baud. Both victims were seriously wounded and underwent emergency surgeries. The motive and responsible party behind the attack were not immediately clear.

Supporters of the National Democratic Alliance, led by leaders such as A.B. Vajpayee of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Charan Singh of the Lok Dal, staged a day-long protest (dharna) at the Boat Club. They were demonstrating against the inclusion of beef and pig tallow in vanaspati, a vegetable ghee product. The protest involved speeches by various leaders from both parties.

The Indian government appeared to postpone its decision to invite the Akalis, a Sikh political group, for talks due to ongoing terrorist activities in the state. Home Minister P.C. Sethi indicated that no specific date had been set for sending the invitation, but emphasized that the government remained open to dialogue with the Akalis.

These events reflect a mix of international concerns, domestic protests, and security-related decisions in India during the reported period.

headline: November 3, 1983, Forty Years Ago: Tax Proposal Opposed
article:
Several chief ministers expressed reservations on the twin proposals to replace sales tax by additional excise duty on selected items and levying tax on inter-state consignment of goods, in spite of assurances by  Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee that the financial interests of the states would be protected. There was total opposition from non-Congress (I) chief ministers, and states under Congress (I) governments expressed qualified support.

US Invades Carriacou
Around 300 US marines invaded the tiny Grenadian island of Carriacou and recovered some weapons but found no Cubans. No shots were fired by the marines as they swept through the 33-sq-km island, 32 km north-east of Grenada, according to Pentagon officials who declined to be named. The marines landed because of US Intelligence reports that Cubans were on the Island.

Tarapur Parts
India and West Germany have exchanged notes stipulating West German agreement for the supply of spare parts for the Tarapur Atomic Power Plant. The notes were exchanged between the two governments in Delhi last month. Available information suggests that the West German firm KWV — a subsidiary of Siemens International —  will supply the spare parts.

Looting In Punjab
Yet another bank was looted in Punjab and two hand grenades found in Amritsar near the shop of a retired police officer who had escaped death at the hands of terrorists two days ago. Six armed desperadoes struck at the State Bank of Patiala’s branch at Shambhu barrier on the border of Punjab and Haryana on the busy National Highway No.1 and decamped with nearly Rs 35.000.
summary:
India and West Germany have reached an agreement to exchange spare parts for the Tarapur Atomic Power Plant. This is a positive development, as it will help to ensure the continued operation of this important power plant.
The United States invaded the tiny Grenadian island of Carriacou in search of Cubans, but found none. This invasion was controversial, as it was seen by some as an act of imperialism.
Several chief ministers in India have expressed reservations about the twin proposals to replace sales tax by additional excise duty on selected items and levying tax on inter-state consignment of goods. There is opposition to these proposals from both non-Congress (I) and Congress governments. Yet another bank has been looted in Punjab. This is a sign of the continuing lawlessness in the state.

headline: HT This Day: October 20, 1983 -- India-born physicist shares Nobel prize
article:
Prof Chandrasekhar is the second Indian-born American to get the coveted Nobel Prize. Dr Hargobind Khurana, who won it for his study in the field of genetics, was the first.
The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said both laureates had done Nobel-caliber research in the evolution of the stars. It said Indian-born Prof Chandrasekhar was honoured for “his theoretical studies of the physical processes of importance to the structure and evolution of the stars.”
Prof Fowler’s citation noted: “His theoretical and experimental studies of the nuclear reactions of importance in the formation of the chemical elements in the universe.”
Prof Chandrasekhar’s award came on his 73rd birthday. “Prof Chandrasekhar’s work deals with a large number of features in stellar evolution,” the Academy said in a statement explaining his award. “A major contribution is the study of the stability problem in different phases of evolution.”
summary:
Summary:
Professor Chandrasekhar, the second Indian-born American to receive the Nobel Prize, was honored for his theoretical studies on the structure and evolution of stars. His award coincided with his 73rd birthday. The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences recognized his significant contributions to understanding various aspects of stellar evolution, particularly his work on the stability problem in different phases of stellar evolution.

headline: P.M. calls for unity
article:
The Prime Minister, Mrs Indira Gandhi, has called for unity among all sections of the people in Assam and other North-Eastern States, in bringing about all round development of the region. She was speaking at a public gathering in Gauhati on Feb 2. She made it clear to the well-attended gathering that disunity would only bring about disaster to the region as well as to the country. She also urged the people to give all possible help and co-operation to the present government in implementing the various schemes launched by it to help the poor.

At Itanagar, the Prime Minister assured that the North-Eastern states of an increase in plan allocation for catching up and keeping pace with the rest of the country in development.


After the Prime Minister left for Delhi, the 36 hour road blockade and other locally organised bundhs and Janata curfew, called by the Assam Movement leaders also came to an end.

The derailment of a train and a bomb explosion on rail track were the only two major incidents reported during the entire period. No one was hurt. The derailment and the damage to the tracks, however, paralysed the rail commuuications in the region for several hours.
summary: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, speaking at a public gathering in Gauhati on Feb 2, called for unity among all sections of the people in Assam and other North-Eastern States to bring about all-round development. She emphasized that disunity would only lead to disaster for the region and the country. In Itanagar, she assured an increase in plan allocation for the North-Eastern states to help them catch up with the rest of the country in development. After the Prime Minister's departure, a 36-hour road blockade and other locally organized protests, including a Janata curfew, called by Assam Movement leaders, came to an end. The only major incidents reported were a train derailment and a bomb explosion on a rail track, causing temporary paralysis in rail communications.

headline: January 30 1984: Significance of Martyrs' Day
article: The date, January 30th, marks the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi in 1948. On this solemn day, the nation remembers not only the iconic leader but also countless others who laid down their lives during the struggle against British colonial rule and for the larger cause of justice, equality, and human rights. The observance of Martyrs' Day serves as a reminder of the sacrifices made by these individuals, inspiring generations to uphold the values of freedom, peace, and unity. Mahatma Gandhi was assassinated by Nathuram Godse on January 30, 1984, just a few months after India gained independence from British rule. His assassination shocked the nation, and the 30th of January was subsequently declared as Martyrs' Day.
summary:
Summary:
The statement discusses the significance of January 30th as the day of Mahatma Gandhi's assassination in 1948, emphasizing its commemoration as Martyrs' Day to honor not only Gandhi but also others who sacrificed their lives for justice, equality, and human rights during the struggle against British colonial rule. However, there's a factual error regarding the year of Gandhi's assassination, which occurred in 1948, not 1984.

headline: More wild life sanctuaries for North-East
article:
The Union Ministry for Environment has taken up a comprehensive scheme to set up some new wild life sanctuaries in the North-East.

Talking to newsmen here this week the Union Deputy Minister for Environment, Mr. Digvijay Singh, said that a national park was being set up at the famous Balphakram area in Garo Hills. The adjacent Siju sanctuary, which is already in existence, would be integrated with the National Park. He informed that a flora sanctuary would be created near the Tura ridge which is the hub of the original citrus genes.

Mr Singh said that at Jatinga in the North Cachar area of Assam a game sanctuary would be instituted covering an area of 130 sq.km. In Manipur, where two national parks are in existence at Ukhrul and Loktak area, decision had been made to set up two more – in the North and Sough Districts.

Mr Singh said in reply to a question “our funding is ready, it is upto the State Governments to do the mapping. It is dependent on how soon they do the ground work.”
summary: The Union Ministry for Environment has initiated a comprehensive scheme to establish new wildlife sanctuaries in the North-East of India. Deputy Minister for Environment, Mr. Digvijay Singh, announced the creation of a national park at Balphakram in Garo Hills, integrating the existing Siju sanctuary with it. Additionally, a flora sanctuary is planned near the Tura ridge. A game sanctuary will be established at Jatinga in Assam, covering 130 sq. km. Two new national parks will be set up in Manipur, complementing the existing ones in Ukhrul and Loktak areas. The initiative awaits groundwork by the respective State Governments.

headline: Govt. to take-over primary education in Khasi Hills
article:
A four-day mini session of the Meghalaya Assembly has been convened on February 24, to transact some important official business.

Sources said that the session which was earlier scheduled to begin from March 16 was preponed mainly for two reasons: to enable the out-going Governor to address the Assembly as in customary for him to do at the first session of the year; secondly, to present the Dutta Commission Enquiry Report before the House to enable the Govt to take-over the management of primary education in Khasi Hills from the District Council.

The take-over of primary education, observers say, is likely to be an important issue at the coming District Council polls. The ruling side expected to grill the regional parties for its unsatisfactory management of primary education. (The Govt and the District Council have been making claims and counter claims on this matter).

Sources said that the mini session would be adjourned on February 29 to enable the members to join the electioneering. The House would in all probability meet immediately after the polls.

Meanwhile, the Govt has decided to present at vote-on-account budget for three months. It is said that the Govt was not prepared with the budget estimates for the next financial year. This would mean that the Assembly would meet against o pass the budget for the remaining nine months within June 30.
summary: A four-day mini-session of the Meghalaya Assembly has been rescheduled to begin on February 24, instead of the originally planned March 16. The decision was made to allow the outgoing Governor to address the Assembly and to present the Dutta Commission Enquiry Report. The report is crucial for the government to take over the management of primary education in Khasi Hills from the District Council. This move is expected to be a significant topic in the upcoming District Council polls, with the ruling side criticizing the regional parties for inadequate management of primary education. The mini-session is likely to be adjourned on February 29, allowing members to participate in election activities, and the Assembly is expected to reconvene after the polls. The government plans to present a vote-on-account budget for three months, with the full budget for the remaining nine months expected to be passed by June 30.

headline: Mehrotra's departure put off
article:
Governor Prakash Mehrotra has been asked by the Centre to delay his departure for London. According to a highly placed source, the instruction was conveyed to the Governor over telephone on February 16.

Mr. Mehrotra, the Indian High Commission -designate for Britain, was to have left Shillong for good on February 26. He was planning to spend a few days in Assam before leaving for Delhi en route to London.


It is understood that the developments in London following the killing of Indian Assistant High Commissioner and the delay in finding a suitable successor to Mr Mehrotra are the principal reasons for the “stay-there” order.
summary: Governor Prakash Mehrotra, designated as the Indian High Commissioner to Britain, has been instructed by the Indian government to delay his departure for London. The directive, conveyed over the phone on February 16, cited developments in London after the killing of the Indian Assistant High Commissioner and the delay in finding a suitable successor as reasons for the delay. Initially scheduled to leave on February 26, Mehrotra planned to spend a few days in Assam before departing for Delhi en route to London.

headline: Indian diplomat shot dead
article:
The government has ordered tightening security measures in India’s 100-odd missions abroad and also within the country — particularly in Jammu and Kashmir where the state government is being advised to crack down on secessionist and anti-India elements.
R H Mhatre, India’s assistant commissioner in the Birmingham consulate has been shot dead by a group believed to be the Kashmir Liberation Army (KLA). Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has personally directed the special (police) branch to see that the culprits are hunted down and captured. In a message to Mrs Indira Gandhi, she said, “The police with full support of the government will continue to bring those responsible to justice”.
summary: The Indian government has mandated heightened security at its missions globally and domestically, particularly in Jammu and Kashmir, urging action against separatist elements. R H Mhatre, an Indian official in Birmingham, was fatally shot by suspected Kashmir Liberation Army members. Prime Minister Thatcher pledged full support in capturing the culprits, assuring justice in a message to Mrs. Gandhi.

headline: Violent mobs in Karnal, Panipat teargassed
article:
The police fired teargas shells and resorted to lathicharge at Karnal and Panipat to disperse mobs damaging private and public property in retaliation to the incidents in Punjab. According to reports, there was tension in Karnal, Panipat, Yamunanagar and Jagadhri, where most of the shops remained closed in a spontaneous protest against the Punjab incidents.
Pakistan’s Atom Bomb
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has said that India was in touch with countries reportedly helping Pakistan in the manufacture of the atom bomb since it would materially affect the security of this country. In an interview to two Polish journalists, she said India still believed that the greatest danger was of a conventional war, but it could not but be concerned about Pakistan acquiring such a capability.
LIC Action Disputed
Bombay High Court allowed Escorts Ltd and H P Nanda to amend their writ petition against the Union of India, the Reserve Bank of India and others, including Swraj Paul and companies controlled by him, to implead Life Insurance Corporation of India as the 13th respondent to the petition and challenge the action of the LIC calling for a meeting of the petitioner company to replace nine directors.
Warning for UP
Congress (I) general secretary Rajiv Gandhi said strict disciplinary action would be taken against detractors who tried to disturb the normal functioning of the government or the party. Reacting sharply to the recent activities of dissidents in Uttar Pradesh, Mr Gandhi said the current dissidence would fizzle out in a day or two. The dissidents have very meagre support against their tall claims.
summary: Police used teargas and lathi charges to disperse mobs damaging property in Karnal and Panipat in response to incidents in Punjab, leading to tension in several towns. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed concern over reports of countries aiding Pakistan's atom bomb development, citing security implications. The Bombay High Court allowed amendments to a petition disputing LIC's actions, while Congress (I) warned of disciplinary action against detractors in Uttar Pradesh, dismissing dissident activities as lacking support.

headline: Zail for vigil against disruptive forces
article:
President Zail Singh has called upon all citizens to cooperate with the government in putting down divisive forces in the country. Addressing the Parliament on the opening day of the budget session, Zail Singh said in the present complex international situation, it was essential to intensify vigilance for preserving economic and political independence. The country could achieve sustained progress only in a climate of harmony.
Punjab Bomb Blast
Four people were killed in three districts of Punjab in shooting and bomb blast incidents in the continuing wave of terrorist violence. Two people were shot dead by terrorists at Sriguruharsahay in Firozpur district and one each killed in Amritsar and Gurdaspur districts. A police inspector’s brother was shot dead and a bomb blast wounded nine persons at Batala in Gurdaspur district. The fresh spurt of violence has claimed 25 lives so far.
NDA’s Boycott
The Lok Dal and the BJP, partners of the National Democratic Alliance, boycotted the joint session of Parliament. Later, Charan Singh and Atal Bihari Vajpayee led a procession of 55 members of Parliament to lodge their protest against the government’s failure to maintain law and order and to protect the lives of innocent people in Punjab.
Israeli Plane Attack
Israeli warplanes pounded targets in the rebel-held mountains east of Beirut for the third time this week as the Lebanese Army troops patrolled West Beirut, which was crippled by a general strike. Sporadic clashes continued along the green line separating Muslim West Beirut from the Christian eastern sector after a night of heavy shelling in which at least 15 persons were killed and 70 wounded.
summary: President Zail Singh urged citizens to cooperate in countering divisive forces for economic and political independence. In Punjab, terrorist violence claimed four lives, including a police inspector's brother, with shootings and a bomb blast. The Lok Dal and BJP, part of the NDA, boycotted Parliament, protesting the government's failure in Punjab. Israeli warplanes attacked rebel-held mountains near Beirut, while clashes persisted in the city, resulting in casualties.

headline: Badal arrested in Delhi for burning Art. 25
article:
Nine Akali Dal leaders were arrested on charges of insulting national honour. Parkash Singh Badal and four others were arrested in Delhi after they burnt copies of a section of Article 25 of the Constitution. In Chandigarh, SGPC president Gurcharan Singh Tohra and others were arrested after they tore copies of Article 25 and deleted the word “Sikh” from a clause clubbing Sikhs and Hindus.
Economic Survey
The pre-budget economic survey speaks of mixed trends in 1983-84 with a relatively high overall rate of growth of six to seven per cent in the gross national product (GNP), improved balance of payments, continued inflationary pressure, particularly on consumer prices, showing an annual rate of inflation of 1.25 per cent sluggishness in government revenues due to lower than expected tax receipts.
Bandh Successful
