The general strike in Delhi to protest against the killings in Punjab and Haryana and the inability of the government to deal with extremist violence was a success as most markets, business establishments and industrial units remained closed for the entire day. Essential services, including transport, water and electricity, remained unaffected as they were exempt by the BJP’s strike call.
Zia’s Surprise Move
Pakistan’s military government, in a surprise move, freed six opposition leaders from detention. One of those released was Sardar Sherbaz Khan Mazari, chief of the banned National Democratic Party and convener of the 10-party opposition coalition, the Movement for the Restoration of Democracy (MRD). Mazari said: “I don’t know the cause of release. The authorities informed me about the withdrawal of the detention order today.
summary: Nine Akali Dal leaders, including Parkash Singh Badal and SGPC president Gurcharan Singh Tohra, were arrested for insulting national honour by burning and tearing copies of Article 25 of the Constitution. The economic survey highlighted mixed trends in 1983-84, with six to seven per cent growth in GNP but continued inflationary pressure. A successful general strike in Delhi protested against extremist violence in Punjab and Haryana. Pakistan's military government surprised by releasing six opposition leaders, including Sardar Sherbaz Khan Mazari, from detention

headline: Opposition in league with separatists: PM
article:
The just-concluded Udaipur talks between the foreign secretaries of India and Pakistan — M K Rasgotra and Niaz A Naik — have led the two countries to agree to resume their dialogue on Pakistan's offer of a no-war pact and India’s offer of a treaty of friendship, peace and co-operation.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said in Jagdishpur that the opposition parties were collaborating with disruptive, divisive and separatist forces. She cautioned countrymen against their “nefarious” designs. Mrs Gandhi said that the growing communalism, sectarianism, casteism and mounting atrocities on Harijans and women were part of a conspiracy to weaken her government by them, though they themselves could not remain united.
summary: The Udaipur talks between Indian and Pakistani foreign secretaries, M K Rasgotra and Niaz A Naik, concluded with an agreement to resume dialogue. Pakistan proposed a no-war pact, while India offered a treaty of friendship. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi warned against opposition collaboration with disruptive forces, attributing communalism, casteism, and atrocities as attempts to weaken her government.

headline: Crackdown on AISSF activists in Punjab
article:
About 100 activists of the All-India Sikh Students Federation (AISSF) have been arrested in a state-wide crackdown in Punjab against the organisation, which was banned. None of its senior leaders have been arrested yet. The president and general secretary are operating from the Golden Temple.

SC Bats For Editor
A constitution bench of the Supreme Court directed that the editor of Eenadu, Ramoji Rao, should not be arrested if the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Council or the committee on privileges issues warrant against him. Rao was called to the bar of the legislative council by the privilege committee for admonition for a report in his newspaper. The objectionable part in the report, according to the committee, was the headline, “Elders’ commotion”.
summary: Around 100 activists from the All-India Sikh Students Federation (AISSF) were detained in Punjab following a state-wide crackdown after the organization's ban. Key leaders remain at large, with the president and general secretary reportedly operating from the Golden Temple. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court intervened to prevent the arrest of Eenadu editor Ramoji Rao, amid a dispute with the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Council over a published report titled "Elders' commotion."

headline: Badal asked Rao for army action'
article: A day after questioning Badal's role during Operation Bluestar, his rival from the Congress, Captain Amarinder Singh, on Wednesday fired this second salvo at the Akali stalwart. In an open letter to the Punjab CM, he even cited March 28, 1984, as the date when Badal had a meeting with the-then union home minister, PV Narasimha Rao. "The object of the meeting was to convey to him (Rao) your concern over the situation at Darbar Sahib and ask the Indian government to take military action," Amarinder wrote to Badal, referring to the Centre's "white paper on the Punjab agitation" published in Delhi on July 10, 1984. The meeting with Rao happened at a Delhi guesthouse in the presence of the cabinet secretary, CM's principal secretary, and union home secretary, says the letter.
summary:
Summary:
Captain Amarinder Singh, a rival of Punjab Chief Minister Badal from the Congress, intensified his criticism by alleging Badal's involvement in Operation Bluestar. In an open letter, Singh referenced a meeting between Badal and the-then Union Home Minister PV Narasimha Rao on March 28, 1984. Singh claimed the purpose was to discuss the situation at Darbar Sahib and advocate for military action, citing the Centre's "white paper on the Punjab agitation" published on July 10, 1984. The meeting allegedly occurred at a Delhi guesthouse in the presence of the cabinet secretary, CM's principal secretary, and union home secretary.

headline: Operation Meghdoot: 34 years ago, how India won Siachen
article: April 13, 1984, was when India first deployed its men at Siachen. Thirty four years on, with 163 casualties in the past decade and nearly 900 overall, the soldiers continue to remain on this icy, barren land. The story of Siachen didn’t start in 1983. Its genesis lies in the partition of India and the ensuing wars between India and Pakistan over Kashmir. At the end of the UN-brokered ceasefire in 1949, India and Pakistan agreed on a ceasefire line (CFL) in undivided Kashmir as per the Karachi Agreement of 1949. The eastern most stretch of the ceasefire line was not demarcated beyond a point called NJ9842 since it was inhospitable and uninhabited. It simply said that from NJ9842, the line would run “thence North to the glaciers” — the Siachen glacier, the Rimo and the Baltoro. As the late Lt General S K Sinha, who was the secretary of the Indian delegation, later wrote, “No one at that time thought that military operations could take place at the forbidding heights beyond NJ9842. In any case, the ceasefire line was only something temporary. After plebiscite, it would become irrelevant. Thus, we drew a straight line running north from NJ9842 to the glaciers. It is easy to be wise after the event. It would have been better if the line beyond NJ9842 had not been left vague.”
summary:
Summary:
The deployment of Indian troops at Siachen began on April 13, 1984, marking the start of a prolonged presence in the inhospitable region. The origin of the Siachen conflict dates back to the partition of India and subsequent wars between India and Pakistan over Kashmir. After a UN-brokered ceasefire in 1949, the ceasefire line (CFL) in undivided Kashmir was established, with the easternmost stretch left undefined beyond a point called NJ9842. This ambiguity eventually led to military operations at the forbidding heights beyond NJ9842, including the Siachen glacier. The situation underscores the complexities arising from territorial disputes and the challenges of maintaining peace in such harsh environments.

headline: I’ Day programme for Shillong
article:
Governor Bhishma Narain Singh, will take the salute at the march past at the Independence Day at Garrison Ground in Shillong on August 15.

The programme in Shillong includes the ceremonial parade at the Garrison Ground at 9 a.m. free cinema show for children under 14 years of age in all local cinema halls, distribution of gift packets to patients of Civil Hospital, Raid Chest Hospital by the Meghalaya Chamber of Commerce and Industry, to inmates of District Jail Shillong and the Home Mentally Ill People, Mawlai and distribution of gift packets by the Rotary Club. From 1 P.M. to 3 P.M. sports for children at the Garrison will be organized. An exhibition football match at the Polo Ground is also being organized at 4 P.M.
summary: Governor Bhishma Narain Singh is set to take the salute at the Independence Day march past at Garrison Ground in Shillong on August 15. The day's program in Shillong includes a ceremonial parade at Garrison Ground at 9 a.m., a free cinema show for children under 14 in local cinema halls, and the distribution of gift packets to various groups, including patients at Civil Hospital and District Jail Shillong. Additionally, sports for children at Garrison and an exhibition football match at Polo Ground are scheduled for the afternoon.

headline: A forgotten carnage: Asta endures sense of injustice for decades
article: Haunted by memories of a massacre and a lingering sense of injustice for nearly 40 years, the residents of Asta village in Uttar Pradesh’s district describe themselves as “forgotten people”. They allege that despite some of them having witnessed the carnage that claimed 15 lives, they were neither summoned to court nor are they aware of the present status of the case. On May 26, 1984, gunshots shattered the stillness of an intensely hot afternoon, recalls Vidya Ram, the complainant in the Asta massacre, who was then 18 years old. He remembers a woman and two men holding many men at gun-point. She was Kusuma Nain, one of the most feared woman bandits, and the two men were Lalaram and Shriram, leaders of the gang. There were others, all heavily armed.Cursing, they began shooting the villagers one by one. Others torched every single house in the village, 70 in all.Stunned at what he saw, the 18-year-old Vidya Ram ran 12 km to Auraiya to inform the police about what came to be known as the Asta massacre --13 people were shot dead, a woman and her four-year-old son were burnt alive. Three were injured in the firing. The Asta carnage was allegedly in retaliation to the Behmai massacre, in which 20 members of the Thakur community were killed by “bandit queen” Phoolan Devi and her gang on February 14, 1981, and the growing power of Mallah gangs. Phoolan Devi had surrendered about a year before the Asta carnage in Madhya Pradesh but her protege Jagdish Mallah was killing Thakurs in the adjoining Jalaun.
summary:
Summary:
The residents of Asta village in Uttar Pradesh's district still bear the scars of a massacre that occurred nearly 40 years ago. On May 26, 1984, Kusuma Nain and two men from her gang carried out the attack, shooting villagers and setting fire to every house. Thirteen people were shot dead, while a woman and her four-year-old son were burned alive. The massacre was purportedly in retaliation for the Behmai massacre, where Phoolan Devi and her gang killed 20 Thakur community members in 1981. Phoolan Devi had surrendered by the time of the Asta massacre, but her protege Jagdish Mallah continued the violence.

headline: Lapang's initiative to end city’s water shortage
article:
Mr D D Lapang, who took over the Municipal Administration portfolio following the recent reshuffle, took stock of the various problems facing the Shillong Municipality at a meeting of all the concerned official agencies here on July 7.

He asked the PHE Department and Shillong Municipality to explore all possible sources of water either through sinking tube wells or by harnessing streamlets for meeting the water scarcity in Shillong. Mr Lapang informed that against the actual water requirement of 20 lakh gallons per day, only 9.49 lakh gallons were being supplied at present. He said pending the completion of the Greater Shillong Water Supply Schemes, the PHE Department and Shillong Municipality should make to interim arrangements augment the water supply. As for the garbage clearance in Shillong, be stated that four new trucks were being purchased and that soon they should be on the road.

Stressing the urgent need to repair the Mawlonghat Cherra Bus Stand Mr Lapang directed to complete the work within four months. The D.C. and the S.P. would assist the PWD so that the work could progress unhindered.

Senior officials of the Public Works, Public Health Engineering, Health, Home, Municipal Administration department, MSEB and the Syiem of Mylliem attended the meeting.
summary: Mr. D.D. Lapang, who assumed the Municipal Administration portfolio in a recent reshuffle, conducted a meeting to address the challenges facing the Shillong Municipality. Concerned about water scarcity, he urged the PHE Department and Shillong Municipality to explore alternative water sources, such as sinking tube wells or harnessing streamlets. Currently, only 9.49 lakh gallons are supplied daily against the actual requirement of 20 lakh gallons. Lapang emphasized interim measures for water supply until the completion of the Greater Shillong Water Supply Schemes. He also highlighted the purchase of four new trucks to improve garbage clearance and directed the urgent repair of Mawlonghat Cherra Bus Stand within four months.

headline: Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi carrying the urn containing the ashes of his mother and late Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi
article:
On November 3, 1984, a solemn and poignant moment unfolded as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi carried the urn containing the ashes of his mother and former Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi. The scene was deeply emotional, symbolizing both personal grief and national mourning following the tragic assassination of Indira Gandhi on October 31, 1984.

Indira Gandhi, a towering figure in Indian politics, had served as Prime Minister for nearly sixteen years before her life was cut short by her assassination. Her sudden and violent death sent shockwaves throughout the nation and the world, leaving a profound void in the political landscape of India.

Rajiv Gandhi, who had been thrust into the role of Prime Minister following his mother's assassination, bore the weight of immense grief as he carried her ashes. The symbolic act of carrying her remains signified not only his personal loss but also his commitment to carrying forward her legacy and vision for the nation.

The urn containing Indira Gandhi's ashes was taken on a journey across India, allowing millions of grieving citizens to pay their respects and bid farewell to their beloved leader. The funeral procession was accompanied by an outpouring of emotion and a sense of collective mourning as people from all walks of life came together to honor her memory.

Rajiv Gandhi's solemn and dignified demeanor during this period earned him widespread admiration and respect, as he navigated the complexities of leading a grieving nation while grappling with his own personal loss.

The image of Rajiv Gandhi carrying the urn containing his mother's ashes remains etched in the collective memory of the nation, serving as a poignant reminder of the profound impact of Indira Gandhi's leadership and the deep bonds of love and duty between a mother and son.
summary: On November 3, 1984, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi solemnly carried the urn containing the ashes of his mother, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, symbolizing both personal grief and national mourning following her tragic assassination on October 31, 1984. Indira Gandhi's assassination left a significant void in Indian politics, given her sixteen-year tenure as Prime Minister. Rajiv Gandhi, thrust into leadership after her death, bore immense grief as he carried her ashes, signifying his commitment to continuing her legacy and vision for the nation. The journey of Indira Gandhi's ashes across India allowed millions to pay their respects, fostering a sense of collective mourning. Despite his personal loss, Rajiv Gandhi maintained a dignified demeanor, earning admiration as he led a grieving nation. The image of Rajiv Gandhi carrying his mother's urn remains a poignant reminder of Indira Gandhi's impactful leadership and the deep bond between mother and son, resonating deeply in the collective memory of the nation.

headline: India celebrates 37th Independence Day
article:
India celebrated its 37th Independence Day with great enthusiasm on Wednesday. The Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, unfurled the national flag at the Red Fort in Delhi and addressed the nation.
 
 In her speech, Mrs. Gandhi said that India had made significant progress since independence. She said that the country had achieved self-sufficiency in food and had made rapid progress in industrialization. She also said that India had played a leading role in international affairs.
 
 Mrs. Gandhi also said that there were still many challenges to be faced. She said that the country needed to eradicate poverty and unemployment and to provide better education and healthcare to its people. She also said that the country needed to be vigilant against external threats.
 
 The Prime Minister's speech was well-received by the public. People praised her for her leadership and for her commitment to the development of the country.
 
 The Independence Day celebrations took place all over the country. People held rallies and marches and hoisted the national flag. They also exchanged sweets and greetings with each other.
 
 The Independence Day celebrations were a reminder of the sacrifices that were made to achieve freedom. They were also a reminder of the challenges that still need to be faced. However, the celebrations also showed that India is a strong and vibrant nation that is committed to progress and development.
summary: On August 15, 1984, India celebrated its 37th Independence Day with great excitement. The Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, hoisted the national flag at the Red Fort in Delhi and delivered a speech to the nation. In her address, she highlighted India's achievements since gaining independence, such as becoming self-sufficient in food and making strides in industrialization. She also acknowledged the challenges that still lay ahead, including eradicating poverty and unemployment, improving education and healthcare, and remaining vigilant against external threats. The public responded positively to the Prime Minister's message, praising her leadership and dedication to the country's development. Celebrations took place across India, featuring rallies, marches, and the raising of the national flag. The day served as a reminder of both the sacrifices made for freedom and the work that still needs to be done, but it also demonstrated India's strength and determination to progress and develop.

headline: IndianOil scholarship for SC&ST engineering students
article:
IndianOil has launched a scheme to award scholarship to deserving students from the scheduled caste & scheduled tribes perusing graduate engineering courses. The `IndianOil Scholar’ would also be considered for employment in the Corporation on successful completion of the Engineering Course.

The Corporation proposes to award 25 scholarships every year to deserving students. Selection of students would be made on the basis of their performance in the 1st year engineering programme as well as pre-engineering qualifying examination.


The Engineering Colleges and Institutions recognized by the Central or State Govt can forward a maximum of two applications each. The selected students would receive a scholarship of Rs. 500/- per month during their entire period of study on the basis of continuous satisfactory performance.


The `IndianOil Scholar’ after graduating in Engineering will be required to appear for written test and interview. If selected, he will be taken in as an Engineer/Officer Trainee in the Corporation. He would be required to serve the Corporation for a minimum period of the three years besides the 12 months’ training period.
summary:
IndianOil has launched a scheme to award scholarship to deserving students from the scheduled caste & scheduled tribes perusing graduate engineering courses.
The 'IndianOil Scholar' would also be considered for employment in the Corporation on successful completion of the Engineering Course.
Selection of students would be made on the basis of their performance in the 1st year engineering programme as well as pre-engineering qualifying examination.
The Engineering Colleges and Institutions recognized by the Central or State Govt can forward a maximum of two applications each.

headline: IndianOil scholarship for SC&ST engineering students
article:
IndianOil has launched a scheme to award scholarship to deserving students from the scheduled caste & scheduled tribes perusing graduate engineering courses. The `IndianOil Scholar’ would also be considered for employment in the Corporation on successful completion of the Engineering Course.

The Corporation proposes to award 25 scholarships every year to deserving students. Selection of students would be made on the basis of their performance in the 1st year engineering programme as well as pre-engineering qualifying examination.

The Engineering Colleges and Institutions recognized by the Central or State Govt can forward a maximum of two applications each. The selected students would receive a scholarship of Rs. 500/- per month during their entire period of study on the basis of continuous satisfactory performance. The `IndianOil Scholar’ after graduating in Engineering will be required to appear for written test and interview. If selected, he will be taken in as an Engineer/Officer Trainee in the Corporation. He would be required to serve the Corporation for a minimum period of the three years besides the 12 months’ training period.
summary: IndianOil has launched the "IndianOil Scholar" scheme, offering scholarships to deserving students from scheduled castes and scheduled tribes pursuing graduate engineering courses. The scheme, awarding 25 scholarships annually, aims to support students financially and potentially provide employment opportunities with IndianOil upon completion of their engineering studies. Selection is based on performance in the first-year engineering program and the pre-engineering qualifying examination. Recognized engineering colleges and institutions can submit a maximum of two applications each, and selected students will receive a monthly scholarship of Rs. 500 based on their continuous satisfactory performance throughout their study period. Upon graduation, the scholars may undergo a written test and interview for potential employment as Engineer/Officer Trainees with IndianOil, with a minimum service commitment of three years, including a 12-month training period.

headline: HT This Day: August 26, 1984 — All passengers, crew of jet freed
article: Twelve pro-Khalistani hijackers of the Indian Airlines Boeing-737 surrendered to authorities in the United Arab Emirates this evening and released all 68 passengers and six crew members unharmed, about 38 hours after they had seized the aircraft over Pathankot. The released hostages are expected back in the Capital early tomorrow morning. Seven hostages, including five women and an infant, freed at Lahore and Karachi, have already arrived in Delhi this evening. The hijackers were taken into custody by the local authorities and whisked away. The welcome development followed nearly eight hours of nonstop negotiations between the hijackers and leaders of the UAE Government led by Defence Minister, Sheikh Mohammad Bin Rashid Al-Maktoum, who were ably assisted by Indian Ambassador, Mr Isharat Aziz, and Capt. B. K. Bhasin, Director of Flight Safety of the Indian Airlines. India’s Minister of State for External Affairs, who was in Dubai was returning home from Rumania, also joined the talks. During the negotiations which appeared to be on the verge of collision on several occasions, the hijackers stuck to their demands, including safe passage to the Untitled States and assurance that the UAE Government would respect its promises.
summary:
Summary:
Twelve pro-Khalistani hijackers of an Indian Airlines Boeing-737 surrendered to authorities in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) after holding the aircraft for about 38 hours following the seizure over Pathankot. All 68 passengers and six crew members were released unharmed. Negotiations led by UAE Defence Minister Sheikh Mohammad Bin Rashid Al-Maktoum, with assistance from Indian Ambassador Mr. Isharat Aziz and Capt. B. K. Bhasin of Indian Airlines, along with India's Minister of State for External Affairs, led to the surrender. The hijackers demanded safe passage to the United States and assurances from the UAE Government, with negotiations almost reaching a breaking point several times.

headline: 1984 anti-Sikh riots: Delhi court to hear case against Tytler on Sept 11
article: A Delhi court will hear on September 11 a case related to the Pul Bangash killings during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots in which Congress leader Jagdish Tytler is an accused. Additional chief metropolitan magistrate Vidhi Gupta Anand adjourned the matter on a request made by Tytler’s lawyer. The accused appeared before the court through video conferencing. A sessions court had earlier granted anticipatory bail to Tytler on a personal bond of ₹1 lakh and one surety of the like amount. It had also imposed certain conditions on him, including that he will not tamper with the evidence in the case or leave the country without permission. Three people were killed and a gurdwara was set ablaze in Pul Bangash area here on November 1, 1984, a day after the then Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated by her Sikh bodyguards.
summary:
Summary:
A Delhi court will convene on September 11 to address a case concerning the Pul Bangash killings during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots, with Congress leader Jagdish Tytler as an accused. Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Vidhi Gupta Anand deferred the matter at the request of Tytler's lawyer, with the accused appearing via video conferencing. Tytler was earlier granted anticipatory bail by a sessions court, subject to conditions such as not tampering with evidence or leaving the country without permission. The Pul Bangash incident occurred on November 1, 1984, resulting in three deaths and the arson of a gurdwara, following the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi by her Sikh bodyguards.

headline: Pilot scheme for improvement of Science & Maths in North East
article:
In order to narrow the existing gap technical manpower in the Hill and Tribal Areas of the North East, the NEC has decided to implement a pilot scheme from the current financial year to provide intensive training annually to 665 teachers of Higher Secondary, Middle and Primary Schools of the Region in science and mathematics.

The North Eastern Council in the meanwhile has accorded sanction for an amount of Rs. 18,23,500 to implement this scheme as a pilot project till 1986 initially. The scheme aims at bringing about improvement of science and mathematics education at school level in the Region by providing necessary training to the existing large number of untrained and under qualified teachers and also by providing support and augment infrastructure for teaching of science and mathematics in the schools and to strengthen the existing State Institutes of Education/SCERT/SIE.


According to the scheme which will be implemented by the Directorate of Education of the Constituent States and Union Territories of the Region the State Institute of Education/SCERT of each of the Constituent Units will be strengthened by providing three qualified teachers for Mathematics, Biology and Physics and Chemistry. At the Higher Secondary level 21 teachers in science and mathematics will be trained in one course from each State/U.T. during 1984-85. At the middle School level altogether 24 teachers covering 8 school of each of the Constituent Units will be trained in science and mathematics in one training camp. At the Primary level refresher training with emphasis on teaching of science and mathematics will be imparted to 50 teachers from each State. It may be mentioned that the NEC constituted at Working Group in 1982 consisting of Secretaries of Education of Constituent Units of the North Eastern and Director of Manpower Development, North Eastern Council as study the issues of strengthening of teaching of science and mathematics in the region. The Working Group identified the existing deficiency and gaps in the areas like lack of proper infrastructure for teaching of science and mathematics in the school especially in the rural and hill areas lack of proper motivation for learning of science and mathematics from primary level upwards and existence of large number of untrained and under qualified teachers. The Working Group recommended for establishment of a Regional Training Institute for teachers and key resource personnel, strengthening of existing Teachers’ Training Institute of States and Union Territories, one Model Higher Secondary School in each district, one Middle School in each block and enlargement of admission capacity at College in science and mathematics group.


The Fact Finding Team constituted by the Ministry of Education & Cultural of Government of India under the Chairmanship of Dr. R.C. Das, Head of the Department of Teachers’ Education NCERT also recommended training of untrained teacher and revision of the syllabus of the State Teachers’ Training Institute.
summary: The North Eastern Council (NEC) plans to implement a pilot scheme aimed at providing intensive training to 665 teachers in science and mathematics in Higher Secondary, Middle, and Primary Schools in the Hill and Tribal Areas of the North East. The scheme, designed to narrow the gap in technical manpower, will train untrained and underqualified teachers, strengthen existing State Institutes of Education, and enhance infrastructure for teaching science and mathematics. The NEC has sanctioned Rs. 18,23,500 for the pilot project, with a focus on improving science and mathematics education at the school level in the region.

headline: For helping over 700 destitute girls stand on their feet, Sarojini Agarwal to be honoured with Neerja Bhanot Award today
article: The Neerja Bhanot Award, instituted in the memory of senior flight purser, Neerja Bhanot, who saved hundreds of lives while sacrificing her own, will be conferred to Dr Sarojini Agarwal, this year. The winner is presented with a sum of Rs 1,50,000, a citation and a trophy. The criteria is that the awardee must be an Indian woman who when subjected to social injustice, faces the situation, overcomes it and then helps others in distress. This year, the proud winner of the award is Dr Sarojini Agarwal. The award will be presented to her by Prof Kaptan Singh Solanki, Haryana governor on September 7 at the PHD Chambers, in Chandigarh.  In 1978, Agarwal lost her eight-year-old daughter, in a hit-and-run accident. Although, she plunged into grief, Agarwal made up her mind to look after destitute girls, who for want of proper protection and guidance are forced to lead a tough life. She then decided to set-up a home ‘Manisha Mandir’ for such girls, with an aim to provide protection, love and motherly care.
summary:
Summary:
The Neerja Bhanot Award, established in memory of senior flight purser Neerja Bhanot, will be bestowed upon Dr. Sarojini Agarwal this year. Dr. Agarwal, who lost her daughter in a hit-and-run accident in 1978, overcame her grief by dedicating herself to caring for destitute girls. She founded "Manisha Mandir," a home aimed at providing protection, love, and maternal care to underprivileged girls. The award, presented with a cash prize of Rs 1,50,000, a citation, and a trophy, recognizes Indian women who overcome social injustice and help others in distress. Haryana Governor Prof Kaptan Singh Solanki will present the award to Dr. Agarwal on September 7 at the PHD Chambers in Chandigarh.

headline: HT This Day: September 30, 1984 -- Golden Temple handed over to high priests
article: The historic Golden Temple and other buildings in its premises were handed over to the five high priests and the representatives of the Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee today, after the Army was completely withdrawn from the complex almost four months after it entered there to flush out terrorists and anti-social elements hiding inside. The handing-over of the Temple complex became possible after an agreement had been reached at midnight yesterday following a meeting between the senior adviser of the Governor, Mr R. V. Subramanian, and the priests. The meeting was also attended by the representatives of the SGPC and the Akali Dal. Before the handing-over, the chief of the Budha Dal, Baba Santa Singh, came to the Akal Takht with his Nihang followers and performed “ardas” on the successful completion of the “kar sewa”. To avoid any clash between the followers of the Nihang chief and the Akalis, the entry into the Temple premises for the public was banned upto 11 a.m. The Nihang chief, who came to the Temple at 7 a.m., stayed there for about three hours during which he performed “ardas”, gave “saropas” to those who had contributed in the “kar sewa” and addressed his followers.
summary:
Summary:
The historic Golden Temple complex, along with other buildings within its premises, was handed over to the five high priests and representatives of the Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee (SGPC) after the complete withdrawal of the Army, which had been deployed there for almost four months to flush out terrorists and anti-social elements. The handover followed an agreement reached at midnight after a meeting between senior advisor Mr. R. V. Subramanian, priests, SGPC representatives, and members of the Akali Dal. Before the transfer, Baba Santa Singh, chief of the Budha Dal, performed a ceremonial prayer ("ardas") at the Akal Takht to mark the successful completion of the "kar sewa." To prevent clashes, public entry into the Temple premises was restricted until 11 a.m. The Nihang chief remained at the Temple for about three hours, distributing blessings ("saropas") and addressing his followers.

headline: 1984 riots: Delhi court to hear case against Tytler on Oct 13
article: A Delhi court will start hearing on October 13 the arguments on whether to frame charges against Congress leader Jagdish Tytler in a case related to the Pul Bangash killings during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots. Special judge Vikas Dhull, who was scheduled to start the proceedings on Wednesday, adjourned the matter on a prayer made by the counsel appearing for the accused. The counsel prayed for adjournment, claiming that he needed time to approach the authorities concerned for certified copies of certain documents related to the case. Tytler appeared before the court during the proceedings.The judge allowed the accused’s plea after the CBI did not oppose the submissions. “The counsel prayed for an adjournment. Same granted as not opposed to by Public Prosecutor for CBI. Put up on October 13, 2023, for arguments on the point of charge,” the judge said. A magisterial court on September 11 sent a case to the distrit judge for further proceedings.
summary:
Summary:
A Delhi court will commence hearings on October 13 to determine whether to frame charges against Congress leader Jagdish Tytler in connection with the Pul Bangash killings during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots. Special Judge Vikas Dhull adjourned the proceedings upon a request from Tytler's counsel, who sought time to obtain certified copies of certain case documents. Tytler attended the court session. The judge granted the adjournment as the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) did not oppose the request. The case was previously referred to the district judge for further proceedings by a magisterial court on September 11.

headline: 1984 anti-Sikh riots case: SC seeks CBI's reply on furlough plea of ex-councillor
article: The Supreme Court on Friday sought a response from the CBI on a plea for furlough by former Congress councillor Balwan Khokhar, serving life imprisonment in a 1984 anti-Sikh riots case. While issuing notice to the CBI, a bench of Justices JK Maheshwari and Sanjay Karol said it may ask the competent authority to decide the matter.Counsel appearing for Khokhar said he is seeking furlough for maintaining social ties.The bench listed the matter for further hearing in the month of April. Besides Khokhar, former Congress MP Sajjan Kumar is serving life term in the case. Ex-MLA Mahender Yadav, who was awarded 10-year sentence, died from Covid in Mandoli jail. Sajjan Kumar and Balwan Khokhar are lodged in Tihar jail since their conviction on December 17, 2018. Khokhar's life sentence was upheld by the Delhi High Court in 2018, while it overturned the Kumar's acquittal by the trial court in 2013. The case involves the killing of five Sikhs in Raj Nagar Part-I in Palam Colony in southwest Delhi on November 1-2, 1984 and burning down of a gurdwara in Raj Nagar Part-II.
summary:
Summary:
The Supreme Court has asked the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to respond to a plea filed by former Congress councillor Balwan Khokhar, seeking furlough while serving a life sentence in a 1984 anti-Sikh riots case. Khokhar's counsel stated that he is seeking furlough to maintain social ties. The bench, comprising Justices JK Maheshwari and Sanjay Karol, indicated that it may instruct the competent authority to decide on the matter. The case involves the killing of five Sikhs and the burning of a gurdwara in southwest Delhi in 1984. Khokhar and former Congress MP Sajjan Kumar are serving life terms in Tihar jail, while another convict, Mahender Yadav, passed away due to Covid-19 while in Mandoli jail.

headline: 1984 riots: One sentenced to death, another to life for killing two Sikhs
article:
Yashpal Singh,55, a transporter, and retired postmaster Naresh Sehrawat, in his late 50s, had been convicted on November 14 for murdering their neighbours Hardev Singh and Avtar Singh by setting them on fire in south Delhi’s Mahipalpur.

Hindustan Times - your fastest source for breaking news! Read now.
This is the first death sentence handed down in a case probed by a special investigation team (SIT) after a fresh inquiry into the cases was ordered by the Centre three years ago. Before Singh, another man Kishori was awarded the death penalty in seven cases by a trial court in 1996. The Supreme Court later commuted the sentence to life imprisonment in 1999, according to senior advocate HS Phoolka.

Following inputs from intelligence agencies that the two convicts could be attacked on the court premises, additional sessions judge Ajay Pandey on Tuesday held the proceedings inside Tihar jail. Singh was awarded the death penalty. The court sentenced Sehrawat to life imprisonment besides imposing a fine of ₹34 lakh each on the two convicts. The court said that ₹20 lakh each would be paid as compensation to the family members of the Hardev Singh and Avtar Singh.
summary:
Summary:
Yashpal Singh, a transporter, and retired postmaster Naresh Sehrawat have been convicted for the murder of their neighbors Hardev Singh and Avtar Singh by setting them on fire in south Delhi's Mahipalpur. This marks the first death sentence in a case investigated by a special investigation team (SIT) following a fresh inquiry ordered by the Centre three years ago. Concerns about potential attacks on the convicts prompted the court to hold proceedings inside Tihar jail. Singh received the death penalty, while Sehrawat was sentenced to life imprisonment and fined ₹34 lakh each. Additionally, ₹20 lakh each will be paid as compensation to the victims' family members.

headline: Two bullets that hurtled Mumbai into the heart of Israeli-Palestinian feud
article:
Two bullets fired in the tepid Mumbai winter dragged India’s financial capital into the heart of the age-old Israeli-Palestinian feud after the British Deputy High Commissioner for Western India was shot dead near his Flora Fountain office on November 27, 1984, by suspected Palestinian militants affiliated with Abu Nidal.

Abu Nidal, which means ‘Father of the Struggle’ in Arabic, was the nom de guerre for Sabri al-Banna, the leader of a renegade group allegedly responsible for a string of attacks across the world in the 1980s and 1990s. The US State Department had once termed his group as “the most dangerous terrorist organisation in existence”. In 2002, al-Banna was reportedly found shot dead in a flat in Baghdad, according to Palestinian and other sources.
summary:
Summary:
The British Deputy High Commissioner for Western India was shot dead near his office in Mumbai on November 27, 1984, allegedly by suspected Palestinian militants associated with Abu Nidal, a notorious terrorist leader. Abu Nidal, whose real name was Sabri al-Banna, led a renegade group responsible for numerous attacks worldwide during the 1980s and 1990s. His organization was labeled as "the most dangerous terrorist organization in existence" by the US State Department. Al-Banna was reportedly found shot dead in Baghdad in 2002.

headline: demonstration to mark anniversary of November 1984 massacre of sikhs
article:
Announcing this, Harchranjit Singh Dhami and Harpal Singh Cheema, heads of these outfits, said their members would walk on the streets and lanes of Jalandhar city to protest against the killings of thousands of innocent Sikhs in the capital way back in November 1984 and to voice their concern against injustice. "The objective of the march is to highlight the dismal plight of Sikhs and to kindle the flame of freedom", said Dhami, while addressing the media here on Sunday.

He said the activists would assemble at a local gurdwara to perform 'Ardas' in the memory of those who had been killed in a "systematic and planned manner".

Expressing concern over the survey conducted by the Global Slavery Index that India is home to highest number of 'slaves', Dhami said that it reflected the mindset of the rulers.
summary:
Summary:
Leaders of Sikh organizations announced a protest march in Jalandhar city to condemn the 1984 anti-Sikh riots in Delhi and highlight the plight of Sikhs. Harchranjit Singh Dhami and Harpal Singh Cheema stated that the march aims to remember the victims of the riots and raise awareness about ongoing injustices. They also expressed concern over India's ranking in the Global Slavery Index, seeing it as indicative of governmental attitudes.

headline: Yesterdate: This day from Kolkata’s past, November 30, 1984
article:
One of the most celebrated Indian singers of the 20th century, Indubala Debi, passed away on this day. She was in her 80s. She was born in Amritsar, the daughter of Motilal Bose, co-owner of Great Bengal Circus, and Rajbala, a trapeze artist at the circus. Soon after her birth, Rajbala returned to Kolkata, where she became a resident of Rambagan, the red light area, and was forced to take up prostitution. She founded the Rambagan Female Kali Theatre with other women who had worked in circus. Indubala’s first stage experience was with her mother’s troupe, when she was very young. Very soon, she joined Star Theatre. Despite her mother’s objections, Indubala trained as an entertainer and also joined prostitution. But she trained with the best teachers and artistes: Gauhar Jaan, Girin Chakraborty, Kamal Dasgupta, Jamiruddin Khan and Kazi Nazrul. She became, like another illustrious singer and her contemporary and friend, Angurbala Debi, a famous exponent of Nazrul’s songs. She recorded her first song for Gramophone Records in 1916 and began to sing for the Indian State Broadcasting Service, which later became All India Radio, an association that would last long. She was also a playback singer for films and acted in many films, in Bengali, Hindi and other Indian languages. Jamuna Puliney (1933) is considered to be her first film.

She has to her credit almost 300 recorded songs.

She lived her life with an astonishing courage and openness, never shying away from talking about her origins. She tried to improve the condition of other women in prostitution and spoke about their rights. She was very proud of her collections of jewellery and perfumes. Her last days were difficult due to her circumstances. She passed away after a long illness.
summary:
Summary:
Indubala Debi, a renowned Indian singer of the 20th century, passed away at the age of 80. Born into difficult circumstances in Amritsar, she overcame challenges and became a celebrated singer and actress. Indubala started her career in theatre and later transitioned to playback singing for films. Known for her association with All India Radio, she was also a prominent exponent of Kazi Nazrul's songs. Despite her past involvement in prostitution, she lived courageously, advocating for women's rights and openly discussing her origins. Indubala's legacy includes nearly 300 recorded songs and contributions to Indian cinema.

headline: What happened on Oct 31, 1984: Recalling the assassination of Indira Gandhi
article:
"Indira Gandhi was assassinated on October 31, 1984. Two of the Prime Minister’s bodyguards, Beant Singh and Satwant Singh, fired over 30 bullets at her from point blank range, purportedly to avenge the humiliation of Sikhs and the desecration of the Golden Temple during Operation Blue Star in June of that year. Indira’s assassination sent shockwaves through the nation, unleashing some of the most vicious communal violence India has ever seen. In just about three days, approximately 3,350 Sikhs (government estimates) were massacred, 2,800 in the national capital itself. This is what happened on that day 39 years ago.In Operation Blue Star, the Indian Army entered Amritsar’s Golden Temple, the holiest Sikh shrine, to flush out separatists residing in the premises. While successful in its intended objectives, it caused great damage to the temple and killed anywhere between a few hundred to a thousand Sikh civilians. This enraged Sikhs worldwide, who saw Blue Star as an assault on their faith. The Prime Minister, who had ordered the operation, bore the brunt of the blame. “Everyone knew that her life was in danger,” Katherine Frank wrote in her biography of Indira (Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi, 2001). Festive offer In the days and months that followed Blue Star, Indira would speak about her impending demise to her family and close friends. “I had rarely seen her in such a mood, her thoughts entangled with death,” Pupul Jayakar, a close confidante and biographer, wrote (Indira Gandhi: A Biography, 2000). When Jayakar asked Indira why she was speaking about death so often, she simply responded: “Isn’t it inevitable?” But she insisted on persisting with Sikh guards Following Blue Star, Indira’s security was beefed up. Although she rejected transferring her security over from the police to the Army, commandos from the Indo-Tibetan Border Police were added to her protection team. Security around her family, especially her grandchildren, Rahul (then 14), and Priyanka (12), was also stepped up. “She had an obsessive fear of her grandchildren being harmed, either abducted or hurt. From June she had lived with that dreadful thought,” Indira’s principal secretary P C Alexander later told Jayakar. However, she refused to remove Sikhs from her protection detail. The Indian Express reported in its November 1, 1984 edition that the Director, Intelligence Bureau, had recommended to Indira in July 1984 that no Sikh should be posted in her security detail “in wake of some adverse reports received by the intelligence agencies”. Indira turned down the recommendation, and reportedly responded, “Aren’t we secular?” (Jayakar, 2000).
She was shot in her own home, by her own guards Around 9.10 am on the morning of October 31, Indira Gandhi emerged from her official residence at New Delhi’s 1 Safdarjung Road, and headed for her personal office in the adjoining bungalow at 1 Akbar Road. She was accompanied by a small entourage comprising constables Narain Singh and Rameshwar Dayal, her personal secretary R K Dhawan, and her domestic help Nathu Ram. As she walked down the garden path, Sub-Inspector Beant Singh, a long-time member of Indira’s security detail, came forward. Constable Satwant Singh, a new recruit, was standing a few paces away. “She smiled and folded her hands in greeting, as she saw him lift his hand as if to salute her… but the hand held a revolver and he shot her in the abdomen from a distance of three feet,” Jayakar wrote. He would fire four more shots at point-blank range, before Satwant Singh emptied his 30-round Sten gun clip at Indira."
summary: On October 31, 1984, Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India, was assassinated by her own bodyguards, Beant Singh and Satwant Singh, in retaliation for the Operation Blue Star in June of the same year, which targeted separatists in Amritsar's Golden Temple. The operation caused damage to the holy Sikh shrine and resulted in the deaths of hundreds to a thousand Sikh civilians. Indira Gandhi faced criticism globally, particularly from Sikhs who considered Blue Star an attack on their faith. Following the operation, her security was enhanced, with additional commandos from the Indo-Tibetan Border Police, but she refused to remove Sikh guards from her protection detail.

headline: The night that tested the resilience of Bhopal and India
article:
In 1984, during the intervening night of December 2 and 3 in Varanasi, a modest baraat from Kashi Hindu Vishwavidyalaya, now known as Banaras Hindu University, arrived at the guest house of Banaras Locomotive Works. Kashi then was esteemed for its scholarly environment, where university professors and vice-chancellors were more revered than leaders, officials, or influential figures. The procession included vice-chancellors from three universities, registrars, numerous professors, cultural figures, and journalists — a gathering unparalleled in its composition. Bhopal gas disaster survivors hold posters during a protest rally. (AFP)PREMIUM
Bhopal gas disaster survivors hold posters during a protest rally. (AFP)
Interestingly, the groom, travelling in a car behind the procession, was largely unnoticed. His decision to not ride the customary mare or wield a sword diverted attention from him. Contrary to the norm in eastern Uttar Pradesh, where weddings often span the entire night, the dwarchar and phere ceremonies were swiftly completed in a mere one-and-a-half hour at the bride’s place. At the dinner table, a friend of the groom whispered in his ear, “Today, because of you I had to cancel my trip to Bhopal. Now I will go tomorrow.” But for him, that tomorrow never came.
summary:
Summary:
In 1984, a wedding procession in Varanasi, featuring vice-chancellors, professors, and cultural figures, arrived at the Banaras Locomotive Works guest house. The groom, despite being part of the procession, remained inconspicuous by choosing not to ride a mare or wield a sword. The wedding ceremonies were completed swiftly, contrary to local norms. At the dinner table, a friend mentioned canceling a trip to Bhopal due to the wedding, but tragically, that friend never made it to Bhopal as planned.

headline: Rajiv Raps BJP for Double Standards
article: TRIVANDRUM, Dec.14 - Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today accused both the BJP and Marxists of shifting their stand on national issues to suit their political convenience. Addressing a series of public meetings on the second day of his two-day election campaign in Kerala, he said BJP leader L. K. Advani's observation that the Anandpur Sahib resolution was charter of national disintegration had substantiated his charge that the party had always followed double standards. If Mr. Advani and his party felt so strongly about the Anandpur Sahib resolution, why were they accepting Akalis' support. In the election, he asked. "The BJP has joined hands with a party which wants division of the country," he alleged. At his meeting at Trichur this morning, Mr. Gandhi urged the Opposition leaders to persuade Akalis to withdraw the demands contained in the Anandpur Sahib resolution. In a sharp attack on the CPI-M, during his campaign in Kerala, he said giving up all Its progressive outlook, the Marxists had joined hands with a rank reactionary party like the BJP. "What has happened to Marxists? They have bartered away their ideology and principles for petty electoral gain," Mr. Rajiv Gandhi added.
summary: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi accuses both the BJP and Marxists of changing their stances on national issues for political convenience during a campaign in Kerala. He criticized BJP leader L. K. Advani for accepting Akalis' support despite calling the Anandpur Sahib resolution a threat to national unity. He also condemned the Marxists for aligning with the BJP, accusing them of abandoning their progressive principles for electoral gain. Gandhi urged opposition leaders to convince the Akalis to withdraw the Anandpur Sahib resolution's demands.

headline: Khadia: The centre of any popular movement or controversy in Ahmedabad
article:
Army patrol in Khadia lanes: Storm centre
There is never a dull moment in Khadia. And that is more true than ever today, when tension stalks this Ahmedabad locality in the wake of the anti-reservation stir. The worst communal clashes and the worst police versus anti-reservationist battles took place here.

Khadia has invariably been at the centre of any popular movement or controversy, and a well-known saying is that agitations and issues are born here. Long before the freedom struggle it was famed for those who questioned the existing state of affairs.

Even in the 18th century it was the cultural capital of Ahmedabad, and in ensuing years did much to influence the city through men like educationist Dewan Ballubhai, the intellectual Uma Shankar Joshi and the poet Sunderam. Khadia came to the forefront to lead and inspire with the advent of the freedom struggle.

Though Ahmedabad was a conservative city where women usually lived in seclusion, Khadia blazed a new trail when its women began stepping out after sunrise to sing patriotic songs and bhajans. Even today the women of Khadia remain different, taking the lead in grappling with the police and not hesitating to pelt them with a barrage of stones.
The locality was in the vanguard of the freedom struggle in Gujarat in another way too. The only underground paper in Gujarat exhorting the people to fight for freedom at any cost came out from here.

This was the Gujarat Satyagraha Patrika - merely a sheet of cyclostyled paper but packing a powerful message. Gujarat Samachar which was recently reduced to ashes during the police revolt was also greatly influenced by the people of Khadia as Thakorelal Thakore, the editor of Prajabandhu which later became the Gujarat Samachar, was a resident. Sandesh, another major Gujarati daily, also began its early rumblings in Khadia.

With the passage of time and the erosion of the joint family system, there was a change in the culture of the area. People moved out to the new areas of the city and typical city flats. This was certainly a change from the lanes of their old home, which were extremely difficult for an outsider to navigate as they all look the same.

The narrow lanes are hugged on all sides by tall three-storeyed buildings, some of which still have old haveli doors and intricately carved pillars. But though many Khadia residents have shifted to new areas, they have taken along their tendency to oppose the Government.

The latest communal violence did not come as a surprise to many either. Khadia has always reacted strongly during communal riots, beginning with a major one in 1926.

In fact the area has the dubious distinction of being the battlefield where the soda water bottle first became a dangerous weapon. Politically it is the strongest BJP bastion in the state and only opposition leaders have flourished here.

Much of the prominence that Khadia gets today is because of BJP leader Ashok Bhatt, who has never hesitated to embarrass the Government on the floor of the house with his disclosures. Last fortnight Bhatt was underground, fearing he would be arrested in connection with the riots.

The basic political stance of Khadia is anti-establishment, and it has never elected a Congress candidate either to the Lok Sabha or to the Assembly. The present secretary of the Janata Party. Brahmkumar Bhatt, was once idolised in Khadia and returned twice to the Assembly as a Praja Socialist Party candidate.

But in 1967 he joined the Congress of Mrs Gandhi. Khadia could not forgive him. While campaigning for the assembly elections he had to be guarded. Predictably, he lost.

The narrow lanes and bylanes are a rioters' dream. The police cannot enter the area in a vehicle, they have to come in on foot, at which time a rain of stones descends on them. The terraces are so built that a troublemaker can hop from one house to another for a good distance and end up far from Khadia. And to escape the police all they need to do is enter any house where they are immediately given shelter.

The residents of Khadia are proud of their notoriety. Says Narhari Logowala, a businessman: "It is said that cats are afraid of Khadia rats. The water we drink here is different and so we stand out."

But the controversial SRP Commandant R.K. Vasisht, who has come under fire for the way he dealt with the residents of Ahmedabad, said: "If Khadia is razed to the ground, there will be no agitations in the state for another decade."

Perhaps, but though Khadia may be razed to the ground, the spirit of the people cannot be broken.
summary:
The Khadia locality in Ahmedabad, India, has a long history of political activism and resistance against the government. Over the years, it has been at the forefront of various movements and controversies, including the freedom struggle against British colonial rule. The area is known for its strong anti-establishment stance and has consistently voted against Congress candidates in elections.

Khadia is notorious for communal clashes and police confrontations, with its narrow lanes and bylanes making it difficult for law enforcement to enter the area. Residents have a reputation for their defiance, and the community has a strong sense of pride in its notoriety.

The neighborhood has played a significant role in the political landscape of Gujarat, and prominent leaders like Ashok Bhatt have emerged from Khadia, challenging the government and making disclosures that have embarrassed the ruling authorities. It is a stronghold of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in the state.

Despite its tumultuous history and potential for violence, Khadia remains a symbol of resilience and a spirit of resistance. Some argue that if Khadia were to be completely destroyed, it might quell agitations for a significant period, but the indomitable spirit of its people persists.

headline: Air India Flight 182 crashes off coast of Ireland, killing all 329 on board
article:
Air India Flight 182, a Boeing 747, crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Ireland on Sunday, June 23, 1985, killing all 329 people on board. The crash was the deadliest aviation disaster in Indian history.
 
 The flight was en route from Toronto to Delhi, with a stopover in London. It was carrying 307 passengers and 22 crew members.
 
 The crash occurred approximately 170 kilometers (110 miles) southwest of Cork, Ireland. The plane was flying at an altitude of 31,000 feet when it suddenly went into a dive and crashed into the ocean.
 
 The cause of the crash is still unknown. However, investigators believe that a bomb may have been planted on the plane.
 
 The Air India Flight 182 crash is a tragedy for India and the world. It is a reminder of the dangers of terrorism and the importance of aviation safety.
summary: On June 23, 1985, Air India Flight 182, a Boeing 747 en route from Toronto to Delhi with a stopover in London, crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Ireland, killing all 329 people on board. The cause of the crash is still unknown, but investigators believe that a bomb may have been planted on the plane.

headline: Rajiv Gandhi launches India's first telecom satellite, INSAT-1B
article:
Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on Monday launched India's first telecom satellite, INSAT-1B, from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The launch was a major milestone in India's space program and a significant boost to India's telecommunications capabilities.
 
 INSAT-1B is a multi-purpose satellite that will provide India with a variety of telecommunications services, including long-distance telephone service, television broadcasting, and radio broadcasting. The satellite will also be used for weather forecasting and disaster management.
 
 The launch of INSAT-1B is a testament to India's growing technological capabilities. India is now one of a few countries in the world that has the capability to launch and operate its own satellites.
summary: INSAT-1B was a significant milestone in India's space program. It was the first Indian satellite to be launched from a foreign country and the first Indian satellite to be used for telecommunications services. The launch of INSAT-1B also made India one of a few countries in the world that had the capability to launch and operate its own satellites.

headline: AP's SOS for more power
article: NEW DELHI, Sept. 30. Andhra Pradesh is seeking more power from the Ramagundam super thermal station in view of the severe drought it is facing. The Chairman of the Andhra. Pradesh State Electricity Board Mr. N. Tata Rao today telephoned the Chairman of the National Thermal Power Corporation in this connection. The Chairman of the NTPC, Mr. M. L. Shishoo told Mr. Tata Rao. that the third unit of 200 MW in the Ramagundam complex had been declared under commercial operation and if adequate coal supplies were maintained. there should be no difficulty in power generation. Mr. Shishoo told reporters this afternoon that NTPC was aware t that the period October March will be 'critical' for the entire Southern region in view of the severe drought in the region. A basic problem faced by the NTPC, he said was the unsteady coal supplies from the pits, NTPC units had to operate even with coal stocks of three days and less when normally a stock of four weeks should be available. Mr. Shishoo said he could not blame any particular agency for the tardy coal supplies bekause drilling mining, loading and trans- port were involved in this. 'In so far as we are concerned we have built up the infrastructures for un- loading as well as handling in our plants, he said and added that most of these supplies from the pierheads to the station were by merry-go-round railways. Mr. Shishoo admitted that the NTPC was also facing the problems of mounting arrears from the State electricity boards to wards power charges and also non-supply of powers to those States which had a share in the Central generation. 'We are trying to sort out these matters he said. According to the NTPC chief, the total arrears from the electricity boards amounted to Rs 161.54 crores of which the outstanding from Andhra Pradesh amounted to Rs 23.16 crores which was the highest among the beneficiary electricity boards linked with Ramagundam. The dues from Karnataka amounted to Rs 10.93 crores and those from Tamil Nadu Rs 4.83 crores.
summary: Andhra Pradesh is urgently requesting increased power supply from the Ramagundam super thermal station due to the severe drought it is currently experiencing. The Chairman of the Andhra Pradesh State Electricity Board, Mr. N. Tata Rao, contacted the Chairman of the National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) Mr. M. L. Shishoo for this purpose who assured that the third unit of 200 MW at the Ramagundam complex is fully operational and can continue power generation with consistent coal supplies. NTPC is aware of the critical period between October and March due to the severe drought in the Southern region, and they face challenges with unstable coal supplies and mounting arrears from electricity boards.

headline: Shah Bano: Supreme Court judgment sparks debate
article:
The Supreme Court's judgment in the Shah Bano case has sparked a debate in India about the role of religion in personal law.
 
 The case involved a Muslim woman who was divorced by her husband. The Supreme Court ruled that the husband was liable to pay her maintenance, even though Islamic law does not require such payments.
 
 The judgment has been welcomed by women's rights groups, but it has also been criticized by Muslim leaders.
 
 The Shah Bano case is a test case for the Indian government's commitment to religious pluralism and gender equality. The government has said that it will respect the Supreme Court's judgment, but it has also said that it will not interfere in the religious affairs of any community.
 
 The debate over the Shah Bano case is likely to continue for some time. It is a complex issue that raises important questions about the relationship between religion and law in India.
summary:
The Shah Bano case was a landmark case in Indian history that sparked a debate about the role of religion in personal law. The case involved a Muslim woman who was divorced by her husband and sought maintenance from him. The Supreme Court ruled in her favor, stating that she was entitled to maintenance even though Islamic law does not require such payments.
 
 The judgment was welcomed by women's rights groups, but it was also criticized by Muslim leaders who argued that it was an interference in Islamic law. The Indian government eventually passed a law that overturned the Supreme Court's judgment, providing for maintenance to Muslim women only during the period of iddat, or the waiting period after divorce.
 
 The Shah Bano case highlighted the complex relationship between religion and law in India, as well as the challenges faced by Muslim women in the country. It is a reminder of the importance of religious pluralism and gender equality in a multicultural society

headline: Good-bye to Tamil Nadu Legislative Council
article:
The curtain has at last rung down on one of the oldest legislative institutions in the country: the Tamil Nadu Legislative Council stands abolished from today. 
 The House, with a hoary past, has been obliterated by the AIADMK with the help of the State Congress-1
 
 With no public debate preceding it, or even a discussion within the State Cabinet or even in his party, Chief Minister M. G. Ramachan- dran had sprung a rude surprise, even as the local bodies were on the threshold of finding voice in the council.
 
 The resolution recommending the abolition was passed on May 14 this year in the Assembly. But "explana- tions" for the move did not explain how a House with so many firsts to its credit, which had been the source of many social reforms, had over- night become "redundant".
 
 The likes of the Rt. Hon. V. S. Srinivasa Sastri, Rajaji, S. Sathyamurthy, Sir C. P. Ramas- wamy lyer. Dr. A. Lakshmanas- wamy Mudaliar, Sir P. T. Rajan, Sir 5. Varadachari, Dr. T. S. S. Rajan. Sir A. Ramaswamy Mudaliar, Dr..
 
 P. Subbarayan. Sir P. Thiyagaraya Chetty, Dr. P. V. Rajamannar. Dr. Muthulakshmi Reddy and C. N. Annadurai had by their eloquence and meaningful speeches brought glory to the House.
 
 Genesis: Though conceived as a mere advisory committee to the British Governors-General, the House through the years became a veritable debating forum on many political, social, economic and other issues.
 
 It was here that in 1927. Dr. Muthulakshmi Reddy initiated moves to abolish the Devadasi system and also brought forward the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Bill. She was also perhaps the first woman to preside over a legislative body anywhere in the world.
 
 The genesis of the Legislative Council can be traced directly back to the 1861 Indian Councils Act which, for the first time, provided for nomination of a limited number of additional members to the Governor-General's council, with functions confined to legislation in an advisory capacity.
 
 The council's scope was expanded along with its strength by the Indian Councils Act of 1892, by which the
 
 Madras Council could have 20 members of which a maximum of nine had to be officials. The council world now discuss annual financial statement and question the Government on administrative matters.
 
 The election of members to the council was first introduced by the Minto-Morley Reforms of 1909. which raised the maximum strength of the Maas Council to 50. Official majorities were dispensed with and the council was given the right to move resolutions on matters of public interest and also on the
 
 The Government of India Act, 1919, went one step forward, ushering in a measure of responsible government. The Legislative Council, with a three-year term, was given a greater say in "reserved subjects" and ministers were made responsible to the House. But the Governor had full veto powers. The proportion of elected members was also raised to over 70 per cent.
 
 First elected govt.: The Government of India Act 1935. was the next stage of evolution. The Madras Legislative Council now had a mini- mum of 54 and a maximum of 59 members, composed of 35 general,
summary:
The article discusses the abrupt abolition of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Council, a historic legislative institution with a significant legacy. The decision to dissolve it was made without prior public debate or even internal party discussions. This move by the AIADMK, with the support of the State Congress, has raised questions about the council's sudden redundancy despite its rich history.
 
 Throughout its existence, the Legislative Council was a platform for prominent figures like V. S. Srinivasa Sastri, Rajaji, and Dr. Muthulakshmi Reddy to engage in meaningful debates on various political, social, and economic issues. Notably, Dr. Reddy initiated efforts to abolish the Devadasi system and introduced crucial legislation related to the suppression of immoral trafficking.
 
 The article traces the council's evolution from its origins as an advisory committee during British colonial rule to a more robust legislative body. Over the years, it underwent reforms and eventually became a forum for responsible government, with elected members gaining significant influence.
 
 In summary, the abrupt abolition of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Council has raised questions about the historical significance and contributions of this institution, which played a crucial role in shaping the political and social landscape of the region.
