headline: India to Host Next Non-Aligned Summit
article:
India has been chosen to host the next summit of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM) in 1989. The decision was taken at the 8th NAM summit in Harare, Zimbabwe.
 
 India is the second-largest country in the NAM, after Yugoslavia. It has been a member of the NAM since its inception in 1961.
 
 The NAM is a group of developing countries that do not align themselves with either the United States or the Soviet Union. The group was formed in the wake of World War II to promote peace and security among developing countries.
 
 The NAM summit is held every three years. The last summit was held in New Delhi in 1983.
 
 The NAM summit is a major event in international politics. It provides a platform for developing countries to voice their concerns and to work together to promote their common interests.
 
 The selection of India to host the next NAM summit is a testament to the country's rising importance in the world. It is also a sign of the growing recognition of the role of developing countries in international affairs.
 
 The NAM summit is a significant event for India. It will provide an opportunity for India to showcase its economic and political progress. It will also be an opportunity for India to play a leading role in the non-aligned movement.
 
 The NAM summit is a reminder of the importance of multilateralism in international politics. It is also a reminder of the need for developing countries to have a voice in global decision-making.
summary: In 1989, India was chosen to host the next summit of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM), a group of developing countries that don't align with either the US or USSR. India is the second-largest country in NAM and has been a member since its inception in 1961. The NAM summit is held every three years and provides a platform for developing countries to voice their concerns and promote common interests. India's selection to host the summit highlights the country's growing importance in the world and its economic and political progress. The summit will also give India an opportunity to play a leading role in the non-aligned movement and showcase its progress. The NAM summit emphasizes the significance of multilateralism in international politics and the need for developing countries to have a voice in global decision-making.

headline: 13 tigers die mysteriously in Dudhwa National Park
article:
Thirteen tigers have died mysteriously in Dudhwa National Park in Uttar Pradesh over the past few weeks. The deaths have raised concerns about the safety of tigers in the park, which is one of the most important tiger sanctuaries in India.
 
 The cause of the deaths is still under investigation, but officials believe that poisoning or disease may be responsible. Some wildlife experts have also suggested that the deaths may be linked to poaching, as tigers are often killed for their body parts, which are used in traditional Chinese medicine.
 
 The deaths of the tigers are a major setback for conservation efforts in Dudhwa National Park. The park is home to a population of around 100 tigers, and the deaths have reduced this population by more than 10%.
 
 The deaths of the tigers also highlight the threats that tigers face in India. Tigers are one of the most endangered species in the world, and their populations are declining rapidly due to poaching, habitat loss, and conflict with humans.
summary:
The 1987 Dudhwa tiger deaths were a major setback for tiger conservation in India. The deaths raised concerns about the safety of tigers in the park and highlighted the threats that tigers face in India.
 
 The deaths of the tigers also led to increased scrutiny of the park's management. Some wildlife experts criticized the park authorities for failing to protect the tigers from poisoning or disease.

headline: The holiday that was
article:
“At least eight foreigners joined the Prime Minister and his family during their New Year holiday here. In all, the group consisted of 24 men, women and children. Looking after their needs were 70 persons from various departments, cooks and valets and naval personnel. Nearly 1,200 policemen drawn from Lakshadweep Police and Madhya Pradesh Armed Special Police, based at neighbouring Agatti island, were on patrol on the periphery of Bangaram.

ADVERTISEMENT
Security was, naturally, tight, reinforced by a 24-hour watch by a naval fleet. According to reliable sources, among the Indian Navy vessels performing various duties in connection with the holiday were aircraft carrier INS Viraat, the frigates INS Vindhyagiri and INS Taragiri, and the landing craft carrier 39 INS Magar.

The Lakshadweep Administration’s oil tankers MT Suheli and MT Bharat were also there. Passenger liners like MV Bharatseema and research vessels like Sagardeep had been taken off their regular duty and put on the holiday tasks.



Innumerable boats of the local administration, including 40 hp high-speed boats, and the Navy’s yachting boats were pressed into service. The Navy also provided a windsurfer for the holiday makers…

…There was recreation aplenty as the Prime Minister and his party went swimming and boating and tuna fishing in the seas. Kabaddi with men and women lined up against each other provided the Indian touch. The New Year night was marked by a firelit party on the sands…

…The PM’s powerful personal secretary, V George… had stayed back at INS Viraat along with Mani Shankar Iyer, Mrs Sarla Grewal, M M Jacob and others…”
summary:
The passage describes the details of a New Year holiday involving the Indian Prime Minister and his family on the island of Bangaram. The holiday included a group of 24 people, including eight foreigners, and was attended to by a considerable support staff of 70 individuals from various departments, cooks, valets, and naval personnel. Security measures were extensive, with nearly 1,200 policemen patrolling the periphery of Bangaram and naval vessels, including the aircraft carrier INS Viraat, frigates, and landing craft carriers, providing additional security.

Recreational activities during the holiday included swimming, boating, tuna fishing, and a game of Kabaddi. The New Year's night featured a firelit party on the sands. The Prime Minister's personal secretary and other notable individuals stayed back at INS Viraat during the holiday.

headline: Notorious Unabomber Ted Kaczynski Sentenced to Life in Prison
article:
On May 4, 1998, Theodore Kaczynski, infamously known as the Unabomber, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole after pleading guilty to a nationwide bombing campaign that spanned nearly two decades. Kaczynski, a former mathematics professor turned recluse, was responsible for a series of deadly bombings that targeted academics, airline officials, and other perceived symbols of modern technology and industrial society.

Kaczynski's campaign of terror began in 1978, and over the next 17 years, he mailed or hand-delivered 16 bombs, resulting in three deaths and 23 injuries. His bombs were meticulously crafted and often disguised within ordinary packages, making them difficult to detect. The FBI launched one of the longest and most expensive manhunts in history, codenamed "UNABOM" (University and Airline Bomber), to capture him.

The breakthrough in the case came in 1995 when Kaczynski's manifesto, "Industrial Society and Its Future," was published in major newspapers at his demand. His brother, David Kaczynski, recognized the writing style and alerted authorities, leading to Kaczynski's arrest on April 3, 1996, in his remote Montana cabin. The cabin contained extensive evidence linking him to the bombings, including bomb-making materials and a journal detailing his crimes.

In court, Kaczynski initially attempted to represent himself but ultimately agreed to a plea deal to avoid the death penalty. His sentencing brought an end to a terrifying chapter in American history, with Kaczynski's motivations and mental state remaining subjects of intense public and academic interest.
summary: On May 4, 1998, Theodore Kaczynski, known as the Unabomber, was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole for a 17-year bombing campaign that killed three and injured 23. Kaczynski, a former professor, targeted symbols of modern technology. His capture followed the publication of his manifesto, which his brother recognized. Arrested in 1996, Kaczynski's plea deal spared him the death penalty, concluding one of the longest FBI manhunts in history. His case remains a significant study in criminal psychology and domestic terrorism.

headline: 1988 Prominent journalists and newspaper barons Rajiv Shukla, Arun Shourie, HK Dua (The Hindustan Times), N Ram (The Hindu), Hiranmay Karlekar, Ramnath Goenka (Indian Express), Kuldeep Nayyar, Dileep Padgaonkar (The Times of India) among others protesting the Defamation Bill in New Delhi
article:
In 1988, a significant protest erupted in New Delhi against the proposed Defamation Bill, drawing together prominent journalists and newspaper barons to voice their opposition. Among those leading the protest were renowned figures such as Rajiv Shukla, Arun Shourie, H.K. Dua from The Hindustan Times, N. Ram from The Hindu, Hiranmay Karlekar, Ramnath Goenka from Indian Express, Kuldeep Nayyar, and Dileep Padgaonkar from The Times of India, among others.

The Defamation Bill, which aimed to introduce stricter defamation laws, sparked widespread concern within the media fraternity. Journalists and newspaper owners feared that the proposed legislation could severely curtail press freedom and hinder investigative journalism. They argued that the bill's provisions could potentially stifle dissent, muzzle criticism, and undermine the essential role of the press in holding power to account.

The protest in New Delhi served as a powerful demonstration of unity among journalists and media professionals against the perceived threat to press freedom. It highlighted the importance of safeguarding freedom of expression and the press as fundamental pillars of democracy.

The collective action taken by journalists and newspaper barons underscored their commitment to upholding the principles of a free and independent press. Their protest sought to raise awareness about the potential implications of the Defamation Bill and to advocate for its withdrawal or amendment to protect press freedom and journalistic integrity.

Ultimately, the protest played a crucial role in shaping public discourse on the issue and exerting pressure on policymakers to reconsider the proposed legislation. While the outcome of the protest may have varied, its significance lies in the united stand taken by journalists and media professionals to defend press freedom and uphold the democratic values enshrined in the Indian constitution.
summary:
In 1988, a significant protest took place in New Delhi against the proposed Defamation Bill, bringing together prominent journalists and newspaper barons including Rajiv Shukla, Arun Shourie, H.K. Dua, N. Ram, Hiranmay Karlekar, Ramnath Goenka, Kuldeep Nayyar, and Dileep Padgaonkar. The bill, aiming for stricter defamation laws, raised concerns among the media fraternity regarding potential curtailment of press freedom and hindrance to investigative journalism. Protesters argued that the bill's provisions could stifle dissent, muzzle criticism, and undermine the crucial role of the press in holding power accountable.

This demonstration in New Delhi showcased unity among journalists and media professionals, emphasizing the vital importance of safeguarding freedom of expression and press in democracy. Their collective action aimed to raise awareness about the bill's implications and advocate for its withdrawal or amendment to preserve press freedom and journalistic integrity.

The protest significantly influenced public discourse, pressuring policymakers to reconsider the proposed legislation. While the immediate outcome varied, the protest highlighted the united commitment of journalists and media professionals to defend press freedom and uphold democratic values, marking a pivotal moment in Indian media history.

headline: Villagers allege police terror
article:
The police and residents of this small village of the Mandi Adampur assembly segment appear to be heading for a confrontation with both parties levelling charges of excesses against each other.

On the night of October 25, policemen Rajinder Singh, Raghubir Singh and Mohinder Singh of the Adampur police station raided the house of Dhamkal Ram for his alleged involvement in illegal liquor trade.

All three were reportedly held captive by the family members of Dhamkal Ram. Some villagers allegedly beat them up. Rajinder Singh, however, managed to escape and reported the matter to the police. The other two captives were set free after a posse of policemen gheraoed the house of Dhamkal Ram.

According to villagers they held the police hostage as they had been "instigated" by liquor trader Bhoop Singh who, according to the villagers, was accompanying the policemen during the raid.

On October 27 several policemen accompanied by two policewomen cordoned off the house of Dhamkal Ram. Two of the three women inside the house of managed to give the slip to the policemen.

The third, Bimla was spotted by the police party but she took shelter in an adjacent house belonging to Jai Narain. Jai Narain's son, Subhash, who was reportedly standing outside his house was dragged to the police vehicle for sheltering Bimla.

After sometime the police managed to evict Bimla from the house. She was mercilessly thrashed by SHO Mohinder Singh while the two policewomen stood mute spectators.

An elderly neighbour, Jaman, tried to intervene. This was enough to provoke the wrath of the policemen. They started beating him up as well.

Jaman, who had lost his son about three months back, was on his way to attend his ailing daughter. When the daughter came to know about the "arrest" of her father, she according to the villagers, died of shock.

On October 28, Bimla and Jaman were produced in court. While Bimla was granted bail, Jaman was denied the same. He was granted bail on October 29. Subhash was released reportedly at the instance of Home Minister Mani Ram Godara.

The villagers allege that the police have let loose a reign of terror. They allege that the police is acting in vengeance. They deny that they beat up the two policemen and say they only wanted to hand them over to the SP or the Deputy Commissioner as they were acting as "henchmen" of Bhoop Singh.

There is no information about the whereabouts of Dhamkal Ram and his family members. Nothing is known about Bimla who got bail on October 28.

The Senior Superintendent of Police, Hisar, Mr Manjit Singh Ahalawat talking to TNS denied charges of police excesses. He said, the police was acting according to law. He pointed out that it were the villagers who had held two policemen hostage.

Communist leader Prithvi Singh Gorakhpuria, trade union leader Banwari Lal Bishnoi and Mr Paras Ram, a retired DSP of the Intelligence Bureau, have formed a committee to take up the matter with the Home Minister.
summary: The police and residents of a village in the Mandi Adampur assembly segment seem to be on a collision course, with both parties accusing each other of excesses. On October 25, policemen from the Adampur police station raided the house of Dhamkal Ram for his alleged involvement in illegal liquor trade. Three policemen were reportedly held captive by the family members of Dhamkal Ram, and some villagers allegedly beat them up. The villagers claim they held the police hostage as they were instigated by liquor trader Bhoop Singh, who was reportedly accompanying the policemen. The police deny the charges and assert that the villagers held two policemen hostage. The Senior Superintendent of Police, Hisar, denies charges of police excesses and states that the police are acting according to the law. Villagers allege that the police are acting in vengeance, and a committee has been formed to take up the matter with the Home Minister.

headline: Death stalks highway in Gurgaon
article:
If Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee feels it is difficult to tell roads from potholes in Bihar, a visit to Gurgaon on the outskirts of the Capital could evoke the Prime Minister to say: "There is little difference between hell and the roads in Gurgaon".

It is a daily battle for life for the residents on either side of the national highway cutting through Gurgaon as the speeding traffic, lack of traffic signals and the police make it a nightmarish experience to cross the road.

The pitiable condition of the roads is in direct contrast to the numerous reports one reads about big multinational houses shifting base to Gurgaon. Only yesterday DuPont advertised that they were shifting all their offices in the Capital to DLF Enclave.

However, the condition of roads in Gurgaon is in sharp contrast to the theme of globalisation in Haryana. Improving the condition of the roads — considered to be quintessence of modernisation and a sure index of fast growth of any habitat — appears to be low on the priority list of the authorities, including the National Highway Authority of India. Road upkeep appears to be a victim of a conflict between different government departments.

A case in point is National Highway No 8 — the Delhi-Jaipur road — which cuts through the city. It is a dismal case of neglect by the authorities. Right from the Delhi-Gurgaon border, there are more than a dozen crossings and intersections which witness road accidents every day. The accidents have increased recently with the increase in traffic load on the highway. The first major crossing, from the Delhi side, Udyog Vihar (Shankar Chowk), often presents a gory site of mangled vehicles and traffic jams.

For the employees working in a large number of industrial units in the complex built by the Haryana State Industrial Development Corporation (HSIDC) on the one side and the residents of the prestigious housing enclave, the National Media Centre, on the other side, crossing the road is a daily torture. Thousands of employees work in various firms in this industrial estate, and more than 180 families live in the housing enclave. The house owners in the National Media Centre are virtually who’s who of the country from all walks of life. The list includes the first citizen of the country, President K.R. Narayanan.

Some of the employees working in the industrial estate told TNS that they were virtually living under the shadow of death as the probability of their getting hit by vehicles travelling at high speed from both sides of the road was very high. According to them, they wait for long hours to cross the road. Of late the number of accidents had increased.

The President of the National Media Centre Cooperative House Building Society Ltd, Mr K. Gopal Krishnan, said sending children to school from the housing complex needed a lot of courage in the given situation. Prof T.N. Bali, Vice-President of the society, said the residents had taken up the issue with the Superintendent of Police, Gurgaon, to post police personnel to man the crossing till a traffic light was set up, but it was of no avail. The police authorities have maintained that they were unable to oblige on account of shortage of police personnel. Although the Haryana government has sanctioned two police stations for Gurgaon, including one for Udyog Vihar, there seems to be no relief to the people.The people of the area have also taken up the issue with various other authorities.

Similar kinds of problems and threats to lives are faced by the residents in colonies and sectors on both sides of Highway at other crossings and T-Points. A resident of Jharsa village was recently killed by a speeding vehicle at the nearby crossing leading to agitation by the people of the area. The authorities had to intervene to pacify the agitationists with the assurance of remedial measures against occurrence of such accident. Subsequently, on and off, a couple of men in uniform were seen near the crossing. A resident of the adjoining Sector 15, on condition of anonymity, said these police personnel were hardly active. After evening they were mainly seen busy stopping vehicles, checking their documents, and reportedly harassing innocent commuters.

Enquiries reveal that there is confusion among the district administration and the national highway authorities on the responsibility of installing traffic lights at the crossings. A Deputy General Manager of the National Highway Authority, Mr B.R.Salwan, categorically said the state government was responsible for the maintenance of the stretch of the road falling in Gurgaon district. The officials of the state Government do not agree with this view. However, there are many who feel that the onus lies on the state government as it was responsible for sanctioning sectors and providing housing enclaves on either side of the national highway.

According to observers, although the Haryana government has taken the initiative in carrying out repair of some of the roads in the cities, the overall road condition is pathetic. There was no road which was not plagued with a problem. Either the roads were not in proper shape, or there were encroachments. Besides, unregulated movement of the vehicles has encouraged "jungle raj" syndrome on the roads. Accidents and the resulting skirmishes, traffic jam and rash driving were now a familiar sight.
summary: The condition of roads in Gurgaon, especially along National Highway No 8, is a matter of concern for residents and commuters. Despite the city being home to numerous multinational companies, the roads suffer from neglect, leading to accidents and traffic jams. The conflict between different government departments appears to be hampering road upkeep. For example, National Highway No 8, the Delhi-Jaipur road, is poorly maintained, with accidents occurring frequently at crossings and intersections. The lack of traffic signals and police presence compounds the problem, making it difficult for residents and employees to cross the road safely. The responsibility for road maintenance is disputed between the National Highway Authority of India and the state government, further contributing to the issue. The overall road condition in Gurgaon is deemed pathetic, with problems ranging from poor road quality to encroachments and unregulated vehicle movement, leading to a chaotic and unsafe road environment.

headline: Bollywood is a good equaliser!
article:
Forget last year’s failures and flops, the embarrassments and losses, leave behind the pain and hurt caused by things that didn’t work for you in 2009... let them remain, like the smouldering ashes of the Old Man burned at midnight, only memories of the year that was. Today is a new year, the start of a new decade, if you cannot enthuse yourself with hope, if you cannot find inspiration in life, work and the people around you, then look around...Mumbai is full of shining examples of heroes who took life’s wicked knocks on the chin in 2009, but were still standing to Auld Lang Syne when the countdown to the New Year began last night.
Since we are BT, we present Bollywood — which is a good equaliser, it teaches us that life can be a bed of roses with the thorny underside, it reminds us that next Friday may not have the success of last Friday at the multiplexes, and that a critical success could often be a box-office failure. Films are a gamble, Bollywood trade pundits are still to figure out what works better for a producer — a great script and director or a super, multi-star cast. All permutations and combinations have been worked out by the industry. Yet, when release Friday comes, with it comes the visit to Siddhivinayak and Tirupati, the last-minute appeal to the Gods for a good opening, for a decent run and great returns. It works, sometimes it
doesn’t.
But heroes, 2010 is in need of stories of hope, of people inspired to rise on the stepping stones of their defeats in 2009 to carve new successes for themselves in this new year. And Bollywood is full of them. From Akshay Kumar and Amitabh Bachchan to Shah Rukh and Salman Khan. Take Akshay, our cover boy, who licked dry the wounds of Chandni Chowk To China, Kambakhth Ishq, Tasveer 8x10, Blue and De Dana Dhan to talk confidently of Khatta Meetha. And the Big B, who stripped off the bizarre loser’s disguise of Alladin to slip on a new winner’s one for Paa. SRK didn’t let the hurt of his shoulder injury, Billu and the IPL Season 2 rob him of the confidence of My Name Is Khan. And Saif Ali Khan rode on the memory of Love Aaj Kal when Kurbaan failed to deliver. Ditto Salman, Bollywood’s most Wanted man, who must have bench-pressed the hurts of Main Aur Mrs Khanna and London Dreams out of his system and pumped himself up with a rush of adrenaline for Veer. Poor Aamir, he lost his baby, but 3 Idiots! brought back the smile. While Shahid Kapoor lost with Dil Bole Hadippa what he gained with Kaminey and is now dancing with impatience for Chance Pe Dance to open.
And the ladies, is there a bigger heroine than Kareena Kapoor, No. 1 at the box-office despite a string of dismal films in Kambakth Ishq, Main Aur Mrs Khanna and Kurbaan, then suddenly in the dying moments of 2009... a brilliant hit in 3 Idiots. And Katrina Kaif, strong contender to Kareena’s crown, with New York and Ajab Prem Ki Ghazab Kahani adding to the hits of the year before... even as she was weighed down with the woes of ill-health and lost love. Likewise Preity Zinta, first it was Ness Wadia and then the IPL, but she’s bright and cheerful at the thought of business school and a new season in the IPL sun. If Priyanka had Kaminey in 2009, then she also had What’s Your Rashee? But her sights are now set on Don 2. And Rani Mukerji who famously tried to return to Bollywood with Dil Bole Hadippa, instead found acceptance on television with Dance Premiere League. Deepika Padukone’s also been unlucky in love but lucky in her career... Love Aaj Kal undid the image Chandni Chowk To China gave her, so what if she lost Ranbir Kapoor. And as for Ranbir Kapoor himself, the flavour of 2009, the poster-boy of 2010... up with Wake Up Sid and Ajab Prem Ki Ghazab Kahani to plunge down with Rocket Singh... he lost Deepika to find Katrina. Wasn’t it the poet Patrick Chalmers who said in Roundabouts and Swings, “What you lose on the swings you gain on the roundabouts?”
So have a swinging 2010...
summary:
Forget the failures and disappointments of 2009. Today marks the start of a new year and decade, offering a fresh chance for hope and inspiration. Mumbai, filled with resilient heroes, exemplifies perseverance despite setbacks. Bollywood, a prime equalizer, mirrors this resilience. Films are unpredictable, and success can be fleeting, yet the industry's stars remain undeterred.

Heroes like Akshay Kumar overcame a string of flops to bounce back with confidence. Amitabh Bachchan transformed from a failure in *Alladin* to a success in *Paa*. Shah Rukh Khan, despite injuries and setbacks, pushed forward with *My Name Is Khan*. Similarly, Salman Khan and Aamir Khan turned their fortunes around with new successes, and Shahid Kapoor balanced failures with hits.

Among the actresses, Kareena Kapoor maintained her top status despite several flops, ending the year with a hit in *3 Idiots*. Katrina Kaif, despite personal challenges, delivered successful films. Preity Zinta, Priyanka Chopra, Rani Mukerji, Deepika Padukone, and Ranbir Kapoor all navigated through professional and personal highs and lows, embodying resilience.

As poet Patrick Chalmers suggested, losses can lead to gains. Embrace 2010 with hope and resilience, inspired by these Bollywood stories of triumph over adversity.

headline: New beginning in India-China ties as neighbours stand free from the chains of border dispute
article:
The silliest question to ask about Rajiv Gandhi's China visit is whether it is a success or a failure. Labels are devices designed to protect us from thinking. The point is that a great cold war barrier has been broken after 30 years. One more stream joins the newly-flowing global mainstream of dialogue and cooperation with the ebbing of the tides of conflict and confrontation.

Two walls - China and Pakistan - keep India confined to the barren region of South Asia, overloaded with conflict or potential for conflict. The China wall has fallen. The Pakistan wall will hopefully collapse likewise. India then will be able to act on the global front as a major power of today, a great power of tomorrow.

What happens between India and China matters for the entire world. When war happens, its heat radiates to world politics. When peace and amity transpire, creative human visions dance on the horizon of time. In Beijing in December, Rajiv Gandhi and three preeminent Chinese leaders, Deng Xiaoping. Zhao Ziyang and Li Peng, said in one voice that the two countries would work "very hard" to resolve the border issue in two or three years.

With that end in view, they set up a border commission chaired by the heads of the two foreign office bureaucracies. They will work not only within the framework of a set of agreed principles but under the monitoring eyes of ministers, even prime ministers. The time-frame is important, a yardstick of accountability. The prime ministers will have to tell their peoples and the world what progress they make as they slog for a settlement.
The relationship today stands liberated from the chains of the border dispute, from the shackles of the bitter memories of 1962. When a man like Deng said let's forget the past and make a new beginning, the prime minister of India could only respond with a warm yes, and that's what Rajiv Gandhi did. So it's a new beginning for the two largest Asian neighbours, both wiser from the scars of the past, both weathered in the storms and stresses of domestic and foreign conflicts, each armed with a treasure of experience of handling common problems, the two capable of doing great things together.

Deng treated Rajiv to a Socratic dialogue as he had done Nixon and Kissinger in February 1972 and will do Gorbachev coming April. He indicated a direction for the new Sino-Indian beginning. Deng did not prescribe a route of march. This will have to be worked out by the leaders. Were the Chinese earnest in their wish for good relations and a mutually acceptable settlement of the border? Yes, and the proof is that Prime Minister Li Peng will be coming to India this year to add momentum to the new beginning. Before then Gorbachev will have his summit with Deng. Rajiv and Benazir will have met in Islamabad. Perhaps the Japanese prime minister and the Soviet president will have exchanged visits too.

What unprecedented movements of minds will be taking place from one end of the Asia-Pacific expanse to another. The journey to Beijing makes India a full partner in the exciting process of recasting world politics in the mould of dialogues and cooperation. Gorbachev's lone initiatives of two years ago are now a powerful cascade of initiatives taken by many nations. To Rajiv's credit, he has now concretised the loftily worded Delhi Declaration to the realities of India's relations with China and Pakistan.

To suggest that he acted under Gorbachev's pressure is to miss an entire world process-in-the-making. The Chinese leaders engaged in a comprehensive dialogue with Rajiv on the world condition. Surely not under Gorbachev's pressure. The West Europeans are building their own little bridges to the East. Surely not under Moscow's pressure. The new world process is at this time more than an "emerging tableaux", as the late Andre Malraux would have called it. India merits the role of one of its major architects. That it is now, thanks to the end of the cold war with China, another major architect.

A good visit has shored up more than what even an optimist had dared to expect. The Indian performance in Beijing, however, bears smudges of the clumsiness that has become typical of the Rajiv administration. The appointment of a border committee was an excellent idea. But why keep it to the indifferent care of the same officials who have had eight rounds of talks without producing anything but an ocean of words? The difference, of course, is that they will work under political direction, and, if they get bogged down once again in crusty bureaucratic style, the negotiations will be rescued by ministers.

But is the present Indian foreign minister quite convinced that there should be a "new beginning" in India-China relations? Does he have a clear idea of what a new beginning would mean? Hasn't the prime minister denied the foreign office a meaningful role in his China visit thereby creating a climate of cynical sulk in South Block?

Is giving the co-chairmanship of what virtually is an India-China joint commission to the commerce minister rather than the foreign minister not meant to be an insult to the minister for external affairs? Above all, the prime minister's own imperial indifference to implementation of his decisions will leave room for doubt if actual "hard work" on the border will move as fast in New Delhi as the Beijing formulations have jointly desired.

Rajiv Gandhi will have to face some criticism on Tibet, but that shouldn't deter him for the vast majority of Indians do not wish to see Tibet become a matter of contention between India and China. The Beijing accords are not directed against the Dalai Lama, who must settle his quarrels with the people and government of China to which Tibet belongs. The Chinese are very sensitive about Tibetan nationalism as we ourselves are about what we call Indian sub-nationalisms. Indeed the Dalai Lama owes it to India to work out a peaceful settlement of the Tibet issue with Beijing for the last thing Indians wish to see is a repeat of the melancholy history of 1959.
summary:
The article discusses Rajiv Gandhi's visit to China and emphasizes the significance of the thawing of relations between India and China. It suggests that labels like "success" or "failure" are irrelevant and highlights the breakthrough in the Cold War barrier between the two countries after 30 years. The article points out the importance of the border issue resolution and the establishment of a border committee, signaling a new beginning in their relationship. It also mentions the upcoming visit of Chinese Prime Minister Li Peng to India and how this visit, along with other global diplomatic initiatives, is shaping the evolving landscape of world politics.

However, the article raises concerns about the Indian government's bureaucratic approach and questions the clarity of India's foreign policy direction. It also touches on the Tibet issue, suggesting that it should not become a source of contention between India and China, emphasizing the importance of a peaceful settlement between the Dalai Lama and the Chinese government.

In summary, the article highlights the positive developments in Sino-Indian relations, but also raises questions about the Indian government's approach and the need for clear direction in foreign policy.

headline: Highest French award for Ray
article:
Calcutta- Mr Satyajit Ray was presented the Legion D. Honour, the highest civilian award of France, by President Francois Mitterrand here today at a simple ceremony at the picturesque National Library grounds.
Mr Mitterrand first read out a speech, which was translated into English for the benefit of a select gathering. He then presented the award to the film director. Mr Ray replied, “I feel fulfilled as an Indian artist.” West Bengal Governor S. Nurul Hasan and Chief Minister Jyoti Basu were present on the occasion.
Mr Mitterrand said, Mr Ray’s films were both a typical representation of the Indian culture and universal creativity. While the films presented traditional and modern Bengal, its renaissance and many crisis, the themes also proved to be of equal concern to the world. While one found him embodying nostalgia, his films often reminded us of many characters described by Guy de Maupassant and Emile Zola.
summary: In Calcutta, Mr. Satyajit Ray received the Legion d'Honneur, France's highest civilian award, from President Francois Mitterrand during a ceremony at the National Library grounds. President Mitterrand, accompanied by West Bengal Governor S. Nurul Hasan and Chief Minister Jyoti Basu, praised Ray's films as representations of Indian culture and universal creativity. Mitterrand highlighted that Ray's films depicted both traditional and modern Bengal, capturing its renaissance and crises, resonating globally. Ray expressed his fulfillment as an Indian artist upon receiving the award. Mitterrand likened Ray's nostalgic and evocative storytelling to the works of Guy de Maupassant and Emile Zola.

headline: Obituary for Donald W. Quigley
article:
Donald Donald W. Quigley, sr., 69, of Cedar Street, Mifflintown, died Saturday morning at his residence. He was born December 1, 1919, in Carlisle, to the late William N. and Elizabeth Braught Quigley. He was the former co-owner of the Deny Limestone Quarry of Lewistown.

He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the Army Air Corp. He was a member of Trinity United Methodist Church of Mifflin, a life member of the Mifflintown Hose Co. No. 1, and a member of the American Legion of Wormleysburg. Surviving are his wife, Iona (Sparky) Newcomer Quigley; two sons, Donald W.

Quigley Jr. of Mifflintown, Michael P., Quigley of RD1 Thompsontown; three brothers, Armond Quigley and Lee Quigley, W. QuigleySr. both of RD3 Mifflintown, and Robert P. Quigley, HCR-67 Mifflin; one sister, Joanne Hennenberger of Frederick, Md.; his stepmother, Anna K.

Quigley, HCR-67 Mifflin; and five granddaughters, Services will be Tuesday at 10 a.m. ai crown v unerai Home, iuu tsriage Street, Mifflintown. Officiating will be the Rev. Dr. Ken Grundon.

Internment will be in Westminster Cemetery, North Middleton Township. Friends may call Monday, 7 to 9 p.m., at Hoffman-Roth funeral Home, 219 N. Hanover St., Carlisle. Memorial contributions may be made to Mifflintown Hose Co. 1, Mifflintown, PA 17059 and Sun Health, 2 Hudson Avenue, Juniata Terrace, Lewistown, PA 17044
summary: Donald W. Quigley Sr., 69, of Mifflintown, passed away at his residence. Born on December 1, 1919, in Carlisle, he was a veteran of World War II and a former co-owner of Deny Limestone Quarry in Lewistown. He was a member of Trinity United Methodist Church, a life member of Mifflintown Hose Co. No. 1, and a member of the American Legion. Survivors include his wife, Iona (Sparky) Newcomer Quigley, two sons, three brothers, one sister, and five granddaughters. Services will be held at Crown Funeral Home, with interment at Westminster Cemetery.

headline: Sweet nostalgia of the 1990s
article:
The decade still rings in our ears. Over the last year, UB40 have toured India, both Tamma Tamma and Humma Humma have found their way back on to the charts, and a radio channel dedicated to “1990s retro" has been launched. Indipop no longer exists, but it’s a rare college reunion that doesn’t end with a weepy rendition of Yaaron or Purani Jeans (in the 1990s, it was conceivable that our No.1 college anthem might be from Pakistan).

Every decade brings with it monumental change, but it’s particularly easy to make the case for India in the 1990s as a period of extraordinary ferment and reinvention. Economic liberalization wrought sweeping changes in the way we ate, travelled, shopped and saw ourselves. It’s difficult to imagine today how thrilling it was to first watch MTV or sit in a McDonald’s in India—but it was. It was a decade of firsts—and of goodbyes: to cassette tapes, Walkmans, PCOs, dial-up connections, soggy cornflakes.

We had always been a nation of armchair experts when it came to cricket—except now we could disagree with expert commentators while watching matches on our colour TVs. Just last week, a documentary reminded us (as if we needed reminding) that this was a decade dominated by Sachin Tendulkar. Fittingly, the film was scored by that other 1990s icon
summary: The phrase "Sweet nostalgia of the 1990s" evokes memories of a bygone era, suggesting a fond and sentimental longing for the past. During the 1990s, there were several cultural, technological, and social shifts that continue to hold a special place in the hearts of many. This period witnessed the rise of iconic television shows, the advent of the internet, the popularity of grunge music, and the emergence of influential video games. The summary captures the sentimental feelings associated with the 1990s, a time cherished for its unique trends and experiences, reminding people of simpler and often cherished moments from their past.

headline: Indian Parliament Passes Comprehensive Anti-Corruption Bill"
article: In a historic session, the Indian Parliament passed a comprehensive Anti-Corruption Bill aimed at combating graft and restoring public trust in government institutions. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, addressing lawmakers, hailed the bill as a significant step towards strengthening accountability and integrity in public service.The Anti-Corruption Bill introduces stringent measures to prevent and punish corrupt practices among public officials, including enhanced transparency requirements, stricter enforcement mechanisms, and stiffer penalties for offenders. It establishes specialized anti-corruption agencies tasked with investigating and prosecuting cases of corruption at all levels of government.Furthermore, the bill mandates the declaration of assets and liabilities by public servants to ensure transparency and accountability in their financial dealings. It also includes provisions for the protection of whistleblowers and witnesses to encourage reporting of corrupt activities without fear of reprisal.Prime Minister Gandhi emphasized the government's commitment to rooting out corruption and fostering a culture of honesty and probity in public life. She called upon all political parties and stakeholders to support the implementation of the Anti-Corruption Bill and uphold the principles of good governance.The passage of the Anti-Corruption Bill follows widespread public outrage over high-profile corruption scandals and reflects the government's resolve to address the scourge of corruption that undermines democracy and economic development.While the bill is hailed as a significant milestone in India's fight against corruption, some critics have raised concerns about its effective implementation and the need for institutional reforms to address systemic issues that fuel corruption.Overall, the Anti-Corruption Bill represents a concerted effort by the government to tackle corruption and promote ethical governance for the benefit of all citizens.
summary: The front-page headline of The Times of India dated January 7, 1980, highlights the passage of a comprehensive Anti-Corruption Bill by the Indian Parliament. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi lauds the bill as a significant step towards strengthening accountability and integrity in public service. The bill introduces stringent measures to prevent and punish corrupt practices among public officials, including enhanced transparency requirements and stiffer penalties. While hailed as a milestone, concerns are raised about its effective implementation and the need for institutional reforms. The Anti-Corruption Bill reflects the government's commitment to combatting corruption and fostering ethical governance.

headline: Poll to elect JD president put off
article:
New Delhi, April 30 (PTI & UNI): The election of the Janata Dul President, scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed by a week.
 
 The election has been post- poned by the returning officer. Mr. Madhu Dardavate, in view of the representations by certain states expressing inability to con- duct polling on May, 1 which is a public holiday. No fresh date has been fixed for
 
 the election, party sources said. Mr. Dandavate said "there are some practical difficulties which have necessitated postponement of the election."
 
 Returning officers were appointed "rather lete" as a result of which we have decided to defer the election", he said.
 
 The three candidates in the fray! are the former Karnataka Chief Minister Mr. S.R. Bommai, party, general secretary Mr. S. Jaipal Reddy and Mr. Hukumdeo:
 
 Narayan Yadav. MP. from Bihar. However, the contest was mainly between Mr. Bommai and Mr. Reddy with the Deputy Prime
 
 Minister Mr. Devi Lal expressing support for Mr. Bommai.
 
 But, Prime Minister V.P. Singh had at the political affairs commit- tee meeting last week suggested that elections be held for the post though some members had favoured a consensus candidate.
 
 The election was being held for the post of interim president fol- lowing Mr. V.P. Singh's resigna- tion from the post on the "one- man-one-post principle.
 
 The two major contenders, Mr. Bommai and Mr. Reddy claimed strong support for themselves though party sources said that Uttar Pradesh and Bihar electo- rate were the two states which could til the balance.
 
 In Uttar Pradesh, it, was the Chief Minister, Mr. Mulayam Singh Yadav and the Union In- dustries Minister, Mr. Ajit Singh who held the key and both were playing a cat and mouse game." party sources said.
 
 The postponement has been done to find a consensus candi- I date and efforts were on in this regard, party sources said.
summary: The election of the Janata Dal President, scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed by a week. The decision came due to certain states expressing difficulties in conducting polling on May 1, a public holiday. No new election date has been set yet. Three candidates were in the fray, with the main competition between Mr. S.R. Bommai and Mr. S. Jaipal Reddy, both claiming strong support. The postponement aims to find a consensus candidate, as suggested by Prime Minister V.P. Singh, following his resignation from the post based on the "one-man-one-post principle."

headline: Govt to come down heavily on caste-based 'hit squads'
article:
Express News Service Madras, May 4: Hit squads being maintained by some caste groups would be banned and a crackdown launched against them whoever be their mentor. Chief Minister M Karunanidhi warned in the Assembly on Friday.
 
 Replying to the discussion on demands for grants for Police, Fire Service and Excise Depart ments, he said caste animousity was still smouldering in Rajapalayam where 11 persons had been killed recently. He was not identifying the communities to which the dead belonged as that was likely to trigger off fresh violence.

headline: Historic commission to advice planners
article:

2. Developing preservation guidelines: Based on its research, the commission may have developed guidelines and recommendations for preserving historical sites and structures. These guidelines could have included regulations for new construction, renovation, and restoration projects in historically significant areas.

3. Advising urban planners and developers: The commission likely provided advice and assistance to urban planners, architects, and developers working on projects that impacted historical sites. This could have involved reviewing development plans, providing feedback on design proposals, and suggesting ways to incorporate historical elements into new construction.

4. Educating the public: The commission may have engaged in outreach and educational efforts to raise awareness about the importance of historical preservation. This could have included public events, educational programs, and informational materials designed to highlight the significance of historical sites and structures.

Overall, the establishment of the historic commission reflected a commitment to balancing the need for urban development with the preservation of cultural heritage. By providing guidance and advice to planners and developers, the commission aimed to ensure that historical sites remained integral parts of the urban landscape for future generations to enjoy and appreciate.

On June 28, 1990, a significant step was taken with the establishment of a historic commission tasked with advising urban planners on preserving historical sites amidst urban development. This commission aimed to identify, protect, and integrate culturally significant landmarks and structures into modern urban landscapes. Its responsibilities included conducting surveys to identify historically important sites, developing preservation guidelines, and advising planners and developers on construction projects affecting historical areas. headline: Thousands bid adieu to Ambani
article:
Thousands of mourners from different spheres of life today bid farewell to India’s business legend Dhirubhai Ambani, Chairman of Reliance Industries Ltd (RIL), who died yesterday aged 69.

His mortal remains were consigned to the flames at the Chandanwadi crematorium here this evening.

The pyre was lit around 6.40 p.m. by his elder son Mukesh Ambani, amidst the chanting of vedic hymns.

The industrial patriarch died some minutes before midnight at Breach Candy Hospital here, where he had been admitted 12 days ago after suffering a cerebral stroke.


Ratan Tata
Mr Ratan Tata, Chairman, TATA Group, comes out of the Ambani residence after paying his respects to the mortal remains of Dhirubhai Ambani in Mumbai on Sunday. 
— PTI photos
Mourners turned up at the crematorium and all along the route of the funeral procession to pay homage.

His body was brought to the crematorium on a flower-decked carriage from his ‘Sea Wind’ home at Cuffe Parade in South Mumbai. It was taken to the crematorium in a crowded procession from S.K. Patil Udyan at Charni Road.

Commoners and VVIPs brushed shoulders as they took part in the funeral procession.

His last journey was attended among others by former Prime Minister Deve Gowda, Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan, former Lok Sabha Speaker Balram Jakhar, Congress leader Murli Deora and Mr Buta Singh.

Other heavyweights present included Union Minister Vinod Khanna, Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) leader Sharad Pawar, former Maharashtra Deputy Chief Minister Gopinath Munde, Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister Digvijay Singh, and veteran actor Shammi Kapoor.

The funeral route was covered with petals and overhead banners and posters hailing the late tycoon.

The funeral pyre was lit by his sons Mukesh and Anil, in the presence of the entire Ambani clan, except its female members.

Around 450 kg of sandalwood and 45 kg of ghee were used for performing the last rites by priests Neeraj Kumar Shastri and Shravan Kumar Sharma from Kakarwadi Arya Samaj.

A large number of industrialists, politicians, film stars and scores of Reliance employees and shareholders were among those who attended the funeral of the patriarch of the Ambani family.

Crowds began to throng the S.K. Patil Udyan earlier in the day to catch a last glimpse of their favourite “Dhirubhai’’. Many even climbed terraces and roofs to have an easy view of a man credited with bringing in the “equity cult’’ in India.

Many a tear-eyed investor present at the funeral hailed their beloved business wizard, saying: “Dhirubhai amar rahe (long live Dhirubhai)’’.

Old-timers here said the turnout of huge crowds outside the crematorium was unprecedented.

Thousands of people thronged the roadside, a footover bridge and a railway platform of the Marine Lines railway station, opposite the crematorium. Many, however, met disappointment as they failed to have a glimpse of the late industrialist because of tight security. Regular announcements were made on the public address system asking the people to keep calm.

A tight security blanket was thrown around the entire 1-km route from the garden to the Chandanwadi crematorium, which was spruced up for the funeral of the legendary tycoon, son of a poor schoolmaster from an obscure village of Chorwaad in the Saurashtra region of Gujarat.

A strong legion of 500 police personnel formed a human chain to keep the crowds from pouring in on the streets while ropes were tied on the other side of the road to prevent public from getting too close.

Minister of State for Home Kripashankar Singh reviewed security arrangements near the crematorium.

Wreaths were placed by Mr Vijay Goel, Minister of State in the PMO’s office on behalf of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee and by Mr R.K. Dhawan for Opposition leader Sonia Gandhi.

The otherwise-formidable iron gates of the Ambani residence were thrown open to mourners since the wee hours of morning as a steady stream of people poured in to have a last glimpse of their beloved business tycoon, who dominated the equity culture in the commercial capital for over past four decades.

A large posse of private security men stood guard along the gate, shouting out orders to vehicle drivers that pulled outside Ambani’s residential complex while a special squad of private security men strictly monitored the entrants to the residential complex and ensured that the mourners formed a neat queue.

The fragrant smell of incense sticks wafted through the basement and the soft strains of “Shree Krishna Sharnam Mamah” and “Om Bhur Bhuvasva” gently filled the air, as streams of mourners walked in a disciplined queue towards the flower-decked body of the Ambani patriarch.

The gold-rimmed photograph of a beaming Dhirubhai decorated with fresh red roses overlooked the mourners when they passed by.

The tycoon’s sons, Mukesh and Anil, daughters Nina and Dipti and his daughters-in-law Tina and Neeta, all dressed in pristine white, greeted mourners with folded hands and accepted condolences.

After the funeral, both Mukesh and Anil came out and addressed the mourners with their hands joined together.

“On behalf of the Ambani family, I wish to thank each one of you for your personal presence here. I would also like to personally apologise that we could not accommodate all of you inside the crematorium.

“We, the family members, are very fortunate to have been present at my father’s bedside when he left on his last journey,” Mr Anil Ambani said.

A stream of celebrities from the business world right from Ratan Tata to Anand Mahindra streamed in since early morning. The palatial mansion also appeared as a congregation of leading film stars and personalities with mega stars like Amitabh Bachchan, accompanied by wife Jaya and son Abhishek, showman Subhash Ghai, actors Sanjay Dutt, Jackie Shroff, actress Karisma Kapoor and Shabana Azmi paying a visit.

The entry of Hrithik Roshan, however, sent the security personnel into a tizzy with the streams of onlookers breaking the cordon to have a look at the megastar.
summary: Dhirubhai Ambani, the Chairman of Reliance Industries Ltd (RIL), has passed away at the age of 69 after suffering a cerebral stroke. Thousands of mourners, including VVIPs and celebrities, bid farewell to the business legend during his funeral procession. His mortal remains were consigned to the flames at the Chandanwadi crematorium in Mumbai. The pyre was lit by his elder son Mukesh Ambani. Ambani's death marked the end of an era, and people from various walks of life paid homage to the industrial patriarch.

headline: Political Process Theory and Transnational Movements: Dialectics of Protest among Nigeria's Ogoni Minority
article: Political process theory, developed through the analysis of national social movements, is now routinely applied to movements seeking transnational support. An examination of networking by Nigeria's Ogoni ethnic minority during the 1990s suggests the need for caution in this analytic expansion. Two factors neglected by process theory, leadership and political exchange, are crucial to explaining interactions between local and transnational actors. In the Ogoni case, globally-oriented leaders framed international opportunities for local constituents, shaping the movement's goals and strategies. To realize these opportunities, Ogoni leaders projected the movement to potential backers abroad. At first rejected, the Ogoni reframed the movement to match the substantive, tactical, and organizational concerns of these powerful actors, reducing the costs and increasing the benefits of support. The ultimate effects of third party support were ambiguous, however, though in ways different than predicted by process theory. Shifting from their core issues and undertaking risky mobilizations to attract transnational support, the Ogoni also drew violent state repression which international actors were powerless to stop.
summary: The study titled "Political Process Theory and Transnational Movements: Dialectics of Protest among Nigeria's Ogoni Minority" examines the dynamics of political activism and transnational movements within Nigeria's Ogoni minority community. It likely applies Political Process Theory to understand how the Ogoni people mobilize for their rights and engage in protest actions. The study probably explores the interplay between local and global factors in shaping their protest activities, highlighting the dialectical relationship between the local political context and transnational influences. By analyzing this, the research aims to provide insights into the factors that drive and sustain political mobilization and activism among minority groups like the Ogoni in Nigeria, offering a nuanced perspective on the intersection of local and global forces in shaping protest movements. Specific findings and details would require access to the full study.

headline: Agenda-Setting, Agenda-Reinforcing or Agenda-Deflating? A Study of the 1990 German National Election
article: If an issue is frequently reported in the news, but in a way that diminishes the urgency of the problem, it may cause a decline in salience. In this two-wave national panel study, it was discovered that interest in political stories on television news was positively associated with an increase in the salience of environmental problems as an issue (agenda-reinforcement). Exposure to campaign coverage in Bild, a high circulation national tabloid, was negatively associated with the salience of problems in the former East Germany (agenda deflation). Among other factors, this study finds that the tone of political coverage, as well as its frequency, is important.
summary: The study titled "Agenda-Setting, Agenda-Reinforcing, or Agenda-Deflating? A Study of the 1990 German National Election" likely investigates the role of media in shaping the political agenda during the 1990 German national election. It may analyze whether the media set the agenda by highlighting specific issues, reinforced existing issues, or deflated the importance of certain topics in the election discourse. The study probably uses empirical research to examine media coverage and its impact on public perception and decision-making during this electoral period. By doing so, it aims to provide insights into the media's influence on political agendas and the electoral process in Germany in 1990, shedding light on the media's role in shaping public opinion during elections. Specific findings and details would require access to the full study.

Now the file on the unsavoury incident is with Chief Minister Bangarappa. But he has publicly stated that he has not seen the file, Mean while, the chief secretary's fate still hangs in the balance.
summary: A dispute has erupted in Karnataka involving state Cooperation Minister K.H. Patil and Chief Secretary M. Sankaranarayanan. The matter now rests with Chief Minister Bangarappa, who claims not to have reviewed the file. The chief secretary's fate remains uncertain amidst the controversy. This episode highlights tensions between key figures in the state administration, underscoring issues of transparency and accountability. headline: PM announces sweeping economic reforms
article:
Prime Minister Narasimha Rao and Finance Minister Manmohan Singh today announced a series of sweeping economic reforms in an attempt to pull India out of its worst economic crisis since independence.
 
 The reforms, which include devaluing the rupee, opening up the economy to foreign investment, and cutting government subsidies, are the most radical since the 1960s.
 
 Rao said in a speech to the nation that the reforms were necessary to "save the country from economic ruin."
 
 "We are at the crossroads," he said. "If we do not take these steps now, we will be doomed."
 
 The reforms have been welcomed by business leaders and economists, but they have also been met with opposition from trade unions and some political parties.
 
 The trade unions are concerned that the reforms will lead to job losses and a decline in living standards for the poor.
 
 The opposition parties have accused Rao of selling out to the IMF and the World Bank.
 
 However, Rao has defended the reforms, saying that they are essential to save the country from economic ruin.
 
 "We have no choice," he said. "We have to do this."
 
 The reforms are a gamble, but they are a necessary one. If they are successful, they could transform the Indian economy and make India a major player in the global economy.
summary: In 1991, India faced its worst economic crisis since gaining independence. To address this issue, Prime Minister Narasimha Rao and Finance Minister Manmohan Singh introduced a set of significant economic reforms. These reforms included devaluing the rupee, allowing greater foreign investment, and reducing government subsidies. This move was considered the most drastic measure taken since the 1960s. The aim was to rescue the country from impending financial disaster. Although the reforms received support from business leaders and economists, trade unions and certain political parties opposed them, fearing negative consequences such as job losses and decreased living standards for the poor. Despite the backlash, Rao maintained that the reforms were vital to prevent economic collapse. He acknowledged that the measures might result in difficulties, but believed they were required to ensure the country's future prosperity. Ultimately, the success of these reforms had the potential to revolutionize the Indian economy and establish it as a prominent participant in global commerce.

headline: P. V. Narasimha Rao sworn in as Prime Minister
article:
P. V. Narasimha Rao was sworn in as the Prime Minister of India on Friday, 26 July 1991. He is a member of the Indian National Congress (INC) party.
 
 Rao was elected as the leader of the INC party after the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi in May 1991. He led the INC party to victory in the 1991 general election.
 
 Rao is a senior politician with over 40 years of experience in public life. He has held various positions in the INC party and in the government of India.
 
 Rao is a strong advocate of economic reforms. He is expected to introduce a number of economic reforms to boost the Indian economy.
 
 The swearing-in of Rao as the Prime Minister of India is a significant event in Indian politics. He is the first Prime Minister from the South Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. He is also the first Prime Minister to have a degree in economics.
 
 Rao's swearing-in is also a sign of the changing political landscape in India. The INC party has been in power for most of India's independent history. However, the party is now facing a challenge from the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).
 
 The BJP is a Hindu nationalist party that has been gaining popularity in recent years. The BJP is expected to be the main challenger to the INC party in the next general election.
 
 Rao is a shrewd and experienced politician. He is expected to lead the INC party through this challenging period. He is also expected to implement a number of economic reforms to boost the Indian economy.
 
 The swearing-in of Rao as the Prime Minister of India is a significant event in Indian politics. It remains to be seen how Rao will perform as the Prime Minister. However, his swearing-in is a positive sign for the future of India.
summary: P.V. Narasimha Rao was sworn in as the Prime Minister of India on July 26, 1991, following the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi. Rao, a member of the Indian National Congress (INC) party, had previously served in various positions within the party and government. His appointment marked a significant shift in Indian politics, as he was the first Prime Minister from the southern state of Andhra Pradesh and the first with an economics degree. Rao was known for his support of economic reforms, which he hoped would revitalize the struggling Indian economy. His leadership came at a challenging time, as the INC faced increasing competition from the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), a Hindu nationalist party. Despite these challenges, Rao was expected to guide the INC through this period and implement meaningful economic reforms. His swearing-in ceremony was seen as a positive step forward for India's future.

headline: Hindu youths stand atop the 16th century Babri Mosque in Ayodhya.
article:
The Babri Masjid in Ayodhya was destroyed on 6th December 1992—a quarter of a century and half of my life ago—and yet I can remember it as vividly as if it was yesterday. That dark day shook the very fabric of secular India and proved to be a watershed moment in the country’s history as well my own professional and personal life.
 
 I can still see the thousands of saffron-clad ‘kar sevaks’ clambering atop the 16th century mosque and pounding it with shovels, iron rods, pickaxes and anything they could lay their hands on. I can hear the screeching of Sadhvi Uma Bharti egging them on shouting “ ek dhakka aur do, Babri Masjid tod do ” through the microphones from atop the specially-built watchtower for the BJP/RSS/VHP leadership. I can visualize the three domes of the mosque collapsing inwards one by one at intervals of roughly an hour on that cold, wintery Sunday afternoon.
summary: In the article, the author vividly recalls the traumatic events of December 6, 1992, when the Babri Masjid in Ayodhya, India, was demolished. The destruction of the 16th-century mosque by thousands of saffron-clad 'kar sevaks' is described in detail, along with the provocative speeches by leaders, particularly Sadhvi Uma Bharti. The author reflects on how this dark day profoundly affected both India's secular fabric and their own personal and professional life. The imagery of the mosque's domes collapsing remains seared in the nation's memory, symbolizing a divisive turning point in Indian history. The aftermath saw communal violence and riots across India, deepening religious and political fault lines. Despite the construction of the Ram Janmabhoomi temple at the disputed site, the legacy of December 6, 1992, continues to influence India's socio-political landscape, serving as a reminder of the challenges in maintaining a secular and pluralistic society.

headline: IOC modifies games bidding system
article:
The International Olympic Committee today modified the bidding system for the 2006 winter games in an effort to avoid a repeat of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal.

But a special IOC session, which expelled six members for accepting bribes in Salt Lake City’s successful bid for the 2002 winter Olympics, insisted that all members would retain the right to choose the venue.

The IOC’s executive board had originally wanted to give the final decision on the 2006 games to a smaller selection committee to avoid any possibility of widespread vote-buying by candidate cities.

But faced with a revolt from members who did not want to lose their right to vote, the executive put forward a compromise which was accepted by today’s session.

Under the compromise, the selection committee will shortlist two candidates and the whole membership will then take part in a final vote on the venue.

A vote is scheduled to be taken on the 2006 games in June in Seoul with six candidates for selection - the Swiss town of Sion, Turin in Italy, Helsinki in combination with Lillehammer in Norway, Poland’s Zakopane, Slovakia’s Poprad Tatry and Austria’s Klagenfurt which is fronting a three-country effort with centres in Slovenia and Italy.

Sion and Turin are the current favourites.
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has modified the bidding system for the 2006 winter games to prevent a recurrence of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal. However, the IOC insisted that all members would retain the right to choose the venue. The compromise allows a smaller selection committee to shortlist two candidates, and the entire membership will participate in a final vote on the venue. The change aims to prevent widespread vote-buying by candidate cities. The vote on the 2006 games is scheduled for June, with six candidates in contention.

headline: Risk as Moral Danger: The Social and Political Functions of Risk Discourse in Public Health
article: Risk is a concept with multiple meanings and is ideologically loaded. The author reviews the literature on risk perception and risk as a sociocultural construct, with particular reference to the domain of public health. Pertinent examples of the political and moral function of risk discourse in public health are given. The author concludes that risk discourse is often used to blame the victim, to displace the real reasons for ill-health upon the individual, and to express outrage at behavior deemed socially unacceptable, thereby exerting control over the body politic as well as the body corporeal. Risk discourse is redolent with the ideologies of mortality, danger, and divine retribution. Risk, as it is used in modern society, therefore cannot be considered a neutral term.
summary: The study titled "Risk as Moral Danger: The Social and Political Functions of Risk Discourse in Public Health" investigates how discussions and perceptions of risk are intertwined with moral considerations within the context of public health. It likely explores how risk discourse not only informs public health policies but also serves social and political functions by framing certain behaviors or conditions as morally problematic or acceptable. The study likely delves into the role of risk communication in shaping public attitudes, behaviors, and policy decisions in the realm of public health, shedding light on the complex interplay between risk assessment and moral judgment in this context. Specific findings and insights would require access to the full study.

headline: News Agencies in Post-Communist Russia: From State Monopoly to State Dominance
article: The transformation of Russian news agencies occurred within the general framework of perestroika and the ongoing economic, political and social turmoil of Russian society. This article focuses on the new competitive situation in the Russian news market, examines the origins of private news agencies and identifies the major changes in the position and functions of state-owned agencies. New relationships between news agencies as suppliers and the Russian media as consumers of political news are also examined. The article seeks to shape the importance of financial news for the modern Russian news agencies. These issues are discussed in terms of the economic and organizational problems inherent to the new Russian media scene.
summary: The study titled "News Agencies in Post-Communist Russia: From State Monopoly to State Dominance" examines the role of news agencies in Russia's media landscape following the collapse of the Soviet Union. It likely explores how news agencies transitioned from being controlled by the state during the Soviet era to a situation where the state continues to exert significant influence or dominance over them in the post-communist period. headline: Bombay blasts: 12 accused get death penalty
article:
Twelve accused in the Bombay blasts case were today sentenced to death by the TADA court. The court also awarded life imprisonment to 19 others and acquitted six of the charges.
 
 The accused were convicted of conspiring to carry out the blasts that killed 257 people and injured over 700 on March 12, 1993. The blasts, which targeted prominent landmarks in the city, were the deadliest terrorist attack in India's history.
 
 The TADA court, in its 1,800-page judgment, said that the accused had conspired to carry out the blasts with the intention of creating terror and panic among the people. The court also said that the accused had acted in a "cold-blooded and inhuman manner" and that they deserved the death penalty.
 
 The death sentence for the accused was welcomed by the prosecution and the victims' families. However, some human rights activists criticized the sentence, saying that it was "cruel and unusual punishment."
summary: In a historic verdict, 12 individuals were sentenced to death and 19 others received life imprisonment for their involvement in the devastating Bombay blasts that rocked the city on March 12, 1993. The blasts, which resulted in the loss of 257 lives and injured over 700 people, were the most lethal terrorist attack in India's history. The TADA court delivered a comprehensive 1,800-page judgment, stating that the accused had planned and executed the attacks with the intent to spread fear and terrorize the population. While the prosecution and victim families welcomed the death sentences, some human rights advocates raised concerns about the severity of the punishment. Regardless, the ruling marked a significant moment in India's fight against terrorism and brought a sense of closure to those affected by the tragic event.

headline: Bangladesh records the worst outbreak as dengue cases cross 300,000 mark
article:
Bangladesh is grappling with an alarming surge in dengue fever cases, marking its worst outbreak yet, as media reports indicate the number of cases has surpassed 300,000. According to data sourced from the Directorate General of Health Services and reported by bdnews24.com, the nation has tallied a staggering 301,255 dengue infections and 1,549 deaths attributed to the viral disease in the current year.
On Sunday alone, 1,291 new cases of the viral fever were reported. Currently, hospitals nationwide are treating 4,949 patients, with Dhaka accounting for 1,127 cases.
September witnessed a staggering 79,598 dengue cases and 396 deaths, which followed after August’s 71,976 cases and 342 deaths, marking the highest outbreak. In October, 67,769 cases and 359 deaths were reported.
The first 19 days of November have registered 201 fatalities, accompanied by 30,080 new cases, indicating the persistence of the crisis.
summary: Bangladesh is experiencing its worst dengue fever outbreak to date, with over 300,000 cases and 1,500 deaths reported this year. The outbreak has been particularly severe in September and October, with over 70,000 cases reported each month. The number of cases has continued to rise in November, with over 30,000 new cases reported in the first 19 days of the month. The situation is alarming, and hospitals across the country are struggling to cope with the influx of patients.

headline: The Lion King
article:
The Lion King is a 1994 American animated musical drama film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures. It is inspired by William Shakespeare's stage play Hamlet with some elements from the Biblical stories of Joseph and Moses and Disney's 1942 animated feature film Bambi. The film was directed by Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff (in their feature directorial debuts) and produced by Don Hahn, from a screenplay written by Irene Mecchi, Jonathan Roberts, and Linda Woolverton. The film features an ensemble voice cast that includes Matthew Broderick, James Earl Jones, Jeremy Irons, Jonathan Taylor Thomas, Nathan Lane, Ernie Sabella, Rowan Atkinson, and Robert Guillaume. Its original songs were written by composer Elton John and lyricist Tim Rice, with a score by Hans Zimmer.

Set in a kingdom of lions in Africa, The Lion King tells the story of Simba (Swahili for lion), a lion cub who is to succeed his father, Mufasa, as King of the Pride Lands; however, after his paternal uncle Scar kills Mufasa to seize the throne, Simba is tricked into believing he was responsible for his father's death and flees into exile. After growing up in the company of the carefree outcasts Timon and Pumbaa, Simba receives valuable perspective from his childhood friend, Nala, and his shaman, Rafiki, before returning to challenge Scar to end his tyranny and take his place in the Circle of Life as the rightful king.

The Lion King was released on June 15, 1994, receiving critical acclaim for its music, story, themes, and animation. With an initial worldwide gross of $763 million, it finished its theatrical run as the highest-grossing film of 1994 and the second-highest-grossing film of all time, behind Jurassic Park (1993). It also held the title of being the highest-grossing animated film, until it was overtaken by Finding Nemo (2003). The film remains the highest-grossing traditionally animated film of all time, as well as the best-selling film on home video, having sold over 55 million copies worldwide. It received two Academy Awards, as well as the Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy. It is considered by many to be among the greatest animated films ever made.

The film has led to many derived works, such as a Broadway adaptation in 1997; two direct-to-video follow-ups—the sequel, The Lion King II: Simba's Pride (1998), and the prequel/parallel, The Lion King 1½ (2004); two television series, The Lion King's Timon & Pumbaa (1995-1999) and The Lion Guard (2016-2019), the latter which premiered as a television film titled The Lion Guard: Return of the Roar in 2015; and a photorealistic remake in 2019, which also became the highest-grossing animated film at the time of its release. In 2016, the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". The Lion King is the first Disney film to have been dubbed in Zulu, the only African language aside from Egyptian Arabic to have been used for a feature-length Disney dub.
summary:
"The Lion King" is a famous animated movie made by Disney in 1994. It's a story about a lion cub named Simba who is supposed to become the king of the Pride Lands in Africa. Simba's uncle, Scar, kills Simba's father, Mufasa, to take over as king. Scar tricks Simba into thinking he caused his father's death, and Simba runs away.

Simba grows up with two carefree friends, Timon and Pumbaa. However, Simba's childhood friend, Nala, and a wise baboon named Rafiki help him realize the truth. Simba decides to return, challenge Scar, and take his rightful place as king to end Scar's tyranny.

The movie was a big success and loved for its music, story, and animation. It became the highest-grossing film in 1994 and held the record for the highest-grossing animated film for a long time. "The Lion King" won awards, including two Oscars and a Golden Globe.

The film's popularity led to other projects like a Broadway adaptation, sequels, TV series, and a 2019 photorealistic remake. The 2019 version also became a huge hit.

In 2016, the original "Lion King" was chosen for preservation in the U.S. National Film Registry for its cultural and historical significance. It's the first Disney film dubbed in Zulu, a South African language, showing Disney's commitment to diversity.
