Many people consider "The Lion King" one of the best-animated films ever made, and it continues to be enjoyed by audiences worldwide.

headline: Tax package for ultra-wealthy; redistributive policies needed for poor, lower & middle class: Report
article:
A tax package for the ultra-wealthy in India including an annual wealth tax and an inheritance tax for those with net wealth exceeding Rs 10 crore accompanied by redistributive policies to support the poor, lower castes, and middle classes has been proposed by a report of the World Inequality Lab.

Economists Nitin Kumar Bharti, Lucas Chancel, Thomas Piketty, and Anmol Somanchi in a note released Friday said the tax package proposal can help tackle the massive concentration at the very top of the wealth distribution and create fiscal space for crucial social sector investments. This note follows up on an earlier paper, co-authored by the same economists and released by World Inequality Lab in March, which had stated that India’s top 1 per cent income and wealth shares have reached historical highs and are among the very highest in the world.

The report proposes an annual wealth tax and an inheritance tax for those with net wealth exceeding Rs 10 crore, equivalent to the top 0.04 per cent of the adult population (~370,000 adults), who currently hold over a quarter of the total wealth
summary: A recent report by the World Inequality Lab, authored by economists Nitin Kumar Bharti, Lucas Chancel, Thomas Piketty, and Anmol Somanchi, has proposed a tax package aimed at India's ultra-wealthy. This package includes an annual wealth tax and an inheritance tax targeting individuals with net wealth exceeding Rs 10 crore. The initiative seeks to address the significant wealth concentration at the top, where the top 0.04 percent of the adult population (~370,000 adults) controls over a quarter of India's total wealth.

headline: India circa 1995: The early internet of things
article:
For those who remember it, 1995 was a remarkable year for India. The Narasimha Rao government just had seen off one of the country’s worst financial crises. The country was becoming part of the “global community”, ending decades of inwardness and semi-isolation.

On January 1, the country formally became a member of the World Trade Organization. The Supreme Court ruled that the airwaves belonged to the people of India, and not the government, legitimising a number of private channels that had sprung up since Zee TV started broadcasting in 1992, granting legal access to a wide variety of Western programming — from MASH to music videos. Telecom minister Sukh Ram made the first mobile phone call, to chief minister of West Bengal Jyoti Basu.

It was the year of Mani Ratnam’s Bombay and Aditya Chopra’s Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge. The year MF Hussain fell in love with Madhuri Dixit. It was a time when the superstars ruled the south. This was the year Rajinikanth’s Baashha, of Mammootty’s The King, of Mohan Babu (and Rajinikanth again) in Pedarayudu.

It was the year of Windows 95. It was also the year the internet came to India.

For digital natives — pretty much any middle-class person born after that year — it may be hard to imagine what the internet looked like back then. You had to fill out an application and submit it to the nearest VSNL office, which might be several suburbs away. In due course, a man would arrive and install a splice on your telephone cable, and connect it to your phone. He would then write your user ID and password on a piece of paper, which you would then keep next to your monitor. And then you would try to dial up to the internet.

It’s hard to explain the feeling of going online then, especially in today’s world where everything from fridges to aquariums are connected to the internet. There was a feeling of wonder, a feeling of entering “a whole new world, a new fantastic point of view”. It truly was a magic carpet ride — though the carpet does seem threadbare and strikingly garish from a 2021 perspective. Still, there was this feeling of excitement, of remarkable things about to happen.

Consider this. In 1996, the hottest thing was this new programming language called Java, which allowed users to run small programs called “applets” within their browser. Netscape Navigator was the software that was going to change the way the world worked, and the business press celebrated Netscape’s model of giving their browser away for free (so that they could sell their high-priced web servers). Microsoft, which famously ramped up the number of people working on its browser and internet software from two in 1995 to over a thousand in 1996, released Internet Explorer 3.

There were forums, Usenet groups where people discussed topics threadbare and where the banhammer was wielded swiftly and mercilessly by moderators. One could stumble into a hilarious parody of Atlas Shrugged on the Robert Jordan fan group, or find Terry Pratchett discussing the joys of shooting aliens with a double-barrelled shotgun in the videogame Doom. Or find oneself on GameFAQs, looking up strategies for dealing with The Lion King’s infamous waterfall level.

There were the personal pages, created on AngelFire or GeoCities or Tripod, full of bright colours, blinking text and pictures – the kind that would give usability guru Jakob Nielsen an aneurysm. These websites had “guestbooks” where visitors were asked to provide feedback, and visitor counters, bragging rights for popularity. And there was porn. Lots and lots of porn. And pioneering priestess Danni Ashe’s website that offered a few glossy images of top-heavy models and promised further delights upon payment of a monthly fee.

This was a pre-Google world, where Yahoo ruled, and services like AltaVista, Lycos, HotBot and Excite were where one went for information, and more often than not ended up on a magical mystery tour.

Yes, things are much better now. More people than ever are connected and online. It’s changed the way we live and work, and the net’s ubiquity has cushioned the impact of the pandemic. But somehow, if you lived through those days, thinking back to that time only gives you a feeling of something lost. Perhaps the idea of, at some point, logging out.
summary:
For those who remember it, 1995 was a remarkable year for India.
It’s hard to explain the feeling of going online then, especially in today’s world where everything from fridges to aquariums are connected to the internet.
There was a feeling of wonder, a feeling of entering “a whole new world, a new fantastic point of view”.
Still, there was this feeling of excitement, of remarkable things about to happen.
Microsoft, which famously ramped up the number of people working on its browser and internet software from two in 1995 to over a thousand in 1996, released Internet Explorer

headline: India's population crosses 900 million
article:
India's population crossed 900 million on Thursday, according to the Census of India. The country's population has grown by 215 million in the last decade, a growth rate of 23.5%.
 
 The growth of India's population is a major challenge for the country. The government is struggling to provide basic necessities such as food, water, and shelter to its people. The rapid population growth is also putting a strain on the country's resources and infrastructure.
 
 The government is taking steps to control the population growth. However, these steps are yet to have a significant impact.
 
 The rapid population growth is a major challenge for India. It is important to address this challenge in order to ensure a better future for the country and its people.
summary: India's population crossed 900 million in 1995. This was a major milestone in the country's history. The rapid population growth is a major challenge for India. The government is struggling to provide basic necessities such as food, water, and shelter to its people. The rapid population growth is also putting a strain on the country's resources and infrastructure.

headline: Shiv Sena wins Maharashtra assembly elections
article:
The Shiv Sena, led by Bal Thackeray, won the Maharashtra assembly elections, defeating the Congress party, which had been in power in the state for over 30 years. The Shiv Sena won 73 seats in the 288-member assembly, while the Congress won 89 seats. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won 12 seats.
 
 The Shiv Sena's victory is a major setback for the Congress party, which had ruled Maharashtra for most of its history. The Shiv Sena's victory is also seen as a victory for Hindu nationalism.
 
 The Shiv Sena is a Hindu nationalist party that was founded in 1966. The party is known for its anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant rhetoric. The Shiv Sena has also been accused of violence against Muslims and other minorities.
 
 The Shiv Sena's victory in the Maharashtra assembly elections is a reminder of the growing power of Hindu nationalism in India. It is also a reminder of the importance of secularism and pluralism in India.
summary:
The Shiv Sena's victory in the 1995 Maharashtra assembly elections was a significant event in Indian politics. It was the first time that a Hindu nationalist party had won power in a major Indian state. The Shiv Sena's victory was seen as a setback for the Congress party, which had ruled Maharashtra for most of its history.
 
 The Shiv Sena's victory was also seen as a sign of the growing power of Hindu nationalism in India. The Shiv Sena is a Hindu nationalist party that is known for its anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant rhetoric. The Shiv Sena has also been accused of violence against Muslims and other minorities.
 
 The Shiv Sena's victory in the 1995 Maharashtra assembly elections is a reminder of the importance of secularism and pluralism in India. It is also a reminder of the dangers of Hindu nationalism.

headline: Celebrating 100 years of Ramnad Krishnan
article: At a time when musicians like GN Balasubramaniam and Semmangudi Srinivasa Iyer were ruling the music scene, a rather unassuming musician,Ramnad Krishnan, came into the picture. Though he was heavily influenced by GNB and VeenaiDhanammal’s style of music, he created his own musical expression that struck a chord with many. Born on September 14, 1918, his music still resonates with young musicians of today.For his centenary year, which from today, his son RK Ramanathan has lined up concerts by musicians every month until next year, to celebrateKrishnanand the impact he has created with his music.“It is amazing whenever I hear young musicians talking about him or using his style of singing in their renditions. If my father can have this impact even during his 100th year, it needs to be celebrated, right?” begins Ramanathan, who, even though took up a career in pharmaceutical, says that he constantly listens to his father’s music to keep the tradition alive.Stories about how Krishnan was a perfectionist, and unabashedly vocal about promoting the traditional way of singing without diluting the essence are many. No wonder he is regarded as an iconic role model by many young musicians today. “My father comes from a family of musicians. He had six brothers, of which Lakshminarayanan and Venkatachalam were trained in violin, Eashwaran andRaghavanwere trained in mridangam, and my father was trained in vocal music. All of them learnt under Madurai Sankarasivam. He was already doing concerts in Ramnad, but he moved to Chennai when he was around 18 years old to become a full-fledged musician. He was attracted to GNB’s style of singing and was a regular at his concerts. Subsequently, he happened to be exposed to Veena Dhanammal through his friend Mottu Krishnaswamy Iyengar (a direct disciple of Kanchipuram Naina Pillai).He was awestruck by the way she played the veenai. He wanted to expand his style of music and was then introduced to T Brindha and T Muktha, who were the foremost representatives of Dhanammal’s school of music. He started picking up their bani and they imparted their knowledge about the style to him.”Around this time, Krishnan was already becoming famous for his style of music. His rendering of ragas, notably Begada and Sahana, and ragas like Umabaranam andNayaki, among others, were unique. He was even called Sahana Krishnan by many. “Musician Jon B Higgins, who was learning under flautist T Viswanathan, was asked to learn from my father when he was doing his post-graduation in Carnatic music,” recollects Ramanathan, adding, “He had the best of everything. He was an A-grade artiste in All India Radio and performed to full houses. He even had the opportunity to move to the US for two years. But my father came back in three months, saying, ‘I was born to sing to people who understand our music’.”When he was around 35, he was regarded as one of the top musicians of Madras. “He was strong, but at the same time, he had a soft personality. I was amazed when he decided to come back from the USA, even though he knew he could have earned more money there. But he would get emotional for the smallest of things and had a child-like behaviour,” reminisces Ramanathan.Krishnan’s terrific sense of humour and punctuality are qualities that many from that generation remember even today. Ramananthan says, “He was quite adamant, too. He would never budge for audience’s likes when he was performing. He would never go for the ‘popular song’ as he believed that the audience must be exposed to the traditional and purest music. He was the torch-bearer of tradition. And for this reason, not just music connoisseurs, even many musicians used to attend his concert.
summary: Ramnad Krishnan, a musician born on September 14, 1918, left a lasting impact on the world of Carnatic music. Influenced by GN Balasubramaniam and Veenai Dhanammal's styles, Krishnan created his unique musical expression that continues to inspire young musicians today. His son, RK Ramanathan, has organized monthly concerts by musicians to celebrate Krishnan's centenary year. Krishnan was known for his perfectionism, dedication to tradition, and his ability to captivate audiences with ragas like Begada and Sahana. Despite opportunities to perform abroad, he chose to sing for those who understood the essence of Carnatic music.

headline: Banks take on HDFC, ICICI in loan war
article:
the recent interest rate cut by hdfc and icici has sparked off a fresh battle among the home loan lenders. banks are now aggressively entering the home loan segment — traditionally the bastion of hdfc, icici and hudco. take, for instance, newcomer standard chartered, which has reduced its interest to a fixed 12.3 per cent on daily-reducing-balance basis (from 12.8 per cent) for a 15-year loan period. company officials said that the cost works out cheaper than hsbc, citibank, hdfc, icici among others, but is at par with what is being charged by state bank of india. while the emi charged by sbi and stanchart works out to rs 1220 for
a rs 100,000 loan (15-year period), hdfc charges Rs 1,224, lic Rs 1,240, hsbc Rs 1,231, icici Rs 1,240. emi for both hdfc and icici is higher because the interest rate is levied on annual-rest basis. ''this is the best value for money a buyer can get,'' avers harpreet singh, head (secured loans) stantard chartered. meanwhile, home loan biggies hdfc and icici —which, between them, control little over half the market share —said that reduction in emi by few rupees won't impact them. currently they are adding customers who are refinancing home loans from lic. while cheap interest rates still dominates a customer's decision to choose a
lending institution, for the first-time banks are battling it out by developing innovative additions. hsbc, for instance, has designed a flexible interest rate package in which customers have the option to move from free to fixed in the beginning of the year. and idbi bank allows the brokerage fee to be added to the loan sanction amount. also, most of the players have waived administrative or processing fees during this festive season. many of them are also issuing personal loans to customers for the remaining 10 or 15 per cent, as they can provide normally 80 to 85 per cent for home loans. banks are also rolling out special housing loan branches to service customers. ''there is a chaos in the home loan mart. the consumers have a wide range of option but have to closely look at hidden costs before choosing the lender,'' warns ac varma, deputy gm at sbi. ''our offer still works out to be the best in the market. we have no hidden cost and disclose each and every rupee that we levy from the customer,'' he adds. the hidden cost in a home loan includes cost of phone calls made by the lender to the customer, costs for sending reminder notice, levying exorbitant fee when a cheque bounces or expenses of a representative visiting the customer. ''the customers are getting the best of the benefits. if all tax concessions are adjusted for, the net rate of interest on home loan will be in the region of just 7 to 8 per cent,'' said harsh roonta, ceo apnaloan.
summary:
The recent interest rate reduction by HDFC and ICICI has ignited a fierce competition among home loan lenders in India, challenging the traditional dominance of HDFC, ICICI, and HUDCO in the sector. New entrants like Standard Chartered have aggressively entered the market, offering competitive fixed interest rates. For instance, Standard Chartered now provides a 12.3% interest rate for a 15-year loan period, competing favorably with State Bank of India.

Banks are striving to attract customers with innovative features, such as HSBC's flexible interest rate package, allowing customers to switch from floating to fixed rates. Many lenders have waived administrative fees and are offering personal loans to cover the remaining portion of home purchases.

However, consumers must be cautious about hidden costs associated with home loans, such as phone call charges, reminder notices, and bounced check fees. Despite the fierce competition and complexities, experts believe that, considering tax concessions, the net interest rate on home loans could potentially be as low as 7 to 8 percent.

newspaper_name: Rs 385 cr for Uttaranchal road projects
headline: Rs 385 cr for Uttaranchal road projects
article: The government has sanctioned rs 385 crore for road projects in uttaranchal during the current financial year, and is considering doubling of the grant under the pradhan mantri gram Sarak yojana to rs 120 crore in 2001-02 for the state. "under the Pradhan mantri gram Sarak yojana, an amount of rs 60 crore was sanctioned during 2000-01 for development of rural roads in Uttaranchal. Efforts have been made to enhance it to over rs 120 crore in the current year," minister of state for road transport and highways B C khanduri said. the bonanza comes on the eve of the assembly elections which are slated to be held early next year. as a prelude to the elections, the Vajpayee government recently replaced nityanand swami with koshiyari as the chief minister of Uttaranchal. congratulating the people of uttaranchal on the occasion of first anniversary of the formation of the state, khanduri said all efforts would be made to increase the pace of development and progress there. an official statement, listing the initiatives taken by khanduri's ministry for road development in uttaranchal, said all the four dhams of yamnotri, gangotri, kedarnath and badrinath are connected by national highways. For the national highways in the state, rs 265 crore has allocated for the current year. it includes the double-laning of the rishikesh-joshimath-badrinath-mana section of nh-58. the satpuli-kotdwar-nazibabad road and haldwani-kaladhungi- bazpur-moradabad road would be developed under the inter-state connectivity scheme, the release added. in the hillstate of uttaranchal, people in remote districts like uttarkashi, chamoli and pithoragarh have to walk more than 20 km to reach the nearest motorable way.
summary: The government has allocated Rs 385 crore for road projects in Uttarakhand for the current fiscal year and is considering doubling the grant under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sarak Yojana to Rs 120 crore in 2001-02. The move comes ahead of the upcoming assembly elections in the state. Minister of State for Road Transport and Highways B.C. Khanduri announced these developments while celebrating the first anniversary of the state's formation. He emphasized the commitment to accelerating development and progress in Uttarakhand. The road development initiatives include connecting the four dhams (Yamunotri, Gangotri, Kedarnath, and Badrinath) with national highways, allocating Rs 265 crore for national highways, and doubling the lanes of the Rishikesh-Joshimath-Badrinath-Mana section of NH-58. Additionally, remote areas in districts like Uttarkashi, Chamoli, and Pithoragarh will benefit from improved road connectivity.

headline: HT This Day: December 24, 1995 -- Over 305 killed in Haryana fire
article:
The fire broke out around 2pm at the Rajiv Marriage Palace which had been hired by the school management for the annual day function. A joyous function was turned into a tragedy.
Chandigarh: The worst tragedy struck the market town of Mandi Dabwali in district Sirsa of Haryana this afternoon when 312 persons, most of them school children, were burnt alive. Over 350 people, again most of them students of the DAV Public School, suffered grave burn injuries.
They have been shifted to hospitals in Sirsa (47). PGI Chandigarh (20), Ludhiana (10), Bathinda (30), Hisar and Abohar.

Wrap up the year gone by & gear up for 2024 with HT! Click here
Unofficial reports however, received here put the death toll at 400.

According to information reaching here, the fire broke out around 2 pm at the Rajiv Marriage Palace which had been hired by the school management for the annual day function. A joyous function was turned into a tragedy.

Meanwhile Haryana Director General of Police Kalyan Rudra told PTI in Chandigarh that the cause of the devastating fire was a short circuit in the “kanat” of the shamiana where annual function of the DAV School Dabwali was being held.

The short circuiting on the roof of the tented structure led to the fire which quickly engulfed the nylon fabric of the tent This led to the collapse of the structure, Mr Rudra said adding some of the dead were electrocuted while others were asphyxiated.Meanwhile, an LPG cylinder exploded as the fire spread engulfing the area, he said.

Some eyewitnesses said the fire broke out due to an acrobatic fire show by students of the school.

Mr Rudra said he was leaving for Dabwali for an on the spot assessment of the situation.

Deputy Commissioner Sirsa M.P Bidlan said he had left the place a little before 2pm along with other officers of the district as well as the Sub Divisional Magistrate.

The place was packed to the capacity with more than 1,200 people, including students, their parents, members of the staff and other participants.

SDM of Sirsa Mr Somnath Kamboj who suffered 90 percent burn injuries was rushed to Hisar hospital. where he succumbed to his injuries, while his wife died in the mishap.Among the injured were the Deputy Superintendent of Police, his wife and daughter. They, along with 60 others seriously burnt cases, have been shifted to the PGI hospital here. According to PGl s senior doctors, emergency arrangements have been made to take care of the serious cases.

According to the local residents. the Rajiv Marriage Palace was over crowded with students and others. The tents rapidly caught fire and made the exit of the people nearly impossible. Unfortunately, there were no arrangements to fight the fire except the one municipal fire tender. He fire tenders, which were rushed from Abohar and Sirsa. could do little to mitigate the tragedy.

There were heart-rending scenes as a large number of burnt children and elders were crying for help. Relatives were rushing helter-skelter to locate their kith and kin.Reports from Dabwali also said that social and political organisations are rushing all help and taking the injured to the hospitals.

The venue of the annual day function was totally gutted within an hour and the rescue operations became very difficult. The stampede that followed the fire crushed many small children.

Among those seriously injured were DSP Anil Yadav, his family and freedom fighter Gurdev Singh Shant, local politician Keshav Singh and journalist Jai Muni Goel, police added.

Sources said that the death toll was likely to go up further as the retrieval operations were still in progress at the site.

Senior district officials have reached Dabwali and were supervising rescue and relief operations there.The local residents beelined at the hospital to donate blood for the injured, doctors said.

Two local philanthropists - Hanstaj Thutalia and Rahul Sethia have announced that they would bear full expenses for the treatment of the injured.

Meanwhile Union Minister of State for Education Selja rushed to Mandi Dabwali, which is her constituency.

It is indeed the worst tragedy that has struck Haryana. According to Additional Director General of Police H. Y Hari Shankar, who rushed to Dabwali along with police chief Kalyan Rudra. said “such a devastating fire has never broken out in the State it is too deep a tragedy for tears Small children have just been roasted alive.”

Information and Public Relations Secretary Anil Razdan said that Chief Minister Bhajan Lal expressed his heartfelt sympathy and rushed to Dabwali around 7pm. He said that initial reports were sketchy, but later the death toll was confirmed.
summary: A fire broke out at the Rajiv Marriage Palace in Mandi Dabwali, district Sirsa, Haryana, causing 312 people, mostly school children, to be burnt alive. Over 350 people, mostly students of the DAV Public School, suffered grave burn injuries. The fire was caused by a short circuit in the "kanat" of the shamiana where the annual function of the DAV School Dabwali was being held. The tents rapidly caught fire, making the exit nearly impossible. Local residents reported that the venue was overcrowded, and the tents rapidly caught fire, making it difficult to evacuate people. The stampede that followed the fire crushed many small children. DSP Anil Yadav, his family, freedom fighter Gurdev Singh Shant, local politician Keshav Singh, and journalist Jai Muni Goel were among the seriously injured. Unofficial reports put the death toll at 400.

headline: Justice J.S. Verma: A stickler for judicial discipline
article:
With his wife and grandchildren at his home: A limited social life
On a Sunday afternoon last fortnight, J.S. Verma was patience personified as he played with his grandchildren at his Janpath residence. As three-year-old Anirudh insisted that he had seen "a ghost in the sky", Verma lifted him onto his lap and began explaining to him in detail why there could be no ghosts. But the child was not convinced, so doting grandfather repeated the entire explanation with a great deal of patience.

As much a family man as a stickler for judicial discipline. Verma has a limited social life - of his own volition. He and his wife have two daughters, one settled in Delhi, the other in UK. Verma turns emotional while recalling his memories of his father. Nearly four decades ago, when he was practising in his hometown Satna in Madhya Pradesh, his father, a retired railway employee, wanted to file a suit and asked his son to represent him. But Verma not only declined to appear as his counsel, he refused to even draft the plaint, a decision that shocked and upset his father. Verma says he saw a potential conflict of interests.

Verma hasn't changed his stand. He still has strong views on judicial ethics; for him, it's not just an intellectual concept but almost an obsession. One that has drawn charges that the judge wears his principled nature on his sleeve.
Surprising for one who came into the legal field by default.

As a young man, Verma had set his heart on joining the armed forces. But discouraged by objections from his mother, he took up law on his father's suggestion. A student of Allahabad University, Verma joined the legal profession in 1955 and, in 1972, before he had turned 40, was appointed a judge in the Madhya Pradesh High Court. Later, he was to become the chief justice of the Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan high courts from 1985 to 1989 successively.

As a Supreme Court judge, Verma gained national prominence for the first time in 1991 when he was appointed as the head of the probe into the security lapses that led to Rajiv Gandhi's assassination. He completed the inquiry in just 15 months - without missing his regular court duties.

Verma is due to take over as the next chief justice of India in March 1997 and hold office for 10 months. Though he is currently the third-senior most judge in the Supreme Court, he is actually the longest serving, having lost out on seniority because of his elevation to the Supreme Court as late as June 1989, much after many of his juniors from other states.

Some lawyers say his several bold rulings against the Government and politicians could have delayed his promotion. Whatever the reason, the one-time lawyer from Satna seems to have come to the nation's apex court with a resolve to make up for lost time by setting for himself a blistering pace of work.
summary:
J.S. Verma, a prominent figure in the Indian legal field, is known for his dedication to both his family and judicial principles. With a limited social life, he prioritizes spending time with his grandchildren and cherishes family moments. His commitment to ethical judicial conduct is unwavering, leading to accusations that he overtly displays his principled nature.

Verma's path to the legal profession was not his initial choice; he aspired to join the armed forces but ended up pursuing law due to his father's suggestion. He commenced his legal career in 1955 and quickly rose through the ranks. He served as a judge in the Madhya Pradesh High Court, becoming the chief justice of both the Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan high courts.

In 1991, Verma gained national recognition when he led the inquiry into the security lapses that led to the assassination of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. He completed this significant investigation within 15 months while fulfilling his regular court duties.

Despite being the longest-serving judge in the Supreme Court, Verma was not promoted to the highest position until 1997, potentially due to his bold rulings against the government and politicians. Nevertheless, he is determined to make up for lost time and set a rapid pace of work as he prepares to become the next Chief Justice of India.

This summary highlights J.S. Verma's commitment to his family, unwavering dedication to judicial ethics, and his remarkable career in the legal field.

headline: Prime minister Deve Gowda's key firefighters
article:
The 48-year-old minister for Information and Broadcasting from Karnataka is Deve Gowda's special confidant and has 24-hour access to him. Being multilingual, Ibrahim's proficiency in Hindi and Urdu has come in handy in Deve Gowda's dealings with leaders of the north.

He has been winning friends and influencing people on Deve Gowda's behalf - calling on an ailing Mayawati in Madras, introducing Deve Gowda to the influential moderate Muslim leader Ali Mian, arranging a meeting with kisan leader Mahendra Singh Tikait and, incredibly, even coaxing Bal Thackeray to sing Deve Gowda's praises. His current tasks: ensuring a "secular" alliance to fight the BJP in Uttar Pradesh and Farooq Abdullah's participation in the J&K assembly polls.
summary: The 48-year-old Information and Broadcasting Minister from Karnataka, Ibrahim, is a close confidant of Prime Minister Deve Gowda with round-the-clock access to him. Multilingual and skilled in Hindi and Urdu, Ibrahim plays a key role in Deve Gowda's outreach to northern leaders. He has built alliances by meeting figures like Mayawati, Ali Mian, and Mahendra Singh Tikait, and even gained Bal Thackeray's support. Tasked with forming a secular alliance against the BJP in Uttar Pradesh and securing Farooq Abdullah's participation in the J\&K polls, Ibrahim is a crucial behind-the-scenes operator in national political strategy.

headline: Priyadarshini Mattoo case: Chronology of events
article:
The Supreme Court on Wednesday awarded life sentence to former IPS officer’s son Santosh Singh in the 14-year-old rape and murder case of law student Priyadarshini Mattoo.

Following is the chronology of events in the sensational case:-

* Jan 23,1996: Priyadarshini Mattoo raped and killed by Santosh Kumar Singh. Delhi Police register the FIR.

* Jan 25,1996: Case handed over to CBI. Agency registers case.
* Apr 11,1996: CBI files chargesheet in the case against Santosh Singh.

* Jun 20,1996: Date of committal of the case to Additional Sessions Judge General B B Chowdhury.

* Aug 29,1996: Charges framed.

* Aug 11,1997: Trial starts in the court of Additional Sessions Judge S C Mittal.

* Jan 3,1998: Prosecution evidence closes. 50 witnesses examined by the court. No defence witness.

* Apr 18,1998: Arguments closed in the case but was marred by a controversy of allegations of money changing hands ahead of judgement. The case transferred to ASJ G P Thareja.

* Apr 21,1998: Case admitted by Thareja

* Jun 1,1998: Thareja summons two prosecution witnesses — Inspector Lalit Mohan of Delhi Police and Prof G V Rao of Microbiological Centre.

* Jun 1,1998: CBI submits case diaries in court.

* Nov 30,1998: ASJ Thareja begins hearing defence and prosecution witnesses.

* Mar 31,1999: Examination of witnesses closes.

* Dec 3,1999: ASJ Thareja delivers judgement; Santosh Singh acquitted; CBI lashed for shoddy investigation.

* Feb 29,2000: CBI appeals in Delhi High Court.

* Apr 26,2000: High Court admits appeal.

* Oct 17,2000: High Court issues bailable warrant against Santosh Singh.

* Dec 17,2001: CBI files appeal for early hearing before High Court.

* Nov 25,2002: CBI files application before High Court for early hearing.

* Feb 14,2003: Accused files application for inspection of files.

* Mar 25,2003: High Court dismisses the application.

* Jul 22,2006: CBI files another application for early hearing.

* Jul 28,2006: Delhi High Court fixes August 31 as date for hearing.

* Aug 31,2006: High Court orders daily hearings in the case.

* Sept 27,2006: High Court reserves judgement in the case. CBI seeks action against five Delhi Police officials.

* Oct 17,2006: High Court convicts Santosh Singh for raping and killing Priyadarshini Mattoo.

* Oct 30,2006: Santosh Singh given death sentence by Delhi High Court.

* Jan 23,2007: Santosh Singh challenges conviction and death sentence in Supreme Court.

* Feb 19,2007: Supreme Court admits Santosh Singh’s appeal against High Court verdict and stays death sentence.

* Jul,2010: Day-to-day hearing on the appeal.

* Jul 29,2010: Judgement reserved.

* Oct 6,2010: SC upholds the conviction of Santosh Singh,but commutes the death penalty into life term.
summary:
Here is the chronology of events in the Priyadarshini Mattoo rape and murder case:

- Jan 23, 1996: Priyadarshini Mattoo raped and killed by Santosh Kumar Singh, son of a former IPS officer. FIR registered by Delhi Police.
- Jan 25, 1996: Case transferred to CBI.
- Apr 11, 1996: CBI files chargesheet against Santosh Singh.
- Aug 11, 1997: Trial begins.
- Jan 3, 1998: Prosecution evidence closes.
- Apr 18, 1998: Controversy erupts over alleged bribery ahead of judgment; case transferred to another judge.
- Dec 3, 1999: Santosh Singh acquitted due to perceived flaws in CBI investigation.
- Feb 29, 2000: CBI appeals in Delhi High Court.
- Oct 17, 2000: High Court issues bailable warrant against Santosh Singh.
- Oct 17, 2006: High Court convicts Santosh Singh of rape and murder.
- Oct 30, 2006: Santosh Singh sentenced to death.
- Jan 23, 2007: Santosh Singh appeals to Supreme Court.
- Feb 19, 2007: Supreme Court stays death sentence.
- Jul, 2010: Day-to-day hearing on appeal begins.
- Oct 6, 2010: Supreme Court upholds conviction but commutes death penalty to life imprisonment.

headline: 72-year-old widow, a vegetable seller, offers 10 lakh to Raipur welfare hospital
article:
If you go shopping for vegetables in Raipur's main market, you probably wouldn't pay the lady much attention. Buy some onions from her, tomatoes, cauliflower maybe. But Binni Bai Sonkar has more beans than anyone bargained for - and nobody is complaining about the price.

The 72-year-old widow has offered to the newly formed Patient Welfare Committee of the industrial hub's 700-bed medical college hospital a sum: Rs 10 lakh. More than what the entire city had put together.

Faced with a funds crunch, welfare committees were set up in all major state-run hospitals last year, and private and corporate donations were invited for basic maintenance and sheltering visitors. Binni Bai heard about the plea, and sympathised.

"My heart goes out to the relatives of patients whom I see cooking in the open and sleeping in the corridors of the hospital," she explains. So when a few months ago, sale of ancestral property brought some money in, she combined that some with her life savings to help out in a way that left people stunned. But not speechless.

The Government recently organised a function in Raipur to felicitate Binni Bai, where Chief Minister Digvijay Singh tried, a little lamely, to reciprocate the gesture. "We will include her in the VIP list of Raipur and give her a monthly pension of Rs 1,000."

Binni Bai refused both offers. "I can spend the rest of my life on salt and chutney," demurred the soft-spoken lady. She has a married daughter who has no eyes, she says, for her mother's money. And till she can, she will sell vegetables. Pluck.
summary: Binni Bai Sonkar, a 72-year-old widow from Raipur, has donated Rs 10 lakh to the Patient Welfare Committee of the city's 700-bed medical college hospital. The donation, more than the entire city's contribution, aims to address the hospital's funds crunch. Binni Bai, moved by the plight of patients' relatives cooking and sleeping in hospital corridors, combined the proceeds from the sale of ancestral property with her life savings to make the generous donation. Despite offers from the government, she declined any personal benefits, emphasizing her commitment to selling vegetables for a living.

headline: Attack on old woman shocks city
article:
AHMEDABAD: Barely 48 hours after an elderly woman was murdered in the Sabarmati area here, an assault on a 62-year-old woman left residents of Paldi shocked.

She was stabbed and bound and gagged in her bungalow on Wednesday by assailants who fled with ornaments and cash.

Bhadra Shah, a resident of Paldi, was saved as her daughter returned home soon after. "Shah was gagged with a saree tied to her neck which was constricting her wind pipe at her residence on Nav Vikas Gruh Road,"said assistant commissioner of police RS Chudasama.
On Monday, Chandra Dave, 61, was murdered at her residence in Sabarmati area. The police are yet to make any headway in the case. Police believe loot was the motive in this case too.


Shah���s husband, a civil contractor, and her daughter, who was staying with her for the past two days, were away when she was attacked.

One of the goons stabbed Shah, injuring her left hand. A knife was recovered from the spot.

One of the goons held her tight while the other blindfolded her with a saree and tied another saree around her neck. Shah fell unconscious as the goons rummaged through her house.
Around this time, Bijal returned home and on hearing the sound of her car, the assailants fled.
summary:
In Ahmedabad, a shocking assault on a 62-year-old woman, Bhadra Shah, occurred just 48 hours after another elderly woman was murdered in the Sabarmati area. Shah was attacked in her bungalow, stabbed, bound, and gagged by assailants who fled with valuables and cash. Fortunately, Shah's daughter returned home soon after, potentially saving her life. Assistant Commissioner of Police RS Chudasama reported that Shah was found gagged with a saree tied around her neck, causing constriction to her windpipe.

The incident follows the murder of 61-year-old Chandra Dave in Sabarmati, with police suspecting a similar motive of robbery. Shah's husband, a civil contractor, and her daughter were not present during the attack. Shah sustained injuries to her left hand from the stabbing, and the assailants fled upon hearing the daughter's arrival. Despite the recovery of a knife from the scene, the police have not made any significant progress in solving the case. The incidents have left residents of Paldi and Sabarmati deeply alarmed, highlighting concerns over safety and security in the area.

headline: Top BMC official in dock
article:
MUMBAI: A writ petition was filed in Bombay high court on Tuesday against assistant municipal commissioner of H (west) ward Anil Khoje, holding him responsible for violation of development control regulations in the Bandra (W) ward office premises at Hill Road.

Civic activist Edwin Britto stated in his petition that the local ward office enclosed the compulsory open space in its premises.
As per the DC rules for reasons of safety, a minimum mandatory 20 feet space has to be left around public buildings on all sides.

"The work of constructing permanent structures totalling 1,500 sq mts was carried out in three phases, the last being in March 2005. The violation is not solely in the ward office premises but has been allowed all over Bandra (west).


Many restaurants have come up in the past five years on the compulsory open space in violation of the development control rules,"said Britto.

Even now, a 2000 sq mt structure is under construction in the compulsory open space between Union Bank and Mandar Nursing home at Turner Road in Bandra. "The local ward office turns a blind eye to these constructions.

Many restaurants like Motimahal, Zaika, Stomach and Tawa have encroached on compulsory open spaces. Once the structure is built, the BMC issues them a showcause notice for which the other party gets a stay from the court and action remains suspended for ever,"added Britto.

While Khoje was unavailable for comment, deputy municipal commissioner Vijay Kalam Patil said: "It is up to the local ward office to serve a notice under Section 354 of the BMC Act to initiate demolition action if the construction is found to be unauthorised.

It is difficult to take action once the construction is completed."
summary: A writ petition was filed in the Bombay High Court against Assistant Municipal Commissioner Anil Khoje, accusing him of allowing violations of development control regulations in the Bandra (West) ward office premises. Civic activist Edwin Britto alleged that the ward office had enclosed compulsory open space, contrary to safety regulations mandating a minimum 20 feet space around public buildings. Britto highlighted constructions totaling 1,500 sq mts, dating back to March 2005, and ongoing violations across Bandra (West), including the emergence of restaurants on open spaces. Despite Britto's claims, Anil Khoje was unavailable for comment, while Deputy Municipal Commissioner Vijay Kalam Patil suggested that once constructions were completed, it became challenging to take action. Britto criticized the BMC's approach, noting a cycle where the BMC issued show cause notices, followed by court stays, perpetuating impunity. The petition underscores concerns over lax enforcement of regulations and potential collusion between authorities and violators, indicating systemic challenges in ensuring compliance with development regulations.

headline: Explained | What is China’s One Country Two Systems policy?
article:
Protests in Hong Kong, now in its 13th consecutive week, have brought a decades-old policy of the People’s Republic of China back into focus — One Country Two Systems.

The protesters, who started occupying the city’s streets in April after the local government proposed a controversial extradition law, say Beijing is trying to violate this policy by infringing on Hong Kong’s autonomy. They want China to end its interference, while Beijing has likened the protesters to terrorists and have said that it won’t tolerate any challenge to its sovereignty over Hong Kong.

So, what’s this One Country Two Systems approach?

Origin of policy
To put it simply, it means that the Hong Kong and Macau Special Administrative Regions, both former colonies, can have different economic and political systems from that of mainland China, while being part of the People’s Republic of China.

The One Country Two Systems policy was originally proposed by Deng Xiaoping shortly after he took the reins of the country in the late 1970s. Deng’s plan was to unify China and Taiwan under the One Country Two Systems policy. He promised high autonomy to Taiwan. China’s nationalist government, which was defeated in a civil war by the communists in 1949, had been exiled to Taiwan. Under Deng’s plan, the island could follow its capitalist economic system, run a separate administration and keep its own army but under Chinese sovereignty. Taiwan, however, rejected the Communist Party’s offer.

The island has since been run as a separate entity from the mainland China, though Beijing never gave up its claim over Taiwan.

Return of colonial territories
The idea of two systems in one country resurfaced when Beijing started talks with Britain and Portugal, who were running Hong Kong and Macau, respectively.

The British had taken control of Hong Kong in 1842 after the First Opium War. In 1898, the British government and the Qing dynasty of China signed the Second Convention of Peking, which allowed the British to take control of the islands surrounding Hong Kong, known as New Territories, on lease for 99 years. London promised Peking that the islands would be retuned to China after the expiry of the lease, in 1997. Macau, on the other side, had been ruled by the Portuguese from 1557. They started withdrawing troops in the mid-1970s.

In the 1980s, Deng’s China initiated talks with both Britain and Portugal for the transfer of the two territories. In talks, Beijing promised to respect the region's autonomy under the One Country Two Systems proposal. On December 19, 1984, China and the U.K. signed the Sino-British Joint Declaration in Beijing, which set the terms for the autonomy and the legal, economic and governmental systems for Hong Kong post 1997.

Similarly, on March 26, 1987, China and Portugal signed the Joint Declaration on the Question of Macau in which China made similar promises for the region of Macau after it was handed over to Beijing.

Hong Kong returned to Chinese control on July 1, 1997, and Macau’s sovereignty was transferred on December 20, 1999. Both regions became Special Administrative Regions of China. The regions would have their own currencies, economic and legal systems, but defence and diplomacy would be decided by Beijing. Their mini-Constitutions would remain valid for 50 years — till 2047 for Hong Kong and 2049 for Macau. It is unclear what will happen after this term.

What triggered the current crisis?
In recent years, there has been a growing outcry from Hong Kong’s pro-democracy civil society against China’s alleged attempts to erode the city’s autonomy. This has created tensions between the city’s youth and the local government, which is effectively chosen by Beijing.

In 2016-17, six legislators critical of Beijing were debarred. In 2018, the Hong Kong National Party, a localist party that has been critical of Beijing, was outlawed. This year, Carrie Lam, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong, proposed the extradition Bill, which sought to extradite Hong Kongers to places with which the city doesn’t have extradition agreements. Critics said it would allow the city government to extradite Beijing critics to mainland China where the judicial system is subservient to the ruling Communist Party.

This triggered the protests, and they went on despite Ms. Lam’s decision to suspend the Bill. The protesters, who often clashed with the police, now want the Bill to be formally withdrawn, Ms. Lam to resign, the arrested protesters to be released and the city’s electoral system to be reformed.
summary: The ongoing protests in Hong Kong, now in their 13th week, center around the One Country Two Systems policy, which allows the city to maintain different economic and political systems from mainland China while being part of the People’s Republic of China. Initially proposed by Deng Xiaoping in the late 1970s, the policy was implemented when Britain and Portugal transferred control of Hong Kong and Macau to China in 1997 and 1999, respectively. However, recent tensions have arisen due to Beijing's perceived encroachment on Hong Kong's autonomy, leading to protests against a proposed extradition law that would allow Hong Kongers to be extradited to mainland China. Protesters demand the withdrawal of the extradition bill, the resignation of Chief Executive Carrie Lam, release of arrested protesters, and electoral reforms.

headline: 1995 And All That
article:
Restoring grants and scholarships and lowering tuition could be initiated with the stroke of a pen. Rescinding corporate welfare, cutting back on defence spending, and eliminating pork-barrel projects would be complex but legislatively attained.

Stopping the war meant unconditional surrender. It meant abandoning the doctrine that had become the world religion Theo-economy. Under this doctrine the economy is God, and finance its philosophy. Though the religious foundation of the doctrine was not usually acknowledged by the faithful, its true nature had been experienced and preached by its mystics and apostles. It was Calvin Coolidge who said : The man builds a factory builds a temple. And the man who works there worships there.... The business of America is business.

Theo-economy had taken root in the industrialised West. Its missionaries, as zealous as their earlier counterparts, had proselytised it universally.
By 1995, with the end of the Cold War, the entire world had embraced the faith. Political beliefs and foreign policy agendas that had once dictated national policies and initiated wars gave way to pure Theo-economic considerations.
Foreign relations:
Money talks, Policy walks
Everyones been saying for a long time foreign policy is becoming economic, but like everything its taken a while for the message to sink in around here, the former Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, said just before he left town [Washington] last month, (NYT, 1/15/95)

After Treasury Secretary Bentsen left town, his replacement, Robert Rubin, drove the message home: The future prosperity and security of the United States requires that our nation remain engaged and lead globally in opening markets, in promoting development, in assisting economies in transition and in dealing with global financial problems.
Trades Bottom Line:
Business over Politics
For the first time in this century, the government has regularly put promotion of business interests at the top of its foreign policy agenda.
Everyone acknowledges that economics now plays a central role in foreign policy that battle is over, one of Mr Clintons top economic advisors said the other day. What no one has really grappled with is what happens when commercial interests push out other interests. (NYT,7/30/95).

Actually, what happens when commercial interests push out other interests had been grappled with in the past. Abraham Lincoln said: The money power preys upon the nation in times of peace and conspires against it in times of adversity. It is more despotic than monarchy. More insolent than autocracy, More selfish than bureaucracy. I see in the near future, a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes me to tremble for the safety of my country. Corporations have been enthroned. An era of corruption will follow and the money power of the country will endeavour to prolong its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until the wealth is aggregated in a few hands and the republic is destroyed.

The era of corruption took longer to establish than Lincoln envisaged. But he had accurately predicted the results of Theo-economic rule. Human rights, political liberties, social justice, and individual freedoms became closet issues. What Lincoln could not foresee was the Rain of Terror the Theo-economic holy war waged on the environment.
The millions massed in the streets at the millennium were calling for an end to the Envirowar. The march ended. The vigil was over. The message was clear.
Not many realised that peace-and a return to planetary health-meant abandoning the articles of the religious faith that had won the unshakable allegiance of virtually every government on Earth. This was not to be accomplished with a pen stroke, not even through top-to-bottom reengineering of government policy.

But people were changing their ideas. When ideas change, everything changes. The articles for a new faith had been drawn.
But it would take tumultuous and troubled decades before the embracing ideals of the new patriotism superseded and supplanted the Theo-economic priesthood and its metafinanciers.
Trendpost: The successful businesses of the Global Age will practise a compassionate capitalism. Money will be made by individuals and firms capable of producing and marketing products and services that satisfy a world with changed values. Products that address real physical, emotional, and artistic (quality-of-life) needs and do not destroy the earth in the process will be in demand.
summary: The article discusses the need for a shift away from Theo-economic doctrine, which considers the economy as God and finance as its philosophy. It emphasizes the dominance of economic interests in foreign policy and the adverse consequences of putting commercial interests above other considerations. The author highlights historical warnings, such as Abraham Lincoln's prediction of corruption and the concentration of wealth leading to the destruction of the republic. The article suggests that a new faith, centered around compassionate capitalism and products that address genuine needs without harming the environment, should replace the prevailing Theo-economic ideology.

headline: Salim Malik ensures draw for Pak
article:
Former captain Salim Malik’s 15th century ensured Pakistan a draw in the second and final cricket Test against Sri Lanka at the Singhalose grounds today.
The veteran 34-year-old right-hander of 96 Tests hit a match-saving knock of 155 to enable Pakistan end the fifth and final day on 285 for five wickets after being set the tall task of scoring 426 runs for victory in 121 overs.
Malik, showing great reserve of concentration and physical resources for his age, batted 338 minutes for his match-saving knock which was scored off 240 balls with 26 fours. With brother-in-law Ijaz Ahmed, who made a painstaking 47 in 265 minutes with a six and seven fours, Malik put on 127 runs for the third wicket which ensured Pakistan of a draw.
The pair, who started the day on 28 for two, battled throughout the morning session, adding 55 runs off 29 overs, and by the time Ijaz was dismissed, 25 minutes before tea break, Pakistan were safe from defeat.
Inzamam-ul-Haq joined Malik in a further stand which produced 121 runs for the fourth wicket in 100 minutes.
Inzamam playing fluently on both sides of the wicket completed a half-century before bad light ended play with seven mandatory overs left to be bowled.
summary: Former Pakistan cricket captain Salim Malik played a crucial innings of 155 runs to help Pakistan secure a draw in the second and final Test against Sri Lanka at the Singhalose grounds. Facing a daunting target of 426 runs in 121 overs, Pakistan ended the fifth and final day at 285 for five wickets. Malik's resilient knock, lasting 338 minutes and scored off 240 balls with 26 fours, anchored Pakistan's innings. Partnering with Ijaz Ahmed, who contributed a patient 47, Malik shared a crucial 127-run partnership for the third wicket. Despite a challenging morning session, the pair's resilience ensured Pakistan avoided defeat. Later, Inzamam-ul-Haq joined Malik, adding 121 runs for the fourth wicket in 100 minutes. Inzamam's fluent half-century further solidified Pakistan's position before bad light halted play with seven overs remaining.

headline: Thackeray allows Sutar’s "sacrifice"
article:
In a move that ostensibly ran counter to Shiv Sena chief Bal Thackeray’s public stance, Chief Minister Manohar Joshi sprang a surprise today by forwarding the resignation of Sashikant Sutar to Governor P C Alexander.
The Chief Minister, following up on his assurance on the floor of the Assembly also appointed Justice M L Dudhat, a retired High Court (HC) judge under the Commission of Inquiry Act to probe charges against Sutar.
According to a Raj Bhavan communique, the Governor has accepted the indicted minister’s resignation.The move caused considerable consternation among the ranks of both the Sena and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), particularly because the Sena Chief’s public articulation against the findings of the Puranik panel gave an indication that Sutar had won respite from immediate consequences of the indictment.
According to sources, both national and State considerations caused the Sena chief to retreat from his public posture. Crucial to the decision was the marathon meeting which Pramod Mahajan, BJP’s national secretary, had with Thackeray. In that meeting, Mahajan reportedly impressed upon the Sena chief that in the wake of the dilemma the Janata Dal was in, owing to the Central Bureau of Investigation’s decision to seek prosecution of party president and Bihar Chief Minister Laloo Prasad Yadav, inaction in Sutar’s case would prove counter-productive to the alliance partners both at national and state level.
summary: In a surprising move contrary to Shiv Sena chief Bal Thackeray's stance, Chief Minister Manohar Joshi forwarded Sashikant Sutar's resignation to Governor P C Alexander, following through on his pledge in the Assembly. Joshi also appointed retired High Court judge Justice M L Dudhat under the Commission of Inquiry Act to investigate charges against Sutar. Despite Thackeray's public disagreement with the Puranik panel's findings, the Governor accepted Sutar's resignation, causing unease within the Sena and BJP ranks. It's speculated that national and state considerations prompted Thackeray's shift from his public stance, influenced notably by a meeting between Pramod Mahajan, BJP's national secretary, and Thackeray. Mahajan reportedly emphasized the importance of addressing Sutar's case to avoid adverse effects on the alliance partners, citing the Janata Dal's situation following the CBI's actions against Laloo Prasad Yadav.

headline: Sena evasive on EC’s diktat on party polls
article:
MUMBAI, April 30: Will Shiv Sena supremo Bal Thackeray hold organisational elections of his party before May 30 the twice-extended deadline set by the Election Commission (EC) of India?

“Despite reminders, we have not received any communication from 18 out of the 39 recognised regional political parties, including the Shiv Sena,” Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) M S Gill said today.

Dr Gill told media persons that by and large, the response of the recognised national as well as regional parties was satisfactory. “All the seven national parties have submitted their organisational election progress to the Commission. However, regional parties were very slow,” he pointed out.
The CEC said the Commission has convened a meeting of all recognised political parties on May 7 to discuss the model code of conduct, the need to hike the limit on expenditure and other issues of interest. “The overall policy of the Commission is that no segment of the country should remain unrepresented either in the Parliament or the State Legislature. Therefore, we now make a point to conduct the by-elections immediately after the vacancy arises. Without waiting for the limit of six months prescribed under the Constitution, we are trying to hold the elections as early as possible,” he added.
When asked if the Commission was gearing up for mid-term polls, Dr Gill said his office was busy preparing for the ensuing Presidential election, which is scheduled to be held in June, as the term of office of the President expires in July.
Reacting to former CEC T N Seshan’s decision to contest the Presidential election, he said, “it is a free country and as such one is free to participate in any electoral process. But certainly, because of Seshan’s decision, I can also throw my turban in the race after my retirement,” he remarked.

Referring to the issue of identity cards for voters, Dr Gill said, “In Maharashtra though 80 per cent of the electorate have been issued identity cards, 30 lakh voters have refused to be photographed, while 23 lakh indicate occupational absence.”
Dr Gill said he had given specific instructions to all the Chief Electoral Officers to ensure that notice was given to the electorate before removal of names from the electoral register.
summary: The Election Commission of India (ECI) has not received any communication from 18 out of 39 recognized regional political parties, including the Shiv Sena, regarding organizational elections despite reminders, according to Chief Election Commissioner M.S. Gill. While the response from national parties has been satisfactory, the CEC noted that regional parties were slow in submitting their organizational election progress. The ECI has scheduled a meeting with all recognized political parties on May 7 to discuss the model code of conduct, the need for expenditure limit adjustments, and other relevant issues. Dr. Gill emphasized the Commission's commitment to promptly conducting by-elections to ensure no segment of the country remains unrepresented in Parliament or State Legislatures. Regarding the possibility of mid-term polls, he stated that the Commission is currently focused on preparing for the upcoming Presidential election scheduled for June, as the President's term expires in July. Dr. Gill also addressed the issue of voter identity cards, revealing that 80% of the electorate in Maharashtra have been issued cards, but some voters have refused to be photographed or indicated occupational absence.

headline: India file– Judoka dies in mishap
article:
Judoka dies in mishap

KOLHAPUR: Three-time National women’s judo champion and Shiv Chhatrapati Award winner, Neelam Pandit alias Pooja Prasad Navare, was killed when the autorickshaw in which she was travelling rolled down into a deep valley near Sinhagad Fort on Sunday last. Pandit’s two daughters, a friend and her eight-year-old daughter were injured in the accident, a delayed report received here said.

Pandit, an employee of Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC), had gone from Pune to visit the historical Sinhagad fort. Neelam succumbed to her injuries on Monday. Aarati Navare (11), Ashwini (6), Neelam’s friend, Madhuri Kulkarni and her daughter were reported to be out of danger in a private dispensary at Pune.
CALCUTTA: The West Bengal government has agreed to allow the final of the Independence Cup to the played at the Eden Gardens here, to start at 4.00 pm. The Board of Control for Cricket in India secretary Jagmohan Dalmiya informed that the state government has agreed to arrange for the requirements needed for a late finish.arlier, Calcutta police had refused permission for a late start, saying that they will not allow the game to go beyond 2200 hrs. BCCI had requested for a 4.00 pm start as it will be very hot before that. Even the spectators will find it very difficult to sit and watch the match, the Board had argued. Dalmiya informed that all the other playing conditions, including the sitting arrangements will remain same.NEW DELHI: There is nothing unusual or foul in India not being invited for the 1997 Alfred Dunhill Cup at St Andrews from October 16 to 19. Officials connected with Indian Golf Union (IGU) and Delhi Golf Club (DGC) clarified that the organisers invited teams by rotation.

“As the Dunhill Cup, comprising 16 nations, is invitational competition, no one can protest or complain as to why India has not been invited,” said two senior coaches. According to the officials, top nations, like, US, Australia, always get invited but many teams, particularly from Asia, were picked on the system of rotation.

Cricket softwareBANGALORE: Stump Vision, the pioneers in development of cricket software in India, launched the `Independence Cup ’97’ edition of `Anil Kumble’s Googly’ series of simulated computer cricket games. The kit provides for strategy options. The user, donning the role of a captain, can decide on changing the batting order or the bowler, depending on the match situation.
summary: Three-time National women’s judo champion Neelam Pandit, also a Shiv Chhatrapati Award winner, died in a tragic accident near Sinhagad Fort. The autorickshaw she was traveling in rolled down a deep valley, resulting in her death. Two daughters of Pandit, aged 11 and 6, along with a friend and her 8-year-old daughter, sustained injuries and were reported to be out of danger. Neelam Pandit was an employee of the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) and had gone to visit the historical Sinhagad fort. The accident occurred on Sunday, and Pandit succumbed to her injuries on Monday. In a separate incident, the West Bengal government has agreed to allow the final of the Independence Cup to be played at Eden Gardens, starting at 4:00 pm. The decision comes after initially refusing permission for a late start, citing concerns about the match going beyond 22:00 hrs. The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) had requested the early start due to hot weather conditions, and all other playing conditions, including seating arrangements, will remain the same.

headline: National Games appears set to meet schedule
article:
BANGALORE, April 30: “The National Games are definitely on,” said G Somashekarappa, Secretary General of the Karnataka Olympic Association.
“Even if the structure is not complete, the playing arena will be made available to the athletes latest by mid-May. The technical areas will be readied and we will be able to host any competition after May 15,” Somashekarappa said.
There were definitely more doubters than believers. And the fourth National Games allotted to Karnataka, it seems was more in the news for all the wrong reasons. Rescheduling, postponing were very frequently used words in this connection. But a visit to the Sree Kanteerava Stadium, the main venue for the 12-day long extravaganza, does put to rest any qualms regarding a prompt start to the event.
The synthetic track has been laid at the Kanteerava Stadium with the `Calcutta grass’ lending the right amount amount of contrast to the brick-red track which is ready for marking. A 200 metre warm-up track is getting ready outside the Stadium. “This practice track will be either cinder or clay right now,” said Somashekarappa but hastened to add that it would be converted to synthetic track at a later date.
summary: "The National Games are definitely on," affirmed G Somashekarappa, Secretary General of the Karnataka Olympic Association, dismissing doubts about the event's readiness. Despite incomplete structures, the playing arena will be accessible to athletes by mid-May, with technical areas prepared for competitions after May 15. Amid concerns and frequent rescheduling talks, a visit to the Sree Kanteerava Stadium, the main venue, dispels doubts. The stadium boasts a synthetic track complemented by "Calcutta grass," providing a contrast to the brick-red track ready for marking. Additionally, a 200-meter warm-up track is under construction outside the stadium, initially made of cinder or clay and planned for later conversion to a synthetic track. Somashekarappa's reassurance signals progress toward hosting the 12-day event, allaying concerns about its viability.

headline: Uphaar Cinema Fire: Death Toll Reaches 59, Hundreds Injured
article:
The death toll in the Uphaar Cinema fire in Delhi on Wednesday rose to 59, with hundreds more injured. The fire broke out during a screening of the film "Border" and quickly spread through the cinema hall.
 
 The fire was caused by a short circuit in the air conditioner of the cinema hall. The fire was exacerbated by the use of flammable materials in the cinema hall's construction.
 
 The fire has led to outrage in India, with many people questioning the safety standards of cinemas in the country. The fire has also raised concerns about the lack of fire safety regulations in public places.
 
 The Indian government has ordered a probe into the fire and has promised to take action against those responsible. The government has also announced that it will provide compensation to the families of the victims.
 
 The Uphaar Cinema fire is a major tragedy for India. It is a reminder of the need for better fire safety standards in public places. It is also a reminder of the importance of enforcing safety regulations.
summary:
A fire broke out during a screening of the film "Border" at the Uphaar Cinema in Delhi on Wednesday, killing 59 people and injuring hundreds more. The fire was caused by a short circuit in the air conditioner of the cinema hall and was exacerbated by the use of flammable materials in the cinema hall's construction.
 
 The fire has led to outrage in India, with many people questioning the safety standards of cinemas in the country and the lack of fire safety regulations in public places. The Indian government has ordered a probe into the fire and has promised to take action against those responsible, as well as provide compensation to the families of the victims.

headline: Shyamji Antala recharges 2.5 lakh wells in Saurashtra using cost-effective technique
article:
For the many farmers of Saurashtra - a huge, hot dustbowl - every summer brings a foretaste of apocalypse. The fear of drought gleams through the cracks of dry well beds as groundwater recedes further into elusive nooks and crannies of the earth.

Every evening, farmers listlessly trudge back home from their thirsty fields, their minds already clogged with the thoughts of misery and impending doom. But all this may be changing. Because of one man, hope is beginning to form on the margins. A man who has taken a vow to bring back water to all the wells of Saurashtra using the simple materials that he possesses - human ingenuity and a rustic pragmatic sense.

Shyamji Antala, 60, is seen almost like a messiah among Saurashtrian folk for he has helped recharge 2.5 lakh wells out of a huge seven lakh dry ones in the region. Says Chunibhai Katheriya, a Rajkot farmer: "He is our Bhishmapitamah ... He will not rest till all the wells are full of water."

Antala, a lean, gaunt man with a shock of white hair, often seen crisscrossing the area to examine long-abandoned wells, is less gushing: "It all started off with a few wells near Dhoraji But now tackling the water crisis here has become a mission for me."
All of Antala's success in well-recharging stems from his pragmatism. He works with what he has. Saurashtra suffers from the fact that there isn't a single perennial river. But what it has is countless erratic rivulets with rocky beds that keep coming alive every monsoon and die soon after.

For instance, recently in Nagarpipadia, Antala prescribed that all dry wells should be connected to the rivulet with the help of 9-inch-diameter cement pipes.

The pre-monsoon showers last month had almost all the wells brimming. In two days the water percolated down. Villagers estimate that with two good showers, the groundwater level will improve dramatically. Says Keshubhai Mepa Katheriya, another farmer: "It will translate to about one acre of additional groundnut crop (a profit of Rs 6,000) for me."

For different situations, Antala has varying methods. If there isn't a rivulet nearby, he improvises with other techniques. In Gundasara village, he proposed that villagers dig 6ft-by-6ft tanks with cemented beds near each dry well. Then by studying the lay of the land, he worked out areas where water naturally collects during the rains. These were connected to the tanks by loosely made canals.

And the upper portion of the tank in turn connected to the well by a pipe. Once the rains trigger off a flow of water, the tanks get filled up, the mud settles to the bottom and clean water trickles down to the depths of the well.

Each shower feeds the well to a point that water can easily be drawn out. Today, with this technique, 210 out of the 277 dry wells in this region are gurgling with water and Gundasara is making a yearly profit of Rs 18 lakh in additional groundnut crop.
Well-recharging isn't an intricate engineering feat. The cost is negligible and the theory environmentally correct. Yet, simply put, the returns are so dramatic that for most it is a modern-day miracle. For Saurashtra, the groundnut belt of Gujarat, Antala's methods are followed with the same reverence as Moses' commandments.

His status, going by people's reactions, is just a few notches below God. And even if the Gujarat Government hasn't yet put well-recharging as one of its development programmes, Antala's work has sparked off a mini-revolution in Saurashtra.

Across the border, Rajasthan, spurred by Antala's success, has started its own well-charging schemes. And though Gujarat itself hasn't emulated this, D.K. Pal, joint secretary of the Cooperative and Rural Development Department, admits: "He has added a whole new dimension to rural development."

Antala's obsession with wells and water began in 1988 when he saw farmers in his native town Dhoraji trying to recharge their dead wells. Till then Antala's life had been largely unremarkable, working as a circulation manager in a Gujarati daily. But the sight of these desperate farmers lingered in his mind.

The four-year-long drought (1984-88) in Saurashtra had already made him think about water conservation. He mulled over it for many days, discussed it animatedly with friends, and finally worked out ways to revive wells. Once confident about his methods, he and a close friend, Natwar Singh Chauhan, decided to launch the Saurashtra Lok Manch. Revolution, he felt, was at hand.

Not quite. Armed with literature and theories, for the next three years both of them scoured villages over the six districts of Saurashtra offering to gift them this "new lease of life". Absurdly, there were no takers. Philanthropy was long dead and everywhere people eyed them suspiciously.

Worse, most felt that the two of them had a personal interest in reviving wells, with some farmers even demanding money for the recharging. "It reflected the greed that subsidies and populism had bred among the people," says Antala. "We were totally frustrated," adds Chauhan.

But as is usual with Antala, he put his mind to it. And his native ingenuity came up with religion. Families of rural Gujarat have a tradition of religious gurus whom they consult on important occasions.

Besides, the state has a huge number of immensely popular spiritual leaders who roam the villages. Antala contacted a few of them - notably Madhavpriyadasji of the Swaminarayans and Swami Kishorchandraji of the Vaishnavas - to sell the idea of well-recharging.

All of them grasped the potential of his schemes and decided to spread his message through their brigades of saffron-clad ascetics. And the message was this: If the villagers didn't listen, Saurashtra "would be a desert in 30 years".

Within months the tables had turned. Not only had the sadhus converted the people, voluntary organisations and cooperative bodies would suddenly turn up at Antala's door wanting to be involved.

"I was overwhelmed. All of them are the real reason behind our success," says Antala. But most farmers disagree. They talk about a tireless zeal that has taken over Antala's life. Yes, he still works as circulation manager. But every free hour is spent trying to spread awareness on water conservation.

Today there are myths about his tremendous physical strength that trace their origin to the fact that he has had a hard life. As a young boy he was denied the joys of childhood, having instead to sell the family's ancestral land because of his father's debts. At varying stages of his life he has worked as farm labour, road labour and done the occasional stint as peon.
He struggled to climb the ladder, first becoming a sanitary inspector in Dhoraji and then a municipal councillor. Says his wife Vanitaben: "But today his well-recharging scheme is like a second wife." She and their two sons (both businessmen) dote on him. "His work gives us pride."

But Antala isn't satisfied. Maybe Saurashtra is on the healing curve and within a few years the bottoms of all the wells will gleam with water. But what of the other water-starved areas of the country? "I feel like going all over and telling them that they should forget about the government and what it is not doing for them. Be self-reliant. Do it yourself. You can solve your own problems."
summary:
In the arid region of Saurashtra, where drought is a recurring nightmare for farmers, a man named Shyamji Antala has become a beacon of hope. Antala, often seen as a messiah by the locals, has taken it upon himself to revive the region's dry wells using simple, cost-effective methods. His efforts have successfully recharged 2.5 lakh out of seven lakh dry wells, offering a lifeline to the parched land.

Antala's approach is practical and rooted in the local environment. He utilizes the occasional rivulets with rocky beds that come to life during the monsoon season. By connecting dry wells to these rivulets with cement pipes, he ensures that they fill up during the rains. In areas without nearby rivulets, he creates tanks with cemented beds and canals to collect rainwater, which then trickles down to replenish the wells.

This grassroots effort has led to a significant increase in agricultural yields, benefiting local farmers. Antala's work has not only improved the water situation in Saurashtra but also inspired similar initiatives in neighboring Rajasthan. His dedication and ingenuity have brought a sense of empowerment to the community and serve as a model for self-reliance in addressing water scarcity issues. Despite his success, Antala remains driven to spread his message of self-sufficiency and problem-solving to other water-starved regions across the country.

headline: The Role of Political Sophistication in Learning From News: Measuring Schema Development
article: Accounting for learning from news has focused on media attention, media gratification, content-specific exposure, and prior knowledge. One measure of prior knowledge is political sophistication, measuring components of both knowledge and ideology. Two studies evaluated the reliability, concurrent validity, and comparative predictive validity of political sophistication in comparison to those of exposure, attention, and civics knowledge. Study 1 focused on the 1993-1994 health care reform debate. Those higher in political sophistication learned more from broadcast and print news, and had more differentiated constructs and higher quality arguments about health policy issues in open-ended essays. These findings were replicated in Study 2, which was conducted within a simulated mayoral election campaign.
